column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.10.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/2/1, which is connected to the Fusion LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "MGMT VLAN100 172.16.0.0/24" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT-VLAN100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - To access the Unleashed Controller, use the link: http://69.36.200.68:60050/ - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: MGMT 100, GuestWiFi 200, GuestWired 205, CCTV-Mount-Shasta 800

column66: This site is PoE WiFi and Guestcast on 40 TV [as test] The Fusion/BTV gateway server is in the server room on WATT Box powered by UPS. The Core switch and IDF switch are Brocade 7150 24 port PoE running layer 3. Room WAPs are h320 on cat6 except room 127 is r510. The Meeting rooms each have ceiling mounted r510 as well as 3 r510 in ceiling of lobby, breakfast, offices, and one wall mounted in Fitness. 1 t310 is wall mounted in the pool area. Guestcasts are on only 40 of the TVs using HDMI2. The Xfinity guest room remote has a TV Input button on the lower right hand corner that is used to change inputs instead of our Slate remotes. This is because of the Xfinity STBs use Bluetooth for control not IR.  Special in room instruction are being provided for this site.
column67: The MDF is located through the Front Desk in the Server Room. Wattbox 50.232.40.148 connected to Fusion, GuestCast Server, Core switch and Business center switch. The WattBox is on a UPS The 3rd floor IDF also has a UPS. it is located in the Housekeeping closet on the 3rd floor near room 331 and the stairwell.  Room WAPs are in rooms on the 3rd and 1st floor see equipment list for locations h320 except 127 is r520 there are 3 R520s in the meeting rooms mounted on the ceiling grid so are easy to see. The 3 R530 in the lobby ceiling are located near   ceiling hatches. There is an r520 in the ceiling of the GMs office as well as on the wall of the fitness center. a T3200 is on the wall in the Pool area facing the Patio

column66: The majority of Unleashed APs get their PoE power and data from the network jacks under the desks in the rooms. The Primary Unleashed  Master AP is located in the MDF.            The APs that are exceptions are the 1st floor rooms in the Cabernet Bldg -these rooms have cables running down the outside walkway and punch into the rooms over the doors on the 1st floor- and rooms 216 and 227 which get their data and power over cables that run through the attic above those rooms. The Pool AP, Lobby and Fitness Center APs have cables that run through the attics to these APs. The Core Switch uplinks to the two IDF switches. These uplink cables are cat5e but are running at gig speeds.        The MDF has a Wattbox but it is connected on LAN1 as there are no spare Public IPs. The MicroTik Backup gateway has the same issue as there is no spare Public IP for it.
column67: The MDF is on the 2nd floor of the Cabernet Bldg in the phone room. There is an IDF switch in the maintenance storage room on the 1st floor of the Cabernet Bldg. column66: - This property has a total of four buildings (one MDF and three IDF).  - The uplink between the East and Suite buildings and the South building is copper, and there is a point-to-point wireless bridge between the Main and South buildings. The topology formed between the SWs is a star-shaped one. -We Installed Common Areas APs (Lobby and Pool) also APs inside the Guest Rooms. All the APs are PoE form either MDF or IDFs (See equipment List for details).
column67: - MDF is located 2nd Floor, between Rooms 217 and 218, above the Laundry.  --pfsense, Mikrotik, Wattbox and CoreSW and UPS are located on the MDF.  - 1st IDF is East Building, located on Maintenance 1st floor front of the stairs.    - 2nd IDF is Suite Building, located in the Electrical Room, 1st Floor.  - 3rd IDF Center Building, located behind the door with the access code, between the front counter desk and the breakfast room.   - The Point to Point Bridge are located, Sender over Roof of the South Building and Receiver over Roof of the Center Building.
column68: ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 67.135.212.124   (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the pFsense-LAN2 (port 1/1/39) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the pFsense. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.0.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200 and 201 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************.

column66: The common areas and conference spaces are on Upgrade phases: -6x APs for Conference Spaces are managed by HIS-vSZ-1 -12x APs for Conference Spaces and BOH are still managed by local ZoneDirector  All the guestroom WiFi is via 6x DSLAM-TS-524 with 135x CPEs TW-522 in every other room. column68: ************************************* +Upgrade 6/24/2021: in the new network, the GuestWifi is in VLAN 200, in the old network is in VLAN 1. In the interconnection between the Old Core Switch(10.61.32.10) and the New one (172.16.14.10) the VLAN 200 is the native VLAN.   IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.14.1) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/2/2, which is connected to the Fusion LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "MGMT VLAN100 172.16.14.0/24" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.14.254/24 to 172.16.14.1/24 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT_VLAN100" using the "Actions" button.

column66: We do not manage the network at this property. This is the IT company that manage the Network. TechGuru Harsh Purohit harsh.purohit@techguru.net +1-704-457-5778 W: (704) 457-5800 this is Brian at TechGuru   The Guest cast are configured on HDMI 3 of the TV, with TV service going into TV via coax.  The chrome cast remotes have a guide and menu button, The menu button has no function.  The Guide button is configured to pull up the channel guide when watching live Tv, and the arrow keys will allow the guest to scroll through the channels and to select a channel by hitting ok.  The casting button on the remote automatically puts the Tv on HDMI 3 to allow guest to access the chrome cast QR screen.  The Tv button on the remote allows the guest to switch back to live TV.  The mute, volume, channel, and number keys have also been configured to be compatible with the TV.
column67: Fusion is located in the MDF in the Linen Closet on the first floor next to the elevator.   The Chromecast are connected on the back of each TV connected to HDMI 3 on the back of the TV with USB power connected on the left side of TV.  The Chromecast are secured with a cable fashioned around the base of the TV set and secured to the Chromecast.  A Guestcast remote with a Guide button and instruction card was also left in each room where the Chromecast was installed.
column68: Guest cast server gets its public address from a TP-Link switch P/N TL-SG2210P. The switch is mounted on wall on the left side of the server rack.  ***Port 4 for Wan1 ***Port 5 for IPMI.   UniFi switch P/N USW-24-POE located in the server rack below the patch panel bearing the insignia USW on the front left side of the switch: ***Lan1 is the guest wireless Vlan1000 connected to Port 17 ***LAN2 is the Chromecast Vlan 500 connected to Port 18  Here is the code needed to access the Philips service menu, using the remote type the following code to access 3 1 9 7 5 3 Mute  Philips Service menu to enable HDMI ports and to turn off CEC also to clone the TV to USB.  To enable HDMI Port 3 "319753 Mute" on the remote. Scroll down to sources and hit ok. Go to enable sources and verify HDMI 3 has a check mark next to it.  The hit TV button three times to get out of the menu.

column66: The System consists of an A series Fusion connected to an ICX-8400-24P Core switch. The ISP, Fusion, MikroTik, IPMI, and WattBox are connected to the Core.  The WATT Box is connected to a 2300-watt USP. It does not have a network connection. The public area WAPs are connected to the first 8 ports of the core switch, Which are 2 T-350, 4 R650, and 2 R550. The in-room 40 H350s are connected to an IXC-7150-48P, which is connected to the Core switch via 10GB copper twinex on ports 1/3/4, respectively.  We are using the Spectrum feed that was being used buy the previous WiFi providers and Admin network     Guest WiFi Client Experience: *Open SSID: VLAN200 "Bozeman Country Inn & Suites" takes the clients to a Portal Page
column67: MDF is the location of all network equipment. It is in a closet net to the guest Laundry on the first floor. It has a card key lock.
column68: ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Log into the WattBox and change the DG to 172.16.99.1 --- You will lose access to it temporarily until you perform step number 5 (since WattBox access is a Port Forward from Mikrotik)  2.Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 72.175.50.90 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 3. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.99.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 4. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/1/24) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.99.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.99.254/24 to 172.16.99.1/24 6. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 7. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 8. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************

column68: The Comcast ISP provides two circuits: WAN IP Block: 50.226.30.200/30 (Their Juniper L3 switch uses 50.226.30.201 as the GW and our Core-SW is using 50.226.30.202 on VLAN999) - This WAN block cable is connected from the Juniper on port 0/0/0 to the Brocade Core-SW on port 1/1/37 LAN IP Block: 50.226.30.224/27 (This is the block where the Fusion, IPMI, and backup EdgeRouter have the public IP addresses - DMZ VLAN900)  WattBox: Outlet-1: Fusion Outlet-2: Core-SW-MDF-1-1 Outlet-3: SW-MDF-1-2 Outlet-4: Edgerouter  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.10.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/1/45, which is connected to the Fusion LAN1 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the VLAN 100 and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.10.254/24 to 172.16.10.1/24. 7. column66: - This is a 7-story hotel. It's a concrete building, the 1st floor has a combination of drop and hard cap ceiling. The ceiling on the upper floors is made of concrete, also the walls between rooms are made of solid concrete, and some walls in the corridors are made of concrete too. - On the 1st floor is located the Restaurant, the bar, the fitness center, 8 conference rooms and all the back of the house offices and areas. From the 2nd to the 7th floor are guest room floors. This property has 1 MDF located on the 1st floor and 2 IDFs, one on the 3rd and the other on the 6th floor.  - The MDF is connected to the IDFs via fiber. There is a 6 threads fiber running from the MDF to the IDF-3 and another 6 threads fiber running from the IDF-3 to the IDF-6, but the connections between switches are home runs. - The cables are running from the MDF to all the APs on the 1st floor. The cables on the upper floors are running from the IDFs to the entrance of the rooms using conduits on the walls.
column67: + MDF: The MDF is located on the 1st floor, in the Server Room, this room is in the back of the store close to the Kitchen. The following pieces of equipment are in the MDF: Fusion, Core-SW, Mikrotik, Wattbox, and UPS. The ISP modems are here too.  + IDFs: There are 2 IDFs on the property, both of them are in the electrical coset next to the service elevator, these IDFs have a 48 port SW and a UPS each of them. The IDF-3 is located on the 3rd floor. and IDF-6 is located on the 6th floor.  +Common areas APs: The APs in the common areas are hidden, except the one in the Garden, this one is mounted on the wall and visible. The APs in the back of the house are installed visible.  + Guest room APs: All the APs in the guest floors are installed at the entrance of the room, hanging from the ceiling.    + Admin  Network Devices:  Firewall is in the computer room, ISP modem is in the MDF back of the house (Check Network Photos on Doc section)
column68: There is 1 ISP: The guest network is running through this one, the conference network is running also on this one. It is located in the MDF, on a shelve close to the door. The ISP is connected to the Core-SW (VLAN 901), then from here, the Core-SW feeds the Wattbox, the IPMI, and the Mikrotik.  /// If Admin Network Devices Fails://////////  https://admin.hotelwifi.com/Document/Viewer/4b9e5716-c841-4fba-9ac3-1857e942ca95  Scope of work: All devices are in the Computer room 1. Provide 24/7 remote monitoring of Admin network public IP addresses 2. Basic troubleshooting of ISP service, which will include: a. Contacting ISP and troubleshooting with them. b. Power cycling Admin Network ISP equipment (modem) through a phone call to property staff. 3. Escalation to Choice Support group for firewall troubleshooting when it is determined that the Firewall is the issue  The IP addresses we were specifically requested to monitor are: Primary ASA “internet” (back-office ISP) IP address: 50.210.41.84 Default gateway: 50.210.41.86 LAN Block: 50.210.41.80/29  This is the ISP information: ADMIN Network ACCOUNT Comcast Circuit managed by Comm-Works (now called New Era technologies) New Era technologies support number 888-806-7836 Comcast Tech Support (800) 391-3000 Serviceability ID: 966560239  The Choice IT contact is : Lenny Shteyman Senior Property Support Engineer Mobile: 612-801-3520 Email: lenny.shteyman@choicehotels.com  Please also send an email to Choice IT support email: reportmoh@choicehotels.com  -------------IF FUSION FAIL - MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 70.89.155.132 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.28.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN-3 (port 1/2/1) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt.172.16.28.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.28.254/24 to 172.16.28.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200, 300 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.   OLD INFORMATION:--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- -There are 2 ISPs: one primary (the guest network is running through this one) and one secondary (the conference network is running through this one). Both ISP modems are in the MDF, on a shelve close to the door. Both ISP are connected to the Core-SW (VLAN 900 and VLAN 901), then from here, the Core-SW feeds the Wattbox, the IPMI, and the Mikrotik using the VLAN 901(secondary ISP). -There are several vendors on this property, we feed one of them, and the rest are not running through our network. See below the list of vendors:      * Vendant: Air conditioning thermostatic system. It's running through our network.      * CCTV: Camera system, it's not running through our network. It's connected straight to the ISP.      * Uniguest: Business Center (2 PCs and a printer). It's not running through our network.      * Relay: Panic button system. It's not running through our network.      * Commworks now called New Era Tech: ISPs - The connection between the MDF and the IDFs is through fiber. The connection between the MDF and the IDF-3 is a homerun, using a 6 threads fiber, the link is made using the 1st pair (blue/orange). The connection between the MDF and the IDF-6 is a homerun too, but in this case, it was used a fiber bridge in the IDF-3, there is a link between the fiber coming from the MDF to the IDF 3 (pair 2: green/brown) and the fiber going from the IDF-3 to the IDF-6 (pair 2: green/brown). - Each conferences room have one hard wire port in the Core-SW, these ports are untagged on VLAN 300 (conference VLAN)

column66: MDF is located on the 1st floor, all common AP's and Guest Room AP's on the 1st floor are connected to the core SW.  All Data jacks from the Guest rooms on the 1st floor are also connected to the CoreSW using Vlan 201.  The 2nd floor Guestroom AP's are connected to the 2nd floor SW (RADPEND-SW-2-1), as well as the Guest room Data jacks are also connect to the SW using Vlan 201.  The 3rd floor Guestroom AP's are connected to the 3rd floor SW (RADPEND-SW-3-1), as well as the Guest room Data jacks are also connect to the SW using Vlan 201.  Staff SSID is using vlan 202.  I have added a Tab in the equipment list for the Guest room Data jacks locations on the Switch and on the Patch Panel. If you look at the low voltage Diagram in CRM, you will notice that the AP's are connected to the orange triangles and they have a text box next to them that states the floor number, number of the patch panel, and the port number.  The Blue triangles listed are the phone and Data jacks, they are labeled the same way as the orange triangles, the have a text box next to them that looks like 02-02-45.  This means that the patch panel is on the 2nd floor IDF, the 2nd patch panel and the port that the ethernet cable is connected to.  Use the Low voltage diagram for all the port numbers and locations.

column68: IF FUSION FAIL!!! ---------------------------------------------------- We have an Spare Gateway onsite: Mikrotik using the same Public IP address the WAN1 on the Fusion--- 216.207.201.170 They can't be ON both at the same time. How to pass the traffic over the Mikrotik? 1. Login into the WattBox. 2. Go over: Control / Status --- notice that Outlet-3 has The Makrotik connected to it and is OFF. 3. Turn ON outlet-3. 4. Once you have ping replay from 216.207.201.170 proceed to Login on the Mikrotik using Winbox Software. 5. Do ssh on the CoreSW (172.16.26.10) through the Mikrotik. 6. Disable the port on CoreSW for Fusion WAN and LAN. 7. Verify you are getting ARP and check with someone onsite that the WiFi services is working.

column65: Radisson Salt Lake City Downtown Hotel
column66: The Radisson SLC Downtown is a 15 stories hotel without a 13th floor. There are basement and subbasement levels, both used for the parking garages, but part of the basement is used as BOH. the Lobby, the admin offices, the restaurant, and the kitchen are located on the 1st floor. On the 2nd floor are located the major conference rooms and the Pool and fitness center. The guest floors are from the 3rd to the 15 floors; the 3rd floor is a combination of guest and conference rooms. There are 2 types of ceilings in the property: hard caps in the lobby area and in the guest rooms; drop ceilings in the rest of the property(BOH, guest floor hallways, conference rooms) The network backbone consists of a 10G fiber, with copper cables branching out to the APs from both the MDF and IDFs. A fiber home run connects each IDF to the MDF, with a joint interconnection occurring in IDF 1 to link IDFs 2, 3, and 4.  This property pays for onsite maintenance. As of June 2023, Willy Vasquez  (801-349-5090) can be hired through Field Nation for maintenance visits. He was contracted for the original installation and is familiar with the property.  Guestcast was installed in the property with most of the  third floor was still in construction.
column67: +MDF: -Fusion, SWcore, Mikrotik.  +IDFs: - Switches.  +WAPs: - The APs on the guest floors are installed in every other room. The APs are installed vertically on the entrance soffit. - All the APs in the common areas and the conference areas are installed horizontally and visible.  Guestcast were installed in HDMI 2 and powered by the USB port on the TV.   Per management guest cast was installed in the Bar, Gym, Conference rooms and guest rooms.
column68: -The UPS operates at 30 A and has been connected to a 20 A outlet. Engineering decided to use this outlet instead of installing the proper outlet. - The PBX is connected to the Core switch on port 1/1/44. VLAN 900. -The IDFs locations don't have AC, so the rooms are super hot.  It has been recommended to the hotel management that AC units be installed in these rooms, as the high temperatures can damage the switches. -On each IDF there are 2 switches, one 7150 48 port, and a 7150 12 port. Both switches are in stack.   /// If Admin Network Devices Fails://////////  https://admin.hotelwifi.com/Document/Viewer/4b9e5716-c841-4fba-9ac3-1857e942ca95  Scope of work: All devices are in the Computer room 1. Provide 24/7 remote monitoring of Admin network public IP addresses 2. Basic troubleshooting of ISP service, which will include: a. Contacting ISP and troubleshooting with them. b. Power cycling Admin Network ISP equipment (modem) through a phone call to property staff. 3. Escalation to Choice Support group for firewall troubleshooting when it is determined that the Firewall is the issue  The IP addresses we were specifically requested to monitor are: Primary ASA “internet” (back-office ISP) IP address: 50.243.6.193. Default gateway: 50.243.6.206  This is the ISP information: ADMIN ACCOUNT Granite Telecommunications/ But the service is subleased through Comcast 866-847-5500 Admin Acct: 04283555 Street address: 215 West South Temple, Salt Lake City, UT 84101 (THIS IS THE ACCOUNT VERIFICATION METHOD) ISP Modem MAC is: A4:56:CC:2C:35:BC Network address: 50.243.6.192 Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.240 DG IP: 50.243.6.206  The Choice IT contact is : Lenny Shteyman Senior Property Support Engineer Mobile: 612-801-3520 Email: lenny.shteyman@choicehotels.com Please also send an email to Choice IT support email: reportmoh@choicehotels.com /////////////////////////////////////  /////// IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: /////// ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 4.1.4.152  (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.62.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN3 is (1/3/1) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT" and change the IP address from 172.16.63.254/23 to 172.16.62.1/23 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Business-Center, Conference, Guest-WiFi, MGMT, Staff-WiFi -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. Device Locations In case a local connection needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24 then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- Note: The IDFs at this property are on the warm side due to a electrical transformer on each one. It was recommended to the property that to add ventilation to each one and Rachel is following up with them.  The previous HSIA vendor (Cloud 5) is still live at this property. The property requested to keep them live and asked them to come to the property to remove their equipment. So both networks might co-exist for a few days. You can easily determine if a device is connected to the old network by the SSID name as their SSIDs are named differently than ours. They use "Radisson" instead of "Radisson_Guest" and "Meeting" instead of "Radisson_Conference".  Guestcast Install All guest rooms have Guestcast installed to the LG TV in the room.  The guestcast is connected to HDMI2 and powered by the USB port behind the TV.  Some guest rooms had damaged HDMI 2 ports so the Guest cast had to be installed in HDMI 3.  Please see equipment list for the rooms that had this change.  Please note some of the guestrooms are still under construction and should be done in 2-3 weeks.  We have 21 Guest cast device that still need to be installed because of constrution, those chromecast and remotes were given to JR head of Engineering.  Per management guest cast was installed in the Bar, Gym, Conference rooms and guest rooms.  Meeting Space --------**** All wired ports like Wasatch Ballroom is configuring in the meeting VLAN 300. Looks like they have a dump switch connected to port 1/1/30 of the core switch. These ports were tested with Rebecca Mazzei's laptop. Basically, we must only create the code for the meeting (shared credentials)

column66: Guest Wifi equipment is located in the MDF behind the Front desk.  The Cox modem is also located in the same location.  The fusion, core sw, WattBox, has been installed in the Wall mount rack.  In the same rack we have a cisco SW that provides internet to all the hotel computers, POS system.  IDF is located in the 3rd and 6th floor electrical closet near the elevator.  We have an ethernet cable connected to the RadAZ-CoreSW-MDF-1-3 on Port 23 and is connected to Port 48 on the Cisco SW in the server room.  Both ends of the Ethernet cable are labeled Oracle PMS.  The port on the Core SW has been disabled until we are ready for the PMS integration.   The smart Zone is virtual at IP address 184.105.79.70:8443, the user name is admin and the password is SZthegoodworks1! The Restaurant AP is located in the middle of the room and is located and identified with a Black tape on the Grid.  The AP is above the drop ceiling.  The Bar AP is located in the Middle of the Bar mounted on the Grid. The Maintenance AP is located outside the Break Room and the Maintenance door. The AP for the Executive Board Room is located and mounted under the desk. The AP for the Gym is located above the drop ceiling in the middle of the room. The AP for the Elevator 1st floor is above the drop ceiling in front of the elevator. The AP's for Canyon 1 and 2 are located and mounted on the wall. The AP for the pool is located outside mounted on the building next to the Whirlpool. The AP for the Canyon Hallway is mounted on the Grid in the Hallway. The AP for the Front desk is located in the MDF in the Rack.   The Admin network is connected to a Cisco sw that is located in the bottom Rack of the MDF. The Oracle server is located in the adjacent room of the MDF.   Oracle and Radisson Corp use a Fortinet firewall and a cradle to communicate with the oracle server.  This circuit is provided by Cox and labeled Shop with a bandwidth of 15/2 account number 247872802.  The uplink cable from the Cox modem goes to Wan1 on the Fortinet firewall, the cradle is connect to port 4 of the Fortinet.

column68: (9/20/23) - RH: I had to move the Edge Router and the 2nd MDF Switch from the WPS, and connect them directly to the Tripp Lite battery backup. I did this because every time they had a brief power outage, the Tripp Lite could not deliver all the current drawn by the WPS via a single outlet. So I moved the two less important remote power-managed devices from the WPS to the Tripp Lite and this fixed the problem.  Guest Wifi equipment is located in the MDF behind the Front desk.  The Cox modem is also located in the same location.  The fusion, core sw, WattBox, has been installed in the Wall mount rack.  In the same rack we have a cisco SW that provides internet to all the hotel computers, POS system.  IDF is located in the 3rd and 6th floor electrical closet near the elevator. The uplink cable from the Cox modem goes to Wan1 on the Fortinet firewall, the cradle is connect to port 4 of the Fortinet.  6/12/21 Andrew and I ran 19 Ethernet cables for VOIP phones and terminate them to a 24 Port Patch Panel in the Engineering PBX room.  I have copied the VOIP excel sheet in CRM that i created.  All the ethernet cables were tested and certified.  Per Chance request we also ran 3 additional ethernet lines for the Phone vendor, 2 for PMS integration and 1 for Internet access with a public IP address.  98.172.67.172	255.255.255.240	98.172.67.161.  This ethernet connection in on the core sw port 1/2/1.  This port has been untagged for Vlan 900. column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.17.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/1/3, which is connected to the Fusion LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. using the "Actions: button, edit the VLAN 100 and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.17.254/24 to 172.16.17.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT-VLAN100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: MGMT 100, GuestWiFi 200

column66: @BSims  The is a WiFi installation consisting of a 10G S-series Fusion connected to two ICX-8200-24P SW-Core-MDF-1-01 and SW-MDF-1-02 utilizing "LAG-1," a 20G fiber channel on 1/2/3 and 1/2/4 of each switch respectively. Ports 1/2/1 and 1/2/2 are uplinks to the IDF switches. A MikroTik backup gateway is connected to the Core switch via dry VLAN 900. on port 1/1/22 with back LAN on port 1/1/23. Fusion WAN2 is the primary WAN connected to port 1/2/1  of the core switch. Primary LAN2 is the on port 1/2/2 of Core. There are 16 R series AP in the ceiling of public areas and 2 T series for the outdoor signal of the public spaces on the outdoor interior of the hotel [Pool and gazibo]. The Core switch uplinks 7 of the room APs and 5 of the public areas. The 2nd switch in the MDF uplinks one of the T350 for the Pool and 1/2 of the outside area. Plus 10 Public area R series APs. The Fitness Center and 2nd outdoor T350 are uplinked for IDF1.
column67: @BSims  MDF behind the front desk in Phone rooms Wall mount rack on the right side wall:  Fusion, MikroTik Backup Gateway, SW-Core-MDF-1-01 172.16.96.10 ICX-8200-24-P, SW-MDF-1-02 172.16.96.11 ICX-8200-24P  connected with 2 10B LAG 1/2/3 and 1/2/4,  WAttBox.  ISP is a grey box on the back wall labeled "Fronteer." Port 3 has a blue CAT6 cable to the Core switch on port 1/1/17   IDF1 is in the Electrical closet on the 2nd floor across from room 263. : 9 U wall mounted reach on the left-hand wall. SW-IDF1-2-01 172.16.96.12 ICX-7150-48PF 48 port patch panel feeds 27 Room AP R320 multimode OM3 fiber panel has 12 stands form MDF only 4 strands have been terminated two strands are patch to IDF2 6 stand pre-made OM3 fiber black box is on the wall next to the 9 U rack.   IDF2 is in the Electrical Closet, which is located inside the housekeeping closet behind the elevator on the first floor across from room 134. 9U rack on the back wall. SW-IDF2-1-01 172.16.96.13 ICX-7150-48PF. 48 port patch panel The Fiber panel is at the bottom of the wall mount rack with 6 strands of OM 3 pre-terminated strands. This IDF feeds 30 room APs R320 plus one R650 on the closet wall above and right of the switch for the Fitness center and T 350 AP on the outside wall behind room 141.
column68: @BSims  ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Log into the IPMI using the port forward https://192.182.146.142:60009/ and modify the DG from 172.16.96.254 to 172.16.96.1 --- You will lose access to the IPMI until you perform step 5. 2. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik192.182.147.142 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 3. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.96.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 4. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/2/2) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.96.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.96.254/24 to 172.16.96.1/24 6. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 7. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 8. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200 -If a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************

column23: AirTies IR Remote with External IR Cable
column66: This hotel is setup for WIF and IPTV for the Guest rooms.  All the TV's on the First floor are connected via coax. We support the VOIP connections via our Brocade ICX 7150 Switches and the Brocade ICX 7250 switch.All the Guest room data jacks are connected to a port on our 3rd and 5th floor IDF.
column67: MDF is located in the Basement, The Fusion, ZD, Wattbox and a Wan CoreSW and a network Coresw is located there.  The Wan CoreSW is there to provide interntet access with public IP address only.  The Network CoreSW has the Basement AP, along with the VOIP Phones in the Basement offices. Also attached to the network coresw we have fiber Gbics connected to the Basement IDF, Garage IDF, 1st floor IDF, 3rd floor IDF and the 5th floor IDF.  1st floor IDF supports the 1st floor common area AP's as well as the VOIP Phones for the Admin back offices, and the FD.  VOIP phones in the Basement and 1st floor use Vlan 801.  No admin Data ports run thru our Switches, the Admin ports are connected to the Cisco SW from JMark.    IDF 3rd floor - gets its uplink from a 6 strand fiber that runs from the MDF, it support all the Guest room AP's (H510) for the 2nd, 3rd and 4th floors.  The H510 are located behind the LG TV, the analog phones are connected on the left hand side of the bed.  There are only 1 Ethernet jack in every room except for Suites that have one in the Bedroom behind the TV and 1 in Living Room behind the TV.  All the AP's in the Depot side from the 2nd and 4th floor run back to the 3rd floor IDF hotel side.  Please see the visio diagram to AP layout and Guest room numbers.  IDF 5th floor - gets its uplink from a 6 strand fiber that runs from the MDF, it also support all the Guest room AP's (H510) for the 5th and 6th floors.  The H510 are located behind the LG TV, the analog phones are connected on the left hand side of the bed.  There are only 1 Ethernet jack in every room except for Suites that have one in the Bedroom behind the TV and 1 in Living Room behind the TV.  Please see the visio diagram to AP layout and Guest room numbers.  The Garage IDF gets its uplink from a 6 strand fiber that runs from the MDF, it also feeds the T610 AP over looking the Terrace area.   The Basement IDF gets its uplink from a 6 strand fiber that runs from the MDF, it also feeds only the R750 AP's in the Vin Depot (MarketHall 1 and 2) only
column68: Here are some toubleshooting information:  MDF is located in the Basement, The Fusion, ZD, Wattbox and a Wan CoreSW and a network Coresw is located there.  The Wan CoreSW is there to provide interntet access with public IP address only.  The Network CoreSW has the Basement AP, along with the VOIP Phones in the Basement offices. Also attached to the network coresw we have fiber Gbics connected to the Basement IDF, Garage IDF, 1st floor IDF, 3rd floor IDF and the 5th floor IDF.  1st floor IDF supports the 1st floor common area AP's as well as the VOIP Phones for the Admin back offices, and the FD.  VOIP phones in the Basement and 1st floor use Vlan 801.  No admin Data ports run thru our Switches, the Admin ports are connected to the Cisco SW from JMark.    IDF 3rd floor - gets its uplink from a 6 strand fiber that runs from the MDF, it support all the Guest room AP's (H510) for the 2nd, 3rd and 4th floors.  The H510 are located behind the LG TV, the analog phones are connected on the left hand side of the bed.  There are only 1 Ethernet jack in every room except for Suites that have one in the Bedroom behind the TV and 1 in Living Room behind the TV.  All the AP's in the Depot side from the 2nd and 4th floor run back to the 3rd floor IDF hotel side.  Please see the visio diagram to AP layout and Guest room numbers.  IDF 5th floor - gets its uplink from a 6 strand fiber that runs from the MDF, it also support all the Guest room AP's (H510) for the 5th and 6th floors.  The H510 are located behind the LG TV, the analog phones are connected on the left hand side of the bed.  There are only 1 Ethernet jack in every room except for Suites that have one in the Bedroom behind the TV and 1 in Living Room behind the TV.  Please see the visio diagram to AP layout and Guest room numbers.  The Garage IDF gets its uplink from a 6 strand fiber that runs from the MDF, it also feeds the T610 AP over looking the Terrace area.   The Basement IDF gets its uplink from a 6 strand fiber that runs from the MDF, it also feeds only the R710 AP's in the Vin Depot (MarketHall 1 and 2) only

IDF-5: Event Space Bldg. -We installed H550 for the Guest rooms and R550 and R650 for the common areas and Meeting rooms. -We installed 1x T350 for the Pool Area: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Note: -At some point the property need upgrade the Basement level. Because they don't have any Wifi-6 in this Area. And they need 1x R550 for the Event Space and 1x T350 for space that they have outdoor by the pool. In this upgrade we may need to add another switch in the MDF. -They need run cables for the Basement Level. Or if they want we can run the cables. (Drywall ceiling and Drop ceiling) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ ------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Old Data: -From the modem it goes to a linksys Pro Series switch(WAN Switch) then to the Fusion and then to the Core PoE switch. ZD is plugged into the Core switch as well. All IDF switches uplinks homerun back to the MDF and plug into the Core switch. There is no fiber uplink at this site, it is all Cat 5e.  ===================================================== -> Upgrade 6/17/2022: -From the modem it goes to a Linksys Pro Series switch(WAN Switch, named: Edge SW) then to the Fusion WAN 1 and another uplink to the CoreSW port 10, the CoreSW feeds the Wattbox, the Mikrotick and the Fusion IPMI. -The PSM is connected through the Fusion LAN 2 to the PCI CoreSW port 6.

column68: IF FUSION FAIL MOVE THE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Login into the Mikrotik via WinBox. WAN/Eth1 is connected to the Core-SW 2. From the Mikrotik do ssh into Core SW, run: system / ssh 172.16.78.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW , disable the SW port where the Fusion LAN (port 1/1/39) to make sure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab (VLAN 200, 201, 202, 203, 300, 301, 801). 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "ETH2/LAN" and change the IP address from 172.16.78.254/24 to 172.16.78.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.

column68: PMS issues contact  ESP 203 951-0355  All access points are PoE fed.  WAN 3 - Centurylink connecting to port 30 on the Guest Wi-Fi core switch 172.27.18.10, from the Centurylink circuit port Gig03.    Hardline Connections: 1/1/28 on IDF-BQT--1-1 - 172.16.0.11 - OId Georgetown Room  IDF 12 Switches are in penthouse 13th floor  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/1/45, which is connected to the Fusion LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Also, using the "Actions: button, edit the VLAN 101, and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.3/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT-VLAN101" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - To access the SmartZone, use the link: https://67.131.39.99:63002 - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: Conferences 300-303, 305, Guest Wi-Fi 99, Lobby Wi-Fi 98, MGMT 101, Staff 804, HVAC Vendor 805, NoiseAware 806, 	Camera System 807, No Portal 27,  MGMT WIFI 69, 	Meeting WiFi 89, Meeting-POS 87  For Guest LAN - 192.168.10.1/23 - vlan 99 they are using Hyatt DNS 103.247.36.36 and 103.247.37.37 FD ticket 54138. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN-2 (port 1/1/19) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt.172.16.0.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. column66: This is a take-cover Property. Only One Main Bldg. We landed on this property because The Hotel staff was not satisfied with the service offered by the previous provider.  They suspended the payment and ended the relationship. But the credentials were never provided.  All the configuration and network information was collected onsite and remotely. The network is a combination of Nomadix, Netgate, and Unifi Network, and then we Installed a Fusion with GuestCast Server. Casting is working from our casting server (Chromecasts were factory reset and placed on a new Google Account; see Equipment list for details) We replaced the old remotes with the Slate Remote (no guide button). Since STBs and TVs are LG we just needed to reconfigure the Casting button to switch to HDMI1. SWs uplink is Cat6. APs are Nomadix; they are PoE.  They had two Gateways onsite before us to manage the guest network (Nomadix and Netgate) with no credentials, then only some networks were moved to the Fusion: See the breakdown below ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------. We installed a Netgear Managed SW between the CoreSW(Nomadix) and Nomadix(LAN) and Netgate(LAN) to split networks.  Netgate: VLAN 101 to manage APs --- This network stays in Netgate in order to guarantee the APs always can reach the Nomadix COntroller on the cloud. Netgate: VLAN 850 to manage the STBs --- This network stays in Netgate to guarantee the STBs don't loose the Channel Lineup. Netgate: VLAN 100 to manage SWs--- Moved to Fusion using a Netgear managed SW. Nomadix: VLAN 1000 Guest  --- Moved to Fusion using a Netgear managed SW.  Nomadix: VLAN 1016 Public --- Moved to Fusion using a Netgear managed SW. Nomadix: VLAN 350 BOH --- Moved to Fusion using a Netgear managed SW. Nomadix: VLAN 650 IP-Phone  --- Moved to Fusion using a Netgear managed SW.  IMPORTANT:  ************The network is at risk of disconnection at any time. They have no contract with the former service providers. *************  There are three common areas on the property, each of which has a NOMADIX AP -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- - Lobby Area (AP located in the Lobby Pantry Room) - Storage No. 1 (Luggage Storage, located in the Director's Office) - Storage No. 2 MDF (Basement Area) All the Admin Devices PCs and Phones are wireless and connected by WiFi to SSID: MAYFAIR_BOH. Only the Front-Desk computer is hardwired.   Note: Chromecast  are on VLAN-1254. We adjusted the Casting server configuration to use the existing vlan and Chromecast. Each TV has a LG WebOS Box  to receive IP TV system.  Note: They have IP-Phone on Admin and Guestroom using VLAN650. Only TWO Phones are PoE (Front Desk), The rest of the phones are WiFi using a Power adaptor (under the bed for guestrooms).  Note: The switches on the property are NOMADIX brand, they provide WiFi and STBs. Noted that they feed STB from AP in rooms where AP.  VLAN 101 to manage SWs.  Note: On every IDF beside the Nomadix SW they also have a Unifi SW for the Camera System. We don't know what is the Gateway for the Unifi network.  Note: The WattBox is not connected to the network, although the Fusion is powered up from Outlet-2 on the WattBox.

column30: The property is using a Comcast STB via coax and connected to the TV via HDMI.  The xfinity remote uses Blue tooth to communicate with the STB.  If we convert the Hotel to a Dish network we can use the same coax or we can install H320 in the guest rooms to provide IPTV service and for the Guest rooms that do not get an AP can connect directly to the ethernet jack, these options will be up to Sales and the Hotel Management Team.
column66: Fusion Guest cast server located in MDF,  guest cast devices installed in every guest room.  The hotel uses two different Hospitality TV's - LG 49LT560H, Samsung HG49NJ477MFXZA.  Ubiquity AP's are located in a hallway deployment.  This hotel would benefit with a in room Guest wireless than using hallway deployment.  Currently while doing a signal test i am getting -63 on channel 149 and i am also getting -76 on channel 1.  The client would be a good candidate for Beyond TV and Dish network.  I have copied the channel line up and the configuration of the LG TV being used by the hotel.  I will upload the configuration file to CRM.  The distribution center for the TV channels are located in IDF A along with all the Ethernet guest room connections.
column67: MDF is located in the basement near the Front Desk, our Fusion is mounted on a shelf next to Comcast modem and a Brocade 7150 - 24 Port which is monitored by Hospitality wifi.  Hospitality Wifi is using Ubiquity AP's in the outside hallway to provide Guest wireless to guest rooms.  IDF A is located in the Basement 1st floor the Door to access IDF A is located in between 119/121 guest rooms.  All guest rooms have ethernet connections near the desk  in the guest rooms.  The Building is concrete and hallways are exposed to the outside elements.  Guest rooms are drywall with stucco. Phone systems are Analog and are connected to an RJ 11 jack near the bed and mounted on the night stand.  All ethernet connections from guest rooms run back to IDF A.  There is a path to walk from the IDF to the MDF in the basement less than 200 feet.
column68: MDF is located in the basement near the Front Desk, our Fusion is mounted on a shelf next to Comcast modem and a Brocade 7150 - 24 Port which is monitored by Hospitality wifi.  Guest Cast is mounted in different HDMI ports which depend on the Make of the TV.  LG has 3 HDMI ports Xfinity STB is connected to HDMI 2 and the Chromecast is connected to HDMI 3 and power is supplied to the chromecast via the USB port on the TV.  Samsung TV has 2 HDMI ports Xfinity STB is connected to HDMI 1 and the Chromecast is connected to HDMI 2 and power is supplied to the chromecast via the USB port on the TV.  The Xfinity remote is the only remote being left in the guest rooms because the xfinity STB use Bluetooth to control functions on Guest room TV.  Our Guest Cast remotes to do not work on that type of system.  We are designing a new guest cast information card explaining to the Guest how to use the input button on the remote so they can navigate the TV and the Guest Cast.

column30: ***DO NOT UPGRADE THE FIRMWARE on STBs*** Until we can control the zoom level of Mbox settings from our own APP, the property should not be upgraded. This is because we have set the zoom level manually on all of the STBs through MBOX settings menu.  HOW TO PROGRAM TVs: 1. HannSpree: a. Change the input to Side HDMI A (or other input if HDMI cable was moved elsewhere) b. take out master remote out of the room  2. Samsung: a: Power off the TV b: Press: MUTE 1 8 2 POWER c: In the installers menu go to Control -> Hotel Option -> Startup -> Startup Option    Currently, STBs in rooms are placed behind the dresser underneath TVs. There is HDMI cord and COAX cable that run to the TV. For each room here is a list of things needed to make it work: 1 STB (with Power Supply and HDMI cable) 1 RC-11 Remote 1 5ft COAX patch cable  1 COAX barrel

column66: AT&T Cisco 4331 router G0/0/1 feeds the guest router Cisco RV042 on port labeled Internet. One of the LAN ports in the RV042 router feeds a NetGear Prosafe PoE switch which feeds the APs. This switch also uplinks 4 more hardwired switches. At this point we can access the Guest router and the Core switch.    Cisco Router 4400 (ATT) is connected to Port 1 on the Netgear GS105, Port 2 is connected , Port 3 is connected to WAN1 on the Fusion.  Port 4 is connected to the Internet port on the Cisco RV042.    Cisco RV042 Port 1 is connected to a 4port unmanaged sw for Grandstream IP phone system.  Port 2 is connected to the Netgear Prosafe JGS524PE on Port 14 admin SW.
column67: MDF - is located behind the Front desk, the core sw, and the Wattbox is located there as well.  In the MDF you will find the phone system and directv head in for the guest TV.  The Guest rooms have LG TV's model 42LY560H with Directv STB boxes.
column68: The property have 7 access point total, but at the time me took over only 4 were online. APs: Lobby 116 130 303 311 319 330  We have installed H510 using unleashed ruckus.  One controller - H510 ip address 172.16.0.51, we have installed AP's in the following rooms and floors. Floor 1 - 116,121,122,129,130 Floor 2 - 201,202,207,210,217,218,225,226,233 Floor 3 - 303,36,311,35,315,321,322,329,330 R310 Lobby, Fitness Center  MDF is located behind the front desk labeled Tele/Video Room, Problems that i have faced is that you can not trust the patch panel for the room numbers.  Some data cables are patched correctly, others were patched with crossed wires.  Others were never connected or terminated, you will need to test the cable and tone it out to make sure you have the correct connection.  With an Unleashed Ruckus network you have no ZD or Smartzone.  One AP is setup at the controller, in this case it is an H510 AP-Room-121 IP address 172.16.0.51.  If you and another unleashed Ruckus AP the new AP will get the IP address from the fusion.  if you would like to see the dashboard please use the following url:  unleashed.ruckuswireless.com, here you can see all the clients attached and AP information.

column38: Ok, the TV has been corrected.  had to disable the HDMI-CEC on the TV.  All four options have to be turned off/deny.  If one is option left on, when the guest turns off the TV and then turn on the HDMI-CEC settings revert back to on.    Once this has been completed then you will need to Set Default Input Upon Power On to Last Input From the Home screen, choose “Settings“. Choose “Display & Sounds“. Select “Set Power“. Change the setting to “Last input“.  You need to turn off the Wifi for the TV,  From the Home screen, choose “Settings“. Choose Network Select Wi-Fi  Change the setting to "off“.  From the Home screen, choose “Settings“. Choose “Display & Sounds“. Select “HDMI-CEC“. Change the setting to “off“. One Touch Play deny ARC/eARC off Power Control off Remote Control Pass Through off  Now the TV will default to the last input used. I want to be clear that this is a setting for the full Insignia and Toshiba Fire TV edition sets only. since the project is not using a STB for TV channels, TV feed is being sent via coax i was able to configure a Guestcast remote to work all functions.  i will send the remote to the office

column68: -------------IF FUSION FAIL - MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 144.121.72.232 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.85.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port where the Fusion-LAN-2 is (port 1/3/1) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt.172.16.85.254/24-VLAN-110" and change the IP address from 172.16.85.254/24 to 172.16.85.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 10, 20, 27, 35, 200, 300, 1000 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5-Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Cabling from IDFs to rooms is in a bad condition. Lost of cables have failed strands or pairs inside individual cables. column68: DNS overwrite was added on the guest router for centuryinnqr.hotelwifi.com since it would ignore the private IP configured through easy DNS.  Additional docs:  https://docs.google.com/document/d/1WPEZCe1a2KwJ4lpIsqmA8tYYmy1U_6iK4zIwMDxcmiw/edit  https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1XD9fBjyXagWdAFb5FYJbzASeN6_BhhCP/edit#gid=810618946    Note from Liveport: Century Inn - not an ideal install due to many, many different tv's. 10 year old TCL, ava, liden, most brands i have not heard of. I tested the remotes in each room, but there may be teething pains with some buttons. In addition, every tv has to go to the source menu to go scroll to the correct input. The client was aware of this, as well as prepared that they may have to reprogram some buttons from time to time. I'm waiting on a call back from them as there are "lots of issues with remotes". However, when I was on site, they said "we have had lots of issues over night", but when enquiring further, it was volume down in 1 room that was not working. Just something to be mindful of when they are reporting issues.

column66: MDF is located on the 2nd floor by the Gym, this site has IDF's located in the Security office, 2nd Floor by Maintenance dept, 4th floor next to service elevator, and on the 4th floor above the MDF.  All the IDF's have an AP inside of them, All Guest room AP's are installed in every guest room.  Depending the Room number the AP's are in the drop ceiling in the laundry room, On the top of the credenza in the Bedroom or in the Closet where the Air Handler is located.  There is a Hardwired ethernet connection behind the TV for Innspire. Please see photos for exact Guest Room AP deployment. The first floor IDF in the security office has 2-48 port 7150 brocade Switches.  This IDF only supports the Sales center, this IDF has a Fiber strand that goes back to the MDF.  2nd Floor IDF located near the Maintenance dept connects the 1st floor, 2nd Floor and 3rd floor AP"s, Outdoor AP's and the Owners lounge along with Innspire STB, and Verkada Security cameras.  The MDF on the 2nd floor connects the 2nd and 3rd floor AP's.  Which include the Guestrooms, Gym, Admin Offices, Biz center, Laundry Room which is located outside near valet, and finally the Valet area.  4th floor IDF connects all the guest rooms on the 4th and 5th floor AP's and Innspire STB, and Verkada Security cameras. Please note that per Hotel Management all AP's are to be hidden from the Guest.  Also note that in the MDF the only color Patch cable that can be used is black.  We can use our standard color in the IDF locations.  We have a 10G backbone from the MDF to all the IDF's, the Fusion, Core Switch and the smartzone 144 are also connected using the 10GB Fiber backbone.  The ISP handoff is ethernet and it comes from the Full enclosed Rack and is connected to the Core Switch.  We have the following Vlans created on this network:  100 Management 200-Guest Wifi 201-Hardwired 801-Innspire STB 802- Verkada Security cameras 900- Public IP distribution 901- Wan Block from ISP.  Below are the Vendors list with IP address:  Innspire:               USABLE-50.220.203.169  SUB-255.255.255.224 GW-50.220.203.161  Knitec:                   USABLE-50.220.203.170-171 SUB-255.255.255.224 GW-50.220.203.161  Fitness:                 USABLE-50.220.203.173-178  SUB-255.255.255.224 GW-50.220.203.161  Bus Center: USABLE-50.220.203.179-180  SUB-255.255.255.224 GW-50.220.203.161          AV equip               USABLE-50.220.203.181-185 SUB-255.255.255.224 GW-50.220.203.161  HVAC                     USABLE-50.220.203.186-187  SUB-255.255.255.224 GW-50.220.203.161  MITEL (PBX) USABLE-50.220.203.172 SUB-255.255.255.224 GW-50.220.203.161  Hilton Admin USABLE-50.220.203.167-168 SUB-255.255.255.224 GW-50.220.203.161  As with this location we have several spare AP's,(located in the MDF) we were supposed to install AP's in the Stair wells and in the Hallways of every floor.  But according to Shon with Hilton IT no ethernet cables were ran to those locations.  Maybe in the near future they will need those AP's installed.  We also have currently 2-7150 24port POE Switches located in the MDF.  These Switches have been configured, firmware was updated, and a working config was installed for future expansion. Please see equipment list for IP address of the Switches.

column65: The Central at 5th by Hilton Club
column66: MDF is located in the Cellar, the 3 IDF's are located in the 2nd, 22nd, and 31st floors. Every Guest room has the following AP's H510 and H320, they are located in the closet.  In the closet you will see a removable cover and the AP's are located there.  Per management the AP's are to be hidden.  Behind the TV we have an ethernet connection that either goes back to MDF or the 3 IDF's.  TV provider is Innspire and they will be mounting the POE STB behind the TV along with a Chromecast device.  The TV service come into the guest room via Coax and the Guest UI is hardwired and we are providing VLAN 801 in DHCP Mode. The Cellar AP's are located in the drop ceiling and the Ground AP's are mounted in the hard ceiling.  On the ground floor where the Lobby is located we have 2 R550 AP's and in the Terrace we have a T610 just above the doors leading outside on your top left hand Corner.  We have installed a R320 outside the MDF and we have installed a R320 in the 2nd floor IDF and the 31st floor IDF.  We do not have any AP's in the Staircase for the reason of the client did not run any cables in those areas.  If the client do install ethernet cables in the Stairwell we have the AP's located in the MDF.    We have Vlan 900 on the CoreSW so we can distribute the Public IP's to either Hilton Admin or there Vendors, in the MDF we have 2 switches a Brocade 7250 and a 7150.  We have a 10 Gig backbone installed even thou we only have a 1 Gig Circuit.  The Fusion has a 10 GB Nic card installed labled Wan3 and Lan3.  The fiber connections are connected to the 10 gig SFP ports on the Brocade 7250.  All the IDF's has 1 Switch on a 10Gb fiber connection and the the other switches in the IDF are connected via ethernet.  The MDF is connected to a APC Rack UPS system, all the the IDF's have several Tripp Lite 1500 UPS.  The following Vlans located in the network: •	VLAN 100 – Management  172.16.0.2/24 GW – 172.16.0.1  •	VLAN 200 – Guest Wifi 192.168.10.2/23 GW-192.168.10.1  •	VLAN 201 – Hardwired 192.168.110.2/23 GW-192.168.110.1  •	VLAN 801 – InnSpire 192.168.211.2/24 GW- 192.168.211.1  •	VLAN 802 – Verkada Cameras 192.168.212.2/24 GW- 192.168.212.1  •	VLAN 900 – Spectum ISP 142.105.73.2-62 255.255.255.192 142.105.73.1  Please note that the Security cameras are 10/100 and are POE.  the port on the Switch that is being used needs to have 6000mW as inline power.  The H510 and H320 also require 6000mW or power.  The Innspire TV STB are POE and require 6000mW of inline power, Our R550 and the T610 require 13000mW of inline power.

IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/2/2, which is connected to the Fusion LAN3 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "MGMT VLAN100 172.16.0.0/24" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT-VLAN100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: MGMT VLAN100 172.16.0.0/24, GuestWiFi VLAN200 192.168.10.0/23, VLAN201-Hardwired, PANIC VLAN 800 192.168.210.0/24, VLAN801-Innspire-192.168.211.1/24, VLAN802-Verkada Cameras, SARA VLAN 803 192.168.213.0/24, VLAN804-PerfectRoom, VLAN805 - No Portal Device Locations

column2: The Quin Central Park by Hilton Grand Vacation
column16: The Quin Central Park by Hilton Grand Vacation
column66: There are separate VLANs for WAPs (ID 1), in-room connection (ID 301), Wireless Lock Vendor (Creston Zigbee - ID 106).  Core Switch feeds every 24-port switches on every floor separately via fiber. All the 8-ports are daisy chained to corresponding floor 24-port switches. 8-ports are mainly for vendors. All the unused ports are DISABLED on all 8-ports.
column67: Fusion, ZD and Core Switch are located downstairs in the basement (MDF).  Spectrum Handoff is in the same room as the Fusion.  It feeds into port 1/12 on the core switch.  All of the IDFs numbers correspond to floors numbers (i.e. IDF3 - floor 3).  Both Web Power switches supply Fusion Gateway, ZD and Core Switch. Fusion and Core switch have REDUNDANT Power Supplies. Each one connects to different Web Power Switches.
column68: ********This Fusion has no IPMI port.******  *********** Cast Now Chromecast Network has this configuration *************** VLAN 500: ChromeCast devices  The Quin Central Park SW-Core-MDF-B-01  Port 4 & Port 5: Untagged Guest VLAN 200 - CastNow Router Port 6: Untagged Castnow VLAN 500 - CastNow Router  Created a Bonjour Service on the SmartZone, and assigned the service to AP-MDF. column66: **ISP feed connects to a Netgear WAN switch and splits to the Admin side and Guest side.**  We do not have access to this switch. - Added 3/27/2018 - Brad  This is a Ruckus POE system with APs in roughly 10 rooms on each of floors 1-4. Each room without an AP mounted on the network jack plate there has a wired room jack and the switches for these jacks are located on each floor in IDF closets 2-4 (located next to the elevator lobby), with two switches located in the MDF for the 1st floor wired connections.      The uplinks for the IDF switches comes from the core switch in the MDF. Each floor's IDF has three switches, one switch providing PoE power to the APs, and two switches for wired jacks in each room without an AP. One of the IDF switches on each floor has an uplink from the MDF and one switch gets its uplink from the AP PoE switch in each IDF.      There is a second switch in the MDF. This switch provides connection to the Business Center PCs and to a piece of phone system equipment. The switch (SW-MDF-1-02) is uplinked from the core switch (SWE-MDF-1-01).  [ Of note is that the old 7352s are still located in the hallways and their cabling still comes back to the MDF but aren't currently plugged in. The old AP map is still in CRM.]
column67: The Fusion, main core switch and ZD1200 are located in the MDF on the 1st floor near reception. The H510 APs are mounted in-room on the network jack plates which sit above the desk. column66: Guest network consists of in-room wired connections, a wireless network.  Modem to Fusion.  Fusion to Core 48port POE Switch. Core to APs via room jacks (jacks only have 2 pair) makes possible only 100Mbps.  The Rooms without APs have an HP switch port untagged on 1050. The in Room APS (H510s) have configured the 4xLAN ports as Access Port for hardwire (untagged on vlan 1050).  Phase 1 Notes: ======================================================= +++APs in Rooms (H510s) are all working at 100M due to contiguous rooms are sharing the same Cat5/6... only Two data pairs per Room. +++The existing Hardware (Old Fusion) does recognize the 10G adapter card (WAN3 and LAN3) but doesn't work properly. +++We may keep an eye on this Fusion behavior, it went down couple times during the Re-Installation and Upgrade process. The Mikrotik is Fully configured in case the Fusion fails. +++UPSs: One of Two is working, providing Fusions and 6xSWs, but not mounted on the rack, still need the NIC.  The Second of Two is not power UP also not mounted on the rack.      Pending for Phase 2: ========================================================= +++Once we get the NIC for the UPSs, we can proceed to insert them on the UPSs, set the UPSs on the Rack, and set up the management IPs and Credentials.
column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 130.250.240.133 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.25.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN3 is (1/2/1) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT-172.16.25.0/24VLAN 100" and change the IP address from 172.16.25.254/24 to 172.16.25.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: MGMT-172.16.25.0/24VLAN 100, GuestWifi-192.168.18.0/23-vlan1000, BTCollins-172.20.0.0/24-vlan1025, RoomHW-10.71.10.0/24VLAN 1050 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.

column66: In the MDF on the 1st floor is the Fusion, Core switch, and ZD. The core switch is also connected to the hardwire room switches in the IDFs next to the elevator on each floor.   The Business center PCs and Printers are connected to the first of the hard wire switches in the MDF.  There are separate VLANs setup on all switches for Business Center, Conference room, Guest Wifi, Equipment Management, and room hardwire connections.       The H500 APs are mounted on the network Jack that is above the desk in the rooms and are POE powered. The AP ports are on the hardwire VLAN.       There is an R500 covering the Lobby, Business Center, and part of the Meeting Room. There is also an H510 in the meeting room itself on one of the walll jacks. The Meeting Room is covered by the Lobby AP, the Meeting Rm AP, and the APs in rooms 103 and 207.
column67: In the MDF on the 1st floor is the Fusion, Core switch, and ZD. column66: The Core Switch, SW-MDF-1-01, located in the server room behind reception, powers all the APs over PoE as well as connecting the Fusion and ZD1200 (.. All the rooms as well as the 4th floor Milpitas Meeting room have wired network jacks. Roughly 10 APs per floor are mounted on the network jack plates in the guest rooms shown above.Of note is that only two of the four pair of the cables going to the network jacks in each room are being used for network.        All the guest room network jacks come back to patch panels in the MDF. From these patch panels the room jacks are connected to ports on switches SW-MDF-1-03 to 08. There are individual vlans for each room jack.       Of note is that the original core switch became SW-MDF-1-02. This switch connects the business center PCs, Dish Smart Box, and all 6 wired switches, These is also the old AP switch in the 2nd floor IDF. This IDF switch still has the 7352 hallway APs connected to it but the PoE power has been turn off on the AP ports.       There is a Wattbox in the MDF and it has its own Public IP. ** Velocity Modem/router box (port 13) connected to SW-MDF-1-01 (Port 42)** 6/02/2025  Wired Guest Room Switches:  Switch - IP Address - VLAN 1 is on Port 1 of all switches  MILCW1B (now SW-MDF-1-03) - 192.168.1.10 - VLANS 101-109,124,126, & 132-137 are on ports 2-24  MILCW1C (now SW-MDF-1-04) - 192.168.1.11 - VLANS 138-141 & 201-219 are on ports 2-24  MILCW1D (now SW-MDF-1-05) - 192.168.1.12 - VLANS 221-224,226,232-241,301-308 are on ports 2-24  MILCW1E (now SW-MDF-1-06) - 192.168.1.13 - VLANS 309-319,321-324,326,332-338 are on ports 2-24  MILCW1F (now SW-MDf-1-07) - 192.168.1.14 - VLANS 339-341,401-419,421 are on ports 2-24  MILCW1G (now SW-MDF-1-08) - 192.168.1.15 - VLAN1 is on Port 1 & Ports 14-26,VLANS 422-423 & 432-441 are on ports 2-13. column66: The network starts at an admin WAN switch. Both the WAN2 Fusion port and Wattbox are connected to this WAN switch.       The network is PoE based. There are H510s mount on the network jack plates in the guest rooms. It should be noted that the network cables to the rooms only use 2 pairs, the other two pairs being used for phone.        In the MDF, the network cables from the rooms are punched down on phone blocks and then from those blocks go to patch panels on the main equipment rack. Note that the patch panel for the 4th floor is located on the back of the rack, not on the front where the patch panels for rooms on floors 1-3 are located.       There is a main core switch, SW-MDf-1-01. This switch provides the PoE power for all the APs.       The old original core switch is now SW-MDF-1-02. This switch provides connections to the Business Center, Muzack Box, a mysterious piece of equipment, and to the 6 guest room wired switches (there wasnt enough ports on the new core switch).       [note: The old 7352s are still mounted in the hallways of the 1st and 3rd floors. The cables for these old APs run back to the MDF equipment rack]

column66: Guest network consists of in-room wired connections, a wireless network and business centers.  Comcast Modem to Fusion . Fusion to HP POE Core switch. HP switches to wired connections.. Each room port is on a separate VLAN.   This system was upgraded using H500 APs installed in rooms. APs were mounted over the existing room data jack mounted on the wall. Phone line was routed through AP and connected to phone jack in the wall.  There is a Web switch in the MDF and this controls power to the Modem, fusion, ZD, and Core Switch.
column67: This system was upgraded using H500 APs installed in rooms. APs were mounted over the existing room data jack mounted on the wall. column66: We installed a Fusion, Mikrotik, Wattbox, Ruckus SWs, and Unleashed APs(we replaced the old Aruba APs with new Ruckus APs) The new Spectrum ISP circuit was contracted through us. The property is a single building with three floors. All the AP cables run back to the MDF.  Master Unleashed AP:  AP-Meeting-Room  Secondary Unleashed AP:  AP-Lobby   The Admin Gateway is Fortinet: That Fortinet is fed from our Core switch (172.16.0.10) port 1/1/39 --- Untagged VLAN900 using Public IP: 47.49.111.126   We are providing internet access through our Core switch to other devices: 		 1/1/34	BIZ-PC-----------------------------------VLAN - 801 1/1/35	BIZ-Printer-------------------------------VLAN - 801 1/1/36	PhoneSuite-Backup-Internet-------VLAN  - 202 1/1/37	Alexa-WAP-Lobby---------------------VLAN - 202 1/1/39	WAN-Admin-Firewall------------------VLAN - 900  The path from the Fusion to the PMS interface computer is through the admin Fortinet firewall using VLAN 2020 and subnet 172.20.0.0/30: Fortinet FW: 172.20.0.1/30 Fusion GW: 172.20.0.2/30 Route: Destination - 10.90.62.131/32 next hop 172.20.0.1 Physical connection: 1/1/38	PMS-Admin-Firewall------------------VLAN - 2020 PMS provider: Autoclerk (Comtrol UHLL)   Phone System: ---------------------- They have IP-Phones at the FD and GM Office and Regular Analog Phones on the Guest area. We do not manage the Phones, but we are providing a DHCP Port on VLAN202 from CoreSW (1/1/36) to the Phone System.  Apparently this is for Remote Access Only, It was connected to the previous Guest SW, so we did the same.  We were not able to contact the Phone Vendor when onsite, so they may ask for Remote Access to their Phone System. All indicates that the Phone System (White Box Labeled: Phone Suite Mikrotik) gets Internet access via LTE6. Please see the Network Diagram for Details.  Alexa at MDF: -------------------- The previous vendor installed a TP-Link AP on top of the rack to broadcast a unique SSID for the Alexa device (also at MDF). So we connected that TP-Link AP to a DHCP Port on VLAN202 from CoreSW (1/1/37). The GM plans to reconfigure the Alexa device, so he might call us to request a new SSID.     Guest WiFi Experience: ----------------------------------- The client will connect to a visible and open SSID: Bestwestern  We provide the Splash page with PMS authentication. The GM requested redirect to: https://www.bestwestern.com/en_US/book/hotel-rooms.50154.html?iata=00171880&ssob=BLBWI0004G&cid=BLBWI0004G:google:gmb:50154 He also asked for a 15Mbps/15Mbps cap on that network.
column67: **MDF** It is located on the first floor behind the kitchen area.  ** Access Points** The access points in the rooms are located under the desk.  **Switches Brocade** They are located in the front rack above the patch panels that connect to the rooms.  **Fusion, Mikrotik, WATTBOX, ISP-SPECTRUM** They are located in the rear rack.
column68: ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 47.49.111.124 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/1/47) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.0.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200, 201, 202, 800 and 801 - In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************.
