column30: The solution is BTV390 box with regular TV signal that comes through the COAX network. The STBs are plugged in into HDMI port 1. Chromecasts are installed next to the STBs and are plugged in into STB's HDMI IN port.  The TVs installed are consumer grade televisions. That means we cannot lock any inputs.   The remote controls switches between COAX and HDMI-1 inputs (LiveTV and APP buttons). Pressing LiveTV twice will also cause a local TV Guide on the TV to show up. The only way to get out of it is it hit the LiveTV button again.  The TV does not have a sleep button that sets a timer, making Sleep button not programmable.  HDMI1 input and number buttons were programmed to BeyondTV remote using Harmony 650 remote.The rest of the buttons were programmed from the native remote.  The Samsung TVs needed a clock setting.  It was required that we created a SSID called TV (May be hidden) with the password h0teltvs so that the clocks could be NTP set.

column68: ********************************************************************************* San Vicente Main Hotel ********************************************************************************** Please note. The Sonic wall WAN for the admin network is connected to the core switch (172.16.0.10) on Port 17 via Dry VLAN 900. The Sonic wall also has a LAN port connected to port 16 for the hidden SVLMS POS network. This is tagged VLAN 801.  Wireless Client Isolation must be disabled for this network. The SSID is only active on 2 access points. (It is hidden and only 2 APs have the vlan tagged)    Kelly Rickard - support@sdcea.net is a good POC to interface with the team managing the Sonic wall if necessary.  David.G - 09/14/2022  No Web Power Switch or Watt Box.  AP's are using Unleashed Firmware Rooms 4223 and 4212 cable run were a bit short and were extended with keystones in the rooms.  **********************************************************************************   ************************************************************************************ Recreational Center: ************************************************************************************ ------------------------IF pFsense fail ---- Move traffic Over Mikrotik------ The pFsense and the Mikrotik are configured with the same Public and Private IPs.  We left the Mirkotik ON but no ethernet cables plugged in. I case of pFsense failure WAN and LAN cables needs to be moved to the Mikrotik.  1. Move Cat6 cable from pFsense WAN2 to ETH1 on Mikrotik. 2. Move Cat6 cable from pFsense LAN2 to ETH2 on Mikrotik. 3. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 98.174.129.84 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 4. Verify Port Forward to Master Unleashed AP. 5. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 6. column66: This is an MDU property, where every unit shares a Common Area for 2, 3, 4, 5, or up to 6 Bedrooms. We used only the Cat6 drop per unit to link a new IDF per Unit.  Residents experience: ------------------------------- All the Residents will connect to the same SSID (8833 Reading Residents).  By using their personal Code the Fusion will provide IP on the static vlan/network linked to their own account. For Hardwire connections, they have a dedicated SW-Port with the specific VLAN per account.  All the IDFs are fed via PoE (Cat6) from the MDF using SWs Brocade 8200ZP. These SWs at MDF have enough power (60W assigned per port) to feed: ***Omada POE Switch ***Omada Hardwire Switch ***APs (1 or 2 per IDF)  Uplinks at the MDF side are terminated on a Patch Panel, while at IDF's side are terminated on RJ45.  Both ends are labeled the same, see bellow: Room xxx - Label ------------------------ Room 505 - AP29 Room 504 - AP28 Room 503 - AP27 Room 502 - AP26 Room 501 - AP25  Room 407 - AP24 Room 406 - AP23 Room 405 - AP22 Room 404 - AP21 Room 402 - AP20 Room 401 - AP19  Room 307 - AP18 Room 306 - AP17 Room 304 - AP16 Room 303 - AP15 Room 302 - AP14 Room 301 - AP13  Room 207 - AP12 Room 206 - AP11 Room 205 - AP10 Room 204 - AP09 Room 203 - AP08 Room 201 - AP07  Room 108 - AP06 Room 107 - AP05 Room 105 - AP04 Room 104 - AP03 Room 103 - AP02  Lounge - AP01  * The AP for the Lobby is fed by the Room-104 POE Switch * Every Uplink was extended from the original end at the room to the Media Box, the uplink extension tie is located under the main AP in the living room in every module. * The Uplink is connected to the POE switch in the port 5, this POE switch fed the hardwire switch from the port 4 to port 8(POE IN) at the hardwire switch * The APs in every room are connected at port 1 and 2 in the POE switch
column67: The MDF is located in the basement of the storage room.  The ISP and the rack with all the wifi and cameras system equipment are in the MDF. All the modules IDFs are located in a small closet commonly used as food storage, except for the room 105 which is in the closet in the last room. The roof AP is near the elevator behind the water tanks The AP Garage-12 is inside the MDF to provide Wifi inside the MDF which is a dead zone due by the place structure Every module has 1 or 2 AP depending on the design. Check the Network diagram for the exact location of every AP.
column68: ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Log into the IPMI using the port froward https://12.191.180.115:60009/ and modify the DG from 172.16.0.254  to 172.16.0.1 --- Will loss access to IPMI until perform step 5. 2. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 12.191.180.115 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 3. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: admin/SsquidPineapplejelly7& 4. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/2/2) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.0.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 6. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 7. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 8. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200, 201 to 324 and 401 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************

column66: This property is managed by the Hargray Communications group. All APs have a Layer 2 connection to the controller. The Traffic is tunneled through the controller to their data center, and the devices get internet through what they call "Cisco Core Router" We do not have access to that router, and escalation to this group will be needed in case of any issues related to it. The Aruba controller is also the DHCP server for all devices.  Elite Resort Group ERG POC 1: Sylvie Moore | smoore@erghhi.com Phone: 617-784-3626 ERG POC 2: Andy Fere Phone: 843-422-5790
column68: ***NOTE: Password would change every 3 months depending on the season*** ***NOTE: Hargray Communications has rebranded to Sparklight***  Escalation Policy for NOC for Hargray Properties:  Property list:  - Coral Reef - Coral Sands - Island Links - Palmera Inn & Suites - Port O Call  These locations are all located at Hilton Head Island in South Carolina. They are all managed by a single Aruba Central controller.  ------------------------------------------------------------------ Common Cases Troubleshooting Notes: (check Policy in CRM Docs) ------------------------------------------------------------------ In the following cases, an escalation should be opened with Sparklight:  1- A guest issue is unable to be resolved due to down equipment 2- Multiple access points down  Steps:   1 - NOC agents should create a freshdesk ticket and call Sparklight TCC at the following number:- Sparklight TCC: 843-686-1138,  2- In the case of no response: report of “Down APs” is emailed to hargray_repair@htc.hargray.com; hargray-wi-fiengineering@cableone.biz ; cableone-enterprisesalesengineering@cableone.biz; EnterpriseServiceOperations@sparklight.biz; Albert.McGraw@sparklight.biz smoore@erghhi.com; afera@erghhi.com; itmanager@palmeravacationclub.com   ------------------------------------------------------------------ Network Outage Cases Troubleshooting Notes:  (check Policy in CRM Docs) ------------------------------------------------------------------ In the case of an outage with the Aruba Central controller, NOC agents should create a freshdesk ticket and escalate to Sparklight NOC:  1- Sparklight NOC: 843-686-1158  2- In the case of no response from Sparklight TCC or Sparklight NOC the following escalation list can be called: 	- Sparklight Sales Engineer Manager: John Gallagher 843-684-0171  For both scenarios:   NOC agents should provide a ticket number for the issue (freshdesk ticket) and explain the purpose of the escaltion.  Please note:  - We can only monitor the access points at these locations, so don't have access to their switches or routers. - At no time should agents identify to end customers as "Touchstone1". We are operating as "Sparklight ". Tier 1 agents have a specific speil for guest calls, but NOC agents should identify as "Sparklight  NOC" or just "Network Operations" when dealing with guests at these properties.   Aruba Mobility Controller: https://67.20.141.134:4343  User: HIS PW: His2023!

column68: This is a Convention Center property  For any question please Contact: Mike (IT department) Phone Number: 602-397-0023. He know every location for the APs, where cables going he have a lot information.   Other Contact: Jarad Carbajal  (IT department) Phone Number: 602-500-2800.  **************************************************************************************************************************************************** Please Note: There are 2 switches in sync with the Fusion.  172.16.20.12 and 172.16.20.22. The Ports used in the meeting rooms are configured to be in VLAN 3000 and disabled when not in use by a conference.  If this needs to change please apply a different Switch port profile to the port and let Jarad Carbajal know. (602)500-2800.  Also, at times when a port is assigned to a conference this will cause the Fusion to not sync with the switch. If this happens AND the switch will also not Generate Diff remove the port from the conference then re-attempt the sync.  -10.13.2022 - David.G ****************************************************************************************************************************************************  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 70.166.189.149 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.20.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN3 is (1/3/1) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.20.254/24 to 172.16.20.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: MGMT-VLAN-100, Guest-Wifi-VLAN-200, Conf-General-VLAN-300, Staff 192.168.138.0/23 VLAN 310, Conf-Wardwire-VLAN-350, HSIA-Generic-VLAN-1050 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.

column68: In case of an outage send email to Michael Ensor and Dano Thompson. When power cycling the fusion through the WPS use the Switch OFF button instead of the Cycle button wait for at least 60 seconds before you turn it back on.   ******************************************** *** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE *** ******************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 4.38.240.94 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh  172.16.82.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (int ETH 1/3/4) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt.172.16.82.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.82.254/24 to 172.16.82.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200, 202, 300, 400, 500, 800 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.

column66: This is a take cover as is. The property has a Fortigate that handles the management and guest traffic. The Nomadix that use to handle the Guest traffic is not in use, but accessible.  The access points and switches are controlled by Aruba central.  SWs and AP management is over Aruba Central, they reside on Group/Side: "Point South Marina Bay Point" SNMP port forwards were setup on the Fortigate. See equipment List for details. All the changes on the SWs has to be done via Aruba Central, except for the case when the SW got out of Sync. See below:  Configuration changes for the SWs doing ssh through Fortigate CLI console: >>>execute ssh hisadmin@10.0.3.13x  The local IT manager has his set of credentials, he will need to use it in case the SWs got offline or out of sync from Aruba Central.

column66: We are involve in an Installation that have been taking more than 1 Year, it implies that every New AP or AP replaced will be connected to the VSZ AWS https://loewshotelsvsz.hotelwifi.com:8443  We are updating the equipment list systematically, new versions of it have been uploaded to CRM. The Conference Tool is in sync with this vSZ, although the AV department most of the time demand the Events SSIDs property wide, for these cases the Conference has to be configured manually (Walter and Shalima are clear on the process).     Guest and public space traffic goes through the guest Fusion.  Conference space traffic goes through the conference Fusion. The conference Fusion is the RADIUS server for both guest and conference networks. Before make any change on the SWs consider that some of them are Sync with the Fusion, some changes can break the sync.  APs on Guest Rooms Bldg. St. Moritz are connected via GPON --- we can monitoring the APs but not the SWs. APs on the rest of the property, including Conference Spaces are connected via Ethernet PoE Switches.  All the APs in Guest Rooms Bldg. Main will be moved to GPON as part as the WiFi upgrade.
column67: The MDF is on the ground floor and there are IDFs on different floors.  The APs on Guest Area (St. Moritz -GPON-) are inside the room.  The APs on Guest Area (Main Bldg. -NO GPON YET-) are mostly on the hallways, some of them inside the room hidden on a ceiling.

column66: ISP first feed our Core switch port 1 .Separate VLAN 900 created for WAN connections on ports 1-4 . Our Fusion  and admin router (the router is located under FD) get their feeds from core switch ports 2 and 3 .  Then Fusion LAN connected to the same switch port 10 . Ports 6-10 are separated by VLAN 200 (Mgmt - VLAN 200) and tagged to VLAN 100 (Guest = VLAN 100) . Web Power switch connected to the core switch port 6 and feed power to core switch, DSLAMs and FUSION.  For More detail see diagram and equipment list . Kiosk is connected to the network via Wi-Fi. The MAC is 00:21:9b:4d:45:ca
column67: ISP located in telephone room (behind the front desk).  Gateway (Fusion) , Two DSLAMs , 8 port HP managed core switch and WPS are locaed in the MDF (telephone room  behind FD)
column68: The MDF temperature is very high . I installed fan (cooler) directed to the rack. Equipment can be overheated if fan stops working. If equipment become overheated again, ask them to leave MDF door open which will get cool from manager's office.  ***Update - The MDF has been cleaned up a bit and they have a fan and small AC unit in the room. Equipment appears to not be overheating at this time. - Brad 11/26/2019*** (See attached MDF photos  )

column16: Secrets Hideaway Resort and Spa Condominium Association
column66: We installed and manage the Wi-Fi network at this site, as well as BeyondTV with casting. This property is a "lifestyle resort". It is part hotel and part condo and is managed by a Condo Owners Association--the condos are rented out as hotel rooms most of the time. Since the rooms are individually owned, there are various types of TVs throughout the property. We created a piece of in-room collateral to help guests navigate their respective TVs with BTV (see Docs tab).   PMS is IQware. Our contact was their Dir of Client Services, Jeffrey Engleberg: 303-221-2071 Ext: 7022, jengleberg@iqwareinc.com  As of 7/12/21, there are eight rooms with coax issues and 17 rooms with bad TVs:  	 Coax Cable Missing or Needs to be Repaired (8) 107	Coax needs to be fixed (no channels) 119	Coax needs to be fixed (no channels) 130	Coax missing (no channels) 151	Coax needs to be fixed (no channels) 219	Coax missing (no channels) 230	Coax needs to be fixed (no channels) 261	Coax needs to be fixed (bad signal) 262	Coax needs to be fixed (no channels) 	 	No TV or TV Needs to be Replaced (17) 162	Construction/No TV  211	Construction/No TV  228	Construction/No TV  266	Construction/No TV  	 126	No TV 138	No TV 208	No TV 215	No TV 	 105	TV needs to be replaced (bad TV) 109	TV needs to be replaced (bad TV) 129	TV needs to be replaced (can't switch inputs) 135	TV needs to be replaced (can't switch inputs) 136	TV needs to be replaced (can't switch inputs) 166	TV needs to be replaced (bad TV) 257	TV needs to be replaced (can't switch inputs) 258	TV needs to be replaced (can't switch inputs) 265	TV needs to be replaced (can't switch inputs)  The Dish channel line-up was approved and finalized in Dec 2020, but the property wants to change it. The change requires a change order (they have the quote), so will not move forward until the sales agreement has been taken care of.

column66: This is a 2 Buildings Hotel, the main one (East Wing) and the back one (West Wing), both are 3 stories buildings. The MDF is located behind the front desk and it's connected to the IDF using a fiber connection, the IDF is located in the basement of the back building.
column67: MAIN BUILDING (East Wing)  +MDF: It's located behind the front desk. - Fusion -Core-SW -EdgeRouter -WattBox  +APs -4 AP in the Basement -3 AP in the 1st Floor -9 AP in the 2nd Floor  BACK BUILDING (West Wing) +IDF: It's located on the back building basement  -SW-IDF-1-1  +APs: -5 APs in the 1st Floor -5 APs in the 2nd Floor.
column68: -The ISP modem is located in a server room on the 1st-floor hallway, in the main building, the ISP is connected to our Core-SW through a cable that is running to the MDF (port 3 on the patch panel in the ISP room -> port 3 on the patch panel in the MDF) * For more details see the pictures on google docs. -The PMS system is connected directly to WAN on the Fusion. (LAN 2 -> port Fortinet firewall port 3, located in the ISP room) -The AP-Kitchen is located inside the basement,  next to the access door in the kitchen. -The APs in the Main building are hidden inside the 2nd-floor ceiling. * See network diagram for more details. -The APs in the back building are hidden inside the closet in the guest rooms. * See network diagram for more details.  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/2/1, which is connected to the Fusion LAN1 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "MGMT" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "Mgmt-172.16.0.0/24-VLAN100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: Mgmt-172.16.0.0/24-VLAN100, Guest-192.168.10.0/23-VLAN200, Associates-192.168.13.0/24-VLAN201, 	LobbyWifi-192.168.14.0/24-VLAN202

column66: This is an MDU property, which is multiple Bldgs. deployment. We have 3 x Brocade SWs at Clubhouse (Bldg1.) We have 3 x Brocade SWs at Building 4. We have 3 x Brocade SWs at Building 5. We have 2 x Brocade SWs at Building 6. We have 1 x Brocade SW at Building 7.  Only one SW per IDF will have its own SM Fiber Link from MDF. The rest of the SWs per IDF will be linked from the first SW.  We sold the ISP in this property.  We are installing a TP-Link SW per unit inside a Media Panel. These SWs are only dedicated to Hardwire connections inside the unit; they are uplinked from the SWs Brocade located at each BLDG IDF. We are deploying One Ruckus AP inside every unit, mounted on the ceiling, and they are directly linked from the SWs Brocade located at each BLDG IDF.

They have 390s, RC-10 remotes, & Chromecast. (NO MPI cables)  When the guest scans the QR code that gets displayed in the BTV UI, it submits the code and room number for them, so they are supposed to just hit the success page of the portal. column68: They have a Unifi network with a Mikrotik gateway.  If the casting ICON is not showing in the BTV UI most likely the Chromecast is not powered or the HDMI cable is disconnected from the 390 STB.  *************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************  PMS ------------------------- Our PMS interface is a local instance of PMS Proxy running on the Caching Server (mercurealbury.hotelwifi.com:50007) at the property. Hibox connects to this local PMS Proxy through a port forward on the Admin router (55194 to 55194) and then another port forward on the Fusion (55194 to 6700). Hibox is configured to hit mercurealbury.hotelwifi.com, so as long as that DNS record is updated in the event of a public IP change, the interface should survive.  On prem, the Caching Server is hitting the Protel PMS Connector at 192.168.2.54 (VLAN 2) on port 5006. The Caching Server's eth0 interface is on VLAN 2 with a static IP of 192.168.2.254.  To check the status of the local PMS Proxy, log into the Caching Server and run:  supervisorctl status all  Or to check logs, run:  tail -f /var/log/pms_proxy/pms_proxy.log

column67: On Samsung and LG TVs, the Guest device is connected to HDMI 2. However, some suites, for example, have an LG TV in the Bathroom, and the Guest cast device is connected to HDMI 3.   All Guest cast devices are powered by the TV's USB port. The Guest cast is secured to the Coax Cable, which allows the Property to replace the TV without cutting the Security cable of the Guest cast.    The guest cast server is located on the 2nd floor MDF, in the Housekeeping closet; this closet is stackable with the 1st through the 3rd floor. Wi-Fi is supported by Unifi AP Pros, and they are configured in a Hallway deployment for the 1st and 3rd floors.  Wan 1 and IPMI are connected to ports 1 and 2 of an unmanaged 5-port TP-link switch, Lan1 and Lan2 are connected to the Unifi core switch on ports 6 and 7.  Lan 1 is the Guest Wifi, and Lan 2 is for the Guest cast devices on Vlan 500.
column68: Please note that VLAN 500 on our server is tagged and not untagged.  The IT vendor is not able to configure VLAN 500 as untagged traffic.  No Configuration to LG TVs was needed, but for the Samsung, we had to disable the HDMI-CEC, which is located in the settings of the TV.  We also had to turn off the Home welcome Logo, so that once the TV is turned on, it will go to a live channel.  To turn off the Home logo, we had to go into the Hospitality mode of the TV by selecting the Mute button, 119, and the Enter button.  Once in the Hospitality menu, you will need to scroll down to a tab called OSD, and in there, you can turn on or off the Home welcome logo.  Please see the Samsung TV video located in the SharePoint folder for the property.    On Samsung and LG TVs, the Guest device is connected to HDMI 2. However, some suites, for example, have an LG TV in the Bathroom, and the Guest cast device is connected to HDMI 3.    The Guest Cast remote has a Guide button, but it is not configured.  The property has sub-channels, for example, 10-1 is the same as channel 10.  We are not able to program the Guide button for a channel.  The Menu Button is configured for either a Samsung or an LG TV. All other buttons have been configured properly to the specifications of the TV.

column66: There are two parts of this project that are connected via a Ruckus 7731 Point to Point Bridge. One side is in bldg 5 (Sender) while the other is in Bldg 11.  On Each Side of the Ubiquites, there is Fiber that goes from building to building. Please see network Diagram for layout of the fiber. From there a Cat 5 cable is run to a Switch on a building which via cat 5 feeds another switch. Each Switch feeds POE to certain AP's. For a list of what ports feed what AP's, please see equipment list.   Building 5 to 21 Air Fiber Connection:  The Air Fiber are connected via Cat 6e in a Point to Point Bridge configuration, One side is in bldg 5 (Master) while the other is in Bldg 21 (Slave). Each air fiber is connected Via Cat 6e cable from the roof.  Building 5 Master is connected to port 20 on Bldg5SW on First floor.  Air fiber (Slave) is connected to the Roof of Build 21 then a cat 6e cable is ran to the 2nd floor IDF room. We have a redundant Cat 5E cable that is connected between Building 20 2nd IDF-21 2nd IDF. We also have a Fiber connection between Building 20-21 in the 2nd floor IDF.

column68: For device reboots contact: (321) 284-6173 Diana, Engeeneer Manager is the best contact.   We added 4 new switches at Parkway: 10.20.8.43 - Building1 1st Floor 10.20.8.44 - Building1 1st Floor 10.20.8.45 - Building1 1st Floor 10.20.8.46 - New Core Building 21 All wireless bridges are now Offline. --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- P2P in Bldg 12 IDF - the key for this room is labeled "S4" in case we need to open the door. They never find the right key for this door... Because the regular master key for the other rooms is labeled as - V-. Just FYI  The property is running dynamic VLANs (201-250) and the clients are load balanced through the 3 fusion cluster nodes. The routing is happening at the switch level with the 2 switches in the MDF (3500y & 2920) and the one on building 5 IDF (2920). The 2 switches in the MDF are handling 17 VLANs each and the one in building 5 is handling 16 VLANs. The default gateway for all those VLANs are the switches and the Fusion doesn't need to know anything about those VLANs. Within each switch VLAN the IP-helper command was issued to point to the respective node to handle DHCP. In the ZD only these 3 switch mac-addresses were white listed for client isolation. Also note that custom DHCP option groups were associated with each DHCP pool to provide: default gateway, subnet mask, and DNS. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Primary wireless link between core and buildings 12-19 is an AirFiber bridge between building 5 and building 12. There is a redundant link between Building 2 and Building 17, that is disabled by default to prevent loops. The master is connected to port 24 on the Building 5 POE switch (10.20.8.14). If this link fails, port 24 on Building 2 POE switch (10.20.8.11) must be enabled to bring up the redundant link.  -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The MDF in building 5 is locked and can only be accessed using a code on the door.  The code to enter this room is 3585.  Many of the staff do not know this code so you made need to tell them what it is if the room cannot be accessed. - Walter 6/6/19 --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Building 1 IDF can only be accessed with a keypad now on the door. The code to enter the room is 8787* --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Bldg12 Airfiber WPS http://4.35.248.123:65405/ In case Link1 is down, enable P2P Bldg2. If Bldg12 Airfiber Receiver 10.20.6.15 is not pinging we can restart it from this WPS.  CASTING SERVER IN BLDG-20: The Guestcast server use only VLAN 272 for the Guest, the Authentication method should be set as Open and not MAC-Address .

column65: Comfort Inn and Suites Port Charlotte
column66: This is the property where we do not manage the WiFi. We only installed the Guestcast Server, Chromecast and Guestcast Remotes.
column67: The guest cast device is connected to HDMI2 and powered by the TV's USB port. The Meeting TV is slightly different; the Chromecast is connected to HDMI3 since HDMI2 was broken. The TV remote was configured to communicate to HDMI3. The guest cast server is located in the 2nd FL IDF with the Guest Wi-Fi brocade SW. The Head End is in the MDF/Server room behind the front desk.  The MDF and IDF on the 2nd FL and 3rd floor are on stacking floors.  We have 2" conduit between the floors. Lan 1 and Lan 2 are connected to Brocade SW1, Lan2 is on port 21, and Lan 1 is on port 22.  Uplink to Guest Cast server is connected to a 5 port unmanaged SW located on the left-hand side of the GuestCast server.  The server is mounted to a 2U Wedge rack, and the Power cord is connected to a UPS.  The ISP link comes from MDF 1st FL (WAN SW) to UN-manage 5Port SW on 2nd FL provided by us (HIS). Then o our WAN1 on Guestcast Server.
column68: The TVs are LG with FTG direct TV. There is no STB behind the TVs; they are mounted on the wall with a Swivel mounting bracket. Chromecast is installed in HDMI2 and secured to the TV Mounting bracket.  The Guest cast remote is the standard remote with no menu or guide buttons.  The Meeting TV is slightly different; the Chromecast is connected to HDMI3 since HDMI2 was broken.  The TV remote was configured to communicate to HDMI3.

column68: For SSH on Switches: It can be performed through the pFsense or the Mikrotik ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 1. pFsense ***SSH on pFsense using the IP public address 12.144.71.202 UN: admin PW: GsquidPineapplejelly7& ***Select option 8) Shell from the menu... just type: 8 and "Enter" ***Then ssh admin@172.16.76.xx into the desired SW 2. Mikrotik ***Log into the Mikrotik via Winbox software using the IP public address 12.144.71.203 UN: admin PW: GsquidPineapplejelly7& ***From left Vertical Menu select "New Terminal" ***Once the Terminal is open type: system and "Enter" ***then ssh 172.16.76.xx into the desired SW   IF pFsense FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 12.144.71.203 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.76.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port 1/1/46 which is for the pFsense LAN1 to ensure it won't be traffic over the pFsence router. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt-172.16.76.0/24-VLAN100" and change the IP address from 172.16.76.254/24 to 172.16.76.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Mgmt-172.16.76.0/24-VLAN100, Guest-192.168.10.0/23-VLAN200, Vendor-WiFi-192.168.210.1/24-VLAN800. -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.

column66: This is a takeover property where we Replaced their Gateway with a Fusion. We also replaced the HP CoreSW with a Brocade ICX-7550-24F on stack (2 units) We also added four more Brocade SWs: one at MDF to supply Eth ports and three spread around separated IDFs. We also installed a local SZ-144 to replace a local ZD-1050; both devices are installed at MDF linked from CoreSW, and accessible. They have Conference Tool setup. The property is composed of 15x separated Buildings with their own IDFs. Mostly, all the IDFs' SWs are linked via Fiber Multimode.  15x different bldgs. with guest rooms.  ----------------------------------------------------- -Topa Court  -Shangri-la  -Hacienda  -Orchard Suites  -Wallace Neff -Casa Loma  - Casa Robles -Casa Blanca -Arbolada -Fontana -Spa Penthouse -Villa Mariposa -Paseo Villas -Villa los Padres -Casa Elar  See below the 6x Public spaces ----------------------------------------------------- -Demerat and Restaurant  -Front Cirle -Indigo Pool -Libbey Market  -Pixie Pool  -Spa  See below the 6x Conference Rooms: ---------------------------------------------------- -Anacapa -Hacienda  -Nordoff and Libbey Boardroom. -Demerat -Farmhouse -Topa Mountain Winery  Guest Experience: ------------------------ ***SSID: Ojai Guest will reach the portal page with the Clickthrough, no WPA network. ***SSID: Casa Elar will reach the portal page with Access Code: casaelar ***SSID: Ojai Meeting will reach the portal page with Access Code: hrtrain   Notes: ------------------------------------------------------- -They are using HP and Aruba switches for the IDFs and we installed 3x new Ruckus switches for new IDFs.  New IDFs:  -Camp-Oak-IDF -Artist-Cottage-IDF -HSK-IDF -The switches are in bad condition and the IDFs are very dusty.  -In some of the switches, the ports no longer work. column68: 02/11/2025 Bill Johnson helped the door lock vendor install the new system. The vendor needed a copper connection to the front desk from the server room, so Bill used a spare admin network jack. But he needed three copper connections to the front desk, which didn’t exist. He used Wi-Fi connection to the Front Desk computers because they didn’t have a copper connection and then used the one copper connection found, to connect to the card-making machine.  They replaced all the existing Salto door locks in the building with this new equipment. Anyway, the guy was able to rig his system so that the Front Desk computers would communicate to his server using Wi-Fi on the Staff SSID, and the one critical connection to the card-making machine would be the cooper line found for him.

column68: troubleshooting for the APs:  *************************************************************************************** There are 3 private networks created for premium sound systems in rooms 1051(VLAN 250),1052(VLAN 251) and 1151(VLAN252). Each network has it's own WLAN group in the vSZ that includes the default networks for the guest rooms.  The additional network is the name of the room and is hidden. For the listed rooms the WLAN group for those APs are manually applied to each access point.   APs per room listed below:  Room 1051: 5C:DF:89:1C:6E:80 -> AP-Room-1051-LR-ET  5C:DF:89:1C:EA:A0 -> AP-Room-1051-BR-ET  Room 1052: 5C:DF:89:1C:62:30 -> AP-Room-1052-BR-2ndFloor-ET 5C:DF:89:1C:D8:B0 -> AP-Room-1052-BR-1stFloor-ET 5C:DF:89:1C:F3:90 -> AP-Room-1052-LR-ET  Room 1151: 58:FB:96:39:A9:E0 -> AP-Room-1151-Hallway-ET 58:FB:96:39:D3:20 -> AP-Room-1151-LR-ET 5C:DF:89:1C:69:C0 -> AP-Room-1151-BR-ET  Please note: RSTP is configured on VLANs 250,251 and 252 on the 172.16.22.10, 172.16.22.19 and 172.16.22.20 switches.  This is due to the Sonos system creating an AD-Hoc network and advertising a root port. Currently the Core SW (172.16.22.10) is set as the root for all 3 VLANs with a priority of 4096.  David.G 08/16/2022 Reference FD ticket 31870    ***************************************************************************************  -Basement Aps: are visible Open Celling. -Cellar level: are visible and is drop Celling, and open celling -Spa Level: Hard celling, inside the Spa the Aps are hidden, always very closet when you open the access panel, the Aps outside the Spa are visible open celling.  -Ballroom level : Areas with drop celling the Aps are visible, and hard celling you need open the access panel to see the AP. in conference room if you go up with the lift you can see the Aps are visible  in the corners.(For better guide to find the Aps see the Diagram). - 4th floor: All the Aps are visible, drop celling there. -One of the Aps in Terrace are in the AV closet and the other are in the first access panel you see no too high.  -In room the Aps we have them behind the cabinet that is in front of the bed ( Room like 508 the Aps are in back of the small desk by the bed, in the Pen Houses please see the the Diagram to find the Aps but always look in the Bed room and where you see phones. -All the Aps in the rooms the cable are terminate with RJ45. -In the rooms we don't have Aps the phone are connect direct to our switches you can see the face place in the back of the cabinet. Phones Troubleshooting: Please if the phone don't work see if the phone have all this Configuration. Volume down to entry in the Phone configuration. Vlan-2  Priority voice-5  Priority Signaling-4 Voice DSCP-46 Signaling DSCP-42 (If you need more help for this please let me know and Yoexy, Raundy andJuan also know about this.)  For troubleshooting contact: -Chief engineer- Omar Phone: 469-773-3303. -IT Department- Cedric Phone: 682-300-6336.  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 12.37.36.90 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.22.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN3 is (1/2/4) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT 172.16.22.0/23 vlan 100" and change the IP address from 172.16.22.2/23 to 172.16.22.1/23 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: MGMT 172.16.22.0/23 vlan 100, Guest-WiFi 192.168.8.0/22 Vlan 200, Common-Areas 192.168.12.0/22 Vlan 201, Admin 192.168.16.0/22 Vlan 202, Meeting 192.168.208.0/22 Vlan 300, Phones VLAN 800 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.

column66: The APs are all powered from the MDF Core Switch (SW-MDF-Basement-01). There is an IDF in the 5th floor stairwell. There is a single uplink cable to the IDF. The IDF switches are only handling the room wired connections.        There are two Comcast Modems. One goes strictly to the Fusion. The other modem feeds a Ubiquity EdgeRouter and their Admin System. The EdgeRouter handles the KeyPr door locks and Tablets (there is one tablet in each room). The EdgeRouter shares the wifi network  with its own SSIDs on vlans 50 and 60.  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 14, which is connected to the Fusion LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. using the "Actions: button, edit the VLAN 100 and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "Mgmt-VLAN100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: Mgmt-VLAN100, Guest-WiFi-VLAN200, GuestRmWired-VLAN205, KEYPR-Kilt, KEYPR-Tablet.

column66: The system is a hybrid of several technologies. Main backbone is fiber optics. Guest Rooms are fed via VDSL 2+ (Zebra), public areas are Ethernet PoE Access points (Cisco) and RV Park is using Ubiquiti Point to Point (PtP) system.  Tower A VLAN 101 - 192.168.10.1/24  Tower B VLAN 102 - 192.168.12.1/24 RV Park VLAN 103 -  	192.168.14.1/24   WE DO NOT PROVIDE COVERAGE FOR PUBLIC AREAS AND CASINO (except pool).  That is still fed with old Cisco WAPs owned by the property and it plugs in into their switches/router. That would be phase 2 of the upgrade for this property.
column67: ISP modem is located in the electrical room(IDF-Tower-1) behind the front desk. There is 5 DSLAMS and a cisco switch at the IDF-Tower-1. There is 11 DSLAMS and a cisco switch at the IDF-Tower-2. Fusion, Mikrotik, Wattbox and the Core SW are in the MDF
column68: "Mikrotik has guest VLANs configured on ETH2 but that interface is disabled. Only enable that interface if Fusion doesn't work to move traffic through Mikrotik"   MDF-Tunica-CoreSW Gi1/0/18 - Wattbox MDF-Tunica-CoreSW Gi1/0/19 - Mikrotik-ETH2-LAN MDF-Tunica-CoreSW Gi1/0/20 - Mikrotik-WAN  MDF-Tunica-CoreSW Gi1/0/22 - Zone Director MDF-Tunica-CoreSW Gi1/0/23 - Fusion-WAN MDF-Tunica-CoreSW Gi1/0/24 - Fusion-LAN  Wattbox: Outlet 1 - Fusion Outlet 2 - Fusion Outlet 3 - MDF-Tunica-CoreSW Outlet 4 - Mikrotik Outlet 5 - Zone Director  *Wattbox is mounted in the wall behind the Fusion  ***RV PARK*** To restart WAPs/PtPs on the pole: There are plugged in at the base of the pole into an outdoor outlet. IT knows how to do it. There is an oval shaped access panel at the base of the poles that allows access to the PoE injectors. On the opposite side of the pole there is a light switch that turns the power on or off to the PoE injectors. The cord from the light switch is wire-nutted to the poE injector power cord. The last time there I found that the PoE injectors and lightning arresters had severe connector corrosion to the point that they had shorted and were no longer working. Cherry picker or scissor lift is needed to reach devices.  To restart WAPs/PtPs on the office building: It feeds from the IDF, can be accessed by the engineering or IT.  Tower 1 is the Tower A and Tower 2 is Tower B is some documents The ISP modem assigned to the Guest Wifi is located at the IDF in the Tower 1. Our modem is the one at the bottom of the wall. The handoff cable(yellow UTP patch cord) comes from port 1 at the modem to the port 23 in our Cisco Switch.  *** RV PARKING AREA *** The pole #1 is the most It is the furthest away, The pole #2 is the one in the middle, the last one is the #3 All the POEs and protections including connections are sealed against the extreme weather  Primary Contact Jim Simpson is no longer with the company. For any computer, printer or network related issues email HCTIT@pngaming.com or for immediate assistance contact 662.357.7715. You can also contact David Church at 662-671-2716 or Jack Robison at 228-216-7193.   Front Desk number - 6623577700

column66: This is an MM Fiber backbone 10G network with CAT5e to WAPs  ---July 21st 2025---  They added a new SW at Harbor View, like the sister property. column70: GCI -  www.gci.com/business GCI | BUSINESS TECHNICAL SUPPORT (BTS) – 24x7x365 =  (800) 800-7754 Acct #: 1001373886 Name: Grand Aleutioan/ Unisea Circuit ID: KQXX/218330 Previous Open Case: 450137 Other credentials: Phone: 907-581-3844 or Password: Salmon Fiber Static IPs:4 Available static public IP: 65.74.42.189 Subnet mask:   255.255.255.248 	Default gateway: 65.74.42.185  Starlink Contact Number: Open Ticket through site/app Acct #: ACC-1555513-77531-13 Satellite IP Addresses:  Starlink provides two IP policies, "default" and "public". The default IP configuration is Carrier Grade Network Address Translation (CGNAT) using private address space assigned to Starlink clients with DHCP from the 100.64.0.0/10 network.   Network Address Translation (NAT) translates between Starlink private and public IPs.   The Starlink public IP policy is an optional configuration available to Business and Maritime customers. A public IP is reachable from any device on the internet and is assigned to Starlink network clients using DHCP. Moving the Starlink to another location may cause the public IP to change. Starlink does not currently offer the ability for Residential or Roam customers to receive a public IP. The public IP option can be enabled from the account dashboard.  Each Starlink is allocated one IPv4 address and delegated a /56 IPv6 prefix for network clients.  All Starlink network clients are assigned an IPv6 address if the router is IPv6 is capable. IPv6 is not supported on the early generation router in the Circular Starlink Kit.  The default IP policy using CGNAT blocks all inbound ports.  Customers requiring inbound ports should consider products with a public IP option.  The following outbound ports are blocked for all customers per information security best practices: TCP/25 (SMTP) and TCP/445 (SMB).  As Starlink continues to expand and upgrade our global internet service infrastructure and rollout new capabilities, some users may see different IP address behavior (for example, publicly routable addresses, IPv6, non-CGNAT).  v. column68: Physical Install ------------------------- Going to each room, I had to take the TVs off the wall and redo a lot of the BTV installation. This is due to a few factors, but I noted that guests have unplugged BTV, and when plugged back in, the Chromecast was plugged into HDMI 2 as well as BTV into HDMI 1 for example. This is something to note as guests bring gaming consoles from time to time and mess up the installation.  Neatening up all the cabling and cable tying everything yielded good results, however, each room has a different powerpoint setup whereby some have 2x power outlets behind the TV, others have only 1.   Due to the BTV power supplies having lights on them, I have put 80% of them behind the TV, with 20% of them powered down by the desk. This was unavoidable, and we would recommend a power board be used behind the TV to plug both the TV and BTV in neatly behind the TV. A powerboard is preferred over getting an electrician to install a double powerpoint as the locations of the power points hit the back of the bracket leaving the TV protruding from the wall.   IR Blasters ------------------------- Working with Raf and Juan, we noted issues with the IR Blasters not working correctly due to poor wifi signal strength. I have placed each IR blaster on the top side of the TV, closest to the side where the nearest AP is. For example, some rooms may have the IR blaster on the top left, others on the top right. This yielded the least interference as placing the blaster down the base of the tv was causing too much interference and not working at all.   WiFi Signal Strength ------------------------- Conducting tests around the property, I noted the network was a 2.4ghz only network, using a cheaper style outdoor AP pointing back towards the rooms.   Firstly, testing indicated average RSSI values of -72dbm in most rooms, with download links of 6-8mbps at the best of times. The best signal strength I saw was -67dbm, and the worst -79dbm.   In the evening, in my room, with an RSSI of -69dbm, download speeds would range from between 2.4mbps, to 8.8mbps. Note this is with only 3 other rooms occupied at the time. The hotel was not busy.  Secondly, capacity will likely be a problem with these access points. With every room having a Chromecast, BTV STB, and IR blaster connecting to the network, I don't believe the current setup will hold up once you introduce client devices.   Whilst I don't know exactly how many AP's they have at the site, I know that there wasn't more than a couple visible.   My experience  ------------------------- In my experience of casting overnight, it worked great, however, the video quality did change frequently due to the wireless signal strength and wireless speeds. When there was no one else at the property, my remote was working, however would be slow at times. At best, it was 1 second, at worst, 40 seconds. I assume this kind of delay would make a customer press the button twice, thus creating a problem for the macros.   Moving forward ------------------------- Jacob will likely be expecting an update, however, due to all the issues we have previously had, I'd like to include you guys in what happens next rather than me sending an email with my findings. You're more than welcome to quote everything I have said, but I think it's best we book in a call tomorrow between LP Australia, and you guys to discuss how to update the client.   *************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************  PMS ------------------------- Our PMS interface is a local instance of PMS Proxy running on the Caching Server (lincolndowns.hotelwifi.com:50007) at the property. Hibox connects to this local PMS Proxy through a port forward on the Admin router (56700 to 56700) and then another port forward on the Fusion (56700 to 6700). Hibox is configured to hit lincolndowns.hotelwifi.com, so as long as that DNS record is updated in the event of a public IP change, the interface should survive.  On prem, the Caching Server is hitting the Protel PMS Connector at 192.168.20.150 on port 5006. The path from the Caching Server to the PMS is simply via the Caching Server's default gateway (the Fusion) to the Fusion's default gateway (admin router) to the PMS interface.  To check the status of the local PMS Proxy, log into the Caching Server and run:  supervisorctl status all  Or to check logs, run:  tail -f /var/log/pms_proxy/pms_proxy.log

column68: ***IN EVENT OF OUTAGE*** Best point of contact is LHO.PT@loewshotels.com for the email address and for the phone number you can call Rodell or Hector Rodell 321 303 8635 Hector 321 231 2478  Public IPs in use for Bright sign and Processor Ascend Studios - 74.121.216.65 and 74.121.216.66 respectively. Detailed notes in CRM notes dated 06/18/2020. - Durga  There are 2 gateways and 2 ZDs at this property.  The ZDs are redundant. In the case of failure of one of the units, the other will take over in a matter of minutes. The SSIDs will be broadcasting, but there would be no connectivity to the Gateway during the switch (tested at one of the properties). No intervention is necessary, just wait.  Fusions on the other hand are not redundant. The main Fusion is the Brain of the operation. It backs up to 2 locations: daily to the backup Fusion (there is a special VLAN for it) and Weekly to ftp.hotelwifi.com.  In the event of the failure of the main Fusion, the secondary Fusion can be accessed through WAN. It will NOT take over automatically. It is a MANUAL PROCESS. The Backup Fusion would have to be loaded with the latest backup from the main Fusion.   Both Fusion's interfaces are the mirror copies of each other in terms of networking on the switches. Once the Backup Fusion is up and running, it will work exactly as the main one.  **where help is needed please email lho.pt@loewshotels.com which is our team email. This will ensure someone from the team can respond as quickly as possible.  **If HIS needs some to assist with PMS side of the interface for any hotel you can contact the Loews help desk as they have remote access the number is 877-748-1469**

column66: East Village Students' Apartments:  Our Mikrotik Gateway is accessible using one Public IP, provided by their IT company, then we created a separate network only for the NVRs and Cameras. The Mikrotik is the DHCP server for the NVRs and Cameras. Our SWs are accessible via SSH from Mikrotik. NVRs are accessible via http from Mikritik (Port-Forward)  We installed:  1x Mikrotik Gateway 121x Indoor/Outdoor 4MP Dome 3x Indoor/Outdoor 4MP Mini Dome --- Inside the Elevators 2x LPR-License Plate Recognition 22x Hikvision 23x LTS  - We installed new cables for all of the new cameras.  - We set up EMT conduits in designated areas, including the garage and outdoor spaces around the building.  - We installed two License Plate Recognition (LPR) systems, allowing the property to capture all license plates as vehicles enter or exit the garage.  - We have taken over the Hikvision and LTS cameras, enabling us to view these cameras through our NVR system. - We also take over some P2P from the property, so we can see a total of 15x cameras over P2P. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- The three Indoor/Outdoor 4MP mini dome cameras were installed inside the elevator.  We used a perle technology to bring them online: IDF-SW(PoE+) + Cat6 patch Cable + Sender on IDF + New COAX + COAX on Elev Juntion Box  + Receiver on Elev Side + Cat6 + Camera. All the necessary power comes from the Brocade SW at IDF.

column66: The system is Ruckus PoE system. WAPs are located in rooms behind the desks (most common place is behind the fridge in the rooms).  The ISP feed comes in in the MDF (Boiler Room, Basement Floor). There we have our Fusion installed along with ZD and the Core Switch. We are feeding WAPs  for the 1 half of the Basement level.  From MDF there are 3 uplinks.   1st uplink goes to the switch in the ceiling of the Basement floor (near room 35). From there all the rooms feed via cat5.  2nd uplink goes to the Laundry room (1st floor). It is placed inside what was supposed to be a guest room 136. From here we are feeding WAPs inside the rooms of the 1st floor and 2nd half of the 2nd floor.   3rd uplink goes to the Accounting Office (2nd floor). It is placed inside what was supposed to be a guest room 200. From this IDF we are feeding WAPs for the 1st half of the 2nd floors, partly 1st and basement floor as well.
column67: MDF (Boiler Room at basement or 0 floor): Fusion, ZD, Modem, WPS Core PoE Switch for that floor WAPs, Meeting Rooms for the 1st floor (Glens and Woodland) and lobby WAP  IDF (Laundry Room) 2nd floor: PoE Switch for that floor WAPs and half of the halway (above room 29) of the floor above.  IDF (Accounting Office) 3rd floor: PoE Switch for WAPs of the 2nd floor from room 00 to 28

column66: New Info: We make a update in the entire property, we installed a new core switch and we install a new IDF-4. Now in the entire property we have Unifi APs model : UAP-AC-M-PRO-US all this APs are outdoor. We install a P2P to put online IDF-4 thought the IDF-1. We have two news Unifi Switches, one of them in IDF-1 and the other are in IDF-4. Switches by IDFs:  MDF: Ruckus switch (ICX-7150-24P) IDF-1: Unifi switch (US-48-500W)  IDF-2: Ruckus switch (ICX-7150-12P) IDF-3: Ruckus switch (ICX-7150-12P) IDF-4: Unifi switch (US-48-500W)  -------------------------------------------------------------------- Old Info : This is a multi-houses property with a difficult Cellular signal, They relay on WiFi for calling services.   ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We install a Fusion upon client request in order to block P2P connections with our portal Page... they have a history on Streaming and Downloading illegals' content.  We ended installing a New Brocade ICX-7150-12P as a CoreSW in main Bldg. and 2xSW-HP-8P on two of the houses. Also a couple Ruckus APs. The rest of the APs are different Unifi models.  All the APs were and are configured as standalone, so separate networks, separate SSIDs.  Credit Card Machines, ATM, FrontDesk PCs are all white listed on Fusion to avoid Splash page.  With the Portal Page Solution for P2P connections we created a problem with the WiFi devices login process across the property with so many separate Networks.... Temporary solutions is described on Troubleshooting Notes.

The Credit Card Machine and ATM on the Bar are hardwire to an Apple device: Apple Device is on port 1 SW-IDF3-Restaurant-1-01.... Both devices are whitelisted   From Field Installer: Bill Johnson... """What happens here is that every time the iPhone moves to a new SSID, it changes its MAC and the Fusion thinks it's a different device and requires the person to go through the portal page again. However, it doesn't end there. If the guest already connected to that antenna, it's saved the password and so the iPhone will just sit there and appear to be connected but won't bring up the portal page, even though the Fusion’s waiting for the portal page to be checked.      There is a temp solution until the Owner upgrades and that is to have the guest forget the network every time he connects to a different SSID, which means a different antenna. It doesn't look like Androids have this issue so it's maybe 50% of the guest will have to forget their network and click through the portal page constantly when moving around the property.       Again, putting in a new network with only one SSID is the solution and I'll get the proposal to Jack ASAP""""

column66: This is a large network with over 250 WAPs installed. There are vLANs setup on the network to manage traffic. The Fusion in the basement is connected to a switch that has a fiber uplink to the 3rd floor. From the 3rd floor there are home run fiber uplinks to all switches on higher floors. There is a POE connection from IDF switches to in room WAPs. The existing switches were reconfigured for the new network.  Guest room access requires billing to room. Lobby access is a click through. Meeting rooms require an access code. Meeting room setups are handled by a 3rd party company called PSAV. They have an office in the basement.

column67: Guest cast server is located in the MDF 3rd floor in the executive office. Guest cast devices are connected on the back of the LG hospitality TV on HDMI 2, the usb cable from the device is connected to the usb port on the tv.  TV service is provided by coax by Dish satellite Headend, the head end is located underneath the MDF on the 1st floor. TV remotes are the Guestcast remotes with Menu, Guide buttons.  Their is no interactive Guide, the only guide is located on Channel 50.
column68: Guest cast server is located in the MDF 3rd floor in the executive office.  Guestcast server gets its public IP from the Meraki Core SW ports 19 for Wan 1 and port 21 for IPMI.  lan1 and 2 are connected to the DBCWIFI-CoreSW on ports 33 (Lan1) port 34 Lan2.  Guest Wifi is on Vlan 1000, Lan2 is configured with Vlan 500.  btvcasting was created and untagged, Vlan 1000 is the Guest wifi  vlan for the hotel and that was untagged as well.  Please note that the brocade ICX 7150 48P switch for Lan 1 and 2 are using firmware 8030 and the ports are configured in dual mode.   The is the issue that was found at the property pertaining the Dish headend: I found the issue with the TV at the Edgewater and the Inn, the dish headend here at both hotels have a controller that holds all the tv information. This controller puts all the TV’s in MPI-FTG mode and this is what is causing all our issues. For us to use a direct button input the TV needs to be in CPU-FTG mode which means the TV will need to have a file (FMA/TLX) that the channel lineup would be installed and then the TV will be able to control these features like HDMI inputs. The way it is now the Dish headend controls those features, so if we cannot by pass this controller the Guest cast remotes will not work correctly. I have tested this theory and I am correct. so what I did was remove the coax from the TV and then did a factory reset on the TV. Once done I looked at the Mode of the FTG and it was changed to CPU-FTG, at that point I was able to use a new guest cast remote and change the input for casting and for live tv. everything worked like it was supposed to. Here is the kicker, when I reconnected the coax cable to the TV and turned it back on the TV the controller at the dish headend reinstalled the file of the TV back to what it was before. Now the Guest cast remote no longer works like it was supposed to do. So the only way we can change the input is to program the casting and live tv button to open the input menu and the  guest will need to select the input they want to use, so the issue is not with the remotes it has to do with Dish network controller.

column66: This property was just Upgraded (8/4/2023)  ---------------------------------------------------------- This property comprises 30 buildings, 28 of which are guest apartment buildings, one is the maintenance building, and one is the clubhouse. Most of the guest apartment buildings are two-story buildings, except for 4, which have 3-story. The rooms feature drywall walls and wooden flooring. The network has a 10 Gbps fiber backbone with a homerun to each building. Each building has an Intermediate Distribution Frame (IDF), and from each IDF, a Cat 6 cable runs to each apartment on the top floor. In the case of the 3-story buildings, there is also a cable to each apartment on the first floor.  NOTE: DSLAMs are installed but not in service, they are disconnected from the power. They will be collected by Lodean during the Low occupancy season (November) as well as the old CPEs and APs in Guestrooms.
column67: +MDF:  The MDF is located on the phone room, in the basement of the Clubhouse Building. Equipment List: - Fusion  -EdgeRouter - CoreSW   -2 Smart UPSs  + IDFs Location I- DF 1 to IDF 28 are located inside the water heater closet: IDF1-> Unit 4B IDF2-> Unit 6A IDF3-> Unit 10A IDF4-> Unit 20B IDF5-> Unit 22A IDF6-> Unit 30B IDF7-> Unit 36A IDF8-> Unit 40B IDF9-> Unit 44A IDF10-> Unit 50B IDF11-> Unit 54A IDF12-> Unit 58A IDF13-> Unit 64A IDF14-> Unit 68A IDF15-> Unit 74A IDF16-> Unit 80B IDF17-> Unit 84A IDF18-> Unit 92B IDF19-> Unit 96A IDF20-> Unit 98A IDF21-> Unit 103A IDF22-> Unit 112B IDF23-> Unit 115A IDF24-> Unit 124B IDF25-> Unit 130B IDF26-> Unit 174A IDF27-> Unit 180B IDF28-> Unit 294A IDF 29 is located inside the office in the maintenance building  +APs Location The APs on the guest units are installed above the doorbell in front of the kitchen. The APs installed on the 1st floor of buildings from 21 to 24 are located inside the water heater closet. Some APs in the Clubhouse building are hidden over the drop ceiling tiles.
column68: +EdgeRouter- Backup: MDF- Club House Connected to CoreSW (WAN to port-1/1/14. LAN1 to Port-1/1/15 and LAN2 to Port-1/1/18.)  +Smart UPSs  -  MDF- Club House Connected to CoreSW port 1/1/7 and port 1/1/12 The Fusion is connected to outlet 1 in UPS-MDF-B-01 Each of the 3 CoreSW in a stack has 2 power supplies. in each switch, a power supply is connected to UPS-MDF-B-01 and the other one is connected to UPS-MDF-B-01.  + The CoreSw is a stack setup consisting of two ICX 7550-24F switches and one ICX 7550-24P switch.  ===================== Call MDF 757 903-2000 ext. 3000 if troubleshooting with people in MDF.  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.67.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/3/3, which is connected to the Fusion LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "MGMT-VLAN100" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.67.254/24 to 172.16.67.1/24 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT-Vlan100" using the "Actions" button.

column66: This is WiFi only property. A main building with Tower North and Tower South. We installed Fusion, Mikrotik spare Gateway, APs, UPSs. We do not run cables for guestrooms.  We run a few cables for uplink IDFs and bring online some common areas APs. We were provided only 2 Public IP addresses, they were assigned to: ***Fusion  ***IPMI We decided to setup the Fusion and the Mikrotik with the same IP. Mikrotik was left OFF.
column67: MDF on Fist Floor Server room: Fusion, CoreSW, Mikrotik, UPS. Every IDF has a SW and a UPS. The property has 10 IDFs all spread in both Towers, one per floor feeding the corresponding AP per floor. The APs on common areas are inside the ceiling except for Pool-Bar and Beach APs. See network Diagram for details. The APs on guestrooms are located in different spots depending on the Room type. The most common location is behind the drawer, the drawer has to be pulled out in order to troubleshoot one of them.
column68: Notice that the ISP is not located at the MDF, it's where IDF-Meting Room is, 1st Floor. We take the ISP feed from a Aruba Admin SW. See equipment list for details.  ------------------------------------------------------------------------- IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Please disconnect Fusion-WAN2 from port 1/2/1 on CoreSW 2. Turn ON the Mikrotik. It's unplugged from UPS.  3. Once the Mikrotik is fully ON. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 50.202.63.38 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 4. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.70.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 5. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN2 (port 1/2/2) to make sure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 6. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab (VLAN200). 7. Enable the interface ETH2/LAN under the Interfaces menu under the Interface tab. 8. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "ETH2/LAN" and change the IP address from 172.16.70.254/24 to 172.16.70.1/24 9. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Guest-WiFi-VALN200, WiFi-MGMT-VLAN100

column66: The APs are mainly located in the rooms mounted behind the desks in the rooms. There are 33 H500 Dual band APs used in the rooms. The Lobby and restaurant have 3 R500 APs. The actual Lobby AP is mounted under the desk of the Business Center PC #1.      The Fusion gets its ISP feed from a WAN switch. There is a Core Switch in the MDF.  IDF Switch that is in the Maids Closet 5th floor powers all the APs in the rooms. There are two Hard Wire switches, one in the MDF and one on the 5th floor maids station. Both are accessible and connect to rooms other than where the APs are and for the meeting rooms in the lobby provide cabled connection. Also connected to the Business center PC and Printer.

There is an HP 2530 48port POE switch that powers the rooms and that is in the 5th floor maids station (IP:10.61.32.5). column67: MDF - located on computer room on Mezz offices access upstairs form back door only Equipment: Fusion, ZD, Core Switch, and Watt Box all connected to our UPS in closet next to MDF is ISP router. Basement IDF in lower right hand cabinet of Fitness room - 12 Port PoE SW-IDF-B-01 Old Tower 3rd floor IDF - in maintenance shop SW-IDF-3-01 Old Tower 6th floor IDF - in back closet through Housekeeping closet SW-IDF-6-01 New Tower 4th floor IDF electrical closet by stairwell near 418 SW-IDF-4-01  New Tower 8th floor IDF -electrical closet by stairwell near 818 SW-IDF-8-01  h320 in guest room over single gang box only orange and green pairs used.  MDF is located on the mezzanine level next to sales offices. The computer and phone rooms are next to one another. The Computer room [MDF] is the room on left and ISP equipment in the room on the right.  The Watt Box is plugged into our UPS and ZD Fusion and Core Switch are plugged into the WattBox. The ISP feed is untagged on core switch on VLAN 900 as are WAN 1 WAN2 IPMI and WattBox. The ISP feed is on fiber and our ethernet feed is labeled on both ends a blue CAT5e cable. There are 3 IDFs in the Old Tower on Cat5e, they are patched on panel at top of the Rack in the MDF and are labeled [see photos]. Basement IDF: SW-IDF-B-01, 12 port PoE is fed on Core Switch as labeled the switch is in the lower right cabinet in the Fitness center and is on a UPS, This SW only feeds a WAP for Fitness Center (attached to a wall). MDF SW: SW-Core-2-01, 24 port PoE feeds The Meeting space WAP (on the ceiling) as well as WAPs 1 and 2 for Lobby, also feeds WAP in Hall 7th floor Old Bldg. 3rd floor IDF SW-IDF-3-01, 24 port Brocade PoE located in the Engineering Office through the housekeeping closet The switch is wall mounted with a UPS WAPs for 2nd, 3rd, and 4th floor old tower are on this switch the are on only 2 pair PoE type A 100Mbps. 6th floor IDF SW-IDF-8-01, HP 24 port PoE switch on the wall of the storage closet through the Housekeeping closet. The switch is wall mounted with a UPS. WAPs for 5th, 6th, and 7th floor Old Bldg are on this switch the are on only 2 pair PoE type A 100Mbps. There is one WAP (R510) in the 7th hallway ceiling for coverage for upstairs rooms 604 and 605.The WAP is on CAT5e from Core switch at 1GBps.   The new tower has 2 IDFs on 4th and 8th floors. The original plans for the Hotel called for 5 WAPs per floor in the hallways so only one CAT5e per room was deployed. We installed one r510 near elevator lobby ceiling on 2nd, 4th, 6th and 8th floors. There are 12 strains of fiber from MDF to Mechanical room on ground level on new tower.  There are 6 strains that loop through the 2nd floor to the 4th, then from 4th through 6th to 8th floor. The strains are color mapped on the Network Drawing page. The 4th floor IDF SW-IDF-4-01, 24 port Brocade Poe int is in the electrical closet next to room 318 by stairs, Switch is wall mounted behind the door on UPS. WAPs on floors 2, 3 4, and 5 are fed on 2 pair PoE type A 100 Mbps except the r520s in the hall ceiling of 2 and 4 they are on CAT5e at 1GBps. The 8th floor IDF SW-IDF-8-01, brocade 48 port PoE mounted on wall behind the door of closet next to 818 stacked above 4th. WAP on 6 to 9 are on this switch  There are 6 WAPs on 9th and on each 8th and 6th at 1GBps cat5e feeds all other are h320 in rooms on 2 pair PoE type A 100Mbps.
column68: Hotel has LG TVs in the North Tower room 01 to 08. They need RC-11 remotes. These TVs are on furniture. All of these TVs now have MPI cables and have been factory reset with power saving set to 001. There are 2 newer TVs in rooms 604 and 605 respectively that are mounted on the wall so, they must be removed for troubleshooting. However they too have been factory reset and power savings set to 001. To check this setting you must first unplug the MPI cable either from the TV or the STB [USB}. Then using the LG remote, press the menu button rapidly until the menu does not paint on the screen, then enter 9-8-7-6 then enter [or select]. You will see the installer menus in white letting. Arrow down to 118 Power Savings   it should be 001  if not enter 0-0-1 then arrow up or down and press select. Plug in the MPI cable and Power cycle the TV and set-top-box. You should be able to turn the TV on and off with the BTV remote RC-11  The TV s in the new South Tower (09 to 18 rooms) are Samsung TVs and have MPI cables with RC-11 remotes. Flash files were left with Engineering on BTV 2GB thumb drive. The TVs are all wall mounted and require 2 people to remove them. Troubleshooting should be able to be performed however without removing the TVs, with exception of the xx18 rooms.  ******************************Chromecasts at this property are connected to STBs. How to verify:******************************************* adb into the set-top box adb shell cat /system/build.prop Look for beyondtv.mpi.chromecasthdmi=hdmi2 command, if this command doesn't exist that means the chromecast is connected to STB. ************************************************   **** For New STBs - LG ONLY **** This property is using STBs as a brain for the TVs. We are controlling the LG TVs via the MPI cables.  If you get an STB online that hasn't been properly provisioned, you need to do the following until we release a new firmware that has all the options built it: 1. Assign the STB a static lease  If you are swapping a STB in a room, make sure to replace that box 2. Ensure the box is running an Elliot Park firmware (use BTV Admin) This is an automatic process and as long as the box is connected to the correct network, it will eventually upgrade. Usually 5-10 minute process. If it is not upgrading (you can use adb_logcal to see that), then reboot it. 3. from the Nagios server, "adb_connect xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx" to the box, where xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx the IP of the box 4. Run the following command "adb_mpi_install" ***************************  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/1/24, which is connected to the Fusion LAN1 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "MGMT-VLAN100" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.7/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT-VLAN-100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - To access the Wattbox, use the link: http://71.78.225.204:60006/ - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: MGMT 100, GuestWiFi 200, Alexa_Devices 801, BTV-Chromecast-Post-Auth 410, Common_Areas 201, Guest-VIP-Wired 203, LONNIES_AMBASSADOR_Club_network 202, Meetings 300, Property-Wide 1101, Property-Wide 1102, Staging 999

column66: Array Computer Solutions is the company that handles the IT for this property (updated 1/17/14)  Two WANs feed the Fusion. Fusion to 24-port Cisco 2960 core switch. Core switch feeds an IDF switch on each guest room floor from 2 - 7. Guest room APs fed off each IDF switch via Cat6. There are four APs on the first floor fed by the Cisco core. column66: This property is managed by the Hargray Communications group. All APs have a Layer 2 connection to the controller. The Traffic is tunneled through the controller to their data center, and the devices get internet through what they call "Cisco Core Router" We do not have access to that router, and escalation to this group will be needed in case of any issues related to it. The Aruba controller is also the DHCP server for all devices.  Elite Resort Group ERG POC 1: Sylvie Moore | smoore@erghhi.com Phone: 617-784-3626 ERG POC 2: Andy Fere Phone: 843-422-5790
column67: ***NOTE: Password would change every 3 months depending on the season***  Escalation Policy for NOC for Hargray Properties:  Property list:  - Coral Reef - Coral Sands - Island Links - Palmera Inn & Suites - Port O Call  These locations are all located at Hilton Head Island in South Carolina. They are all managed by a single Aruba Central controller.    ------------------------------------------------------------------ Common Cases Troubleshooting Notes:  ------------------------------------------------------------------ In the following cases, an escalation should be opened with Hargray:  1- A guest issue is unable to be resolved due to down equipment 2- Multiple access points down  Steps:   1 - NOC agents should create a freshdesk ticket and call Hargray TCC at the following number:- Hargray TCC: 843-686-1138,  2- In the case of no response: report of “Down APs” is emailed to hargray_repair@htc.hargray.com; hargray-wi-fiengineering@cableone.biz ; hargray-salesengineering@cableone.biz; smoore@erghhi.com; afera@erghhi.com   ------------------------------------------------------------------ Network Outage Cases Troubleshooting Notes:  ------------------------------------------------------------------ In the case of an outage with the Aruba Central controller, NOC agents should create a freshdesk ticket and escalate to Hargray NOC:  1- Hargray NOC: 843-686-1158  2- In the case of no response from Hargray TCC or Hargray NOC the following escalation list can be called: 	- Hargray Field Supervisor: Dwain Wright 843-422-1434 	- Hargray Sales Engineer Manager: John Gallagher 843-684-0171  For both scenarios:   NOC agents should provide a ticket number for the issue (freshdesk ticket) and explain the purpose of the escaltion.  Please note:  - We can only monitor the access points at these locations, so don't have access to their switches or routers. - At no time should agents identify to end customers as "Hotel Internet Services". We are operating as "Hargray communications". Tier 1 agents have a specific speil for guest calls, but NOC agents should identify as "Hargray communication NOC" or just "Network Operations" when dealing with guests at these properties.  Aruba Mobility Controller: https://67.20.141.134:4343  User: HIS PW: His2023!
