column66: ***************New Information******************  The property is a single building, with a basement, a lobby level, and four guest floors. All the APs are in Unleashed mode and are PoE.  The cabling is Cat6, and they are homerun to the MDF (basement) through PVC pipes. The MDF is located in the Basement inside the Storage Room.   **************** Old information**************** This is a Zebra VDSL solution. APs are in the rooms and get signal over phone lines from the phone blocks in the basement.     The Fusion, DSLAM, and Wattbox is connected to the HP 12port core switch. The Zebra DSLAM connects to the phone blocks next to the MDF.
column67: ***************New Information****************** **MDF** ISP Modem, Fusion, Core Switch, MIKROTIK are in the basement, Storage Room The APs are in Unleashed mode; the master AP is located in the Brake Room. Name: AP-Brake-Room, the secondary AP is in the Laundry Area. Name: AP-Laundry. In the rooms there are R320. The TW-522 APs are located in these rooms: 11 14 16 17 22 25 29 31 34 36 37 42 45 49 Lobby (Is in the basement on the ceiling of the the laundry room under the lobby)
column68: ***************New Information****************** In the property, they are not using the telephones, there is only a CELL PHONE in Front desk where customers contact.  ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 50.189.105.67 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/2/2) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.0.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200, 201 and 202 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************  **************** Old information**************** The phones for the rooms at the front of the hotel have their cables going outside and around the building. These cables are degraded from the weather and in recent weeks, with all the rain here, three of those lines went dead in rooms 11, 31 and 42. The TW-511s in these rooms were moved to rooms 21, 41 and 32 (42 went 32). However, I noted after the last rain a few days ago that the TW-511 I moved to 41 went down. The other two are still functioning.

column32: Park Central and West House New York
column66: ****This property shares the building with another hotel (Westhouse NYC). Park Central is Level B3 to 18.**** Each property has its own Fusion, both Fusions are in the same Room (Server Room) on the Mezzanine Level. Both Properties share the same CoreSW 2x ICX-7450-4P stacked. Both Properties are on HIS vSZ-H-1 but working separately on different Domains.  Convention APs are fed by MDF Switch. Basement APs are fed by Basement IDF on B3. For the most part, APs on Floors 3 - 8 get fed by IDFs on 7th/8th Floors For the most part, APs on Floors 9 - 18 get fed by IDFs on 10th/11th Floors There are APs on floors that have long runs example from the 3rd floor to the 11th  All APs are labeled on the ports.
column67: The MDF is located in the Mezzanine level MDF near Employee Cafeteria. It contains: Fusion - Park Central Core Switch stacked IXC-7450 Mikrotik Wattbox - 12  APs are located in rooms, stairwells, and basement levels of the property. They are of mixed models: Guest Rooms H550, R550, and R750  Basement 3B APs are R550, 2B R550, 1B 1 R750 and other R550  The Basement IDF is located on the B3 level. It has two switches mounted in the rack that is located in the Guest Response Office/IT office.  There are 7 IDFs located in the Service Elevator rooms on floors B3, Mezz, 6, 7, 8, 10, and 11. Mez in OLD PBX room near Executive Office 1 IXC-8200-24P OLD Fusion and ZD 6th-floor Elevator Landing Fiber patch panel for 12-strand Fiber 7th-floor Elevator Landing 3 ICX-8200-48P 8th-floor Elevator Landing 1 ICX-8200-24P 1 IXC-8200-48P 10th-floor Elevator Landing 3 ICX-8200-48P 11th-floor Elevator Landing 1 ICX-8200-24_p 2 ICX-8200-48P
column68: IF FUSION FAIL MOVE THE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Login into the Mikrotik via WinBox. WAN/Eth1 is connected to the Core-SW 2. From the Mikrotik do ssh into Core SW,  Select New Terminal from Menu, then type: system. Then ssh 172.16.72.10 ( user=admin ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& ) 3. Once on the CoreSW , disable the SW port where the Fusion LAN1 (port 1/2/2) to make sure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab (VLAN 11, 14 15, 19, 224, 260, 300, 301, 500, 800, 1100, 1200, 3000). 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "ETH2/LAN" and change the IP address from 172.16.72.254/24 to 172.16.72.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  For PMS issues contact Centrada and have them check the HTNG interface in the HotSOS server. The HTNG interface can be restarted by using .bat files on the desktop or in c:\htng. Opera Ticket on Old PMS Issue: 3-18290724071  PMS Troubleshooting Steps: 1) Run .bat file on HotSOS server 2) Reboot HotSOS server 3) Run .bat file on HotSOS server again  4) Have Centrada contact Opera

column38: This is how Guestcast server is connected to the different devices in the MDF: •	WAN1: connected to port 4 on a Netgear dummy Switch. •	IPMI: connected to port 3 on a Netgear dummy Switch. •	LAN 1: connected to port 8 on a Fortinet. •	LAN 2 connected to ETH 5 on a Radius Gateway 651h.  -This is a 7 stories building, it has also a basement level and a mezzanine level. The Basement, 1st and Mezzanine level has 2 rooms each one, from 2nd to 6th floor there are 6 rooms each one and the 7th floor has 3 rooms. -All the TVs are wall-mounted, and they have a spectrum set-top box attached at the back of the TV. -The coax line is going to the set-top box, then an HDMI cable is going from the set-top box to the TV HDMI 1. -The Chromecast is connected to the HDMI 2, and the USB is connected to the TV USB port on the TV.

column68: Notice that not all the phone lines are homerun to MDF. They have a cross-connection on 2nd Floor Storage by Room-226 for Rooms: 226-239 *****************************************************************************************************  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/1/15, which is connected to the Fusion LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "MGMT VLAN100" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT_Vlan_100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - To access the Unleashed Controller 1, use the link: http://98.152.65.53:60002/ - To access the Unleashed Controller 2, use the link: http://98.152.65.53:60003/ - To access the DSLAM 1, use the link: http://98.152.65.53:50001/ - To access the DSLAM 2, use the link: http://98.152.65.53:50002/ - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: MGMT 100, GuestWiFi 200, Staff 202

column66: This is a simple setup, we have a E-Fusion, a brocade ICX 7150 24P as the core sw.  We have an IC NVR with 17 security Dome cameras, all the cameras are attached via Ethernet to the patch panel in the MDF.  We are using H320 in the Guest rooms to provide Guest wireless, the AP's are located either by the desk or the night stand near the bed.  LG TV's are mounted on a low profile mount or a Swivel mount, TV service is provided in each guest rooms via coax.  Chrome cast is installed on HDMI 2 and powered via the USB port of the TV.  The remote that we will be using to control the TV is the Guest cast remote for LG TV mode.  All phones for the property run back to the MDF and are punch down.

column30: All the guest rooms have LG hospitality TV's currently the TV are controlled by Cox, they have there own STB in guest rooms and the TV channels are controlled by the STB. column66: This is a 3 story hotel recently built next to a casino. Each room has a wired connection. POE fed APs are mounted in the Guest rooms There is an AP in the lobby. MDF: 1st floor of hotel, center of building. Back room behind landry room. Fusion, Core switch, webpower switch & ISP feed. Equipment is rack mounted. We have upgraded the hotel Wifi with a Unleashed system.  The master controller is the AP-BoardRm IP address 172.16.0.2, the Guest room AP's are H320 unleashed.  The AP's are located under the Desk in the guest rooms.  The old Hallway AP's have been turned off but as per IT we have left them in the drop ceiling.  In the MDF those old AP's are connected to a 24 port patch panel to be used at some other date if needed.  Please see equipment list for AP location and what port they are connected to on the core SW.   The R550 AP-Boardroom is mounted on the right hand side of the wall, this is also the Wireless AP controller.  The other R550 AP-lobby is located in the middle of the lobby, to access this AP you will need a Boom lift that the hotel has.        Client offering 512kpbs download to guests free of charge with upsell option (bill to room) for higher speed. PMS system is opera.      3 x dell 48 port switches were added into the network to handle wired room connections. These are vlan'd. Hotel purchased equipment but they put the mgmt ip address in the equipment lan of the guest network.

column65: Sea Crest Surf and Racquet Club
column66: We have taken over the hotel's Guest wireless network and deployed Cambium XV2-22H throughout the hotel's five floors. The MDF is located in the electrical closet on the first floor. The hotel offers three Wi-Fi networks: Sea Crest Wi-Fi, Seacrest OTT, and Sparklight_HSO.   The Guest SSID utilizes our Splash Page for authentication, requiring an access code of 12344321.  They have a Single SM FC/LC for the MDF and the IDF, they have a Single SM SC(APC) to LC (UPC)
column67: Core SW (CoreSW-MDF1-1) is located in the MDF.  The other two 48-port switches (SW-MDF-1-1 and SW-MDF-1-2) are also located in the MDF.  The Microtik Backup GW is also connected to the MDF. The following equipment is also located in the MDF, specifically in the Wattbox, the Fusion, and the Eaton 3000VA UPS. We also have the Fiber patch panel, which is a Single SM FC/LC. In the Admin office, we have the 12-port Brocade SW (SW-IDF-1-1). The following APs are connected to ports 1-2: the AP Lounge and the AP IDF. We also have a Tripplite 1500VA UPS.  The fiber patch panel from the IDF is a Single SM fiber with SC/LC connectors.
column68: MDF is located on the 1st floor, in the Electrical closet.  The UPS is on the side of the Rack due to the rack not being deep enough to support the Eaton 3000VA UPS and the Fusion.  The Patch panel is at the bottom of the rack because the Ethernet cables were not long enough, the LV team was testing, or replacing the Ethernet cables as needed.  The existing Ethernet cables are Cat 6 unshielded, and they are not in conduit.  The Cables are on the ground, and most are sitting in water. The cables that were replaced were damaged due to rodent activity, specifically chewing on them.  Please note that most issues with AP down are due to cabling problems.  The pathway of the Ethernet cables from the MDF to the Guest rooms is from the ground level of the 1st floor through the AC closet of the 1st guest room to the 5th floor.  For example, room 107 has a stackable AC closet, followed by 207, then 307, and so on, until you reach 507.  This is the only way to get Ethernet cables from the 1st floor to the 5th floor.  There are 3- 48-port switches in the MDF. The first switch controls the guest rooms 101 to 303.  The Second Switch controls the Guest rooms 305 to 424.  The third switch controls the guest rooms 501 to 524 and Pool 1 and 2.  We have an SC/LC fiber patch panel from the Admin Office - IDF that connects to a Fiber patch panel FC with an LC connector.  Please note that the fiber (SM) was distributed as a single connection fiber. To use any of the strands, you will need a Bidirectional SFP.  The ISP fiber switch is located in the MDF. The circuit is a 2G/2G SM fiber. Our uplink port on the fiber switch is port six, which is connected to Port 1/3/1 of the Core switch.  The 10 Gbps connections from the Fusion are connected to the core switch in ports 1/3/2 (Wan2) and port 1/3/3 (Lan2).  On the CoreSW port 1/3/4 is the 10G direct cable to SW-MDF-1-1, Port 1/3/1. On Sw-MDF-1-1 (port 1/3/2) to SW-MDF-1-2 (port1/3/1).  There are six patch panels. The 1st patch panel is for the Pool APs, the 2nd patch panel is for the guest rooms on the 1st floor (101-124), and the 3rd patch panel is for the 2nd floor (201-224).  3rd patch panel are for 3rd floor 301-324, the 4th patch panel are for the 4th floor 401-424, and the 5th patch panel is the 5th floor 501-524.   ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 170.205.131.92 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/3/3) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.0.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200, 800 and 801 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **********************************************************************************************

column66: This is a large campus installation (100+ APs) which uses a combination of Motorola VDSL & POE switches. The property is divided into 3 basic areas: Cottages (DSL), Apartments (POE), Memory Support (POE).  FROM THE MDF: IDFs (Apartments & Memory Suppor  A new building with 15 Ruckus H500s was added (QUAY400). The IDF for this building is on the ground floor electrical closet. There is a fiber uplink from there to the trash room on the 1st floor and from there another fiber uplink to the MDF.  APARTMENTS UPGRADE The apartment section of this property was upgraded by putting h500s into every apartments unit. They were generally placed into the living room space. Old ZF7341 equipment was removed from the hallways. Network cables to specific rooms that were previously cut were repaired. HP switches were put into every IDF on each floor.  Spanning-Tree Protocol and BPDU-Protection (Guard) have been configured on the switches. This has been done to prevent users from connecting an unmanaged Switch to one of the Switches ports or even the h500 AP's ports.  GLEBE Cottages get their Internet uplink from the Quay 400 Building IDF.  The uplink SW is a Brocade 7250 in L3 mode, we are using the 8 fiber ports to feed the GLEBE 558-565 Buildings which is using 50/125 OM3 2M LC to LC.  The uplink for the Brocade is coming from the Bishop_Quay400-SW (HP2530-24P) on Port 24 to port 24 on the brocade SW.  GLEBE buildings 558-565 are feed via fiber from Bishop-Quay-BLDG400-SW-2.  The fiber that they are using is 50/125/OM3 5M SC to LC which is located in the Garage next to the electrical Gang box.  The SW is located in a Low voltage cabinet.
column67: MDF - Located behind main reception area. Secure area. - devices: Fusion, ZD, Core Switch, DSLAMs, 1 AP.  IDFs - located in various locations around property. See site map/network drawing for details. - Apartments: There are 4 IDFs per floor. There are 3 floors. 1st Fl: Trash Room 1 (TR1), E101, E102, E108, E109 2nd Fl: TRB, E202, E203, E212, E213 3rd Fl: StorageRm SR302, SR303, E312, E313  APs  - Cottages: APs generally located directly above the attic access hatch.  - Apartments: H500 installed in each apartment. Generally in living room. - Arcadia Close: located in attic - Myers hall - drop ceiling & attics   Common Areas:  - Pub - located on shelf under cash register  - Winningham Dining - on shelf at waiter station between dining room and cafe kitchen.  - Cafe: mounted under table by desert cashier.  GLEBE Home - AP's are located in a Storage Room on the 1st floor next to the kitchen.  2nd AP is located in a Storage room on the 2nd floor next to the bathroom. Aruba 10 Port SW for GLEBE cottages are located in the Garge in a Low Voltage Cabinet next to the Gang Box.

column66: VLANs available for property-wide SSIDs that won't be modified by the conference tool: 1008 and 1009 - Walter 11/30/20  To get the Fusion going, here is what you need to do:  Plug in a computer into LAN3 of the Fusion. You will get 192.168.5.x IP address. That will take you to LAN3 of Cluster Controller.  Login into the Fusion https://192.168.5.1/admin Alternative way would be to get into WAN3 port. CC is on 69.36.84.151 / 255.255.255.240  Connect WAN1-WAN3 and LAN1-LAN3 to a switch Get the Fusion online  To configure iDRAC on-site: Connect iDRAC to a switch port so it can get DHCP from LAN3 Login into iDRAC Change public IP  To configure ESXI on-site: Connect monitor and keyboard to the server press F2, login Change IP data under Network Configuration   If we are doing it remotely: Connect iDRAC to a switch port so it can get DHCP from LAN3 Setup VPN to the property (configure on CC, download config from Node1)  VPN into Node1 Change iDRAC to be public IP. Change the VLAN on if the iDRAC Port to be WAN VLAN  Change IP address of the ESXi to be public IP. Change the VLAN on if the ESXi Port to be WAN VLAN
column68: ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 74.85.99.32 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 10.144.101.211 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Main-Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/1/42) is to ensure there is no traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT10.144.101.254/24-VLAN-101" and change the IP address from 10.144.101.254/24 to 144.101.201/24/x 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 101, 120, 800, 801, 813, 815, 835, 1000, 1001, 1004, 1005, 1006, 1007, 1016, 1025, 1101, 1109, 1111, 1113, 1115, 1135, 1138 - In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 in the browser.  ******************************************************************************* ******************** TROUBLESHOOTING NOTES ********************** *******************************************************************************  ***Offline WAPs*** ********************* As of 9/11/2025, 4 APs are offline; they weren't online when Ronnie finished the installation. - 40:B8:2D:31:40:80 ------ Elevator-PE-02 - 40:B8:2D:31:44:50 ------ Elevator-PE-03 - 40:B8:2D:31:A5:80 ------ Elevator-PE-07 - 4C:B1:CD:01:B4:00 ----- CONAP_06_BrushCreek  ***Guest Experience*** *************************** - The Lobby SSID is open, and the Portal Page is a Click-through with an email service question. - The Guest SSID is open, with a captive portal integrated to the PMS. Users must authenticate using their personal information in order to gain access to the network.  ***Core SW*** ***************** The Core switch was originally a stack of 2 × Ruckus ICX7650-48F. After a stack failure, one unit was replaced, but the stack was not rebuilt. Currently, each switch has different IPs (10.144.101.210 and 10.144.101.211).    ******************************************************************************* ******************************OLD NOTES********************************** ******************************************************************************* Guest Room APs for this property travel from the CoreSW at 10.144.101.210 across the 2nd LAG port (2/1/39 & 2/1/40) to a GPON network managed by QYPSYS/Corning. We do not have access to the devices on the other side of the link. If a large number of guest room APs go offline make sure to check that the LAG port is online.  -07/01/2022 David.G

On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "10.7.254.10/24-VLAN7" and change the IP address from 10.7.254.10/24 to 10.7.254.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 7, 8, 700, 800, 809, 810, 814, 826, 835, 1000, 1016  -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH13/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **********************************************************************************************

column66: They have a FortiGate firewall that handles the management traffic for AP's, switches, phones, & guest; and a Nomadix gateway that handles the Guest traffic for the Lobby SSID. The WAN and LAN interfaces of Nomadix and FortiGate are connected to the Core SW, we manage it. There are 56 APs connected to the 7 switches we have access. See the equipment list for details. All the APs are managed by Aruba Central.  This is a Takeover property. Firewall and Gateway is a Fortigate. SWs and AP management is over Aruba Central, they reside on Group/Side: "The Lodge-30A". SNMP port forwards were setup on the Fortigate. All the SWs are in Sync with Aruba Central, which means that all the changes can be done through Aruba Central. The only one with Radius Server Authentication ON is the CoreSW. In case they lose Sync they can be accessed via SSH through the Fortinet: Open CLI on WUI and do this command: execute ssh hisadmin@10.0.3.13x >>>execute ssh yourradiususer@10.0.3.13x  The local IT manager has his set of credentials Radius Credentials: stjoeit / $tJo3@dm1n3#

column68: ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 74.85.99.139 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 10.152.101.203" ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port where the Fusion-LAN1 (CCA port 1/1/5 and CCB 2/1/5) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT 10.152.101.254/24-VLAN-101" and change the IP address from 10.152.101.254/24 to 10.152.101.201/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 28, 44, 101, 120, 800-801, 806, 808, 812-815, 825-826, 835, 1000, 1008, 1016, 1025, and 1102 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************.  Our Fusion and core switch is fed from the Cisco 12 port switches after the Barracuda firewall  Both of the Fusions have a USB drive plugged in inside the case with pre-loaded 11.044 Fusion OS installer image. If you are going to re-install the OS, here is what you need to do:  1. Login into IPMI (admin/c0c01509hki!!) 2. Go to Remote Control - iKVM/HTML5 for remote screen 3. Reboot the Fusion to get into boot selection screen 4. Hit F11 to get to the boot options 5. Select Sandisk (NOT UEFI)  *********************************************************************************************************************** VLAN 1110 / Loews_Conf_10 is a reusable VLAN for custom Network configurations.  This is due to their version of the conference tool not being able to create Wireless networks that use WPA2. If the network is using the portal page with a shared credential please have them use the conference tool. Please do not modify any other conference networks.  - David.G  09/08/2022 ***********************************************************************************************************************

column66: The MDF rack is in the basement towards the street. The rack has a Fusion, a 24port PoE core switch, an EdgeRouer4 backup gateway, and the Unleashed Master AP (an R320). The floor APs are all cabled from two IDFs: one on the 2nd floor in the BC, and one on the 5th floor in the Maids Closet there. Two R510s are located on the hallway ceilings at the ends of the hallways.  Each floor also has two H320s inside the rooms on each floor. The H320 APs in the rooms are either mounted on the wall facing the bed or are just above the access panel in the bathroom, or are on the coat closet ceiling.      There are special door lock communication devices mounted in the hallways with cabling that comes back to our IDF and MDF switches and are on their own vlan 810. These devices communicate with the door locks and are made by a company called Salto. Of note is that there are noise sensors in the rooms to detect if a guest is getting to loud and these are connected on their own hidden SSID "Sense", to our wifi.   Updated: 2-5-16 by ZACH

column66: ***Property had full new upgrade April and added more in July 2019***  This is a blended system. A Fusion gateway, HP and Zyxel switches, Ruckus Unleashed AP's(5 R510s and 14 T310s) and a Motorola T-5 DSLAM's. There are 6 DSLAM's with modems in every room. (33 TW511 and 90 TW522 CPE's)
column67: MDF - Located in phone room in Building 2 in the 2nd Floor maids closet. ISP router, Fusion, core switch, DSLAMs are located here. (There are 2 more small rooms in the this maids closet)  Zone Director was removed: Ruckus WAPs are unleashed. Master Unleashed is AP-Fitness-Ctr (R510 172.16.0.176).  Motorola  TW511 and TW522 modems are located in every room listed on equipment list. There is only 1 phone in guest rooms. Lobby AP is a R510 located inside Lobby (right side),  Boardroom AP is a TW522 located in the street wall. Bistro AP is a R510 inside a closet in the back of the restaurant.   Ruckus APs: Is a combination on R510 & T310 APs (Exact locations can be found in Network Diagram)  Switches: BLDG 1: BLDG 1 IDF - 2nd Floor maids closet. Feeds 2 AP's and P2P receiver. column68: ********************************************************************************************** ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* **********************************************************************************************  1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 50.172.61.148  (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.83.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: GsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN (port 1/2/2) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt.172.16.83.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.83.254/24 to 172.16.83.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200, 201. -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.

column68: Outlet 1. Fusion Outlet 2. Core-SW-MDF-300-1 Outlet 3. Comecast Modem Outlet 4. EdgeRouter Outlet 5. Empty  Chromecast installation: behind the TV: Chromecast STB to HDMI1 Chromecast to HDMI2 Chromecast powered from USB port on the back of the TV.  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/1/21 and 1/1/22, which is connected to the Fusion LAN1 and LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "Mgmt-172.16.0.0/24-VLAN100" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "Mgmt-VLAN100" using the "Actions" button. column66: Two New Fusion in Cluster Configuration: CCA-WAN2 to CCB-WAN2   ========================================  We replaced HP SWs, DSLAMs CPEs in all the Guest Bldgs. All Brocade switches have a direct fiber connection back to the MDF. Each building is on its own VLAN. VLAN ID & IP scheme of has been customized to correspond to building number. All LAN ports of the Fusion have been used to distribute VLANs.  Placement of AP are in either the "A" unit of "B" unit depending on layout. See equipment list for this information.  All the Guest Bldgs. have 2x IDFs, except Bldg.1-Sage that has only One IDF. All the IDFs are in 1st Floor. See below an Example of how the SW are named: For Bldg3-Lily: SW-3-Lily-Main-IDF-1-01  -------> "3" stand for Bldg 3, also named Lily.   -------> "Main" stand for the IDF that has the link from the Core-SW.    ------->  "1" stand for 1st Floor  ------->  "01" tells the  SW sequence   SW-3-Lily-2nd-IDF-1-01  -------> "3" stand for Bldg 3, also named Lily.   -------> "2nd" stand for the IDF that has the link from SW-3-Lily-Main-IDF-1-01.    ------->  "1" stand for 1st Floor  ------->  "01" tells the SW sequence  Guest Ruckus APs were name as follow: Example: AP-2-Primrose-105B  -------> "2" stand for Bldg. 2, also named Primrose.   -------> "105B" tells the room number where the AP is installed.    Ruckus equipment for Pool APs, Lobby AP, and MDF AP are still online over the Old ZoneDirector.
column67: MDF: Main building/Registration/Lobby Building - IT Room  Modem: As you enter the IT room in the main building, they are on the back wall, on the right hand corner. There's two black boxes mounted to the wall, the modem is right next to those two boxes. There are two Modems. WAN 1 and WAN 2 is labeled on Each Modem. Modem has a small COX tag on it. These do not have a time-out device connected to them for rebooting.  FUSION Gateway, Brocade core switch and ISP Brocade SW are in the IT room in main building on a rack.  IDFs: Lilly - Electrical Closet West End and East End. Rack with Brocade switches. Primrose - Electrical Closet North End and South End. Rack with Brocade switches. Jasmine - Electrical Closet South End and North. Rack with Brocade switches. Daisy - Electrical Closet East End and West. Rack with Brocade switches. Sage - Electrical Closet West End and East End. Rack with Brocade switches..  Iris - Electrical Closet West End and East End. Rack with Brocade switches. Honeysuckle - Electrical Closet North End and South End 1st floor. Rack with Brocade switches. ==========================================================================================
column68: To switch traffic from the Fusion to the Mikrotik: Need Someone onsite to move a couple of Cables: ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1 - Ask a person onsite to disconnect Cable CCB-WAN1  ---- SW-MDF-ISP-1st-02  port 1/2/2  2 - Turn ON the Mikrotik... connect the power cable to a power outlet.   3 - Connect to Mikrotik http://4.26.30.38 4 - From Mikrotik do ssh on the CoreSW 172.16.40.10 5 - Disable ports for LAN1 and LAN2 on SW-MDF-ISP-1st-02 (1/2/3, 1/3/2, 1/3/3, 1/3/4) 5 - Make sure ports 1/1/47 and 1/1/43 are enable 6 - Enable ETH3 and ETH4 on Mikrotik 7 - Enable Guest Address, VLANs and DHCP Servers on Mikrotik (202 to 250)  8 - Enable MGMT Address, VLANs and DHCP Servers on Mikrotik (601 to 609)    Old Information: ========================================================================================== This location was converted to ALL Motorola/Zebra network with TW522 WAPs located in rooms on 1/20/2016. All Ruckus room APs were removed. Lobby, MDF, & Pool APs (in Sage, Rosemary, and Iris) remain.  DSLAMs are accessed through https://grandviewvegasnode1.hotelwifi.com: then put port forward - Marc 1/26/15  DSLAMs have a known bug wherein they will be up but not accessible via web interface or telnet and will not respond to SNMP (and therefore will show as down in Nagios). If you attempt to log into the web interface and receive an error message that simply says "Network" - it is due to this bug. A reboot of the DSLAM will fix the issue and Erick regularly reboots them when he is at the property performing maintenance. The issue is known and is being monitored so if this is seen the outage can be disregarded.  If you need to call the staff at Grandview to get down APs or down switches back up then ask for the manager on duty when you call. - 9/28/11 ===========================================================================================

column66: -------------Upgrade 02/2023----------------------------- This is a property with 22 Guest buildings and a Clubhouse. Each building has 8 apartments, 4 on the second floor and 4 on the 1st one. The network backbone was changed on the upgrade, and now it is a 10G backbone in the inner buildings, each one has a fiber homerun to the MDF, and the outside buildings are connected P2P to the close inner building. The WAPs are connected on the 2nd floor of the buildings, and the CAT6s are running through the attic to the IDF.  + The fibers are aerial fibers, so they are running thru the attic and after they are hanging and come across to the next building, from building to building the fiber has cross-connections using fiber jumpers -------------Old Network------------------------------------  Fusion   45 Ruckus R510 AP's 1 Ruckus T300 AP's 1 ZoneDirector 1200  (30) NS M5, Ubiquiti NanoStation M5 Outdoor 5GHz (8)   Ubiquiti NanoBeam  (1) Partner Premium Support for the ZoneDirector (22) HP 2520-8-POE Switches (1)  HP 2530-24G-POE switch in MDF  Every Building has a Ubiquiti device on the roof.   From the Ubiquiti the outdoor tuff cat6 cables go to a Ubiquiti ground (power ground) device, then to POE injector, then down to the IDF.  Building A, G, O, & V are hub building that feed up to 4 other buildings.
column67: -------------Upgrade 02/2023----------------------------- + MDF: -Fusion, Mikrotik, SWcore, Wattbox  + IDFs: -Switches  WAPs: + There are 4 WAPs on the Clubhouse building, one of them is outdoor(the AP-Pool) + In the guest rooms, the APs are located in the living room, hanging from the ceiling. there is one per room on the second floor, for a total of 4 WAP per building; + One WAP in the Maintenance shop + One WAP in the security booth. +The P2Ps are installed on the roof of the buildings. -------------Old Network------------------------------------ Modem, Fusion, Core Switch and Zone Director are located in the MDF. The MDF is located in the telephone room which is in the Clubhouse 1st floor near the water machine.  APs are located in the Attics of the Assigned Room The POE Injectors for Clubhouse Ubiquiti are located in the MDF above the Fusion The POE Injectors for Ubiquitis for all roofs are in the attic above the IDFs.
column68: Check the equipment list to identify the IDF location for each building.  ------------------------------------------------------------------  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 63.144.138.154 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.51.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the address "WiFi-MGMT.172.16.51.254/24- VLAN 102" and change the IP address from 172.16.51.254/24 to 172.16.51.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 101, 200, 800, 801 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.  -------------Upgrade 02/2023----------------------------- + The coming from building R to Building Q is terminated in the attic of building Q, from here long patch cables are going to the MDF. + The P2P connected to the IDFs G, J, O, M, S, U, and Security are using a PoE transformer from poe 802.3af to 24V, the Ubuiquiti are connected on the port 1/1/5(in building V there are two P2P, the sender to the security booth is connected in port 1/1/6) + The fiber patch panel layout for every building is saved as " Cliffs at Peace Canyon- Fiber Patch Panel Layout.xlsx" in the Documents Tab on the CRM, under the section Others. + There are 4 APs per building, there are installed on the ceiling of the rooms on the second floor. + The Mikrotik LAN is connected to the SWcore-MDF-1-01 port 2/1/17, the port is enabled, in case to need to use the Mikrotik as the main gateway, please access to the Mikrotik settings and enable the VLAN for the LAN port.  + The SWcore are 2 switches in stock, the master is the ICX7650-48F + The Switch on the security booth feeds the P2P, if the switch is down, the 1st thing to check is if the switch is plugged on. -------------Old Network------------------------------------ if you see and Ubiquiti Receiver go down. Reboot the sender that feeds it. That 95% of the time will bring them back up.  Doug is no longer with this property 06/10/2022 - David.G  Ping Watchdog was configured on the P2Ps. Please see the document "Cliffs at Peace Canyon P2P Ping Watchdog Notes" in the Network diagram section of Docs.

column66: We provide both wired and wireless connections. There is an SSID for the lobby and an SSID for the guest rooms, both on separate VLANs, but both SSIDs direct to the same portal page. Authentication is through PMS (Last Name/Room Number), but it is free access for unlimited devices. Brocade 7250 in Layer3 Mode core switchs. The ZoneDirector and web power switch are directly connected to the core switch.   From the core switch, there are fiber feeds to each IDF. In each IDF there is an Brocade 7150 Layer 3 mode POE 48 port switch and a Brocade 7150 Layer 3 Mode non-PoE 48 Port switch. The PoE switch feeds the APs in the rooms and the Non Poe SW feeds the hard wire connection in the desk.  As you may gather from reading the "IP Information" field, there are a lot of vendors who are running through the guest Internet backbone and switches. The concept here was to have a simplified, converged network without a ton of redundant equipment and cabling. So there are two primary infrastructures that everything else piggy-backs on: guest Internet (us) and IPTV (KoolConnect).    In the MDF, ISP's fiber router connects to the Fusion, which plugs into an  On our infrastructure, we are providing connectivity for a number of systems: wireless door locks for all guest rooms, the mini bar system, climate controls, security systems and a/v systems, to name the primary ones.  If you have any Questions regarding help needed please contact Damian (lead engineer at 646-664-0360. He works from 7:30/8 AM to 5:00 PM.  If Damian is not there please contact his Assistant Norman at 516-581-9826.  Night Engineer Edwards at 929-888-3073

column66: They have a FortiGate firewall that handles the management traffic for AP's, switches, & phones; and a Nomadix gateway that handles the Guest traffic.  The Nomadix and FortiGate are not connected to any of the switches we manage, but upstream on an admin switch.  There are 64 APs connected to the 2 switches we have access to and 43 connected to other admin switches that we do not have access to. See equipment the equipment list for details.   All the APs are managed by Aruba Central.  This is a Takeover property. Firewall and Gateway is a Fortigate. SWs and AP management is over Aruba Central, they reside on Group/Side: "Watercolor-Inn". SNMP port forwards were setup on the Fortigate. The Two SWs we have access to are Monitoring Only on Aruba Central because of the model of the SWs, they only allow to have a single Local administrator, so we activated the Radius Server Authentication on the SWs. The local IT manager has his set of credentials Radius Credentials: stjoeit  / $tJo3@dm1n3# Configuration changes for the SWs shown as Monitoring only have to be done doing ssh through Fortigate CLI console: >>>execute ssh yourradiususer@192.168.161.10x

column66: VLAN info: Guest Vlan 100: 192.198.100.0/24  Office vlan 10: 172.16.10.0/24  Owner LAN: 172.16.0.0/24  Net MGMT: 10.1.10.0/24  Switches: 10.1.10.16 - CoreSW 10.1.10.3 -server room - site08  10.1.10.4 -site1  10.1.10.5 -site23  10.1.10.6 -site62  10.1.10.7 - site13  10.1.10.8 -site31  10.1.10.9 -site53  10.1.10.10 -site96  10.1.10.11 -site 67  10.1.10.12 -IDF27  10.1.10.13 -Site19  (*) last visit to the property we found some location changes (sept 1st 2023): 10.1.10.9 -site23 10.1.10.5 -site32 10.1.10.11 -site53  Each dedicated cat6 run goes to a field switch, which is on a single mode fiber ring back to the "core" switch an ICX7450-24P that has all 12 SFP slots available (11 field IDF's in the park coming back to that switch.  We have implemented per account DVLANs with the Fusion as the RADIUS Server. Pre-auth VLAN is 200 and the Post-auth VLANs are 201 to 360. Each site is tied to a VLAN using a static VTA to a mac address on the aa:bb:cc:XX:XX:XX format. Each AP hardwired ports are on the same VLAN as the account for the site using the LAN to SSID mode on the ports. There was an SSID created for each site just to tie the ports to the specific VLAN there isn't any other use for that and they are not been broadcasted. The portal page has a custom code to ask the client to disconnected and reconnect to the Wi-Fi so they get moved to the corresponding VLAN

column66: This is an all cabled network. The network starts in the MDF with the Fusion, ZD1200, and Core Switch. There is a WAN switch that feeds the Fusion. There are IDFs on floors 3, 5-9, and 13 (R). The APs are all PoE WITH THE EXCEPTION of the Engineering Office AP on the LG level which could not be PoE power due to the distance of the cable run. This AP gets its connection from AP-Room-UGWmLockerRm AP's spare ethernet port. The Engineering Office AP gets power from a Ruckus power adapter plugged in the Chief Engineers Office.        It should be noted that the 5th floor Switch, SW-IDF-5-01, is up-linked on a fiber connection that goes through two 10/100 Fiber to Ethernet Converters. One of the Fiber Converters is in the MDF and the other is in a closet on the 4th floor. Since the Fiber Converter only runs at 100megs, its being proposed to replace it.       A second thing to be aware of is that their remote wireless A/C controllers (InnCom) are connected into the 8th floor IDF switch on VLAN860. In the photos you will note that there are small white boxes with pink cables next to the IDF switches. These InnCom wireless devices are powered from the Negear PoE switch on the 8th floor.
column67: The ISP WAN feed comes from the Transbeam-GTT ISP fiber modem to a fiber junction box on the side of the rack in the MDF. From the fiber junction box single mode fiber cable goes to the fiber converter on the wall, by the rack. Cat5e cable going to the LAN-WAN SW (172.16.0.9), port 15 and feeds the network.   Rittenhouse consists of a hotel portion, floors 1,2,3,5,-9 and 13, and a resident portion on floors 4 and 14 up.    There is an underground garage that goes down several floors. The MDF is on what is call the "Upper Garage (UG)" which is the first level down below the Lobby level.        There are APs on the UG level to cover the staff areas. There is only one AP on a level lower than the UG level and that is the AP in the Engineering Office on the "Lower Garage (LG)" level. The R510 APs located on the LG and UG levels are located as follows: UG Level - Elevator Lobby UG Level - Security UG Level - Men's Locker Rm UG Level - Wemen's Locker Rm UG Level - MDF AP LG Level - Engineering Off        The MDF is next to the PSAV Office on the UG level. There is a Fusion, ZD1200, a Core Switch, and a WAN switch in the MDF.         The Lobby level (ground or 1st floor), 2nd floor Lacroix Restaurant, 3rd Floor SPA and Salon, have R510s covering public areas. These are located as follows:  LOBBY1 AP - Above the ceiling access panel near the door of the "library" leading into the Bar LOBBY2 AP - Above the ceiling access panel over the point of sale terminal for the Terrace Restaurant. LOBBY3 AP - Above the ceiling access panel where the stairs begin. LOBBY_BC  - In a cupboard in the Business Center. (This is currently being renovated) LOBBY_BehindFD - Its above the ceiling tiles in the front desk back office. 2nd Floor Lacroix - Above the ceiling tiles in the corner of the kitchen of the Lacroix restaurant. 3rd Floor SPA - In the ceiling tile just around the corner from the Salon front desk. 3rd Floor FitnessCt - Above the ceiling access panel in the middle of the Fitness Center room. 3rdLockerRmHall - Above the ceiling access panel just outside the door to the men's fitness center locker room in the hallway. 3rdHallSoffit_A - Above the soffit in the hallway outside the "P" rooms on the 3rd floor near the door to the service elevator lobby (IDF2 3rd Floor). 3rdHallSoffit_B - Above the soffit in the hallway outside the "P" rooms (specifically outside P2 guest room). 3rd Floor SPA_IDF1 - Above the ceiling tiles outside the 3rd floor IDF1, which is in the back-lines area. 3rd Floor 3rdMassageRms - Above the ceiling access panel just as you come into the massage rooms hallway. 3rd Floor Pool - Above the ceiling access panel just after you come into the pool area.     With the exception of the 3rd Floor IDF1 (SPA) Switch, which is located in the back-lines area of the 3rd floor, all of the IDFs are located in the Service Elevator lobbies on floors 3,5,6-9, and 13 (also called the "R" floor).       In the IDFs on the guest floors 5-9 and 13 (R), you will find two sets of switches. This is because there are two sets of network cables going to each room on these floors. There is one set of cables that go to a phone/cat5 jack plate near the desk in each room. These cables share a wire pair for the phone and the remaining pairs are punched down on separate a patch panel (from the AP patch panel) that is patched to a E2620-24 switch. These cables are not currently being used for APs and are only for a guest using their Laptop at the desk.          The second set of cables going to the rooms is Cat6 and goes to a network jack biscuit usually found behind the TV. These are the cables that the APs are connected to and these go to the second switch, a PoE switch, in the IDF.          Some of the IDFs have an R510 ( though there will also be an H320 put into the 8th floor IDF in the future) that covers staff access to wifi in these back-lines areas. These APs are located in these IDFs currently: 5thElevLobby 7thElevLobby 9thElevLobby 13thElevLobby       The remaining APs are in the guest rooms as listed here: P1 (3rd floor) P2 (3rd floor) P3 (3rd floor) P4 (3rd floor) P5 (3rd floor) 500 502 501 504 507 510 511 516 517 518 520 600 601 604 605 608 609 610 615 616 618 620 702 701 706 707 710 711 714 717 718 720 800 801 804 805 808 809 815 818 **816 (The Presidential Suite, room 816, is still under construction but an H320 will be install in this room eventually) 820 900 902 905 906 907 908 911 914 917 919 920 R3 R4 R5 R6 R7 R9 R10 R14 R12 R15     The only thing else to be aware of is that there are two PCs in the MDF connected to the SW-MDF-UG-02-LANWAN switch. One PC is for the InnCom system remote access AC controllers. The InnCom system - you will see the Netgear PoE switch on the 8th floor connecting all the wireless controller antennas on floors 5-13 - is a system that  wirelessly controls the AC units in the guest rooms. The InnCom siwtch on the 8th floor is connected into our switch on VLAN860.       The other PC in the MDF is for the PurpleCloud system. The PurpleCloud system is what is used for the Staff tablets for inter-hotel messaging. This PC is connected to the WAN side of SW-MDF-UG-02-LANWAN switch.
column68: a.) Per the Hirsha Rep only about 85% of the guest room cables that we installed the APs on were operational (ie, either not missing or damaged). Per what we found when installing the system,there are a few Guest Room APs where the cables were damaged and had to be rewired to get two working pairs. These APs must run at a static 100FDx in the IDF switches and the patch cables for the APs should stay on those ports on the switch (unless another port is configured for static 100FDx, ie, not "Auto"). There are also a few guest room APs that are running at 100 on Auto which may also have cable issues but have at least two working pairs. The rooms where the cables were actually rewired are: AP-Room-517 (port 15, SW-IDF-5-01) AP-Room-907 (port 17, SW-IDF-9-01) AP-Room-919 (port 18, SW-IDF-9-01 b.) Note:Their SPA Music box is connected to SW-IDF2-3-01 IDF switch and is passed through the Fusion. c.) Note: Their InnCom wireless controller Netgear Switch is connected to port 2 on SW-IDF-8-01 d.) Note: There are two spares in the Chief Engineers Office. One is for the 8th floor IDF service elevator lobby. The other is for the Presidential Suite, 816, which is currently under renovations. Without these two APs, the Presidential Suite will not be covered.  Room 816 - Presidential Suite has Lutron-Lighting (VLAN 810) system. There is an iPad in the room and has to be connected to: SSID: Lutron-Lighting PW:  lu1r0n816      -        FYI in case if the Guest changing the SSID in the iPad settings. 2 Lutron-Lighting devices is hardwired on the SW-IDF-8-01 (172.16.0.16) Port:11 and 22     4 APs only broadcasting the SSID Room 717, 815, 818, 917 in AP group "Room-816".

column66: All guest room APs (H510s) are mounted on RJ45 jacks in the rooms as listed above and are all powered PoE. There is a fiber backbone from the MDF to the IDF switches on 2,5, and 8.      The rooms without APs have hardwried connections to either 3COM switches or un-managed switches in the 3 IDFs. This hardwire switches are connected to the Brocade IDF switches in the IDFs. The MDF consists of a Fusion, Brocade core switch and ZD3050.
column67: The Fusion, Core Switch  and ZD 3050 are in the basement server/phone room (MDF). Floors 2,5, and 8 have IDF closets by the elevator and there are Brocade PoE switches there.    There are two R510s. One is located above the roof of the restaurant on the lobby level and can be accessed from the closet in the lobby hallway (see photo in DOCs). There is another R510 and it is in the basement above the ceiling tiles just outside the basement Meeting Room.    All the Guest Room APs are located on jacks in the guest rooms on floors 2-10, in rooms as follows: 202 203 205 208 210 301 304 306 307 309 402 403 405 408 410 501 504 506 507 509 602 603 605 608 610 701 704 706 707 709 802 803 805 808 810 901 904 906 907 910 1002 1003 1005 1008 1010
column68: 1) Note that the Brocaded core switch is configured with untagged VLANS such as 2,3, 10 etc.. These are used by the hotel for god knows what. VLAN3 on ports 7-10 is the LAN side of a Linksys Router and is probably something to do with their Admin system. Please take that into account if changing VLAN settings on the core switch. Other cables connected to VLAN1, 2, and 10 ports mostly are not powered and may go to wall jacks in meeting rooms. 2) The old Web Power Switch is still being used in addition to the new WattBox. None of the Guest network equipment is on this WPS but we still have access to it and such things as the Camera switches are plugged into this WPS.

column66: Prior to the upgrades done in April 2021 many of the outdoor APs connected via Meshing and links between the IDFs in many cases was via P2P. As part of the April upgrade the link between the WaterTower IDF and the Cottage IDF was converted from P2P to fiber in conduit underground. Also a new IDF was created at RV Site39 and connected via cable to the WaterTower IDF. This allowed several APs to be connected with copper instead of Meshing. All the Village APs were connected by copper cable as well.        The ISP feeds come into the Office/Motel building to the MDF in the phone room. From the MDF, fiber goes to the Villiage IDF and over copper to the Billiards Building IDF. From the Billiards building a copper uplink goes to the Tent Rest Room IDF and from there to the Cottage IDF via Fiber. From the Cottage IDF it goes P2P to the Cabins IDF.
column67: The MDF is located in a phone room back of the Front Desk. The Front Desk and main office is in the "Motel" building, where there are 8 hotel rooms. There are 4 indoor APs covering the Front Desk and hotel rooms plus the rest of the APs, all outdoor APs, are located as follows: Billiards/Arcade-outdoor Billiards-inside Cabins-Tree Cottage-front Motel-FrontDesk Small Club House-indoor Store-indoor Tent RR-South Water Tower Tent-Site120 Cabin-#2 Cabin-#3 Cabin-#5 TentRR-North Village-Site 1 Village-Site 8 Village-Site 12 Village-Site 17 Site 34 Site 36_MESH Site 39 Site 60 Site 69 Bathrooms Motel-Rm2 Motel-Rm5 Motel-Rm8      IDFs are located in outdoor all weather boxes at various locations on the property.

column66: -The property is made up of 7 two-story units. There are 2 APs in each unit, one per floor, on the 1st floor they are in the living room, and on the 2nd floor in a bedroom. -There are 2 outdoor APs, one facing the parking lot and the other one facing the pool. -There are 16 cameras on the property.  New SSID: ----------------- -A New and Only One General SSID was configured "The_Crossing" to be broadcast on the entire property.--- WPA2 M1nn3sot@735  -- No Portal Page.    Old Info: ------------------ -A General SSID was configured 'Winter_Park_Guest" to be broadcast on the entire property.--- WPA2 -- Portal Page with Clickthrough.   -Seven different SSIDs were configured one per Bldg.  --Ex.  Bldg_735_WiFi only broadcast by APs on Bldg. 735 ---- Open --- Portal Page with an Access Code. --Ex.  Bldg_737_WiFi only broadcast by APs on Bldg. 737 ---- Open --- Portal Page with an Access Code. --And so on with the 7 Bldgs.
column67: - All equipment are housed in an A/C Enclosure outside with a padlock (code 5370). - The enclosures are located between the buildings: - MDF is between 735 and 736.   - IDF 1 is located between 741 and 740. - IDF 2 is located between 737 and 738.   - APs are located in the Guestrooms and we have an AP for the Parking lot and the Pool area.   - The MDF and the IDFs have 2 - brocade Switches,  Only One is ON per MDF/IDF handling the traffic, The Second One considered as SPARE is OFF in each MDF/IDF, in case the First fail we will need someone onsite to move all the connections. - Each enclosure has an AC unit attached as well as a UPS. - All the buildings have a grey Connex box that comes from the enclosure to another grey Connex box that is mounted to the building in this box we have ethernet and coax cables for the guest rooms.  - Fiber is connected in the MDF Enclosure and then from there fiber is feed to IDF1, In the Enclosure for IDF1 fiber is feed to IDF 2.  IDF 2 fiber ports are 1-2 and it goes back to IDF 1 on the 2nd pair of fiber strands it is labeled (Fiber 1-2 IDF -2) IDF1 fiber comes from the MDF labeled (Fiber 12 MDF).   - CoreSW MDF-1-1 feeds IDF-1 and IDF-2 via SFP at 10GB.   MDF- 172.16.24.10 ------  172.16.0.10 (Spare Off) IDF1- 172.16.24.12 ------  172.16.0.12 (Spare Off) IDF2- 172.16.24.15 ------  172.16.0.15 (Spare Off)
column68: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --> Padlocks Combination: 5370  --> The cables for the APs are run from the MDF or IDF to a junction box outside of the units, from there, there is a keystone connection in the cable that goes inside the unit to the APs. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- WATTBOX:  Outlets Mapping: --> Outlet-1: Fusion --> Outlet-2: CoreSW-1-1 --> Outlet-3: Mikrotik --> Outlet-4: NVR --> Outlet-5: Empty ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- CAMERA SYSTEM:  --> The NVR is located in the MDF. The cameras are connected through the network, not straight to the NVR.  --> To configure the cameras and troubleshoot, it can be used 2 different methods:  --> Accessing the NVR through the fusion port forward: http://thecrossingatwinterpark.hotelwifi.com:58010 (For access use user and password listed above)  --> Accessing the NVR through the app Config Tool (Finder Utility) (Download app: https://icrealtime.com/downloads) (For access use user and password listed above) ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- MIKROTIK:  We have only one public IP in this property, so, if the fusion fails, we need a tech onsite to swap the gateways and put the Mikrotik online. column66: The Covington:  -The Main bldg. Has a fourth floor.  -In the main bldg. We have 11x IDFs on different floors.  -We run SM fiber to every IDF. We have a cross connection in the IDF-1, IDF-4, and IDF-8. With these cross-connections, we ensured each IDF was connected to the core switch.  -All the Cat6e cables are new. -We use the existing j hook in some areas.  -We use EMT conduit and waterproof boxes to cover the cables for the outdoor areas and garage.  Assisted living bldg.:  -We run an SM fiber from the MDF to this bldg. We also created the IDF-12 here on the second floor.  -With the IDF-12, we covered the two floors that this bldg. It has some outdoor areas.  -The APs for the units are inside every unit. All the common areas APs are visible.  P1 and P2 Garage.  We installed 8x T750 in these garage levels. All these cables have been run through the EMT conduit. In garage level P1, we also run the fiber from MDF to IDF-1, MDF to IDF-3, and IDF-1 to IDF-2 with EMT conduit.   APs:  -We installed 265 APs, different types of APs, R550, R650 and T750. -1x MDF and 12x IDFs. -265x new cables run. -All the SM fiber is new.  Permanent Admin-Interconnection Info: ---------------------------------------------------- COV-CORE-SW01-STK (Port-channel/Agg.Port)  for us is LAG Port 1/24 ---- SW Brocade ICX7550-24F-E2 Name: CoreSW-MDF-P1-01 IP: 172.16.94.10 port 1/1/17 Port 2/24 ---- SW Brocade ICX7550-24F-E2 Name: CoreSW-MDF-P1-01 IP: 172.16.94.10 port 1/1/18 We configured 4 VLANS as Dry-Vlan on our SWs (UPlinks and APs), we did no spanning tree on since they have some sort of Spanning tree on the Admin Side: *Vlan 4 name POC, Untagged. On their side is Vlan1 Native. *Vlan 10 name Partner, Tagged in both ends. *Vlan 56 name POS, Tagged in both ends. *Vlan 60 name Internal, Tagged in both ends.

column68: Guestcast Troubleshooting:  Chromecasts are powered by TV, and the HDMI of Chromecast is connected to TV on HDMI port 2. In order to exit casting, the Menu or Back button should be pressed.  Guestcast Remotes work with the default Samsung configuration.  All TVs work with the same remote settings.  How to factory reset a Samsung TV: 1. Mute, 1, 1, 9 and enter to get the settings menu 2. Last option should say TV reset 3. Press TV reset. At this point TV will be power off. 4. Wait for 5 seconds and turn on the TV. 5. TV Will be on channel 0, then press Mute, 1, 1, 9, enter to get settings menu. 6. Second option on setting menu will be on EBI that should be set to Samsung by using left arrow and then press return button 7. Go to 3rd option on settings menu, which is power, click enter on power, 2nd option from bottom will be on TV. 8. External source option on setting menu is selected and 2nd option is Banner ON and that should be set to OFF and press return button. 9. Power off the TV and turn it back on. TV is set to Power on to TV input

column66: This is Client where we fully provide WiFi: There is a Mix of PoE APs and xDSL system on the gest rooms (Motorola DSLAMs and TW522). At the MDF there are 4 Power Circuits are: LP108 #1, #3, #5, and #7. #1 is UPS #1 for DSLAMs 0 and 1 #2 is for UPS#2 for DSLAMs 2, 3, and 4 #3 is for UPS #3 for DSLAMs 5 and 6  #4 id for UPS #4 for WattBox which powers – Fusion, Router Board, and SW-MDF-LL-02.  We also have 2 dedicated 20 amp circuits for our system Each of 4 UPS uses its own 20 amp.  We have 2 different types of TW-522 WAPs on this site. DSLAMs 0 to 4 are "US" and DSLAMs 5 and 6 are "WR". They can’t be mixed. There is a DSLAM tab in the equipment list all Rooms have a reference line for the Country code. Please check before having a TW-522 replaced.    Bill Notes: ------------- MDF is in the phone room located in the Engineering shop on the Lower Level. Core switch, WattBox, and 7 DSLAMs are in a wall-mounted rack and the Fusion, Router Board, 2nd switch, and UPS are in a free-standing rack next to the wall-mounted rack. The 4 circuits are: LP108 #1, #3, #5, and #7. #1 is UPS #1 for DSLAMs 0 and 1; #2 is for UPS#2 for DSLAMs 2, 3, and 4; #3 is for UPS #3 for DSLAMs 5 and 6 and #4 id for UPS #4 for WattBox which powers – Fusion, Router Board, and SW-MDF-LL-02. We have 2 dedicated 20 amp circuits for our system Each of 4 UPS uses its own 20 amp. We have 2 different types of TW-522 WAPs on this site. DSLAMs 0 to 4 are us and DSLAMs 5 and 6 are WR. They can’t be mixed. There is a DSLAM tab in the equipment list all Rooms have a reference line for the Country code. Please check before having a TW-522 replaced. There are 4 other locations for switch gear: one on the first-floor server room. And 3 on the 2nd floor, 2 on the West side – the Pinnacle Ball Room side: 1 in storage closet and 1 on the East side near the Summit room in the AV storage.   First floor IDF I ICX-7150-24P for first floor Aps.  2 East has an ICX-7150-24 from 2nd for East Aps and wired ports and an ICX-7150-12 for future use. 2 west storage closet behind guest elevators has 1 ICX-7150-24 for 2nd floor west Aps and 1 ICX-7150-12 for future use. 2nd-floor West 2nd closet is between Pathway and Pinnacle and has a 24 port Aruba switch for wired ports throughout the 2nd floor.

Verify you are getting ARP and check with someone onsite that the WiFi services is working.

column68: IF FUSION FAIL MOVE THE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Login into the Mikrotik via WinBox. WAN/Eth1 is connected to the Core-SW 2. From the Mikrotik do ssh into Core SW, Select New Terminal from Menu, then type: system. Then ssh 172.16.75.10   ( user=admin ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& ) 3. Once on the CoreSW , disable the SW port where the Fusion LAN (port 2/1/48) to make sure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab (VLAN 12, 13, 17, 27, 249, 300, 801, 1300). 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "ETH2/LAN" and change the IP address from 172.16.75.254/24 to 172.16.75.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  When dealing with PMS issues contact Centrada and ask them to start the HTNG interface using the executable file. This file need to be run as an administrator.

All of our programming was don from in front of the TV with master remotes These are early hotel model flat screen TVs    *************CABLE PLANT / CHANNEL ISSUES********************* (added by Alex Shalima 04/15/2022)  If we can’t handle the issue right there and then (like terminating a COAX cable while visiting or something simple like that), then the correct handling of issues with channels, delivery of channels or problems with quality of ANY Free To Guest (FTG) channels should be as such:  1.	The GM (Edwin Zaragoza (619) 792-2209) should be made aware of the issue, if not already.  2.	The service request should be forwarded to the DirecTV local dealer (California Commercial Satellite LLC) 3.	Public area TVs should NOT have BTV on them. 4.	Public area TVs MUST have an STB provided by California Commercial Satellite LLC if the TV is not a hospitality TV. If not sure, call the vendor and ask.   619-795-9444 California Commercial Satellite LLC  They don’t have a service contract with the property. They fix the TV issues on time and materials basis. They are local to the property.  ****************************************************************************

column66: The system is running Ruckus WAPs only. H550s, R550s, T350s, T310c They delivery methods to IDFs is mainly by Fiber Optics (62.5/125 all ST multimode).  WattBox is using Management Private IP address  Outlet-1 Fusion Outlet-2 MDF-CoreSW-01 Outlet-3 MDF-SW-02.   Traditional building: Has 4xIDFs Valet-IDF-SW  ---- Fiber Meeting-IDF-SW ---- Cat6 GM-IDF-SW  ---Cat6 Food-Beverage-IDF-SW ---Cat6  Buildings A, B (Ariel), C (Caledonia), HSK-ENG : Each IDF gets and uplink via fiber from HP MDF-CoreSW-01. Each IDF has an HP-48P PoE Switch but HSK-ENG that has an HP-8P. WAPs are fed via hardwire.  Every guest room has 1-2 Ethernet jacks in it. If it is not working, most likely it's not patched into the switch.  Spa Building: Has an HP-8P SW Fiber uplink from MDF-SW-02 Brocade ICX-7150-24P (port 1/3/1). Feeds SPA area, Pool, Pool Bar, Fitness Center and Locker Rooms.  WAP for Fitness Center is in the storage room of the fitness center and that also feeds the locker rooms. The Bar WAP feeds the bar and the pool. The Spa WAp feeds all of the spa and Relaxation room inside of it.  Engineering and Housekeeping: WAP for housekeeping and chief Engineer's office is in the attic above it. The Engineering WAP is in the shop over a door way.
column67: MDF: Fusion, MDF-CoreSW-01, MDF-SW-02, WattBox   9XIDFs: Valet-IDF-SW Bldg-A-IDF-SW Bldg-Ariel-IDF-SW Bldg-Caledonia-IDF-SW Meeting-IDF-SW GM-IDF-SW Bldg-HSK-ENG-IDF-SW Bldg-SPA-IDF-SW Food-Beverage-IDF-SW  In room APs are in different parts of the units, either under the desk, behind the TVs, etc.  Note: AP-Caledonia-1-Rm-78 is on the floor, underneath the couch.
column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 209.196.180.55 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.0.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: lib3rty 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN (port 24) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt.172.16.0.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 18, 19, 101, 200, 201, 800, 801, 1000 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. -------------------------------------------------------------------------  They have WLAN "IPCEXEC" for Admin purposes, Using our network, it's on VLAN 123, as Dry Vlan, We do not provide DHCP from our Fusion, it's broadcast on the entire property.  AP-Caledonia-Outdoor-Roof is powered up via Cat6 from LAN4 on AP-Caledonia-01-Rm_72 PoE SW on Bldg. HSK-ENG is up-linked from LAN1 on AP-Engineering-Shed--- for cameras   Power outages (frequent for the area)  Most knowledgeable guy about the system is Jim Wood. He works days and sometimes nights. Chief Engineer Robert (everyone calls him Bob) has some knowledge too. The rest are too afraid to touch it and the most that they can do is to check if there is power in IDFs or if the unit is plugged into power inside the rooms.

column66: We have taken over the hotel's Guest wireless network and deployed both Ruckus and TP-Link APs throughout the hotel's three floors.  The MDF is located in the GM office on the first floor behind the FD (Only One IT-Location).  The hotel has 3 SSIDs: Comfort Suites_GUEST,  Comfort Suites_LOBBY, and Comfort Suites_CONFERENCE.  Guest SSID use our Splash Page  for authentication with access code: comfort16 .    They have SM 9/125 fiber connected to the ISP Router (Juniper). The handoff is ETH Red Cat6 from port 0/0/0, which is connected to the Temp-Wan Switch port 8.
column67: The MDF is in the GM office, behind the FD.  Comcast did run a Fiber connection from the outside Demarc to the MDF The Coax Headend is on the first floor in a storage room next to Rm101. Please see the photos in CRM.  The Breakfast and Lobby AP is located in the middle of the two locations; it is an R300. Please see the equipment list to see where all the APs are located.
column68: We added a Netgear Temp WAN switch for our Public IPs. --- Connected to Juniper ISP Modem (Port 0/0/0 on Juniper to Port 8 on Netgear SW) They also have an NVR connected to the Netgear WAN SW using a Public IP address (Lorex-NVR	50.216.191.182) --- We do not manage that NVR. They have an HP 2530-24Port Core switch that controls the Ruckus R300 APs in the Building.   They are arranged in a hallway deployment throughout the hotel.   The Hotel has TP-Link EAP 245 APs in a hallway deployment.  Please note that we adopted the TP-Link APs on our Omada Cloud Controller, they are all connected to an 18-port POE Ethernet unmanaged switch (Mokerlink is the brand linked to HP-CoreSW port 15).  They also has another TP-Link Umnaged SW connected to HP CoreSW on port 16. Since the Mokerlink is an unmanaged SW, we configured port 16 on HP Core-SW untagged vlan 1000, then the TP-Link APs are all in vlan 1000.  An HP printer in connected via USB to Front Desk computers also using Guest SSID.  The Canon printer with an IP address of 172.20.12.244.    ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 50.216.191.181 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 10.10.137.131 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LANx (port 22) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "SW-MGMT/VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 10.10.137.190/26 to 10.10.137.129/26 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 101, 805, 1000, 1016, 1025, and 1050 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************.

column68: IF FUSION FAIL!!! ---------------------------------------------------- We have an Spare Gateway onsite: Mikrotik using different Public IP address --- 50.228.171.172 How to pass the traffic over the Mikrotik? 1. Login into the Mikrotik using WinBox Software. 2. Go over: Interfaces/Ethernet 3. Double Click on LAN/Eth2 and enable the Interface, then Apply. 4. At this moment you can have access to the core SW via SSH through the Mikrotik. 5. Do ssh on the CoreSW (172.16.0.10) through the Mikrotik. 6. Disable the port on CoreSW for Fusion LAN. 7. Verify you are getting ARP and check with someone onsite that the WiFi services is working.  Contact Onsite:  Sabrina Grasso is the main contact: 561-379-2056. column66: The 1820 STBs connect over Wifi provided by Shields Networking, a local company. The Wifi APs and controller are Ubiquity Unifi. The Fusion BTV server is connected to the guest wifi company's core switch in the MDF on these ports: 20 - Fusion LAN1 21 - Fusion LAN2 22 - IMPI 23 - Fusion WAN1  (note that ports 22 to 24 act as a WAN switch with the ISP feed coming to port 19 on the core switch)      WAN2 is connected directly to the ISP modem.
column67: There are 25 rooms numbered 1 to 26 (excluding room13). They have LG TVs and there are two basic models:  Larger LG: 43UT570H9UA Smaller LG: 32LT570H9UA      The smaller LGs are in cabinets and the larger LGs have desk top mounts and sit on a chest of drawers in front of the bed. For the larger TVs on the chest of drawers, the STB is mounted behind the chest of drawers. For the smaller TVs that are in the cabinets, the STB is mounted either on the back of the cabinet or behind the TV on the back panel. The STB controls the TV via an MPI cable.      The BTV server is located in an electrical closet on the 1st floor just to the right of the lobby reception area outside. Access to the closet is by the stairs that go to rooms 6 to 10. The guest wifi company also has their gateway and core switch there.
