column66: ##### Introduction #####  This property is a coworking space. The Fusion controls the network, and the wireless conroller is hisvsz2.hotelwifi.com. The property is managed by a special coworking management software called Nexudus.  The Colette Club SSID is setup for dynamic VLANs, with each office space having it's own dedicated VLAN, as determined by the static VTAs in the Fusion. When a user first connects, they are part of a general VLAN that contains all devices. Once they are associated to an office space, their accounts are switched to the dedicated VLAN for that particular space.  There are two types of network users: coworkers (or members), and visitors (or guests). Each authenticates on the network using a unique access code that is created in Nexudus. Property staff help each user get their access code. For members, the access code is called "Internet access, check-in and printing pin-code." This can be found in the Nexudus dashboard under Operations > Customers > Members & contacts > {Member Name} > Account > Access Rights. For guests, the access code is called "Check-in code," and can be found under Operations > Customers > Visitors. The captive portal has an access code field, and checks the user's entry against both the member codes and the guest codes, and creates the applicable Account depending on which the user is. Member Accounts are valid for the length of time defined by the "member_expiration_days" CDK, which is currently set to 365 days. Guest Accounts are valid for the length of time defined by the "user_expiration_days" CDK, which is currently set to 1 day. Additionally, all guest accounts are purged nightly to avoid having a returning guest auto-added to an office space they are no longer visiting.  After either a member or a guest is authenticated, they are put in the generic VLAN. Members get associated to an office space when they have an active booking for a specific office in Nexudus. Nexudus hits an API on the Fusion every time a booking is created or updated, and the Fusion moves the applicable member's account into the VLAN for the applicable office space. Guests get associated to an office space by scanning a unique QR code displayed on a tablet in each space, or by manually navigating to the URL displayed on the tabled (http://wi.fi/portal/access/signin) and entering the unique code for that space, which is also displayed on the tablet. The code for each space changes daily so that a guest can't return on some other day and re-authenticate without being in front of the tablet in the room they are in.  ##### HIS's Coworking Space Solution Components: #####  There are several pieces to this new Coworking Space product, which will be described here:  - Integration from the Fusion Custom Portal template to Nexudus's API to validate the existence of a coworker or visitor using their "Internet access, check-in and printing pin-code" or "Check-in code." - Integration from the Fusion Custom Portal template to Nexudus's API to check for an active booking at the time a coworker is authenticating. - All Nexudus related functionality is included in the default Fusion Custom Portal template, including 10 new Custom Data Keys to configure the Nexudus integration: 	+ nexudus_login (which pairs with account_login to display the proper login form) 	+ nexudus_username (our username to authenticate against the Nexudus API, support@hotelwifi.com) 	+ nexudus_password (our password to authenticate against the Nexudus API, nH4zhl$Z!22I1U) 	+ member_account_group (the Account Group coworkers/members should be associated with, usually "Nexudus") 	+ member_expiration_days (the number of days a coworker/member account should be valid for, usually "365") 	+ user_account_group (the Account Group visitors/guests should be associated with, usually "Nexudus_Visitor") 	+ user_expiration_days (the number of days a visitor/guest account should be valid for, usually "1") 	+ nexudus_meeting_gracetime_minutes (the number of minutes before and after a booking period that the coworker/member devices get added to or removed from that booking's VLAN, usually "5") 	+ nexudus_meeting_purger_weeks (number of past weeks before which all booking records, which are stored in the Shared Credential Groups table, should be purged, usually "2") 	+ nexudus_location (the name of the location within Nexudus, in this case "Colette") - An API endpoint in the Fusion Custom Portal template (https://{Fusion DNS}/portal/access/nexudus_booking) that Nexudus hits each time a booking is created or updated. The Fusion stores each new booking in the Shared Credential Groups table. In Nexudus, this endpoint is configured under Settings > Show advanced settings > Integrations > Webhooks. The two webhooks we have configured are "Fusion - Booking Created" and "Fusion - Booking Updated". - An API endpoint in the Fusion Custom Portal template (https://{Fusion DNS}/portal/access/nexudus_qr?room={Nexudus room name}) that each in-room tablet hits and receives a JSON object containing a qr_url, display_url, and code. - A form in the Fusion Custom Portal template (https://{Fusion DNS}/portal/access/nexudus_booking/signin) that can be hit by scanning the in-room tablet's QR code, or manually navigated to and the unique code can be entered in. - The Fusion's Accounts, PMS Guests, PMS Rooms, and VLAN Tag Assignments tables to manage Nexudus office spaces and coworker/visitor accounts - The Fusion's Shared Credential Groups table to store the information on all bookings, including: Booking Unique ID, Office Space Name, Coworker ID, Booking From Time, and Booking To Time - A Fusion Backend Script to pull all office space locations via Nexudus's API and create a PMS Room and Account for each space. This automates the installation process by automatically adding all office spaces at the click of a button. This script also runs every day to add any new spaces if any are configured within Nexudus (prior to any new space functioning with the dynamic VLAN functionality, a static VTA will need to be created for the new space). - A Fusion Backend Script that runs every minute, looking at the SCG table for any bookings that have started and moving the applicable coworker account into the correct PMS Room for that booking. - A Fusion Backend Script that runs every 5 minutes, looking at the SCG table for any bookings that have ended and moving the applicable coworker account back into the "General" PMS Room.  - A Fusion Backend Script that runs at the end of each day and deletes all visitor/guest Accounts and PMS Guests, as well as moves any coworkers who scanned an in-room QR to manually join space back into the "General" PMS Room. - A Fusion Backend Script that runs every day and which purges all bookings from the SCG table that expired earlier than the number of weeks set in the nexudus_meeting_purger_weeks CDK.  ##### Configuration Dependencies #####  In addition to the components above, there are critical items of configuration in both the Fusion and SmartZone.  # Fusion: - All of the standard configuration to support dynamic VLANs must be in place: 	+ A WLAN Controller 	+ A RADIUS Server Option that has the SmartZone whitelisted 	+ A Pre-Auth RADIUS Server Realm with the applicable SSID as the Called-Station_Id attribute, set to per-Device 	+ A Post-Auth RADIUS Server Realm linked to the Policy in which all coworker/visitor accounts will be contained, set to per-Room 	+ Account Groups for members and visitors that match the member_account_group and user_account_group CDKs 	+ A Policy, or Policies, for these Account Groups 	+ Static VLAN Tag Assignments for every PMS Room, assigning the applicable VLAN to each office space, as well as to the pre-auth PMS Rooms (General and User) 	+ A General PMS Room in which member Accounts are placed when they do not have a booking 	+ A User PMS Room in which visitor Accounts are placed when they have not scanned an in-room QR 	(NOTE: The General and User PMS Rooms can be assigned the same VLAN if network segmentation between the two types of users is not required) - The Pre-Auth VLAN DHCP Pool needs to have default-lease-time, max-lease-time, and min-lease-time DHCP Options set to "30" - A DNS Record of wi.fi needs to be in place. This record is automatically configured in any Fusion that has been newly installed in the past several years.  # SmartZone: The WLAN must have this configuration, in addition to any other standard configuration: - Method: MAC Address - Authentication Service: On, and the Fusion selected as the RADIUS Server - Accounting Service: On, and the Fusion selected as the RADIUS Server (RADIUS CoA on VTA change will not work without this) - RADIUS Options > NAS IP: User-defined and set to IP of SmartZone - Enable Dynamic VLAN (AAA Override): On  ##### Special Mentions ##### - Colette has two office types, Huddle Rooms and Enclaves, which do not have any shared network resources, therefore, any booking for these spaces are ignored (as hard-coded in the "Nexudus Booking Start Check" Backend Script), and we do not need static VTAs for these spaces. - If a member books two or more spaces simultaneously, their Account bill be placed in the PMS Room that happens to show up last in the list. If the member wishes their device(s) to be part of one of their other spaces, they need to scan the QR code in that room, following the same process a vistor would.  ##### How to View Nexudus API Endpoints #####  It's quite easy to look at the information returned by Nexudus via any of their APIs that we use. The full documentation on their API is contained here: https://developers.nexudus.com/reference/getting-started-with-your-api-1. All of the APIs we use are contained under the "REST API REFERENCE" section.  You can use a browser to check any endpoint we use, which could be helpful in troubleshooting. All you need are our credentials for Nexudus and the below endpoints:  To search for a coworker by their email address: https://spaces.nexudus.com/api/spaces/coworkers?page=1&size=25&Coworker_Email=applicable@email.address.com  To search for a coworker by their access code: https://spaces.nexudus.com/api/spaces/coworkers?page=1&size=25&Coworker_AccessPincode=ACCESSCODE  To search for a user by their email address: https://spaces.nexudus.com/api/sys/users?page=1&size=25&User_Email=applicable@email.address.com  To search for a visitor by their email address: https://spaces.nexudus.com/api/spaces/visitors?page=1&size=25&Visitor_Email=applicable@email.address.com  To search for visitors expected on a certain date: https://spaces.nexudus.com/api/spaces/visitors?page=1&size=25&from_Visitor_ExpectedArrival=YYYY-MM-DDT01:00&to_Visitor_ExpectedArrival=YYYY-MM-DDT23:00 (Note: This endpoint is used to find visitors by their access code. Nexudus' API to search the visitors table directly by access code is broken, so we first pull all visitors expected that day, and then iterate through each visitor and check their access code against what was entered in the captive portal.)  To search for bookings for a specific coworker on a specific day:  https://spaces.nexudus.com/api/spaces/bookings?page=1&size=25&Booking_Coworker=COWORKERID&from_Booking_FromTime=YYYY-MM-DDT00:00:00&to_Booking_ToTime=YYYY-MM-DDT23:59:00") (Note: To find the coworker ID, you can either look at the "Address 2" field in their Account in the Fusion, or use the above coworkers endpoint to find the correct coworker by their email address. If you only have the coworkers name, and not their email, you can look them up by name in the Nexudus GUI under Operations > Customers > Members & contacts, and their ID might be under Account > Identifiers > Tag. If it's not there, you can find their email address under Account > Account Details and use the coworkers API above to find their ID. There are a lot of different IDs in each coworker record, you want the one that is simply "Id".)  To search for all office spaces: https://spaces.nexudus.com/api/sys/floorplandesks?page=1&size=50
column68: ##### No Longer Receiving New Bookings #####  If the Fusion is no longer receiving booking notifications from Nexudus (no new SCGs are being created for each booking), this means the Webhook in Nexudus has been disabled. Nexudus tries a webhook 10 times, and if it fails (could fail due to a timeout, if the Fusion goes offline, or a fatal 500 error, if the custom portal code is broken), it automatically disables that webhook, and it needs to be manually reactivated.   To investigate the cause of the disabling, and to reactivate the webhooks, navigate to Settings > Show advanced settings > Integrations > Webhooks in the Nexudus GUI. The two webhooks we have configured are "Fusion - Booking Created" and "Fusion - Booking Updated". You can see their status, Active or Disabled, right in the list. If they are disabled, click on the name of the webhook and look at the "Last error" field. Whatever it says will need to be resolved before reactiviting the webhook, or it will just fail again. After you have resolved the issue, switch the "Active" toggle to on and save changes. Do this for each disabled webhook.  ##### Issues with the Captive Portal #####  To investigate issues with the captive portal, including log in issues, QR code retreival issues from the in-room tablets, QR code scan issues, and issues with receiving bookings, navigate to Archives > .log Files > HTTP (prod) and search for HISLog in the "Filter field" [use HTTP (dev) if the Fusion is running in development mode]. To look at log messages live, SSH into the Fusion and run "tfpro | grep HISLog" (or "tfdev | grep HISLog" if in development mode).  ##### Issues with Backend Scripts/Notification Actions #####  To investigate issues with any Backend Scripts, the first place to look is Output column under Services > Notifications > Backend Scripts. This will show you the output the last time the script ran. A couple of these scripts run every 1 to 5 minutes, so that gets overwritten quite frequently. If you need to look at more historical data, each Backend Script includes data on how to search for that scripts logs, such as "go to Archives > .log Files > Background Jobs and Filter by 'Nexudus Booking'"

column66: This property is managed by the Hargray Communications group. All APs have a Layer 2 connection to the controller. The Traffic is tunneled through the controller to their data center and the devices get internet through what they called "Cisco Core Router" We do not have access to that router and escalation to this group will be needed in case of any issues related to it. The Aruba controller is also the DHCP server for all devices.  Elite Resort Group ERG POC 1: Sylvie Moore | smoore@erghhi.com Phone: 617-784-3626 ERG POC 2: Andy Fere Phone: 843-422-5790
column68: ***NOTE: Password would change every 3 months depending on the season*** ***NOTE: Hargray Communications has rebranded to Sparklight***  Escalation Policy for NOC for Sparklight Properties:  Property list:  - Coral Reef - Coral Sands - Island Links - Palmera Inn & Suites - Port O Call  These locations are all located at Hilton Head Island in South Carolina. They are all managed by a single Aruba Central controller.  ------------------------------------------------------------------ Common Cases Troubleshooting Notes: (check Policy in CRM Docs) ------------------------------------------------------------------ In the following cases, an escalation should be opened with Sparklight:  1- A guest issue is unable to be resolved due to down equipment 2- Multiple access points down  Steps:   1 - NOC agents should create a freshdesk ticket and call Sparklight TCC at the following number:- Sparklight TCC: 843-686-1138,  2- In the case of no response: report of “Down APs” is emailed to hargray_repair@htc.hargray.com; hargray-wi-fiengineering@cableone.biz ; cableone-enterprisesalesengineering@cableone.biz; EnterpriseServiceOperations@sparklight.biz; Albert.McGraw@sparklight.biz smoore@erghhi.com; afera@erghhi.com; itmanager@palmeravacationclub.com  ------------------------------------------------------------------ Network Outage Cases Troubleshooting Notes:  (check Policy in CRM Docs) ------------------------------------------------------------------ In the case of an outage with the Aruba Central controller, NOC agents should create a freshdesk ticket and escalate to Sparklight NOC:  1- Hargray NOC: 843-686-1158  2- In the case of no response from Sparklight TCC or Sparklight NOC the following escalation list can be called: 	- Sparklight Sales Engineer Manager: John Gallagher 843-684-0171  For both scenarios:   NOC agents should provide a ticket number for the issue (freshdesk ticket) and explain the purpose of the escaltion.  Please note:  - We can only monitor the access points at these locations, so don't have access to their switches or routers. - At no time should agents identify to end customers as "Touchstone1". We are operating as "Sparklight". column66: First HA 2.0 deployment by HIS. This is similar to a traditional Cluster + Nodes setup with some additions.   Physical hardware: Like any HA setup this setup has more than 1 physical machines for Fusions for redundancy purposes. This particular cluster has 2 physical Dell R640 servers on-site. Each R640 has Fusion Cluster Controller and 2 Nodes installed on it. This is done using VMWare ESXi. There is also a third machine (that will be a physical machine in the future) that will carry 1 functions of what is called a Witness Node. Witness Node funtion is not to route traffic, but to participate in a quorum to determine which Cluster (CC + Nodes) will be the working cluster.  CC: In this setup there are 2 Cluster Controllers (CC) - Primary and Secondary. CCs constantly sync databases between each other. If one CC goes down, the other will take over and the setup will continue working. for the sake of differentiation we call CC-A the primary Cluster Controller and CC-B the secondary Cluster Controller.  Nodes: There are 4 nodes that route traffic (just like traditional setup) and  a new Node that we call Witness. Witness node (eventually) will be located on a separate hardware. It is a Fusion that does no guest traffic routing. It is simply there to witness the failure and participate in a fail-over process as a voting machine (witness of the failing cluster).

column66: The La Terrace & La Plage properties are included under this account although network devices are connected to the same network.  La Terrace:   The IDF is located on the ground level. APs are mounted in the rooms. Network connections are via POE Type A. A jumper cable connects the switch to the 110 phone block using the Orange & Green cable pairs. CAT 5 cable goes to each room which supports phone and now POE data. LAN speeds to AP are up to 100mbps.   Certain units are owned by individuals. Client told us not to install APs in these units so they were not.   La Plage:  This building uses SMC VDSL connection to rooms. Main line generally comes into room via the bedroom. Network cable goes from SMC into POE injector then out (POE Type A) to AP in living room. Blue pair used to connect telephone. Rooms in this building have all concrete walls.

column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the Mikrotik using Winbox Software. 2. Ask to the person onsite to disconnect LAN1 cable from the Fusion (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 3. Change the IP address for MGMT Network (Native on Eth2). Go to IP/Addresses, select the MGMT Network doing Double-Click and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 4. Also enable DHCP Server for MGMT. Go to IP/DHCP Server and double click on MGMT DHCP, then click on "Enable" button. 5. On the Mikrotik Interfaces Tab, enable VLAN 200 and VLAN 201 doing Double Click on each VLAN and click the "Enable" button.  In case Mikrotik local connection is need it use ETH5 ---- http://192.168.88.1 ---- admin / GsquidPineapplejelly7&  Notes: - To access the Master Unleashed, use the link: https://50.250.52.180:60050 - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Guest Wi-Fi Vlan 200, Private-ATLAS Vlan 201   - According to Raundy with the HIS installations Team, the Netgear switches at this property are dumb switches which means there is not a way to access them or monitor them (Odari 08-23-23)

column66: This is a large deployment with different AP models (including T300s) located in different areas of the property. IDFs are connected via fiber and all APs have wired connections (no meshing). A management SSID is broadcasted throughout the property. There is an extensive use of vlans throughout the network which enable specific uses for each SSID.   Guest access SSID's require registered guests to input name & room number to access the basic free connection of 256k. Guest can logout by going to www.upgrade. com and should they choose to purchase higher speed connection during their stay.   Sonesta Maho Beach Resort & Casino Guest Wireless Internet Installation Project 	  Given the wide scope of the project, its overviews and installation plans have been broken down into logical segments and laid out in the general sequence in which they expected to be completed.  Vlan Setup!  Vlan 1000 – Wifi Management – 10.60.30.1/23 Vlan 1100 – For Maho Beach and Ocean Point (SSID will be Sonesta WiFi) – 10.60.110.1/22 Vlan 1200 – For La Terrace and La Plage (SSID will be Royal Islander WiFi) – 10.60.120.1/22 Vlan 1300 – For Casino (SSID will be Casino Wifi) – 10.60.130.1/24 Vlan 1400 – For Meeting Rooms (SSID Will be Convention WiFi) – 10.60.140.1/23 Maho Beach (Old Sky Tower)  Installation Plan: Install property infrastructure equipment in the 2nd floor MDF: Fusion RS2000 HP ProCurve 3500-24G-PoE yl Switch (J8692A) Ruckus ZoneDirector 3000, with 450 AP license  This equipment will be connected via fiber to all major property sections: Ocean Point La Plage Casino – (Will use his current switch which is POE to feed our AP’s.) La Terrace   The pre-exiting fiber to these locations is single-mode terminated to SC. 15m LC/SC patch cables are required between the HP ProCurve 3500 and the SC connections. (x3)  The property infrastructure equipment will: serve as the Internet gateway for all guest traffic, provide centralized authentication for all network users, provide centralized management for all wireless access points, provide direct PoE power to three Ruckus 7372 access points located in the Sky Tower lobby (2) and Rainbow A room (1), provide data uplink for the Oasis Pool Bar Ruckus 7762 access point, provide data uplink to the Sky Tower 5th floor IDF.  Within the Sky Tower, all guest room wireless access point cabling will terminate to patch panels in the 5th floor IDF. Two HP ProCurve 48-Port PoE switches will be installed in an enclosed wall-mount rack, with patch cables connected to the patch panels. Copper provides the uplink from the 5th floor IDF to the 2nd floor MDF.  The guest room access points will be installed in the hallways on each floor, floors 1 through 10, in the following quantities: 	Floors 1 – 2: 	4 access points each 	Floors 3 – 8: 	10 access points each 	Floor 9: 	7 access points 	Floor 10: 	5 access points  Sky Tower Equipment List: 	Infrastructure (1)	Fusion RS2000 (1)	HP ProCurve 3500-24G-PoE yl Switch (J8692A) (1)	Ruckus ZoneDirector 3000, with 450 AP license (3) 15m LC/SC Single-Mode Fiber Patch Cables (3) HP X121 1G SFP LC LX Transceiver (J4859C) Guest Rooms (2)	HP ProCurve 2530-48G-PoE+ Switch (J9772A) (3)	Ruckus ZoneFlex 7372 WAP (1)	Ruckus ZoneFlex T300 802.11ac WAP (80) Ruckus ZoneFlex 7352 WAP (40) Cat5e Patch Cables – (3foot) (40) Cat5e Patch Cables	- (2 foot)  (1) Enclosed Wall-Mount Rack	  Out-of-Scope Action Items: •	Install all required data cable from the 5th floor IDF to all access point drops indicated in the property maps provided by the site surveyor.    Casino  Installation Plan: Fiber from the MDF to this building terminates in the accounting room IDF. Within this IDF will be installed an HP ProCurve 2530-8G-PoE+ switch with a 5m LC/SC single-mode fiber patch cable. The HP switch will provide direct PoE power to the following access points:  (When I last spoke to Hubb he said that we could just use his Switch and tag our vlans through there. I don’t know if this is still accurate)  	Middle of the gaming floor – Ruckus ZoneFlex 7372 WAP (Should by a 7982) 	Theater area behind casino – Ruckus ZoneFlex 7372 WAP  Hotel Internet Services will run the Cat5e cable that feeds these access points.  Casino Equipment List: (1) HP ProCurve 2530-8G-PoE+ Switch (J9774A) – NOT NEEDED (1) 5m LC/SC Single-Mode Fiber Patch Cable – NOT NEEDED (1) HP X121 1G SFP LC LX Transceiver (J4859C) – NOT NEEDED (2) Ruckus ZoneFlex 7372 WAP  Casino Authentication The casinoaccess Custom Portal is directly integrated with the property's Nexio system, which is their player management system. When a user enters their player number and email into the portal page, we verify that information against what is stored in Nexio, and if it matches, we log the user in with a Shared Credential of "internet". If the data doesn't match or the player is expired, we return the appropriate error message in the portal page.  The credential we were provided to test the Nexio integration is: 101237/mkeys@playmaho.com  Ocean Point:  Installation Plan: This building is currently undergoing remodeling.  Fiber from the MDF to this building terminates in the 1st floor IDF located near the convention area. Within this IDF will be installed an HP ProCurve 2530-24G-PoE+ switch with a 5m LC/SC single-mode fiber patch cable. The HP switch will provide direct PoE power to the following access points:  	Ocean Terrace Restaurant – Ruckus ZoneFlex T300 802.11ac WAP 	Ocean Terrace Garden – Ruckus ZoneFlex T300 802.11ac WAP 	The Point Bar – Ruckus ZoneFlex T300 802.11ac WAP 	Royal Pavilion – Ruckus ZoneFlex 7372 WAP 	Bonaire – Ruckus ZoneFlex 7372 WAP 	Staff Kitchen Area – (4) Ruckus ZoneFlex 7372 WAPs 	Islander Room – Ruckus ZoneFlex 7982 WAP 	Maho Room – Ruckus ZoneFlex 7982 WAP  The 1st floor IDF will also provide data uplink to two other IDFs, locations to be determined, which will in turn house three HP ProCurve 2530-48G-PoE+ switches.  129 Ruckus ZoneFlex 7055 wall-plate wireless access points will be installed in rooms, direct PoE fed from the three HP ProCurve 2530-48G-PoE+ switches mentioned above. Exact room locations will be determined once remodeling is complete.  Ocean Point Equipment List: (1) HP ProCurve 2530-24G-PoE+ Switch (J9773A) (3) HP ProCurve 2530-48G-PoE+ Switch (J9772A) (1) 5m LC/SC Single-Mode Fiber Patch Cable (1) HP X121 1G SFP LC LX Transceiver (J4859C) (6) Ruckus ZoneFlex 7372 WAP (3) Ruckus ZoneFlex T300 802.11ac WAP (2) Ruckus ZoneFlex 7982 WAP (129) Ruckus ZoneFlex 7055 WAP (129) Cat5e Patch Cables – (2 ft) (3) Server Racks – (NOT NEEDED! Hubb is Putting them in)  Out-of-Scope Action Items: •	Install all required data cable from the appropriate rooms to pre-designated IDFs. •	Install all required cable from the 1st floor IDF to all other IDFs.    La Plage:  Installation Plan:  This building will get its feed via SM fiber from the MDF. Fiber from MDF terminates on 2nd floor Network Closet. From there we will need to do VDSL to Every Room on the 1st and 4th floors. We will be installing 2 AP’s per room. One AP will go in the Main Bedroom and the other AP will go in the living room. The AP in the Bedroom will receive the VDSL Signal. From there we will be coming out of the AP with a small patch cable that goes into a POE injector. From there we will need to run a Cat 5 cable coming out of the POE out port through a conduit that goes from the Bedroom to the Living room. Per Hubb this conduit already exists. Hubb wants us to ensure that we have a nice looking box for each room to put all of the Bedroom Equipment in. There are 28 rooms on floors 1 and 4. 4 is a bit smaller than 1, but the rooms are bigger. So I am taking the 2nd floor and doubling it. We may have to move a few AP’s from the 4th floor to cover the 3rd floor because this building tapers from top to bottom.   Note: This Building has an interesting floor layout. It goes:  Ground Floor 1st Floor – AP’s will go on this Floor 2nd Floor 3rd Floor 4th Floor – AP’s will go on this Floor 5th Floor   La Plage Equipment List:  (1)	HP ProCurve 2530-24G-PoE+ Switch (J9773A) (1)	10m LC/SC Single-Mode Fiber Patch Cable        (112) 7352 AP’s        (56)  SMC VDSL 2 CPE’s        (3)  SMC VDSL 2 Switches         (3)  66 Blocks         (3) 20 Foot Amphonal Cables.  ( Plz see what which kind we will need. I know that going into the VDSL switches you will need a Male side. When getting the 66 Blocks we need to get ones that already have the female ends on each side of the block. So if this is the case we will need Male to Male cables)        (56) Nice Boxes to hide Master Bedroom Equipment (Here is what is inside that box, Plug strip, AP,  AP Power Supply, POE injector and VDSL CPES)        (1) HP X121 1G SFP LC LX Transceiver (J4859C)        (2) Ruckus ZoneFlex T300 802.11ac WAP (For Pool Area)        (56) 1 foot Patch Cables. For SMC modem to AP. (Color doesn’t matter)        (56) 1/2 foot white patch cable.         (2) 1000 foot cat5e boxes (White)        (56) Ruckus Wireless AP Power Supply – For Bedroom AP.  La Terrace: This building will get its feed via SM fiber from the MDF. Fiber from MDF terminates In basement Network Closet. From there will we need to feed all AP’s via POE. They have cat 5 cable to each room. Currently one pair is being used. We will need to make a male end, plug that into our switch and on the other end will need to punch down to a 110 block in the IDF. From there we will need to go to room and take two pairs and punch it down to a female jack. From the Female jack we will feed AP with a white patch cable. We will need to have 2 outdoor AP’s that will run Back to the IDF. Cable is already there.   (1)	HP ProCurve 2530-48G-PoE+ Switch (J9772A) (1)	5m LC/SC Single-Mode Fiber Patch Cable (1)	HP X121 1G SFP LC LX Transceiver (J4859C) (28) 7352 Ruckus AP (1) 7372 Ruckus AP for the Lobby (2) Ruckus ZoneFlex T300 802.11ac WAP (28) Female Jacks Cat5e Leviton is the best        (28) 1 Foot White Patch Cables.

column67: MDF located on the 1st floors in the service area, behind the guest elevator and FD. There is a security at the FD 24/7, so there should be no issue getting inside.  Fusion, ZD, Core Switch and a WPS are in the this room. The Fiber feed (WAN1) comes from another building via 10G fiber line. The backup modem (WAN2) is behind the Fusion plugged directly in to it.  There are IDFs about every 3rd floor.  There are 2 distribution IDFs, on 12 and 33 that are fed via 1G fiber. There rest of the IDFs feed from 12 or 33 via CAT6. There are 2 Ethernet cables available to each IDF. Also, there is spare fiber to IDFs.
column68: There is no portal page at this property.  Each unit has their own AP and SSID, with a WPA2 password.  If a resident calls and and wants to change this password then it is ok for them to do that.  There is an 8 character minimum for a wpa2 key.  These passwords are changed in the ZoneDirector by going to Configure > WLANs, and editing the SSID that goes to their unit.  There is a section called Passphrase once you are editing the WLAN, and that is where the WPA2 key is changed.  There is poor cell phone reception (not wifi) in this building.  If a resident calls in complaining that they are having problems with making calls on their cell phone then they should be instructed to enable wifi calling on their phone, and to connect to the SSID that is in their unit.  If caller already has their phone on WiFi calling and gets dropped often, have them set their phones on Airplane Mode, turn wifi on and connect to their SSID. This should remedy the dropping of calls. If the caller continues to have problems with their phone calls after enabling wifi calling and/or Airplane Mode, then the case should be escalated to NOC.  ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** The Mikrotik is connected as follow: WAN-ETH1 on CoreSW port 1/1/21 LAN-ETH2  on CoreSW port 1/1/22   Cutover Steps 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 38.142.118.156 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=admin 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: lib3rty 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN1 (ports 1/1/24) and Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/1/4) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT-VLAN100 and change the IP address from 172.16.1.254/23 to 172.16.0.1/23 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100,200-203, 205-206, 300-682, 800, 850 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH13/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.208.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.208.1 on the browser. *******************************************************************************

column66: ---------------------------------------------------- Before this upgrade the ISP was through a 5 Port Netgear non managed switch and them to the Fusion. Now we connected the ISP directly to the Core switch (using VLAN 900 to provide Public IP addresses to all equipment needed). The property now has a backup gateway (Mikrotik), We installed also a Watt-Box. MDF: In the Core Switch we connected the APs for the basement, lobby and conference room. We also connected a hard line in the Core Switch from the Office-1 in Lobby area. IDF-1: First floor to feed 4x APs supporting the First floor. IDF-2: Second floor to feed 17x APs supporting the 2nd, 3rd floors.  IDF-5: Five floor to feed 27x APs supporting the 4th, 5th, 6th floors. IDF-8: Eighth floor to feed 30x APs support the 7th, 8th, 9th floors. All the Uplink cables coming from the MDF core switch. ----------------------------------------------------
column67: ---------------------------------------------------- All the APs in the Rooms are above the door. (Check Network Diagram for specific Rooms). -We re-built the MDF located on the Basement Server Room (1xFusion, 1xBrocade SW 7250-24P, 1xMikrotik backup Router, 1xWattBox, 1xUPS). --Two new APs were installed on the Basement: One located in the Lunch Room, and the other one in the Hallway by Engineer office.  --Two APs were replaced: One in the lobby area and the other in the Conference room. -We installed a new IDF-1 in 1st Floor (House Keeping Closet) feeding the Four APs that cover rooms in first floor.  All this APs are in the Hallway (Check Network Diagram for specific locations). -We re-built IDF-2 on 2nd Floor on Closet by Room-207 (1xBrocade SW 7150-12P, 1xUPS).     -We re-built IDF-5 on 5th Floor on Closet by Room-507 (1xBrocade SW 7150-24P,  1xBrocade SW 7150-12P, 1xUPS).     -We re-built IDF-8 on 8th Floor on Closet by Room-807 (1xBrocade SW 7150-24P,  1xBrocade SW 7150-12P, 1xUPS).  ----------------------------------------------------
column68: IF FUSION FAIL!!! ---------------------------------------------------- We have an Spare Gateway onsite: Mikrotik using different Public IP address --- 50.204.239.149 How to pass the traffic over the Mikrotik? 1. Login into the Mikrotik using WinBox Software. 2. Go over: Interfaces/Ethernet 3. Double Click on LAN/Eth2 and enable the Interface, then Apply. 4. At this moment you can have access to the core SW via SSH through the Mikrotik. 5. Do ssh on the CoreSW (172.16.30.10) through the Mikrotik. 6. Disable the port on CoreSW for Fusion LAN. 7. Verify you are getting ARP and check with someone onsite that the WiFi services is working.  All the SWs have Radius Authentication Login Active  Comcast recommends the following on the device attached to their device: Customer Device Turn-up Information: On the customer device connected to the Comcast Service, Comcast recommends the following: •	Port set as a trunk port •	Speed hardcoded to 100 Mbps* (No auto-negotiation) *Except 1G or larger circuits •	Duplex hardcoded to Full (No auto-negotiation) •	Traffic Shaping/Policing - limit output rate at or below the bandwidth usage subscribed for that connection •	For ports supporting multiple EVCs, traffic will need to be tagged with a Comcast provided VLAN. Comcast is a layer 2 transport service which only allows for complete content transmission. ----------------------------------------------------

column68: ***IN EVENT OF OUTAGE*** Best point of contact is LHO.PT@loewshotels.com for the email address and for the phone number, you can call Kevin: +1 (407) 630-0035  Here they have 2 gateways (CCA and CCB). The property shares the SZs-144 (3 in a cluster) with Sapphire Fall  DP HA is enabled, if one box goes down the other box will take over all VLANs associated with it  Both Fusion's interfaces are the mirror copies of each other in terms of networking on the switches. Once the Backup Fusion is up and running, it will work exactly as the main one.  **where help is needed please email lho.pt@loewshotels.com which is our team email. This will ensure someone from the team can respond as quickly as possible.  **If HIS needs some to assist with PMS side of the interface for any hotel you can contact the Loews help desk as they have remote access the number is 877-748-1469**  The SNMP for some SWs works over the Sapphire Fall CCA (198.199.206.138 (51058-51072)) The SNMP for the rest of the SWs works over the Royal Pacific CCA (74.121.217.51 (51007-51057)

column68: The main ISP feed is StarLink. It is a satellite feed. The feed is on the 2nd floor IDF closet on the South [West side] the IDF cabinet has “2W” outside. The Device connected to the Dish is connected via ethernet to port 1/2/1 untag VLAN 901 on SW-IDF-2S-01. The WAN1 feed is DHCP on a public network 98.97.102.47 ip address assigned default gateway 98.97.96.1. Their plan is to add another dish and connect it to 1/2/2 of the same switch on VLAN 902 for WAN2. All the ports are set up for this already. The throughput varies up to 300 Mbps.  The GCI feed is 25/25 Mbps and will remain in place as an MGMT WAN3 to access all our equipment.  H510s are located above Hatches in from of the guestroom doorways. The pattern is every other door.   IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 65.74.42.186 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.69.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN3 is (1/2/2) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT 172.16.69.0/24 vlan 100" and change the IP address from 172.16.69.254/24 to 172.16.69.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: MGMT 172.16.69.0/24 vlan 100, Guest-WiFi 192.168.10.0/23 Vlan 200 (needs to be changed to enable) -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.
column70: GCI - www.gci.com/business GCI | BUSINESS TECHNICAL SUPPORT (BTS) – 24x7x365 = (800) 800-7754 Acct #: 1001373886 Other credentials: Phone: 907-581-3844 or Password: Salmon Fiber Static IPs:4 Available static public IP: 65.74.42.189 Subnet mask: 255.255.255.248 Default gateway: 65.74.42.185   Starlink Contact Number: Open Ticket through site/app Acct #: ACC-1555513-77531-13 Satellite IP Addresses: Starlink provides two IP policies, "default" and "public". The default IP configuration is Carrier Grade Network Address Translation (CGNAT) using private address space assigned to Starlink clients with DHCP from the 100.64.0.0/10 network.  Network Address Translation (NAT) translates between Starlink private and public IPs.  The Starlink public IP policy is an optional configuration available to Business and Maritime customers. A public IP is reachable from any device on the internet and is assigned to Starlink network clients using DHCP. Moving the Starlink to another location may cause the public IP to change. Starlink does not currently offer the ability for Residential or Roam customers to receive a public IP. The public IP option can be enabled from the account dashboard.  Each Starlink is allocated one IPv4 address and delegated a /56 IPv6 prefix for network clients. All Starlink network clients are assigned an IPv6 address if the router is IPv6 is capable. IPv6 is not supported on the early generation router in the Circular Starlink Kit.  The default IP policy using CGNAT blocks all inbound ports. Customers requiring inbound ports should consider products with a public IP option. The following outbound ports are blocked for all customers per information security best practices: TCP/25 (SMTP) and TCP/445 (SMB).  As Starlink continues to expand and upgrade our global internet service infrastructure and rollout new capabilities, some users may see different IP address behavior (for example, publicly routable addresses, IPv6, non-CGNAT).  v. column66: Internet Uplink comes from the Data center on the 2nd floor in the Cloister Building.  The uplink feeds our MDF located in the adjacent Telco Room.  Fusion is connected to Port 1 on of the core sw (SI-Telco-SW-2-MDF).  ZD is connected to Port 2 of the Core sw.  Core switch is connect on Port 28 to Port 2 on the Fiber SW (SI-Telco-FSW-2-MDF).  Fiber SW is connected to a fiber patch panel 1.  From there it goes to 1766 IDF to Fiber patch panel 1 port M1.  Fiber patch cord SC/LC MM to FSW (SI-1766-FSW-1-IDF) to port 1.  Port 2 on FSW goes to Port 28 on (SI-1766-SW-1-IDF) on a LC/LC MM fiber patch cord.  FSW Port 2 is connected to Panel 3 prt D1 DF2 IDF with SC/LC fiber patch cord MM.  From 1766 IDF fiber goes from Panel 3 port D1 to DF2 IDF Panel 1 J2.   DF2 IDF panel 1 to FSW (SI-DF2-FSW-1-IDF) port 1.  FSW Port 2 is connected to 24-Port AP SW on port 28.  FSW port 3 is connected to SI-DF2-SW1 port 48.  FSW port 4 is connected to SI-DF2-SW2 port 48.  FSW port 5 is connected to SI-DF2-SW3 port 48.  FSW port 6 is connected to SI-DF2-SW4 port 48.    1766 IDF panel 2 port F2 feeds Beach club IDF SC/SC SM fiber.  From Fiber patch panel in Beach Club IDF, it is connected to SI-Beach-1-IDF port 28.    1766 IDF Panel 2 Port H4 feeds Corn Barn, from the SI-Cornbarn-FSW-IDF 172.16.0.26 to Fiber patch panel pass thru located in the Electrical closet at the Shipping Docks.  From here the fiber is split from SC/SC MM to SI-Lodge-SW-1-IDF-228 which feeds SW 172.16.0.15 port 28, then there is a SC/SC SM to SI-Lodge-SW-1-IDF-237 172.16.0.14 port 28.  From the SI-Cornbarn-FSW-IDF  Port 3, there is a SM SC/SC to the SI-Retreat-SW-1-IDF 172.16.0.13 via SC/LC SM to port 28 on the switch.   VTP is running on the Cisco switches. The core switch is on server mode and the rest of the switches are on client mode, so when adding a VLAN to this network it would have be to be added in the core switch and it would be transfer to all the switches.  VTP Domian -- seaisland VTP password -- hotelw1f1

They are all managed by a single Aruba Central controller.  ------------------------------------------------------------------ Common Cases Troubleshooting Notes: (check Policy in CRM Docs) ------------------------------------------------------------------ In the following cases, an escalation should be opened with Sparklight:  1- A guest issue is unable to be resolved due to down equipment 2- Multiple access points down  Steps:   1 - NOC agents should create a freshdesk ticket and call Sparklight TCC at the following number:- Sparklight TCC: 843-686-1138,  2- In the case of no response: report of “Down APs” is emailed to hargray_repair@htc.hargray.com; hargray-wi-fiengineering@cableone.biz ; cableone-enterprisesalesengineering@cableone.biz; EnterpriseServiceOperations@sparklight.biz; Albert.McGraw@sparklight.biz smoore@erghhi.com; afera@erghhi.com; itmanager@palmeravacationclub.com  ------------------------------------------------------------------ Network Outage Cases Troubleshooting Notes:  (check Policy in CRM Docs) ------------------------------------------------------------------ In the case of an outage with the Aruba Central controller, NOC agents should create a freshdesk ticket and escalate to Sparklight NOC:  1- Sparklight NOC: 843-686-1158  2- In the case of no response from Sparklight TCC or Sparklight NOC the following escalation list can be called: 	- Sparklight Sales Engineer Manager: John Gallagher 843-684-0171  For both scenarios:   NOC agents should provide a ticket number for the issue (freshdesk ticket) and explain the purpose of the escaltion. The Camera System Server has static address: 192.168.102.126    IF FUSION FAIL --------------------------------------- How to move Access and Traffic over Mikrotik If Fusion Fail!!! --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1.	Identify port WAN1 on the back of the Fusion. Disconnect it and move it to Mikrotik WAN port (ETH1 in the front of the Mikrotik). 2.	Identify port LAN2 on the back of the Fusion. Disconnect it and move it to Mikrotik LAN port (ETH2 in the front of the Mikrotik). Please proceed with a power cycle. Unplug power for 20 seg and put it back.

column66: The MDF is located on the Sub cellar two floors below the ground level. From the MDF to every IDF there are 18 strands of MM 50/125 fiber. There is a 3800 series HP 24 ports SFP switch in the MDF that uplink every single switch in this building, so there isn't daisy chain here at all. All the IDFs have PoE Switches that feed our access points. Our network is also the backhaul for other different vendors/systems. Each vendor has its own VLAN and assigned ports, so be careful when configuring/moving/swapping switch ports; before doing so please see the port mapping document.  WAN 1 is connected to the Core Switch 10.60.30.10 VLAN 2000 WAN 2 is connected directly into the Fusion  Updated: 2-8-16 by Zach

column66: MDF Troubleshooting: - In the MDF we have all the cables for Bldg. D 1st,2nd,3rd,4th Floor. -All the cables run inside conduit 3/4. -We have APs in every other room. (see Network Diagram for more information) -From the MDF we run Fiber to IDF-North and IDF-South. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- IDF-North: -This IDF feeds all the 3BR Units in North side. (Bldgs. A,B,C) -All the cables run inside conduits 3/4. -This IDF has a Fiber Uplink from the MDF. (12 Strand OM3 50/125) -From here we run a Fiber for the Market-Restaurant (6 Strand OM3 50/125) ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- IDF-South: -This IDF feeds all the 3BR Units in South side. (Bldgs. E,F) -All the cables run inside conduits 3/4. -This IDF has a Fiber Uplink from the MDF. (6 Strand OM3 50/125) ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- IDF-Restaurant: -This IDF feeds 7x R550. (Restaurant, Kitchen and 4x Conference rooms) -This IDF has a Fiber Uplink from the IDF-North. (6 Strand OM3 50/125) ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- IDF-Executive-Office: -In this Bldg. we have the Pool, Executives offices and 2x Conference rooms. -Uplink from the MDF (Cat6 Cable) -From this IDF we feed the P2P sender to the Maintenance shop. -In this switch we have a connection from the Admin-SW with a port untagged on Vlan 800...  to put online 2x Phones in Maintenance Shop.  -To put this two phones online we use VLAN800. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- IDF-Maintenance-Shop: -We have the P2P receiver and the sender in the Executive Office Bldg.  -We have 2x R550 to cover all the area.  -In this switch we connect an uplink cable (untagged Vlan 800) to 1x Unifi 8Port switch to put online 2x Phones and 2x Computer (Admin-Network).  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 68.116.54.246 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.55.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN2 is (1/1/20) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt-172.16.55.1/24-VLAN100" and change the IP address from 172.16.55.2/24 to 172.16.55.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Admnin-Staff VLAN202, Conference VLAN300, Guest-WiFi VLAN200, Mgmt-172.16.55.1/24-VLAN100, Premium-Guest VLAN201 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.  Admin-Network: --------------------- They have an Admin network mostly running on Vlan1, for IP-Phones, wireless computers and register machines. We created a Dry vlan800 in our Guest-Network to interconnect the Admin-Network.... We had to do this configuration to keep alive their wireless devices since the old Cisco APs used to broadcast SSIDs for both (Guest and Admin), all the Cisco APs were disconnected from their SWs. We also create a WLAN: "DWS Private" on vlan800.

column66: There are two network backbones here. The main Fiber backbone connects all of the switch gear except the indoor pool switch connected by the air fiber link. there are 2 T300s one in the Waterpark on CAT6 and one at the Registration Pool connected via CAT6 and a pair of Nano beams there are  18 R510 all on CAT6 PoE. Building 22 also known as the Lofts has 8 R510 units in the hallway ceilings on the 1st and 3rd floors The other network is CMTS based C110s 58 units on each of 2 CMTS The CMTS on the North side of the resort in Building 2 and  includes the Presidential units. The south side is connected to the CMTS in the TV shack next to Building B and includes the south side lodge buildings.The C110 are a combination of cable modem and WAP
column67: Fusion, Smart Zone, Core Switch and WATT Box are upstairs in the Sales Center in the Telco Room  There are also IDFs in the registration/Activity center in the IT closet Building 22 on the 3rd floor electrical closet next to the elevator - The Waterpark IT room - Housekeeping Office - In door pool equipment room - Building 2 electrical closet and the TV shack next to Building B the old sales center also has an IDF that is not in use at this time
column68: 25 Aug 2022 by B Sims according to Mac Martin, Manager of Facilities Operations, Buildings E, F, G, H, L, and M are shut down. Steve Byrne would like to be copied on every support communication for this property.   Please use the following list of contacts when emailing the property about down AP's.   Contact Email Sydney Wooten swooten@holidayinnclub.com Matt Whitney mwhitney@holidayinnclub.com David Benson dbenson@holidayinnclub.com Chad Jackman cjackman@piratescay.com Steve Byrne sbyrne@orangelake.com  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ If there are a large number of down APs the CMTS should be checked for low SNR (anything less than 28 is considered low).  This can be done by SSHing to the CMTS and running the "show cable modem phy" command.  If the output does not provide a USSNR (dB) column but only returns one or two MAC addresses then the CMTS should be rebooted.  After the reboot give the CMTS about 15 minutes and then run the "show cable modem phy" command again.  The SNR should now be shown.  The cable modems that connect to the CMTS in building B (the Pace CMTS at 172.16.0.19) need a config file called config3.cfg which they pull from the Fusion via tftp. This file in saved in the backups section on the docs tab here in the CRM. If the modems are not able to get this file then they will stay in the init(o) state which can be viewed from the CLI of the cmts using the "show cable modem" command. I had to reload this file into the Fusion after doing a backup restore because the backup did not contain the config3.cfg file in the tftp directory. -Walter 5/31/24  If the Blonder Tongue CMTS is reset to factory a config file needs to be loaded into the CMTS in addition to re entering the configuration. The file on the Docs tab in the CRM called D_full_255.cfg is the config file that needs to be loaded. There is also a backup of the config saved on the Docs tab. The factory default IP of the CMTS is 192.168.168.100. I have given the Fusion an IP in that subnet so that if the CMTS is reset to factory we should be able tor each the CMTS via the CLI. -Walter 8/29/24

column66: Zone Director - 10.60.30.5 - CaP_WiFi_1  This is a SMC VDSL 2 Setup. From the MDF we have AP's located throughout the property. From the CPE we plug the AP's directly into it. These AP's and CPE's are located under the Couches and for outdoor will be inside of a cabin attached to the rear sight of buildings 8, 7, 6, 1. We used the Electrical Outlet behind the Couch so unplugging shouldn't really be an issue.  Zone Director - 10.61.32.5 - CaP_WiFi_2  This system is distributed via Ubiquiti backbone beginning from the registration building. Receivers & AP are mounted on lightpoles on the street. Other AP's are connected via mesh connections.  NOTE:  There are 2 SSID’s at this Property. The reason for this was because we wanted to know what Guests are connecting to what AP’s.  ZD – 10.60.30.5 – Controlling all 7372's and T300's (CaP_WiFi_1) ZD -  10.61.32.5 – Was controlling all 2741 & 2942's (CaP_WiFi_2)  Both Networks are handing out the same DHCP Addresses. They both have the same Portal page and same UN and PW Credentials.  PLEASE DON’T UPGRADE THE ZD FIRMWARE ON THE 10.61.32.5 ZD. IF YOU HAVE QUESTIONS PLEASE CALL ME ON THIS. (It is not supporting any APs right now).  Raundy Llanes.
column67: MDF is located in back room in the registration building. They have the 2 ZD's, Fusion, Modems, 2 SMC VDSL Switches and 3 Ubiquiti POE Injectors in that Room. Kahou - IT Manager has a Key to that Room.  Outdoor AP's are mounted on lightpoles on the street & in back of buildings 8, 7,  6, 1 near center of building. Indoor AP's are located In the Rooms. These would be the 7372 AP's. See ZD and Equipment list for each AP Location.  The VDSL CPE's are located in the Rooms and for outdoor will be inside of a cabin attached to the rear sight of buildings 8, 7, 6, 1. Majority of them are either Under the Couch or Mounted behind the Couch.  I left Kahou 1 Additional T300 AP preconfigured auto, able to mesh as soon as they are plugged in. I also left to her 1 Ubiquiti Nanobean 5AC Ge2, and 1 extra PoE Injector for T300 AP. I left them in the MDF area.
column68: For down APs or any assistance at the property email the following people... Kehau - cacob@cliffsatprinceville.com Glenda Diego - gdiego@cliffsatprinceville.com Theresa Yadao - tyadao@cliffsatprinceville.com Blake Conant  - bconant@cliffsatprinceville.com  Be alert to the fact that T300reds will mesh when a PtoP link goes down. If the PtoP still has power, Nagios can access the PtoP through the meshed AP which makes it look at first that the PtoP links are up. Use the GUI on the PtoP to verify.   Also, in the last 4 years, the hose clamps holding the PtoPs to the poles rushed and broke. The PtoPs then went out of alinement. Always have engineering check if the PtoP is pointing in the right direction when suspicious of a linking problem between PtoPs.

column66: This system uses H500 APs mounted in rooms using existing wired connections. APs are mounted on the wall behind the desk. The phone line goes into the H500. Wired connection terminate in the MDF in the garage. Yellow cables were used to connect specific rooms to the network equipment. Black cables were used for hard wired connections and red cables were used for uplinks between devices. All floors have APs installed in a staggered format.   System was setup so that 5ghz is the primary band to be used. Floors 2, 5 & 9 have default setting on them while other floors are in separate AP group.  Meeting room and restaurant space connections terminate in the 2nd floor IDF. Meeting room wired connection (M03A & M03B) terminate in MDF. They are plugged into ports 37 & 38 of wired room switch. See Equip List for details.

column66: From the MDF there is iether VDSL or Fiber going to IDFs. Then the majority of the APs are PoE fed through a PoE  switch. There are 4 APs that are fed via PoE injector or power adapter: MDF, Old FD outdoor, Foundry Ballroom Mesh, and the Melting Point.
column67: Fusion, ZD, MDF AP, Core SW, Web power switch, Enable-IT Ethernet extenders (to HK, FC, Admin/Suites BLDG), and Fiber media converter are locate in the MDF in the old FD Building. There are two APs in this building one inside the MDF in top of the rack and the other is an outdoor AP mounted on the southwest wall of the building.  There is one IDF in building B second floor storage by room 219. The switch is mounted on the back wall. (10.60.30.11).  There is one IDF in building C second floor house keeping room. The switch (10.60.30.12) is mounted on the side wall near the ceiling and the Enable-IT Ethernet extender is located on top of the shelve.  All the APs in buildings A, B, & C were installed on the ceiling inside the guestrooms. (See equipment list for locations)  There is one IDF in the Fitness Center inside the water heater closet. The 8 port switch (10.60.30.13), fitness center AP, and Enable-IT extender are located on top of a shelve. There are two more APs in this building (Hoyt Hose) that were installed in the attic (Suite 404 and Paviling).  There is one IDF in the 1st floor admin/suites building storage right before the admin office. The 8 port switch and Enable-IT extender are mounted on a wall mount rack. There are 5 APs in this building the Suites APs were installed on the second floor attic and the office APs were installed on the drop ceiling.  There is one IDF under the stairs, closet on the left before you go in to Galleria 1. There are 4 APs coming from this IDF. Galleria 2 and Terrace outdoor are directly connected to the switch then Foundry Ballroom is a mesh from the outdoor AP and also the lobby AP is fed from this same AP PoE out.  The Melting Point AP is on the Drop Ceiling Kitchen area.

column68: 10.7.254.232 Pavilion Switch is in Pavilion under the power drop  ***CONFERENCE SETUP*** From time to time you will receive a call from PSAV at this property to enable certain SSID for guest rooms. This is for a special setup for convention services. They use rooms for overflow/special setup for convention inside guest rooms. The rooms that are used for this purpose: 11xx 7xxx 8xxx  We have a special group for these WAP inside the SmartZone. Here are the steps to accommodate the special requests: 1. PSAV creates SSID in the conference tool (it must be active before you can do anything!) 2. They call us to add the SSID they have setup. In order to know which SSID to add, they need to provide the SSID name. 3. Go to Smartzone-> Wireless LANs -> Conference Zone -> default 4. Check if the SSID exists. Also, get the VLAN 5. Go to Smartzone-> Wireless LANs -> Default Zone -> Guest/Conference 6. Create same SSID with the same name and VLAN as the one they reported (can be checked under Conference Zone) 5. Have PSAV test it ********************************** IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(10.7.254.254) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/1/15, which is connected to the Fusion LAN1 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "Switch Management" located on the dashboard tab "All" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 10.7.0.2/16 to 10.7.0.1/16.  - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: VLAN7-Switch Management, VLAN8-AP-Management, Loews_Conf_01 VLAN 1101 to VLAN 1108, Loews_Conf_10 VLAN 1110, Conf-VLAN1112, lhservice-VLAN1200

column66: There are 3 IDFs and the MDF in this property. Here is the backhaul: WiFi bridge between the MDF and the Office Building IDF, outdoor cable between the MDF and the West building IDF, and a WiFi bridge between the West building IDF and the East building IDF. The majority of the APs are Motorola TW511 but there are also four standalone Ruckus 7372 for the West and East pools. Please see network diagram for details.
column67: The MDF (Fusion, HP core switch, and Ubiquiti PoE injector, Wattbox, EdgeRouter) is located on the 3rd floor book keeping office of the West building.  Also outside the office on the sun deck is the Ubiquiti Building Bridge.  The West building IDF (West Motorola DSLAM and Enable-IT CPE/CO) is located in the meter room on the back of the West building. The East building IDF (Motorola East DSLAM and Enable-IT CPE) is located on the 2nd floor housekeeping room of the East building.  There is also the office IDF (Brocade SW) by the GM office on the East side.  On the south corner of the office building by the pool heaters there is the Ubiquiti Building Bridge.  The Motorola East DSLAM and the Motorola West DSLAM are connected through a UniFi Building Brige(West Building: located in the 3rd floor hallway, East Building: located in the parking lot by the front desk entrance)
column68: Ping Watchdog is running on the P2Ps. Please refer to the document "P2P Ping Watchdog Note Canada House Beach Club" in the Network Diagram section of Docs.   ************************************************************************************************* For the DSLAMs, if they are showing offline in Nagios but you can still ping them from the Fusion, then ssh to the DSLAM, remove the default gateway and then re add it. This should resolve the issue.  ************************************************************************************************* IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Telnet into the Core Switch(10.61.32.5) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/1/26, which is connected to the Fusion LAN1 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "LAN to Core-SW port 23" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 10.61.32.2/24 to 10.61.32.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "Equipment_LAN-eth2" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: GuestWifi 1000, No_Portal 200, VisitorLAN 10

column66: The system is campus style property.  There is 1 main building, that is the office, and 7 building that have apartments in them. In order to deliver signal to the the apartment buildings Ubiquiti outdoor system is used. There is 4 senders on the main building (Access Point Mode) that act as point to multipoint. There are 7 receivers, 1 per building.   To provide internet access we have used 2 x 7352 Ruckus APs per building. That seems more than enough. The average signal strength per building is -55 dBi to -65 dBi.
column67: The APs are located in the attic above the units. The switches are located in the same attics as well by the attic hatches. The power line for the switches comes back to the breakers on the side of the building. The breaker can be reset to restart the equipment without going into the attic. All the breakers on every building is labeled with "WiFi" mark on them.  Ubiquity receivers on all the buildings are powered via POE injectors. The injectors plug in into the same plug as the switch. That means it can be restarted from the same breaker as the switches, on the side of the building.   MAIN BUILDING: There are 4 main Ubiquities that act as Point to Multipoint (Access Point Mode). The all terminate and powered from the MDF. Each individual Ubiquiti has a POE injector.  Fusion, ZD, Core Switch, Web Power Switch and POE injectors for Ubiquities are located in the MDF (storage room). The modems are at the Managers desk, right next door to the Storage room.

The Lobby AP is located in the drop Ceiling in front of the front desk, next to the security camera.
column68: ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 24.216.233.44 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LANx (port 1/1/37) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT-VLAN100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 20, 100, 200  -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************  MDF is on the 3rd floor of the hotel next to room 328.  The IPS feed comes from the Modem to Lucky7-CoreSW-MDF-3-1 (172.16.0.10)  on port 1/1/48.  We have 2 ICX 7150-48P Switches that are configured for APs and Hard-wired connections. Cambium xv 2-2 APs are being used in the 2nd-floor guest rooms. Please see the equipment list for the current Model APs and the Guest room deployment. The Cambium APs are on the wall behind the desk. The Hotel APs are connected to the first eight ports on the switches.  Ports 9-35 are configured for hard-wired connections.  These hard-wired ports are on VLAN 200, the Guest network.   Please note that all the Ethernet connections in the guest rooms go back to the MDF on the 3rd floor. I would also like to point out that after we did a 1:1 replacement of the APs, I have found that the signal test needs to be addressed.  Please see the signal test tab in the equipment list.   A 2nd-floor deployment will provide internet service to the hotel, but not efficiently.

column66: ************************On Monday, October 27, 2025.*******************  The old Aruba switches were replaced with three new Ruchus switches: two 48P-2x10G switches and one 48P-2x10G switch.  - The 48P-2x10G switches are stacked, and the third one was configured with a “Lag” connection. The connection between them is via fiber optics. - All IDF switches were replaced with Ruckus switches (ICX7150-24P-2x10G and ICX7150-C12P-2x10G). The connection between them is via fiber optic cable.  ***Fusion ***CoreSW (Stack of 2 Units) plus 1  Edge SW (24F) ***Local SmartZone100 ***Mikrotik Backup Gateway (Failover test was deployed) ***WattBox  This property had a Fortigate and a Nomadix doing the Firewall and Gateway for the Guest Network.  Both devices were replaced by the Fusion.  There are Two ISP circuits on site: Fusion and Mikrotik have IPs on both. ***Verizon, Fiber, Native VAN 901  --- High Priority ***Spectrum, COAX, Native VLAN 900  An SSID named "sbi" is running on VLAN 10 for the Office Network; the Fusion does not provide DHCP or DG for them; It's a Dry VLAN for us.  Client Experience: -------------------------- The SSIDs for the client (mohonk_conf   mohonk  MohonkDorms) are open, no WPA no portal page. The Fusion provides DHCP.  Bron replied to this on a ticket regarding some switches and our monitoring system: Let’s deprioritize through the winter. No need to call if any of these go out.  We’ll want to re-prioritize in May.  GRAN GOLF PICNIC WHITECEDARS *********************************************************************************************************************************

column66: This is an Unleashed Network of 28 Ruckus APs. On Main Server Run we have: Fusion, CoreSW, Mikrotik, WattBox  All the APs are connected to the CoreSW.  Old  deployment before WiFi Upgrade --- 04-26-2024 ------------------------------------------------------------------------ This hotel has a Unifi network and during the takeover, four APs (AP-RM-106, AP-RM-106, AP-RM-208, and AP-RM-212) were offline. Currently, the HIS Unifi cloud controller manages the 14 access points in the network. The network is simple, consisting of a Fusion and CoreSW located in the MDF. The Fusion WAN is connected to a Cisco WAN switch that does not pass through the CoreSW. Additionally, Fusion LAN 2 is connected to port 0/24 of the CoreSW.

column67: Clifton: GuestCast server is located in Cellar. Public IP's are coming from a 5-port unmanaged switch that is connected directly to the cable modem, that then feeds the edge router.  An uplink cable from the edge router feeds the LAN side of the network.  The Combast STB is connected to HDMI 1 and the Chromecast is connected HDMI2.     Collina: GuestCast server is located in the Living Room in the entertainment center. Public IP's are coming from a 5-port unmanaged switch that is connected directly to the cable modem that then feeds the edge router.  An uplink cable from the edge router feeds the LAN side of the network.  T
column68: Note: The property is called The Clifton Inn.  There are two separate buildings with two separate circuits and servers: Clifton and Collina.  Please see the Equipment List in the Docs Tab for specifics, but Clifton does not have room numbers--they are room names (a total of 15 rooms) Collina's rooms are numbered (a total of 5 rooms)  Both buildings use the Xfinity/Comcast remote. The remote has an Input button that is used to switch the input from TV to GuestCast.    If working with on site staff to power cycle equipment, reference attached pictures below in order to provide aid in identifying equipment. For example, the Fusion can be found in the image "fusion and unmanaged SW" it is at the top of that image labeled as "CI-GUESTCAST-MDF-1"

column66: -The Carlton Hotel has ten floors. The guest rooms are located from the 1st floor to the 9th floor. The 1st floor have  the lobby and restaurant. The basement contains the MDF, housekeeping supplies, and storage. -The property has a system for controlling the Door Locks, Key-Fobs called Saltos. -The Saltos are PoE hardwire to our SWs, the ports are untagged vlan 800, with internet access.
column67: The MDF is located in the basement level by the stairs. The ISP, our core switch, Fusion, MikroTik and NVR are also located here.  IDF-1 is located by RM 105. This IDF contains all the APs for the 1st Floor, including the APs for the lobby and restaurants.  IDF-2 is located by RM 208. This IDF contains all the APs for the 2nd Floor, including the cameras and the Saltos WAPs.  IDF-3 is located by RM 308. This IDF contains all the APs for the 3rd Floor, including the cameras and the Saltos WAPs.  IDF-4 is located by RM 408. This IDF contains all the APs for the 4th Floor, including the cameras and the Saltos WAPs.  IDF-5 is located by RM 508. This IDF contains all the APs for the 5th Floor, including the cameras and the Saltos WAPs.  IDF-6 is located by RM 608. This IDF contains all the APs for the 6th Floor, including the cameras and the Saltos WAPs.  IDF-7 is located by RM 708. This IDF contains all the APs for the 7th Floor, including the cameras and the Saltos WAPs.  IDF-8 is located by RM 808. This IDF contains all the APs for the 8th Floor, including the cameras and the Saltos WAPs.  IDF-9 is located by RM 908. This IDF contains all the APs for the 9th Floor, including the cameras and the Saltos WAPs.  The APs are located above the door in every other room. The Salto APs are situated in the hallways. All common areas APS are visible.

column16: Sonora Hotel LLC dba Hotel Lumberjack
column66: Hotel Lumberjack is actually TWO properties (Two Hotels): Lumberjack and Sonora. They are joined via P2P. BestComm Network Company Installed all the Core-Equipment including Aruba WAPs, ZyXEL SWs, Aruba P2P to join the Two properties. They did Wireless Cloud Controller. They provide us access to: (Wireless Cloud Controller, Master Aruba WAP, ZyXEL SWs, P2P). We need to be carefully when configure our provisions not to break all built on it.  Hotel Sonora Inn: ------------------------- The Guestcast Server is in this side. ---WAN1 Direct to ISP Modem ---IPMI Direct to ISP Modem ---LAN1 to Port-23 SW3 192.168.25.4 ---LAN2 to Port-24 SW3 192.168.25.4 We do DHCP for Guest-WiFi vlan 100.  Hotel Lumberjack Inn ----------------------------- We did provide and mount 34xTVs (33x50" and 1x43"). Samsung... We install 34xChromecast, only in this Lumberjack side. Chromecast Powered Up from USB port on TV and Connected to HDMI2 We do DHCP for Guest-WiFi vlan 300 We do DHCP for Chromecast Vlan 500
column67: The GuestCast Server is on MDF, basement Sonora. The Lumberjack is connected to the Sonora, where the MDF is located, via a P-to-P on the roof of the Sonora. Both the Lumberjack and Sonora are on the same physical network. TVs hanged to wall. Chromecasts    Physical Switches may be named deceivingly. SW-03 (192.168.25.3) is in the Lumberjack hotel across the street (connected by P2Ps) and SW-02 and SW-04 are in the MDF.  The core switch, SW—02, in the MDF ( in the Sonora Hotel) powers an HP P2P on Sonora roof which goes to an HP P2P on the side of the Lumberjack which is powered by SW-03 in the Lumberjack IDF (2nd floor). The P2P in Sonora MDF comes off port 24 in SW-02 (192.168.25.2) in the MDF. The P2P is on port 23 on switch SW-03 (192.168.25.3) in the Lumberack, just so you know.
column68: - Since Sonora and Hotel Lumberjack are on the same network, all Chromecast devices for both hotels are listed in 'Casting-Admin' under Hotel Lumberjack. -At completion of the install, all the Chromecast devices were tested and were casting but there are four rooms where the TV cable has not been run to the TV. During renovations, the furniture in all rooms was changed which made the TV coax cable jack no longer in the right position to connect to the new TV mounting locations. Four of these rooms still need a major handling by the general contractor to get the TV cable over to the new TV location in the room. Those rooms are: 204, 210,218,302 -Also, there is a TV channel issue in 306 and 312 where the higher number channels don't show due to weak signal. Room 306 doesn't show channels 72 to 86. Room 312 doesn't show channels from 56 to 86. This is most likely because the TV cable plant needs to be re-tuned. column66: This property has their own IT staff that will handle onsite maintenance. HIS is providing call center and monitoring.   This is a ruckus system. There are APs on every floor fed via POE. They have wired connections in the rooms. Switches have VLANs on them (1/room). Data is documented on wap list.
column67: ZD and Fusion are at the Carib Royale Resort, a sister hotel next door. The LAN is fed through a fiber line that connects the two buildings. 407-238-8066 is the number for their MIS department.   MDF: located in back room behind front desk.  IDF/Spider Room: located on 1st floor. This is where all the switches for the wired connections are and the uplink to the 5th floor IDF where the switch for the APs is located. IDF - 5th Fl This is where the POE switch for the AP's is located. It is mounted on the wall on a backboard.  APs - mounted in hallways. Currently on all floor but there are plans to move them so that there will be 4 aps/floor on odd # floors. Hotel staff will be doing this work.
column68: ***For suspected ISP outages an email should be sent to mis@cariberoyale.com explaining to them why you think there is an ISP issue (for example we lost access to all gateways). If there is no response to this email within 10 minutes then it is okay to contact the ISP. If the outage resolves then a follow up email must be sent to mis@cariberoyale.com letting them know that the network is now back online. Windstream should also be contacted again letting them know that we now have access to the equipment*** - Walter 6/5/19  In case of down equipment the local IT department, and Keith Folsom should be contacted mis@cariberoyale.com, 407-238-8066 Keith Folsom KFolsom@cariberoyale.com, 407.238.8445
