column66: This is mainly a Zebra VDSL based system with TW-522 APs providing Wfi for the guest rooms of the hotel. Because the owner also wanted the pool, "Barn" (a building down the hill from the main hotel with a guest room), and the lobby building meeting rooms covered, some of the old 7341s and a 7352 were used to cover these areas. The TW-522s that the 7341/7352s are connected to are essentially acting as CPEs connecting these Ruckus APs to the ZD using tunneling. But as well, the TW-522s are providing 2.4/5G signal as well as being a connection point for the Ruckus APs.      This property also recently had GuestCast installed. All the rooms now have a Chromecast device attached to HDMI2 (with the exception of three rooms that have the Chrome device on HDMI1 - see TV model by Room spreadsheet). The GuestCast Server is located in the MDF on the 2nd floor.
column67: The two ISP modems, Fusion, HP Core Switch, and Zebra TS524 DSLAM are located in the MDF, 2nd floor Maids Closet, between rooms 207 and 208. The phone blocks are in the housekeepers Laundry room directly below the 2nd floor MDF and there is a cable path from the MDF on the 2nd floor, to the phone blocks on the 1st floor.   There are twenty TW-522 AP/CPEs mounted in the rooms on the phone jacks plates as follows: 201 203 205 207 209 211 214 216 218 220 222 224 226 230 232 235 237 238 240 LobbyGuestPhone       There are an additional three TW-522 AP/CPEs mounted in the following locations that also have Ruckus 7341s or 7352s connected to them:  RestHostStation PoolPumpHse BarnStorRm   There is one Ruckus 7341 in the MDF connected directly to the Core switch.    There is one Ruckus 7341 in the Restaurant MESHed to the Bar 7341.
column68: The VGA connector on the back of Fusion is broken. If you wiggle it, you can briefly get a display on your monitor. Because of that, I used SSH to the Fusion CLI to access and modify IPMI.

column66: They have a fiber ISP feed that goes to the ISPs fiber switch. From that switch a cable goes to a 5-port TP-Link un-managed switch which then distributes the ISP feed to WAN2 of the Fusion and to their Admin Gateway. There is a Fusion and ZD in the MDF. The Core switch is in the 2nd floor closet and supplies POE power to the 2nd floor APs. There are 12 APs of which 1 are MESHing.     Of note is that their new time clock will be plugged into Core Switch port 21 on VLAN 800.
column67: The property recently got an upgrade, 30Jan15, where cable was run down the second floor hallway and all MESH APs in the rooms remounted in the hallways. The only MESH AP is the one in the 1st floor kitchenette. Unplug the MPI cable from the TV 2. With the LG remote, press the menu button until it locks up  3. Press 9876 Enter 4. Scroll up to Option 117  5. Press 413 Enter  6. Enter the password - 0413  7. Pull out the TV power plug for several seconds  8. Insert the USB stick with the MPIBTV flash file into the TV 9. Power on the TV  10. Select the correct TLX in the Wizard and flash the TV 11. Plug the MPI cable back into the TV

column66: ****VLAN 8 default gateway is the Core switch and VLAN 8 does not exist in the Fusion. VLAN 10 is the interconnect VLAN between the Fusion and the core switch****  The Fusion V10,000 is composed of one cluster controller and ten Fusion nodes. Node 1 is the gateway for the management, staff and public spaces networks. All equipment is reached via a port forward through Node1, including vSphere access to ESXI. Nodes 2-10 are for guest Wi-Fi. The SmartZone spreads guests across a VLAN pool of 1000-1008, and each Fusion Node from 2-10 is configured with just one of these VLANs. The Fusion has 6 physical ports: em0 - 10Gb SFP+ Port - WAN1 (Physically labeled "1") - This is the current WAN port for all Fusions em1 - 10Gb SFP+ Port - LAN1 (Physically labeled "2") - This is the current LAN port for all Fusions em2 - 1Gb Copper Port - WAN2 (Physically labeled "3") - This is currently unused em3 - 1Gb Copper Port - LAN2 (Physically labeled "4") - This port provides local access to the Cluster Controller. DHCP is provided in the 192.168.5.0/24 subnet. em4 - 10Gb SFP+ Port - WAN3 (No physical label. The top port of the additional NIC) - This is currently unused em5 - 10Gb SFP+ Port - LAN3 (No physical label. The bottom port of the additional NIC) - All cluster communication is on the native VLAN of this port, but passes between Fusions on the vSwitch and doesn't use the physical port. If any other networks are every added to this port, be sure to use VLAN tags, not native subnets assigned directly to the interface.  This property also has a cluster of three SmartZones. The leader is at 10.8.0.252 The followers are at 10.8.0.251 and 10.8.0.250

column66: ****VLAN 8 & 9 (AP MGMT) default gateway is the Core switch and they do not exist in the Fusion. VLAN 10 is the interconnect VLAN between the Fusion and the core switch**** RPR AND SFR APs ARE MANAGED THROUGH THIS FUSION****  The hardware in Visio (HA Fusion Diagram) shows what is needed in order to support a High Availability V12000 Fusion Cluster. The hardware consists of 2 computing Nodes (Main and Backup), Storage Server (SAN)  The Main Nodes are Dell R940 Blade Servers with 4xCPU in each and 250+GB RAM. They connect to SAN storage using SAS 12Gbps Cables. There are 2 SAS cables connected from each of the Nodes to SAN. Each SAS cable connects to a separate motherboard on the SAS.   This is a High Availability Cluster. This means if one Node, either Primary or Backup goes down, the Fusion VMs will boot up and will be ready to go on the other (working node) within couple of minutes.  In order for HA to work, it must meet one condition: SAN storage must be powered on and accessible by both Nodes.  This is required for the VMs to find it’s Hard Drive. In order to get into the SAN, you can port forward some of the IPs or use Windows VM to access it. (there is also Ubuntu Backup VMs on each of the nodes in the case of SAN failure).  ESXi License: 4563Q-0W140-Q8M81-0QC0H-287Q0 vCenter License: HM23N-09J80-L8T9C-0TAKH-90730

column66: IMPORTANT --DO NOT CONNECT WAN FUSION AND MIKROTIK AT SAME TIME (BOTH HAVE THE SAME IP ADDRESS)     Admin MDF is located on the 1st floor in Housekeeping office FTG MDF is located on the 3rd floor Utility room IDF are located on the following floors: 1st floor Housekeeping 2nd floor is on the 3rd floor connected to the core sw 3rd Floor Utility Closet 4th floor Utility Closet 5th floor Utility Closet 6th floor Utility Closet 7th floor Wine Closet  Cat6 Ethernet uplink to all IDF's from the FTG MDF on the 3rd Floor and up to the 7th floor via 3" diameter Riser Conduit. From the Admin MDF to the FTG MDF there is a Cat 6 Ethernet connection running thru the Fiber conduit.  It is a very difficult run with Fishtape, so i left a pull string just incase if we need to run another ethernet cable, please note that even with a pull string it will be difficult.  I created two access panels from the 1st floor Coat room to the Side of the Admin MDF.  Total length from the 1st floor coat room to the Admin MDF is approximately 115 FT.  Once in the Coat room there are 2-3" riser conduit that go all the way to the 7th floor. In the ADMIN MDF we have a Brocade 12 Port SW that is used to split the ISP feed so the Admin network gets a Public address and the FTG MDF will get a Public address.  The 1st floor AP's are connected to the Brocade SW (172.16.0.11) located in the Admin MDF/Housekeeping room.  The Gym AP is also connected to the same SW, you will see that the patch cord is connected to a RJ-45 Housing, that connection goes all the way to the Sales office in the adjacent building to the hotel.  There you will find Maintenance, Gym and the Sales office.  The Sales office Admin IDF is located in the back of the sales office.  there are at least 1 other ethernet connection labeled A46 that connects to the Admin MDF Patch panel in the Enclosure rack also labeled A46.  2nd Floor IDF is connected to the FTG MDF Core SW on the 3rd floor.  All patch panels are labeled from the 2nd floor to the 6th floor with the correct room numbers.  AIl IDF's have a home run ethernet connection to the Core SW.  Please note the Fiber connection from the ISP is located in the Coat Room on the First floor.  There are 3 pairs of Fiber that are terminated S/C only one pair is working, the other 2 pairs can be activated for a cost.  The 7th floor IDF does not have any guest rooms but the Bar and the Heritage Meeting Rooms are located here.  Guest Rooms AP location:  All Rooms that have an AP for example x01,x02,x04,x06,x07,x09,x11 are located under the Desk.  this is the same for all the floors with guest rooms.  The 7th floor does not have any guest rooms but the AP's there are specific locations for the AP.  Bar AP is located in the Storage room next to the bar entrance.  in the storage room there is a 2 door cooler and the AP is mounted on Top of this cooler towards the back against the wall.  Restroom AP is located outside the Heritage room above the ATM machine.  Heritage Room AP is located in the back of the Room on the left by the Glass wall right next to the phone.    Sonos Audio and Visual system:  The sonos system in the following areas are controlled with specific hidden SSID labeled : AHOK-Internal which is on the Admin network 192.168.200.x Vlan 800.  Lobby, Restaurant, and the Bar, This equipment can only be access via the SSID above. via staff only  Sonos for Guest usage in the following areas: to use this equipment the Guest will need to connect to the specific SSID (Heritage-Sonos or the Mesta-Sonos) Passwords are located above.  Mesta Room and the Heritage Room

column68: IF FUSION FAIL MOVE THE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Ask a Tech onsite to move the WAN-1 from the Fusion to the Mikrotik... Once have ping replay for the public IP: 24.248.246.83 ---(WAN1 back of the fusion to WAN front of the Mikrotik-ETH1) 2. Login into the Mikrotik via WinBox. WAN/Eth1 is connected to a Core-SW 3. From the Mikrotik do telnet into CoreSW, run: system / telnet 172.16.0.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: lib3rty 4. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port where the Fusion LAN1 to make sure it won't be traffic over the Fusion, notice LAN1. 5. Tag Vlans 200, 300,301,401 on Core SW port 1/1/37 where the Mikrotik-LAN is connected to.   6. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab (VLAN 200, 300, 301, 302, 401). 7. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the VLAN -100 and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 8. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.   Admin MDF is located on the 1st floor in Housekeeping office FTG MDF is located on the 3rd floor Utility room IDF are located on the following floors: 1st floor Housekeeping 2nd floor is on the 3rd floor connected to the core sw 3rd Floor Utility Closet 4th floor Utility Closet 5th floor Utility Closet 6th floor Utility Closet 7th floor Wine Closet  Cat6 Ethernet uplink to all IDF's from the FTG MDF on the 3rd Floor and up to the 7th floor via 3" diameter Riser Conduit. From the Admin MDF to the FTG MDF there is a Cat 6 Ethernet connection running thru the Fiber conduit.  It is a very difficult run with Fishtape, so i left a pull string just incase if we need to run another ethernet cable, please note that even with a pull string it will be difficult.  I created two access panels from the 1st floor Coat room to the Side of the Admin MDF.  Total length from the 1st floor coat room to the Admin MDF is approximately 115 FT.  Once in the Coat room there are 2-3" riser conduit that go all the way to the 7th floor. In the ADMIN MDF we have a Brocade 12 Port SW that is used to split the ISP feed so the Admin network gets a Public address and the FTG MDF will get a Public address.  The 1st floor AP's are connected to the Brocade SW (172.16.0.11) located in the Admin MDF/Housekeeping room.  The Gym AP is also connected to the same SW, you will see that the patch cord is connected to a RJ-45 Housing, that connection goes all the way to the Sales office in the adjacent building to the hotel.  There you will find Maintenance, Gym and the Sales office.  The Sales office Admin IDF is located in the back of the sales office.  there are at least 1 other ethernet connection labeled A46 that connects to the Admin MDF Patch panel in the Enclosure rack also labeled A46.  2nd Floor IDF is connected to the FTG MDF Core SW on the 3rd floor.  All patch panels are labeled from the 2nd floor to the 6th floor with the correct room numbers.  AIl IDF's have a home run ethernet connection to the Core SW.  Please note the Fiber connection from the ISP is located in the Coat Room on the First floor.  There are 3 pairs of Fiber that are terminated S/C only one pair is working, the other 2 pairs can be activated for a cost.  The 7th floor IDF does not have any guest rooms but the Bar and the Heritage Meeting Rooms are located here.  Guest Rooms AP location:  All Rooms that have an AP for example x01,x02,x04,x06,x07,x09,x11 are located under the Desk.  this is the same for all the floors with guest rooms.  The 7th floor does not have any guest rooms but the AP's there are specific locations for the AP.  Bar AP is located in the Storage room next to the bar entrance.  in the storage room there is a 2 door cooler and the AP is mounted on Top of this cooler towards the back against the wall.  Restroom AP is located outside the Heritage room above the ATM machine.  Heritage Room AP is located in the back of the Room on the left by the Glass wall right next to the phone.    Sonos Audio and Visual system:  The sonos system in the following areas are controlled with specific hidden SSID labeled : AHOK-Internal which is on the Admin network 192.168.200.x Vlan 800.  Lobby, Restaurant, and the Bar, This equipment can only be access via the SSID above. via staff only  Sonos for Guest usage in the following areas: to use this equipment the Guest will need to connect to the specific SSID (Heritage-Sonos or the Mesta-Sonos) Passwords are located above.  Mesta Room and the Heritage Room    There are 2 STB's in room 604, This is the only room with 2 boxes. As of 04/25/19 there are 55 total STB's at this property in BTV admin  PMS INFORMATION -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We have two PMS interfaces with their Opera System: Fusion, port 5013 BeyondTV, port 5099  The BeyondTV interface is running on the Caching Server as a local instance of PMS Proxy. The pms_proxy.ini file is stored in the Docs section in CRM, along with the version of PMS Proxy we're using (pmsproxy_springermiller). Use "supervisorctl status all" to see the status of PMS Proxy. Use "tail -f /var/log/pms_proxy/pms_proxy.log" to see live outputs of the PMS Proxy log. Hibox communicates to PMS Proxy via a port forward in the Fusion (56700 to 6700).   The Fusion and Caching Server are directly attached to the Admin Network (VLAN 800, 192.168.200.0/24). The Fusion has a static IP of 192.168.200.80. The Caching Server is on DHCP. The PMS interface computer is at 192.168.200.3.

column66: ***Update 8/9/2023 Alex Shalima*** The was a change to the Fusion setup here. Client has purchased an additional Fusion Gateway to achieve redundancy. Both Fusions are now installed in the new MIS Department Server Room (not the telephone room anymore).  Fusions are now running in Cluster mode. Fusion CCA is the primary Fusion and handles all the traffic. Fusion CCB is the backup device. ***************************************** CCB is working as a manual backup only. If CCA fails here is how you move the traffic to CCB: - Access CCB fusion:  https://sunsetmarquisccb.hotelwifi.com/admin - Go to network/LAN/Ethernet Interfaces and on the search box enter LAN2. The LAN2 interface for CCA and CCB will display. - Edit CCA LAN2 interface and uncheck all 7 VLANs and remove the 2 addresses (MGMT and Guest) and update - Edit CCB LAN2 interface and check all 7 VLANs and add the same 2 addresses (MGMT and Guest) that were removed from CCA and update - Go to network/LAN/Ethernet Interfaces and on the search box enter wan1 - pms. The WAN1 interface for CCA and CCB will display. - Edit CCA WAN1 interface and remove the ccA PMS LAN addresses and update - Edit CCB WAN1 interface and add the same address (ccA PMS LAN) that was removed from CCA and update - All LAN traffic is now through CCB.

column66: PMS is Opera now.  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ***OLD DATA*** ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We installed a Fusion at this location. Property had existing Ruckus WiFi and wired room connections. Property did not supply full documentation.  Each wired connection is on a separate VLAN, which equates to 1339 VLANs. There are also 16 Wireless VLANs - One for each of the three guest towers, eight for the common areas around their convention spaces, four for guest villas, and one for the pool and lobby area.  There is a vendor, SPA, that uses the Internet connection as well. They are on their own VLAN and they are not sent to a portal page.  The Pool AP has a "Cabana" WLAN with ZD Guest Pass authentication, so the subnet for that WLAN is passed through the Fusion portal page.  The property PMS is Agilysys' Visual One. We are interfaced with them through a Comtrol interface.
column67: We were not provided property maps showing exact locations of devices.  The Fusion, backup Fusion, Buena Vista Suites and the core switch for all of these are located in the MDF at Caribe Royale.
column68: ***For suspected ISP outages an email should be sent to mis@cariberoyale.com explaining to them why you think there is an ISP issue (for example we lost access to all gateways).  If there is no response to this email within 10 minutes then it is okay to contact the ISP.  If the outage resolves then a follow up email must be sent to mis@cariberoyale.com letting them know that the network is now back online.  Windstream should also be contacted again letting them know that we now have access to the equipment*** - Walter 6/5/19  A Cluster controller was added to this property this week. So now both Fusion are handling traffic simultaneously. Both Fusions have active DHCP service which ever response first to the request will get the session. All the configuration could be done from the cluster controller. At this point only the wireless VLANs were added to the backup Fusion. So if the primary Fusion goes down there would not be hardwired connections. Here is how you access the cluster controller:  When a guest calls for WiFi related issues and you are not able to resolve he issue, send an email to helpdesk@cariberoyale.com so one of the techs can assist the guest. Local IT phone # 407-238-8066.  From Caribe IT Dept Added 5/16/2017: "Please inform your staff that in some support cases we are installing these Linksys additional access points to eliminate customer complaints and usually only after we have been contacted.  There will only be three SSIDs. “ Tower1”, “Tower2” or” Tower3” coinciding with the tower that the guest is staying in.  Ask the guest if they see one of these SSIDs with 3 to 5 bars and if the bars are more than the Caribe SSID then they should be connecting to the Tower SSID.  If the guest isn’t present we leave a voice mail message so guests may or may not be getting the message."  Any room numbers that begin with a 3,4,5,6, or 7 will not have a wired connection. Please refer guests to the property's IT department if they are staying in one of those rooms and need a wired connection.

column66: Unifi Network with lots of mesh APs. P2Ps to each IDF
column67: MDF is located in the office be the FD above the storage closet. Here you will find the ATT router and Ciena fiber switch, Fusion, Ubiquiti Core switch, CloudKey and UPS.  Restroom 1 IDF is at the nearest restroom to the office. There is 1 switch and a UPS.  Barn IDF is north of Restroom 1 and has 1 switch.  Pool IDF east of Restroom 1 and also only has 1 switch. Restroom 2 is on the east side of the park. There is only one switch here. Cabin 98 IDF is located at camp site 98 and is on the west side of the cabin inside a weather proof box. There is one 8 port switch inside it with a small fan that is controlled by a heat sensor on the switch.   ~~P2P Bridges~~ P2P goes from Main Gate (MDF) to Site 5 (Restroom 1), Restroom 1 to Barn, Barn to Pool and Pool to Site 91/92 (Restroom 2). All of these are powered by PoE on the switches.   ~~Meshed AP's~~ Meshed AP's are located all throughout the park. See documentation for locations. The path in which they are connected can change depending on what AP's are online and line of sight.
column68: Call the main number and ask for maintenance to check on what equipment might be down. The meshed AP's are plugged into the power for the camp sites. So guests or staff might turn the power off without realizing it.  This is a Ubiquiti network with a CloudKey controller. Therefore any changes to the network need to be done through the Cloudkey via GUI.  ***P2P bridges are not controlled by the CloudKey*** Pool IDF has a lot of corrosion due to the pool and the chemicals. If the port fails its most likely due to corrosion and another port will need to be used. If the switch fails its also most likely sure to the corrosion from the pool.

column66: Solaire Venice Apartments:   -Student Apartments. All the apartments have 6 bedrooms except 101, which has 4 bedrooms. -We have 3 Brocade PoE SWs on the MDF. Two of them are ZP (they can allocate up to 90 Watts in a certain amount of ports) -We build a PoE IDF in every unit (no AC on the closets).  -Every IDF has: ** 1 x TP-Link PoE in / Poe out 5 Port SW fed from MDF via Cat6, to feed 2 x Ruckus APs and another TP-Link PoE in SW.  ** 1x TP-Link PoE in / not PoE out 8 Ports SW, fed from the SW above, to provide hardwire to every unit room. -All units have only 2 APs installed, Except the two-story units with 3 APs( 1 in the 1st FL and 2 on the 2nd FL). -We also run a new Cat6 hardwire to every bedroom.  -The community room and the rooftop have been covered with APs, too.  -The Staff is using the SSID name Peak -The Residents are using the SSID Solaire Venice Residents. Each resident has his code to connect their phones and other equipment.  -Every Resident has a dedicated VLAN associated with their account. -The guest can use the SSID Solaire Venice as a general guest.  -All the uplink cables go to the MDF. Only one cable goes to every unit except the two-story units with one per floor.   -------------------------------------------- Residents WiFi Experience -------------------------------------------- *Every Resident has account on the Fusion, based on a DPSK Code generated on the Fusion. *The account's name include: Last name, Name, and Unit number. Ex. albanojoseph203-5 --- Stands for Joseph Albano, Unit 203 room 5. *The DPSKs are associated with a VLAN from (201-320). The DPSKs are setup to be available during the leasing time. *A separated email was automatically generated by the Fusion to every single Resident providing the SSID name "Solaire Venice Residents" and the 16 Digits Access Code. *For support matters the Access Code can be verified by editing the Account on the Fusion. Identities/Accounts *In order to generate a new Account: ** We will need to re-load the import.csv file located on: Fusion root directory: /tmp/  ** Then trigger a located on Fusion Web Interface: Services/Notifications/Backend Scripts ----> Import Rent Roll --------------------------------------    ------------------------------------------------ ****** The user Access Code and Status can be verified by editing the Account on the Fusion. Identities/Accounts ** Account must be *Active* Always double check the Status of the account ****** ******  As an MDU Users need to be contacted directly,  do not call the property to transfer the call to residents ******  ------------------------------------------------
column67: MDF:  Garage Level - IT Room  APs -The APs are inside the unit on the left side of the Living room and the right side of the kitchen. -We have 1x R550 on the community RM and 2x Outdoor APs on the rooftop.
column68: *********Site is in the process of transitioning management companies over to UCLA Housing*********  Michelle - Property Manager. Austin - Assistant Manager.   ------------------------------------------------ ******For "Solaire Venice Residents" SSID, The user Access Code and Status can be verified by editing the Account on the Fusion. Identities/Accounts ** Account must be *Active* Always double check the Status of the account ****** ******As an MDU Users need to be contacted directly,  do not call the property to transfer the call to residents****** ------------------------------------------------  Most residents have a Wi-Fi extender (TP-Link) in their room to connect Laptops and consoles hardwire. -This devices are connected to our Wi-Fi. and some residents connect the devices to Residents SSID our Solaire Venice. -Only 1 cable goes from the MDF rack to every unit. And them they have Wi-Fi extenders (LINOVISION) to connect 2 APs with only 1 uplink cable. -If in the future we want to remove this Wi-Fi extenders from the APs. We need to separate the pair for the cat6 cable and connect our APs on 100M.   ********************************************************************************************** ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 76.53.115.13 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=yuor-radious-user 172.16.98.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/2/2) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.98.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.98.254/24 to 172.16.98.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. 8. Modify Residents SSID. Log into the vSZ / Wireless LANs / Partner Domain Peakmade / Domain Solaire Venice. Modify SSID "Solaire Venice Residents" by: 8.1 Disabling the Dynamic PSK option under Encryption Options 8.2 Turn OFF Accounting Service under Accounting Service.   Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200 and 401. -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **********************************************************************************************

column66: From the MDF in north building, fiber runs feeds all of the IDFs in the north and south building also. The IDFs has PoE switches what feeds the APs in the rooms. In the IDFs from the SW, patch cables connecting to patch panels. North bldg 2nd floor SW feeds the APs on the 2nd and 3rd floor and the 4th floor IDF's SW feeds the 4th and 5th floor APs via PoE type A (100 Mbps) through on each floor 110 blocks. The 110 blocks are located on each floor in the housekeeping unit by the elevator. The Lobby and the Basement level APs getting their feeds via PoE from the core SW in the MDF. The patch panel in the MDF is located in the ADMIN rack, which is in the same room as the HIS rack on the wall. Longer patch cables running from the ADMIN rack to the Core SW. In the South Bldg. the IDF's SW on the 2nd floor feeds the 2nd and the 3rd floor APs the same way as the north bldg, through on the 110 blocks. The 110 block are in the IDFs and for the 3rd floor right above the electrical rooms as the IDFs are. The IDF by the room 215 feeds the first half of the Bldg and the IDF by room 242 feeds the other half of the Bldg on both floors.
column67: MDF is in the North Bldg's (5 story) basement, close to the bathrooms. The FUSION, ZD, Core SW, Wattbox and the Fiber trays mounted in the rack on the wall in the 12 u wall mounting rack. The ISP is an Adtran fiber modem in the next room by our rack, Cat5e/6 cable running to the Core SW from it.  Brocade SWs and fiber junction boxes in the IDFs North bldg 2nd and 4th floor in the Housekeeping room by the elevators. The South Bldg IDFs are on the 2nd floor electrical closet next to room 215 and 242. APs in the rooms mounted on the wall by the telephone outlet.

column66: MDF: *We installed a Fusion at the MDF only to Manage Property SWs and Property APs, only vlan 200. That's is the only traffic over the Fusion. *They have a Gateway Sophos managed by another Network Vendor (Netcetera), this is the one handles all the DHCPs and traffic for the rest of the networks at the property.... See equipment list for detail.    *We installed a couple SZ144 on cluster with Local IPs on vlan 200 (MGMT) they are behind a 1:1 NAT configured on the Fusion. This 1:1 NAT guarantee the APs on the Cottages can reach the SZ.  Network Topology: -------------------------- *One part of the Property have Fiber backbone between Bldgs. surrounding the Clubhouse, also a couple  P2P Ubiquiti links. We can monitoring and have remote access to all these SWs and APs.  *The other part of the Property is what they called Cottages, they have each one a Spectrum Modem proving Internet access. We sold the SWs and APs for that part. SWs are default, everything in vlan1, they are direct connected to Modem, them form the SW all their connections (APs, PC, etc) We don't have access to the SWs, they are DHCP. The APs visible on SZ, they were provisioned from Main CoreSW to reach the Local SZ144. The SSID for the guest CabotGuest has to be Tunneled on VLAN70.  Important: ------------- The IT department was trained on how to configure SWs, APs, Fusion, SmartZone. Although they may need support eventually.  The IT department will report to us when new APs come online in order to add them to monitoring

column68: The RCA is an LG TV with LG components, so to go to the menu, you need to use an original LG remote. We also had to disable the HDMI-CEC. Please see the steps below:  To disable HDMI-CEC on your RCA TV, navigate to the TV's settings menu, find the System or Setup section, locate the HDMI-CEC or CEC option (it might be under a heading like "HDMI Control" or "EasyLink"), and then disable it  Detailed Steps:  1.	Access the Menu: Press the "Menu" or "Home" button on your RCA TV remote.  2.	Navigate to Settings: Use the arrow keys on your remote to find and select the "Settings" or "System" option.  3.	Locate HDMI-CEC: Look for a setting related to HDMI, such as "HDMI Control," "CEC," "EasyLink," or similar.  4.	Disable CEC: Select the CEC option and then choose "Off" or "Disable" to turn it off.  5.	Confirm and Exit: Confirm your selection and exit the settings menu.   On the RCA TVs, the Guest device is connected to HDMI 2, and the Direct TV STB is connected to HDMI 1. However, two of the Rooms we had to connect the TV to HDMI2 and the Guest cast device to HDMI3. Please check the equipment list for Guest rooms that have the change.  The Guest cast remote that was installed did not have a guide button, so we are sending them replacement Guest cast remotes with a Guide button. The remote will be programmed to work with the RCA TV and the DirecTV STB.  The Guest cast device is secured to the TV bracket on the wall.

column68: The WAN setup at this property is unique compared to our other properties.  Here is how it is setup: There are 2 ISP modems each with unique WAN and LAN public IP blocks.  One of those modems connects directly to the Fusion on WAN 2 and the other connects directly to the EdgeRouter on eth0.  The EdgeRouter acts as the default gateway for the admin network and for several devices on our network (Fusion WAN 2 and IPMI).  Refer to the diagram on the docs tab labeled "Ramada by Wyndham Tucson Public IP Data Hotel Admin Network" for details on how the admin network is connected to Cox.  The Gem Show Every year they have a gem show at the property and we come out to help support the setup and troubleshoot any issues that arise. Only vendors are staying at the property. There are no guests.  Work they do: The local staff does all the physical setup. Running cables, mounting/connecting switches and AP.   Work we do: Confirming all the equipment is connected and running correctly, all AP's are broadcasting and have good throughput. Assist staff and vendors with connection issues. Several vendors will setup cameras and credit card machines and may need assistance with getting them setup.  Vendor security cameras with hardline connections are setup on the guest hardline VLAN 250. All other vendor devices are on the Gem Show EXHIBITOR SSID. Their cameras are cloud based so they just need internet access to use them.   Upload speeds are often maxed out. Management has been informed about this and understands that this affects the speeds of the network. Hopefully they will upgrade their upload speeds for the next show.  The Edgerouter4 is configured to act as the backup router incase there are any issues with the Fusion.  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 24, which is connected to the Fusion LAN2 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "Mgmt-172.16.0.0/24-VLAN100" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.0.3/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MgmtVLAN100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: Mgmt-172.16.0.0/24-VLAN100, RamadaWiFi-192.168.210.0/23-VLAN200, AssociateWiFi-192.168.212.1/24-VLAN210, Gem_Show_Guest-192.168.220.1/24-VLAN220, Gem_Show_Admin-192.168.221.1/24-VLAN221, Gem_Show_EXHIBITOR-192.168.222.1/24-VLAN222, Gem Show Private Admin Network - 192.168.232.1/22 - VLAN 223

Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 104.243.115.157 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 10.153.214.250 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. column66: This a big old hotel, a 17-story. column67: +MDF: -Fusion, SWcore, Wattbox.  +IDFs: - Switches.  +WAPs: - The APs on the guest floors are installed on the ceiling of the guest rooms. - The APs in the conference rooms are installed hidden inside the ceiling in some rooms and visible in others.
column68: - The core switch is doing the routing for the Guest Circuit. It has an IP on the /30 and the /28 subnets and its default gateway is 64.238.140.229. Its management is protected by and ACL that only allows our public IPs  - Several cables from the former network were used. On the IDF side, the new cables are terminated on the top patch panel, and the used ones are terminated in the button patch panels. - The PMS computer interface is connected to the Admin SW on port 16, in our side the PMS interconnect cable is connected to port 1/1/17 on the SWCore. - All the guest SWs are linked from the fiber switch connected on the 5th Floor IDF. -The Sonifi server devices are connected to the switch in the IFD on the 15th floor. Notice some special configuration on the DHCP server for this Vendor. Like DHCP Option 6, the DNS server is not our gateway (10.40.0.10) The TV equipment is located inside a close in the service elevator hallway. - SynergyMMS Support: 877-430-3696 Note: if outside normal business hours please leave a voicemail and they will call back within an hour for an emergency.  For additional Vendors information please check the Vendor tab of the equipment list  *********************************************************************************************************************************************************************** New Switch Ruckus 8200 installation for Pure HD TV systems (6/5/2025) Name: SW-IDF9-6-02 IP: 172.16.56.32 User: admin Password: SsquidPineapplejelly7&  Instructions: The SW-IDF9-6-02 will be set up on the 6th floor IDF. column66: The basement location has a Fusion, ZD3050 and Brocade core switch. The guest room APs get their PoE power from Brocade Switches in the IDF closets on 3, 6 and 9 (middle of hallway). All APs are wired and PoE. The MDF has a Microtik backup gateway.       There are 4 H510s located on each floor (2-10) mounted on the wall jacks, except in the Meeting room, 203, there is an R510. There is one SMC switch on each of floors 3, 6, and 9 that are connected to the new Brocade PoE switches in the IDFs there, These SMCs provide wired connection to the rooms that do not have H510s.       All the APs have their spare ports set to untagged VLAN200.       There are some old cables connected to the Core Switch in the MDF that were left on VLAN1 and the old subnet of 10.61.32.1 that as its not clear what these were being used for before. One cable definitely goes to the phone DSLAM, so should not be disconnected.      The Web Power Switch is connected directly to the Comcast modem on Public IP 173.13.137.24. Its currently pingable but the login page wont come up. Should get replaced by a WattBox.

column68: Mikrotik  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the Mikrotik using Winbox Software. 2. Do SSH on the CoreSW via Mikrotik ---Click on "New Terminal" /  Once has the prompt type System  and do "Enter" / then type ssh 172.16.0.10  3. Disable Fusion LAN2 and LAN3 form CoreSW ports 1/2/2 and 1/3/1 respectively. (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 3. Change the IP address for MGMT Network on Vlan100. Go to IP/Addresses, select the MGMT Network doing Double-Click and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24. 4. Also enable DHCP Server for MGMT. Go to IP/DHCP Server and double click on MGMT DHCP, then click on "Enable" button. 5. On the Mikrotik Interfaces Tab, enable VLAN 199, 200, 202, 205, 300 and VLAN 301 doing Double Click on each VLAN and click the "Enable" button.  In case local connection need it: use ETH5 ---- http://192.168.88.1 ---- admin / GsquidPineapplejelly7&   1)There is a Netgear AP that is configured as a standalone, getting its IP address from our guest DHCP pool, that provides wifi connection for the tablet mounted on the front desk. The Netgear AP is passed through the Fusion and has an SSID like "Garden Hotel Lobby". This AP is mounted and connects to an unmanaged 3COM switch under the Front desk which is connected to the spare port on the R510 lobby AP mounted under the Front Desk. This Tablet is used by guest and the Bellman so be aware its there.

column67: Guest cast server is located in the MDF 2nd floor in the executive office. Guest cast devices are connected on the back of the LG hospitality TV on HDMI 2, the usb cable from the device is connected to the usb port on the tv.  TV service is provided by coax by Dish satellite Headend, the head end is located underneath the MDF on the 1st floor. TV remotes are the Guestcast remotes with Menu, Guide buttons.  Their is no interactive Guide, the only guide is located on Channel 50.
column68: Guest cast server is located in the 2nd floor in the executive office. Guestcast server gets a public IP from the Meraki Core SW ports 15 for Wan 1 and port 18 for IPMI. lan1 and 2 are connected to the DBCWIFI-SW04 on ports 7 (Lan1) port 8 Lan2. Guest Wifi is on Vlan 1000, Lan2 is configured with Vlan 500. btvcasting was created and untagged, Vlan 1000 is the Guest wifi vlan for the hotel and that was untagged as well. The casting and live tv button have been programmed to show the input menu and the guest will need to choose the correct INput for Chromecast on HDMI2 and Live TV on the TV input.  The TV is controlled by the FMA controller with Dish, the channel line up and the configuration of the TV model is being pushed to the TV.  The TV does not accept direct input from the guest cast remote button because the FTG on the TV is in MPI/EBL mode.  Dan is working with World Cinema on getting that corrected, I have created the TLX file with a channel lineup for the two LG TV models in the INN and is stored in CRM.   The is the issue that was found at the property pertaining the Dish headend:  3.	I found the issue with the TV at the Edgewater and the Inn, the dish headend here at both hotels have a controller that holds all the tv information. This controller puts all the TV’s in MPI-FTG mode and this is what is causing all our issues. For us to use a direct button input the TV needs to be in CPU-FTG mode which means the TV will need to have a file (FMA/TLX) that the channel lineup would be installed and then the TV will be able to control these features like HDMI inputs. The way it is now the Dish headend controls those features, so if we cannot by pass this controller the Guest cast remotes will not work correctly. I have tested this theory and I am correct. so what I did was remove the coax from the TV and then did a factory reset on the TV. Once done I looked at the Mode of the FTG and it was changed to CPU-FTG, at that point I was able to use a new guest cast remote and change the input for casting and for live tv. everything worked like it was supposed to. Here is the kicker, when I reconnected the coax cable to the TV and turned it back on the TV the controller at the dish headend reinstalled the file of the TV back to what it was before. Now the Guest cast remote no longer works like it was supposed to do. So the only way we can change the input is to program the casting and live tv button to open the input menu and the  guest will need to select the input they want to use, so the issue is not with the remotes it has to do with Dish network controller.

column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ---------------------------------------------------- We have a Spare Gateway onsite: Mikrotik, using different Public IP address --- 206.71.228.12 How to pass the traffic over the Mikrotik? 1. Log in to Mikrotik using WinBox Software (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&). 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.65.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN2 is (1/3/4) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.65.254/24 to 172.16.65.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. 7. Verify you are getting ARP and check with someone onsite that the WiFi services are working.  ***For local connection to Mikrotik use ETH5 ---- http://192.168.88.1 ---- admin / GsquidPineapplejelly7&  ------------------------------------------------------  There are guests in the hotel while construction is being completed. The hotel should be fully open in November/December 2023.  The hotel opened on September 12th with 3 guestroom floors: 9, 10, 11. As of 10/18/2023,  there are four active equipment closets: MDF (cellar), 6th floor, 9th floor & 11 floor IDF's  Admin- Interconnect 192.168.255.250/30 - Fusion 192.168.255.249/30 - Firewall Untag VLAN = Wireless POS TAG VLAN 255= 192.168.255.248/30   Admin network is managed by Edge Communications. column67: The Fusion is located on a wedge rack straight when you walk in on right. The Unleashed Master AP is located on the ceiling just above the rack in the MDF. The is a UPS on the wood shelf on the wall at the back near the rack which powers the Fusion and core switch.       Underneath the wedge rack there is a VDSL bridge that connects to the IDF in building 2, There is a second POE Switch which is located in the 2nd Bldg in the phone closet just up the stairs from the building 2 lobby entrance. The IDF closet also has a VDSL bridge that connects to the MDF in Bldg 1.    The APs are located in the 2nd floor hallways on the Ceiling. There are two buildings. Bldg 1 is the where the main lobby is located. Blding 2 has the IDF. The APs are outside these rooms: Outside RM 120 Outside RM 124 Outside RM 128 Outside RM 134 Outside RM 177 Outside RM 171 Outside RM 167 Outside RM 163     There is one AP in the MDF in Bldg 1 which is the Unleashed Master AP.   11/6/2018 - The Fusion Gateway has been replaced by Rishee with Alex S on the Phone. Old Gateway was unplugged and left as a spare at the property.

column68: ********************************************************************************************** ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 142.44.76.113 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh 10.7.254.254 " ----- and the PW: c0c01509hki! 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-CCA-LAN2 and CCB-LAN2 (ports A7 and A8) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "SW-MGMT-7" and change the IP address from 10.7.254.9/16 to 10.7.0.1/16 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 7, 8, 700, 800, 801, 802, 808, 835, 1016, 1025, 1100, 1101, 1109, 1110, 1111, and 1112 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. ***********************************************************************************************  I had to change VLAN 901 for VLAN 100 for the backup ISP because leaving VLAN 901 untagged on our port was causing Spanning Tree issues on the Nitel Cisco SW.  ***********************************************************************************************  The Lutron Lights in the conference area are configured in VLAN 808 (Business Center) because the controller with MAC 98:89:24:30:b3:2b was configured with a static IP 192.168.8.250. LORD_SW01_Museum_South IP 10.7.254.240 - port 18 (controller) and port 27 LORD_SW01_Museum_North IP 10.7.254.242 - port 37

column66: This is a super simple setup. There are 3 modems that connect to Satellite antennas. There is port per WAN connection used in the Fusion. The LAN side has only 1 subnet on VLAN 1. All equipment and guests are using the same subnet. The WAPs are added to MAC passthrough so they can talk to cloud controller (cloud trax, formally known as open mesh).  From the Fusion there is 1 unmagged switch that powers up 3 WAP via PoE. The other 3 WAPs are mesh. The mesh units use local power.  Don general manager wants to charge for premium WiFi. The agreed speeds should be 5/1 Mbps for 2 devices. The free plan would be 0.5/05 Mbps. They will have by-weekly rotating password with the Fusion for the free WiFi that will email the new passwords to: don.black@longhousebethel.com frontdesk@longhousebethel.com

column66: This is a mixed system with VDSL and Ruckus APs. AP placement for modems are next to the beds and Ruckus APs are in the closets or behind the TV. A Fusion, 48 Port Brocade Core Switch & two Motorola T-5 DSLAMs, Wattbox and Triplight UDPS are in the MDF.   Building 4 IDF has a Brocade 12 port switch with a Triplight UPS.  The ISP comes the back office above the desk. Both admin & guest wifi ISP lines come here. The PMS router is on the shelf and the feed passes through our core switch but not into the Fusion.
column67: The router and switches are located on the 2nd floor in a closet of the boiler room. Modem is located downstairs behind the front desk. There's a cable run from the modem up to the 2nd floor equipment room that feeds the router.  APs are in-room. Pool AP is on building 5, second floor, next to the pool hanging on the lip of the roof.  Building 4 IDF is located on the 2nd floor closet nearest next to room 221.
column68: ***LEDs on APs are turned OFF. Turn them back on for troubleshooting and back off again once done.***  This is a mixed network. Modems in buildings 1-2 and 5 with Ruckus in buildings 3-4. Modems are controlled with the DSALM and the Ruckus AP's are running on Unleashed OS.  If there are power outages or equipment that needs to be checked call the FD and ask for the manager on duty.

column66: Core Switch has /30 from Cruzio and WAN Block /29 We used a Netgate 4100 series Gateway instead of a Fusion here. MikroTik on its own WAN and LAN for easy transition if Netgate goes down Fiber OM3 MM from MDF to 3 IDFs Copper CAT6 and CAT5 some existing copper used to rooms form IDFs and or BOXes existing outside the Buildings.  We installed outdoor CAT6 and or connected new Outdoor CAT6 to existing CAT5 into guest rooms ONLY 101 to 110 needed cables drilled from outside.   Server Port Mapping: ----------------------------- ***WAN1: is connected to ICX 8200 48P  Switch port 1/1/38 ***LAN1(Guest Wifi): is connected to a ICX 8200 48P Switch port 1/1/48 ***GC(Chromecast Vlan 500) is connected to a ICX 8200 48P Switch port 1/1/45  Behind TV: ------------------------ ***Chromecasts are connected to HDMI 2 and powered by the USB port on the TV. ***TV service is provided via coax.  ***TVs: are LG ------------- ***The LG TVs are hospitality Models, please see equipment list for model  Remotes: --------------- GuestCast remotes that were sent to the property were with a guide and menu button, if replacement remotes are sent please sent the remote that does not have a menu or guide button, The remotes for live TV is configured for Coax and the Cast button is programmed for HDMI 2. Please note that the property does not have a interactive guide only a rollover guide on channel 7-1. The guest cannot interact with the guide its view only.

column68: For SSH on Switches: It can be performed through the pFsense or the Mikrotik ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ 1. pFsense  ***SSH on pFsense using the IP public address 63.249.68.131  UN: admin PW: GsquidPineapplejelly7& ***Select option 8) Shell from the menu... just type: 8 and "Enter" ***Then ssh admin@172.16.0.xx into the desired SW 2. Mikrotik ***Log into the Mikrotik via Winbox software using the IP public address 63.249.68.133  UN: admin PW: GsquidPineapplejelly7& ***From left Vertical Menu select "New Terminal" ***Once the Terminal is open type: system and "Enter" ***then ssh 172.16.0.xx into the desired SW  NOTE: You may not be able to SSH or Serial to the Core Switch. I had to manually power cycle it to Serial to it while on-site.  8/12/24  IF pFsense FAIL MOVE THE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Login into the Mikrotik via WinBox. WAN/Eth1 is connected to the Core-SW port 1/1/40 2. From the Mikrotik do SSH into Core SW, type: system then "Enter" --- ssh 172.16.0.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port where the Netgate LAN is (port 1/1/48) to make sure it won't be traffic over the Netgate. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab (VLAN1000). 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT-VALN100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 6. On the IP menu, select the submenu DHCP Server and enable all the DHCP servers. column66: There are 11 Clusters in the property. Each Cluster has 2 to 4 building and each building have an IDF that is fed via single mode fiber from the MDF. There is an additional building for the VIP suites that also have an IDF. Incoming TV to our ucrypts is spectrum fed via ATX box with a brighthouse sticker.  ****OLD****** The PureHD SmartBox IPTV handoff is connected to our core switch in the MDF port B20 (VLAN 853). The SmartBox is handing off the multicast traffic with Verimatrix encryption.  Here is how the CAS server was configured on the SmartBox: IP: 52.14.60.61 Port: 12704 Access Criteria: 0x00000191 Encryption : ECB Crypto Period: 30 minutes

column68: VLAN 140 is for switch Management VLAN 400 is for the BTV servers and also where the multicast traffic is fed Each cluster has its own VLAN: VLAN 401 - Cluster 1 VLAN 402 - Cluster 2 VLAN 403 - Cluster 3 VLAN 404 - Cluster 4 VLAN 405 - Cluster 5 VLAN 406 - Cluster 6 VLAN 407 - Cluster 7 VLAN 408 - Cluster 8 VLAN 409 - Cluster 9 VLAN 410 - Cluster 10 VLAN 411 - Cluster 11 & VIP suites We are using multicast routing (PIM sparse mode) to bridge the multicast traffic from VLAN 400 to VLANs 401-411. The core switch is the default gateway for VLANs 401 to 411.

column66: The new system is a full Ruckus network.   The MDF is located on the first floor near room 105. The MDF is where the Time Warner Coax feed comes into the. Hotel Fusion gets its feed directly from Time Warner Coax modem and then feeds our HP PoE/Core switch. all of the APs and other LAN devices are feed form this HP Switch  We do have a web power switch installed on the property that allows you to reboot the GW and ZD. if you turn off the port for the HP switch you will lose access as this feeds the WPS with data.   See network diagram for more details

column66: This is a mixed system with Ruckus AP's on the 4th floor, MDF and in the Lobby and there are Zebra VDSL Modems in the 3rd and 4th floor rooms. The Ruckus AP's are connected to the modems on the 4th floor. The modems on the 4th floor have their radios turned off so not to overlap with the Ruckus AP's.  There is a ZD 1000 controlling the Ruckus AP's.
column67: WAN 1 Telepacific Modem is in the MDF WAN 2 Cox Cable Modem is located on the first floor in the accounting office.  It is a Technicolor DPC3848ve.  There is a blue cable run from this modem to the WAN IDF Switch that has a cable run which goes into port 6 on our core switch.  MDF: 2nd floor telephone room: Fusion, core switch, DSLAM, ZD, WPS, MDF AP and WAN1 modem.  IDF: HP Switch in the back office area. This is the uplink for the WAN 2 connection, and has the Lobby AP/Kiosk connected on port 1. The Kiosk is connected through the Lobby AP on port 3.   APs: TW511 located in 3rd and 4th floor rooms and with Ruckus 7341's and 7343's in the 4th floor rooms, MDF and Lobby. AP in rooms are behind beds or nightstands. The Lobby AP is in the managers drop ceiling. There are pictures showing its location.
column68: If you need assistance at the property you can call the FD or email Karen Wormald.   The 4th floor Ruckus AP's are connected to the modems. If the Ruckus AP's are showing down check the modems to make sure they are up. The Modems on the 4th floor have their radios turned off so there is no conflict with the Ruckus AP's. Both Modems and Ruckus AP's have the LED lights disabled. They will need to be turned back on during troubleshooting.   Currently the Ruckus AP in room 421 is plugged into an outlet that is controlled by the light switch at the door. If this goes down it is most likely due to the light switch being turned off. Call the FD and have them send someone to turn it back on. I am trying to get Karen to change this. - Brad 8/30/2018

column66: This network uses both Ruckus 7372, 7055 and h510 APs with are fed via POE injectors in IDFs on floors 5-10. 3rd floor IDF is a PoE switch and feeds the 3rd and 4th floor AP's. Switches in the IDFs are HP2626 switch which they already had. The fusion & zone director are in the maintenence shop in the basement. Most IDF's are located in a maids closet by the elevator. Refer to network diagram for reference.
column67: MDF - Garage level by maintenance office. Has ISP router, Fusion, Zone Dir, Core switch, WAP. IDFs - In maid storage closet by elevator on each floor (except 4 & 11). Switches located on rack shelf. Waps use yellow cables. APs - The 7372 are located in the hallways in the drop ceiling by the room listed on the equipment list. A 7055 is located at the biz center under the desk. Computers are plugged into it. Meshed AP (7372) is located on a shelf by the switch rack in the back office and in housekeeping located on a shelf at the entrance to the laundry area. There are also h510's in guest rooms behind the dressers/TV stand on the 9th and 10th floors.  Lobby: Biz Center computers & printer. Both have a DHCP address from Fusion. Do not have administrator password to change IP address data.
column68: The Fusion’s hard drive was damaged last time site had a power outage. If they connect a keyboard and press “F1” then wait about 5-10 min the internet should come back up. Let them know that it’s okay to take the Fusion off of the rack to reach the USB on the back.    Engineering team is aware of the network equipment's locations and can reboot equipment if needed.  Contact John (Chief Engineer) in regards to an outage.

column66: This property is currently using two Fusion boxes: *Main is for Guest and Staff use. *The second Fusion is for the Conferences only; this box will be discontinued once the vendor ENCORE takes full care of the Conference Spaces.. column68: Core Switch: 10.7.254.254  ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 142.44.120.57 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 10.7.254.254 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN1 (port 1/1/2) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT10.7.0.254/16-VLAN-7" and change the IP address from 10.7.0.254/16 to 10.7.0.1/16 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 7, 8, 27, 28, 29, 700, 802, 806, 808, 810, 813, 814, 816, 818, 820, 835, 850, 1000, 1016, 1025, 1100, 1110, 1200, 1350, 2000 - In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.  ******************************************************* As of 9/4/2025, the property is not fully installed. There are still 6 APs that are not installed and several APs that need troubleshooting. Touchstone will return in the future to complete the installation, and after this, the Technical Tab in the CRM will be updated. For more details, consult the Equipment List.   -------------------------------------------old notes----------------------------------- Do not Used 198.233.146.4 for any conference device. column68: The Management VLAN for the access points is 101. so in order to provision an AP with the ZD do the following steps: - Add the mac address to the fusion and assign an IP address to the AP - Make sure that the port were the AP will be connected is untagged on VLAN 101 - Wait until the AP shows in a disconnected stage in the ZD and then tag the switch port with VLAN 101 - Since none of the SSIDs are tunneled make sure that all the VLANs are tagged on the port ****Telnet was disabled on all the switches**** *****Radius authentication was configured for all devices*****   Cloud 5 Device Public IP Public IP : 52.119.87.54/28 Gateway : 52.119.87.49 Subnet mask : 255.255.255.240 Port 14 on core switch is configured for this.  ------------------------------- There is a backup Mikrotik gateway, if Fusion goes offline we can move traffic through the Mikrotik:  1- Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 52.119.87.51  (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2- From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.0.10 user=admin"   -----  PW: GsquidPineapplejelly7& 3- Once you are on the CoreSW disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN2 is (1/3/2) to make sure it won't be traffic over the Fusion.  4- Under Interface tab, enable the VLANs 65, 101, 500, 800, 1000, 1016, 1025, 1029. 5- Under IP tab, DHCP Server, enable DHCP to the VLANs

column66: Campus style property. Backbone is a combination of CAT5, Motorola T5 VDSL connections and Ubiquiti Wireless Bridges. VDSL connections to specific sections are to a modem which is then connected to POE switch or POE injector. All devices in main building are CAT 5 connections. Most WAPs are located in basement underneath guest units.  DSLAM2 plugs into the lan port of the POE injector for  Ubiquiti Receiver for Building 701-704 (172.16.0.23)
column67: We have 2 Pairs of Ubiquities. These are there to feed the 701-704 Buildings in the back half of the property. It goes from the MDF to the Cove Fantasies Building and then from the Cove Fantasies Building to Building 701-704. These Ubiquities are linked together via a Cat 5 cable. The reason for this is because we didnt want to go through the switch. From the Receiver on Cove Fantasies from the MDF a Cat 5 cable goes into the POE Port of the POE Injector. From there a Cat 5 Cable goes from the LAN side of the Receiver to the LAN side of the Sender to Building 701-704 POE Injector.     NOTE!! WE DIDNT HAVE ENOUGH PORTS ON THE DSLAM 1, SO WE HAD TO USE 1 VDSL BRIDGE TO HARBOUR TOWERS ROOM 403! THAT VDSL MASTER PLUGS INTO PORT 23 OF THE CORE SWITCH.   DSLAM2(172.16.0.4) is in Champagne Towers Room  701-704 Basement

column66: System SummarySingle-Bldg. MDU Property: ------------------------------------ 5 Story Bldg. (Basement, 1 to 4 plus Roof). We provide WiFi in Common areas and residents units. We also provide Hardwired connection to residents in their own bedrooms. They have a total of 21 Units, every unit has 6 bedrooms.  All the Uplink between MDF and IDFs are SMF (Brocade Network).  Every hardwired connection per bedroom has a unique private vlan assigned.  TPLink SWs are cloud managed --- Omada Cloud Controller Cambium APs are cloud managed --- Cambium Cloud Controller.  We have integrated the Fusion with a Reservation Management System called Entrata to create a DPSK per Resident Bedroom. We have integrated the Fusion with our Cambium Cloud Controller (Only the corresponding Side/Property) to have the WLAN "4367 Berryman Residents" use the Fusion Radius Server.  We deployed: TPLink SWs in every unit (Media Box Panel inside the Closet). Every media box panel contains: *1x TPLink PoEin-POEout-5P power up from Brocade SW *1x TPLink PoEin-nonPoEout-8P power up from TPLink above. This provides Hardwired Connection to every Bedroom on that unit. *1x 12P Cat6 Patch Panel where converges all the in bedroom hardwired connections.  Clients Experience: ----------------------------- As initial configuration, we created Three SSIDs: * 4367 Berryman Residents --- Designed for Residents to have their private network (specific VLAN from 201 to 358). No Portal Page. Every resident will be provided with a Pre-Shared Key generated on the Fusion. No portal page. This network is accessible property-wide. * Peak --- Created for Satff --- Clients will use a WPA2: L3@$ing! (This is Peakmade standard) using VLAN (401). No portal page. This network is accessible property-wide. * 4367 Berryman Guest --- Created for Fusion Fail purposes only. --- Clients will use WPA2: 4367Gues$t! using VLAN (200). No portal page. Currently Hidden and Disabled, see Troubleshooting Notes to bring it alive.
column67: Device Locations**MDF** It is located in the basement IT Room.  **IDF 2nd Floor** Located in the 2nd floor IT Room.  **IDF 4th Floor**. Located in the 4th floor IT Room.
column68: *********Site is in the process of transitioning management companies over to UCLA Housing*********  ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 776.81.124.237 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 172.16.0.10 " ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/2/4) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT 172.16.0.254/24-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. 8. Login to the Cambium Cloud Controller: Enable and Make visible the SSID "4367 Berryman Guest" --- Property needs to be provided with the corresponding WAP2. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200 and 401 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************  -------------------------------------------------------------------------- Port Configuration Sec-Cameras Peakmade Properties: -------------------------------------------------------------------------- 4367 Berryman ----- Reference, up and running: SWCore-MDF-B-01 (172.16.0.10) port-15

column68: If there is a power issues at the hotel unplug both power cord for about 30 seconds Make sure the lights on the power supply's are off then plug both power cords back in. The Fusion will come back up.  Or I have set up the IPMI so we will be able to log into the motherboard and power cycle it. It plugs into WAN2 modem.  Get with me (stevo) if you have any questions. IPMI https://96.88.120.204 un - root pw - c0c01509hki  If there is any major network issue at the property then an email should be sent to  aonorato@dmresorts.com and support@dmresorts.com letting them know what is going on.  This includes ISP techs being dispatched to the property.  Also for issues with Switches, Ubiquiti Devices and Aps keep foll. emails in CC along with POCs in mentioned already in contact details.  rlinares@dmresorts.com dolivera@dmresorts.com rcanas@dmresorts.com  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(172.16.0.10) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 1/2/3, which is connected to the Fusion LAN3 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. Using the "Actions: button, edit the "LAN to CoreSW port 1/1/5"  located on the dashboard tab "All" and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 172.16.1.254/23 to 172.16.0.1/23. 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MGMT-VLAN100" using the "Actions" button. 8. Access the ZoneDirector through the port forward, go to the Configure menu, then click on the WLANs tab. Edit the SSID "HotelWireless" and change the Authentication Options Method from "MAC Address" to "Open." Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: MGMT-VLAN100, Guest-WiFi-VLAN200

column67: On Samsung and LG TVs, the Guest device is connected to HDMI 2. All Guest cast devices are powered by the TV's USB port. The Guest cast is secured to the Coax Cable, which allows the Property to replace the TV without cutting the Security cable of the Guest cast.    The guest cast server is located on the 2nd floor MDF, in the Housekeeping closet; this closet is stackable with the 1st through the 3rd floor. Wi-Fi is supported by Unifi AP Pros, and they are configured in a Hallway deployment for the 1st and 3rd floors.  Wan 1 and IPMI are connected to ports 1 and 2 of an unmanaged 5-port TP-link switch, Lan1 and Lan2 are connected to the Unifi core switch on ports 6 and 7.  Lan 1 is the Guest Wifi, and Lan 2 is for the Guest cast devices on Vlan 500.
column68: Please note that VLAN 500 on our server is tagged and not untagged.  The IT vendor is not able to configure VLAN 500 as untagged traffic.  No Configuration to LG TVs was needed, but for the Samsung, we had to disable the HDMI-CEC, which is located in the settings of the TV.  We also had to turn off the Home welcome Logo, so that once the TV is turned on, it will go to a live channel.  To turn off the Home logo, we had to go into the Hospitality mode of the TV by selecting the Mute button, 119, and the Enter button.  Once in the Hospitality menu, you will need to scroll down to a tab called OSD, and in there, you can turn on or off the Home welcome logo.  Please see the Samsung TV video located in the SharePoint folder for the property.    On Samsung and LG TVs, the Guest device is connected to HDMI 2.   The Guest Cast remote has a Guide button, but it is not configured.  The property has sub-channels, for example, 10-1 is the same as channel 10.  We are not able to program the Guide button for a channel.  The Menu Button is configured for either a Samsung or an LG TV. All other buttons have been configured properly to the specifications of the TV.

column68: -------------------------Guest-WiFi:----------------------------- APs inside the Rooms, mostly located behind the desk, not visible, to access to them a heavy assembled furniture has to be moved. APs and Phone share the same One Gang Box (Dual: DataBlue + VoiceWhite), it means the Phone Line comes through from one edge of the AP.   We powered up the APs using Yellow Patch Cables (100 %). Common areas APs are always hidden above the celling, except(the Three on 10th Floor and the One in Patio 1st Floor). The customer has some WAPs as spare (1xT610, 1xR510, 1xR320, 5xH510), they are in the Fixed Host table as Spare1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8.  -------------------------GuestCast:------------------------- Chromecast are secured to the TV brackets.  HDMI----to----HDM2, Powered Up from USB port on TV***(Both ports on the TV's Left Side). Harmony Remote was used for programing Input sources on the Guest-Cast Remote. There is a Master Remote saved on Clearwater's Office. The customer has 5 Remotes as Spare (fully functional) The customer has 6 Chromecast as Spare (they have to be fully set up for the client account and specific TV-Room).  -------------Registering New Chromecast------------- In order to register these are the steps: 1. Have the person on-site associate with btvcasting SSID, password is HEcasting1! 2. Have them download and open up Google Home App. 3. Click on add a new device 4. Follow along with the steps they are doing (name it like this example Room-728) 5. Once they get to the point of the Chromecast associating to the Wireless network, go to ZD and turn off Wireless Client Isolation on the btvcasting SSID 6. Once the device associates successfully, turn the Isolation back on 7. Wait for the Chromecast to get QR code on the TV screen 8. Find the new Chromecast in the list of devices, click on it, go to setting (Top Right, looks like Settings (cogwheel) button) 9. Once inside the settings, turn off Wireless Client Isolation one more time 10. Have the person on the phone edit Guest Mode and turn it off 11. Once turned off, go back and turn on Wireless Client Isolation again 12. Test (connect to guest WiFi and scan the QR code. Follow instruction on the screen)   *******If a guest has issue casting*************** This is a temporary measure until permanent fix is in place. Guest have moved the rooms and now can't cast to the new room TV.  The fix is: 1. SSH to Overcast VM hoteleffiesandestin.hotelwifi.com port 50003 2. root/c0c01509hki 3. run this command: supervisorctl restart overcast  Should look like this: [root@overcast ~]# supervisorctl restart overcast overcast: stopped overcast: started  4. Confirm it is running: [root@overcast ~]# supervisorctl status all analytics                        RUNNING   pid 2358, uptime 21:09:33 overcast                         RUNNING   pid 2926, uptime 0:00:29  5. Have client try again  ACLs assigned:  Ron Director of IT noticed some vunerablities on our system on ESXi, Fusion and IPMI Assigned ACL on IPMI Assigned firewall rules for ports 443,80 and 9080(iofiltervp) on ESXi Assigned Wan targerts to authorized remote access to Ports 60002 (SZ) ports 50003 and 50004 (guestcast equipmets). In authorized remote access also assigned IP address of one wileshire, IP of fusion and ESXi) just in case. - Durga

column68: How to move the traffic over the pfsense Backup Gateway: ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- All the Vlans are created on the pfsense backup gateway but not enable If the Fusion goes Down, login into the pfsense. (You also can do SSH into the SWs through SSH on the pfsense). ***go to: Interfaces/Interface Assignments ***Enable them one by one. Note: In case the reason you are moving the traffic over the pfsense is for Maintenance or Upgrade on the Fusion, then you need to make sure the vlans aren't assigned to a LAN interface on the Fusion.  Other Information ------------------------ -The ISP is not connected directly to the Fusion. ISP is connected to port 1/1/39 on Core switch which is untagged vlan 900 "ISP Feed". -All the IDFs are connected to the Core-SW through 10Gb fiber. -IoT USB modules are connected in all the H510 AP in the guestrooms, and in almost all the APs in common areas(see equipment list for details)

column66: We Installed a Fusion to replace the old Procurve E-MSM 720. We did the whole new Cat6 network for the WiFI service. New SWs, New APs inside every room. The IDFs are installed inside Outdoor Cabinets (Air Condition). The uplinks are inside underground pipe.   They still have the mixed network. Netgear 8P-SW, Grandstream switches and ubiquiti P2Ps for providing service to Phone System. Ubiquiti P2Ps are used to connect between buildings. This is used only for the phone systems with DVS Technologies.  Ubiquiti AP's were removed from the guest rooms.  Russ Goeckner is the contact for this equipment.  702-938-8003 Russ.G@DVST.Com -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 76.53.36.197 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.60.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN2 is (1/1/11) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "MGMT" and change the IP address from 172.16.53.254/24 to 172.16.53.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Guest-WiFi, MGMT, Vendors -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ APs information: This property have 3 Bldgs. Each bldg. with 12 Apt. -Each Apt have AP R320. -in the Pool we installed 1x T310. -We also installed 1x R320 in the office. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- IDFs Information: -We run Cat6 uplink cables to each IDF with conduits under ground. -We installed 3x outdoor IDFs with A/C. -We run cables to each Apt and we installed the AP above the door. -All the cables that we run are Cat6 outdoor. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ More Information: -They Current have the P2Ps for the phone system. (VDSL System)

column66: ATTENTION!!!!! DONT EVERY REBOOT THE CORE SWITCH OR THE MDF HARD WIRE SWITCH, IF YOU DO THE WAN FEED WILL GO DOWN. THIS WILL CAUSE THE HOTEL'S OPERA AND ADMIN NETWORK TO GO DOWN!!! IT WILL ALSO CAUSE THE BIZ CENTER TO GO DOWN. IF YOU NEED TO PLEASE SPEAK WITH FERDINAND OR TREVOR DOWSWELL!!!   This System is an All Cat 6 infrastructure. From the MDF it feeds two IDF's. From those IDF's it feeds AP's on those floors and well as in Room Hard Connections.  MAJOR NOTES!!!  All Port that arenâ€™t being used are DISABLED! New APâ€™s that are plugged into the ZD will go to Default AP group. This group will have the HISadmin SSID on it only. If you want the Guest to be able to see Hyatt SSID, you will need to add that AP to the Hyatt AP Group. If you want the Guest to see Hyatt/Hyatt Convention you will need to add them to the Hyatt Convention AP Group.  NO DHCP ON MANAGENT SUBNET. IF YOUR ADDING AN AP YOU WILL NEED TO CREATE DHCP FOR VLAN1. Start your DHCP Pool at 10.60.30.50 through 10.60.30.90. Dont go any Higher as you will start having addresses that are already static to certain AP's  All Cables are Color Coded.    Red Cables - Uplink to Switch, Fusion, Web Power Switch and ZD Yellow Cables - Hooks up to WAP's Blue Cables - Hooks up to In Room Hard Connection Gray Cables - WAN Feed for Fusion and Vendors.
