column66: All the Hotel AP's from 1st floor to the 3rd floor are connected to the 1st floor IDF near the ATM is located, also you will find the CoreSW and the ZD in the IDF.  On the 2nd floor above the IDF is where the fusion is located this room is called the server room.  Please look at network diagram for AP locations.  The Motel is the adjacent building to the hotel, the IDF for this building is located on the 2nd floor Engineering dept.  All the Motel AP's are connected to the Ruckus 24 Port POE sw.  Please see network diagram for AP locations.  All AP's of the motel are on the 2nd floor, there are no AP's on the First floor.  Admin Switches are located in the following places, Hotel 1st floor Lobby/ Front desk area, hotel 2nd floor server room.  Motel admin switches are located on the 2nd floor engineering dept.    All switches are connected via 50/125 MM OM3 fiber cable LC/LC.  Uplink from Comnet is Microware and its is handed off to the Hotel via ethernet.  Both hotel and motel are connected via fiber and a redundant Ethernet  connection  from the CoreSW to the 2nd Floor IDF located in the Motel.  The Hotel has 2 internet connections, Wan1 is comnet 100/100, Wan2 is DSL 10/1.  We do not have any information on the DSL other IP address, Juan Diego has stated that he has a local tech that handles the DSL connection.  Per Juan, he stated that the guest of the hotel will not be calling HIS for support but they will need to call the front desk.  Juan will call HIS if he is in need of assistance.

column30: Each Room has 2 ethernet ports, one for the TV and the other for hardwire connection to the internet.  The Property has 1 MDF in Basement and 2 IDFs located on the second floor in building 2 and 3.  The IDF has 2 - HP1410 24 port SW unmanaged, all the rooms are patched into the SW.  Please see photos in CRM docs.  Here at the property we have a Guestcast server E series fusion, we also have an aruba 2530-24Port POE Core SW.  All the IDFS have a Home run ethernet cable to the MDF which are connected to the Core SW on a untagged port for Vlan 200.
column66: The property is using Ubiquity AC access point, currently there are 4 AP, 2 are located in the 1st building 1st and second floor.  One Ap is located in Building  2nd floor in front on room 212. The last AP is located in Building 3 2nd floor in front of Room 312.  Our Fusion is located in the Basement Rack and we have an Aruba 2530-24 Port Poe SW as the Core.  The four Ubiquity AP's are connected to Ports 1-4 on the CoreSW. Fusion Lan1 is connected to Port 24 on the Coresw.  IPMI cabled is installed on the ethernet port for the Fusion.  Virtual server is connected to Wan 2 on the Fusion.  ATT fiber circuit is connected to the Wan1 port on the fusion.  We have 3 Vlans- 100 Management, 500 Chromcast, 501 Guest Wifi.  We have 2 IDF's located in the 2nd Building 2nd floor and in the 3rd Building 2nd floor.  All the Guest rooms have Ethernet connection behind the TV and under the Desk or chair.  The Current Sw in the IDF's are 2- Unmanaged 1410 24 Port one for IPTV and the other for Hardwired Internet, Please see photos in CRM Docs.  Building 1 is connected all the way back to the MDF which is located in the Basement.    Admin network is connected to Ports 5/6 on the ATT Router, HIS is using ports 2/3/4 for the Fusion, IPMI, and EXsi virtual server. Currently the hotel has a cable modem as well but this circuit will be removed.   David the IT tech for the hotel will be adding his unmanaged switches to the CoreSW on a untagged port using Vlan 200.  Juan will be creating the Vlan on the Fusion and on the Virtual server.  Vlan 200 is for the Hardwired ethernet connections in the Guest rooms.  PMS server for the property is called MYHMS, it is a Web based PMS software.

column66: The hotel has two buidlings. The Main Villa building is where the Lobby and MDF are located. The back building is referred to as Building B.  The MDF is just off the Lobby. The MDF core switch has fiber running to IDF's in the Villa basement and to IDF1 on the 1st floor of Bldg B. From these two IDFs there is fiber going to IDF2 and IDF3.        The rooms have network jacks and the majority of rooms that have APs have H320s. There are three rooms on the 2nd floor of Bldg B that have R320s and these R320s are there to help cover the Pool area. There is one meeting room in the Villa Bldg on the 2nd floor. There is a second meeting room on the 2nd floor of Bldg B. These are covered by an R650 and R610 respectively. The Lobby has an R650 covering it as well as an R610 covering the staff offices in the basement of the Villa Bldg. Of note is that there are to SSIDs that were previously used for the lock system and some Tablets but per the GM are no longer used.       The MDF has a Fusion, Mikrotik backup router, and Wattbox. The Wattbox and Mikrotik are currently not on valid Pubic IPs. The hotel will soon be upgrading to a fiber circuit.

column67: +MDF: It's located on the Mezzanine Level in the Server Room(Fusion, CoreSW, Microtik, Zone Director, Wattbox) +IDF 1: It's located in the same room as the MDF equipment (1 Switch). +IDF 2: It's located on the 5th floor in the storage closet (3 Switches) +IDF 3: It's located on the 5th floor in the storage closet (1 Switch) +IDF 4: It's located on the 17th floor in the kitchen.  +WAPs: The APs in the guest Areas are visible in the guest hallways hanging out from the ceiling. column68: +The Fusion has 2 ISP circuits(WAN 2: 63.105.9.18, WAN 1: 24.249.210.13) +The coreSW is composed by 2 stacked switches(1 48 port HP switch and 1 24 port HP switch) +All the IDF switches are connected to the CoreSW via Fiber.  Move the Traffic over Mikrotik if Fusion Fail =======================================================================================  Eth1 ---WAN ---- CoreSW, Port 1/2  Eth2 ----LAN ---- CoreSW, Port 1/3 1. Proceed to login into the Mikrotik. 2. Go to: Interfaces/Ethernet 3. Double click on ETH2 LAN 4. Select Enable 5. OK  For service calls related to Manually creating Conferences: (WiFi and Hardwire) ======================================================================================== WiFi: ------ Note: There are 5 Conferences Pre-set, with Conference Access Code Portal. 1. Login into the ZoneDirector, choose an SSID from the list (Graduate_Conf_01, Graduate_Conf_02 ... Graduate_Conf_05). All the 5 Conf SSIDs have Client Isolation. 2. Rename the SSID as client request... please do not change the description field.  3. Make it visible (Unchecking the Hide SSID option) 4. Verify the corresponding VLAN and keep it in mind (VLAN 1011, VLAN 1012. VLAN 1013, VLAN 1014, VLAN 1015). 5. Login into the Fusion and go over Identities/Shared Credential 6. Select the matching Credential from the list: (Graduate_Conf01 VLAN1011, Graduate_Conf02 VLAN1012 .... Graduate_Conf05 VLAN1015) 7. Edit the Credential: Modify fields like: ***Credential: As client request. ***Effective and Expires dates: As client request ***Simultaneous Users: As client request  Hardwire: ------------ Note: There are 4 Ports identified as Hardwire on a SW (10.6.62.211) already Sync with the Fusion. If the client also wants a Hardwire on the Meeting then proceed with the following steps:  1. Log into the Fusion. 2. Go over Network/Wired/Switch Ports 3. Select "Edit" on the SW Port where the client wants to connect the Device. 4. Assign the port to One of the Five Switch Port Profiles pre-defined for Vlans on Conference (HW-Conf-01-Vlan-1011, HW-Conf-01-Vlan-1012, HW-Conf-01-Vlan-1013, HW-Conf-01-Vlan-1014, HW-Conf-01-Vlan-1015). 5.  Update.

column66: This project uses h500s located in every room and was installed by a 3rd party company. r700s are used in meeting spaces and public areas. All have a wired connection back to a switch. Switches are configured with vlans according to Loews hotel HSIA standards. There are several systems which run off the network including IP phones, room controls, TV and mini-bar.  At the time of installation one of the cables labeled (room#-D-2) was used to connect h500. Port1 of the h500 used the phone, port 2 used the room controls. Each port of the h500 has a vlan on it.
column67: MDF - Located on 2nd floor. Go entrance to women bathroom. There is a door that goes to the MDF. IDFs - Located on floors 5, 9 & 14. They are near the x07 rooms. There is a fiber home run to each switch which comes from MDF. There is a rack where switches are mounted on.  APs - Rooms - There are 2 cables to each room. They terminate in either a grey box located in bedroom clothes closet or above the sink in the living room. There is a false cover over the space above the sink held on with magnets.   SW-Conf-Front1 - located in Meeting Room Vashon 1/ Vashon 1 Conference Room
column68: There are 2 home run cables to each room. #1 cable feeds intellajack device. TVs are plugged into this. Line #2 plugs into h500 which are in every guest room. IP Phone (VOIP) is plugged into port1, room controlls in port 2.  It was noted that when phone cannot get to network it will not complete a call. Phone has power and will get dial tone but when dialing out, call will drop. All phones were tested to be working after AP installation. Service calls relating to this potential issue should be direct to hotel IT staff. ____________________________ New Fusion Installation 9/26/2022 We installed the HA Cluster (CCA and CCB):  hotel1000seattlecca.hotelwifi.com hotel1000seattleccb.hotelwifi.com - CCA-WAN1 is connected to LH1000_CORE_MDF port A12 - CCA-LAN1 is connected to LH1000_CORE_MDF port B17  - CCA-LAN2 it is connected straight to CCB-LAN2  (It was connected to the LH1000_CORE_MDF port B14, but the link was unstable.)  - CCB-WAN1 is connected to LH1000_CORE_MDF port A14 - CCB-LAN1 is connected to LH1000_CORE_MDF port B18 - CCB-LAN2 it is connected straight to CCA-LAN2 (It was connected to the LH1000_CORE_MDF port B13, but the link was unstable.)  The Backup Fusion hotel1000seattlebackup.hotelwifi.com (208.45.191.86) it was left power on, the Guest LAN port is connected to LH1000_CORE_MDF port B2 (disabled). In case the cluster CCA and CCB get offline the cable from port B2 can be moved either to LH1000_CORE_MDF port B17 or B18.   Notes: The new server that is labeled as "HOTEL 1000 BACKUP" at the back side is actually the CCA              The one labeled as "HOTEL 1000" is actually the CCB

column68: ********************************************************************************************** ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* **********************************************************************************************  1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 50.184.118.59 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.88.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN (port 1/2/2) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt.172.16.89.254/23-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.89.254/23 to 172.16.88.1/23 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 4,8,10,12, 100, 200-202, 500. -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Old Information: ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- For any refund requests send an email to Lisa and copy Jeannie and sample should like this  Name: Adonnika Thompson Amount: $32.10 Date of Purchase: 2/12/21 Authorization#: AH3A3C9D250C Email: adonnika@gmail.com   Reason: The guest was unable to access their work site. column66: This is a guest cast-only property where we do not manage the WiFi.  Server Port Mapping: ----------------------------- ***WAN1: is connected to USW#4 Pro port 7. ***LAN1(Guest Wifi): is connected to USW#4 Pro port 5. ***LAN2(Chromecast Vlan 500) is connected to USW#4 Pro port 6.  ***IPMI: is connected to USW#4 Pro port 8.  Behind TV: ------------------------ ***Chromecasts are connected to HDMI 2 and powered by the USB port on the TV.   ***TV service is provided via coax.  ***TVs: ------------- ***The TVs are not hospitality but Retail Models.   ***They have several brands of TVs mostly LGs (Samsung, Sansui, Hitachi, Sony, TCL, FIRETV) ***BY NEXT YEAR ALL THE TVS WILL BE LG, THEY WILL BE REPLACING ALL TVS THAT ARE NOT LG  Remotes: --------------- Guestcast remotes with no guide are configured for TV on Coax and the Cast button is programmed for HDMI 2.  The only TV that has the Guest cast device on HDMI1 is a Sony in the Captain's Meeting Room.  The reason is that the TV was too heavy to move, so Maintenance requested that we use HDMI 1.  The Guest cast remote for that TV was programed to use HDMI 1 for Guestcast.
column67: Fusion is located on the 3rd floor of MDF in the Main Building. Core SW is a Unifi USW Pro switch numbers 4 and 5.  Guest cast devices are located behind the TVs on HDMI2; the only TV that has the Guest cast device on HDMI1 is a Sony in the Captain's Meeting Room.  The reason is that the TV was too heavy to move, so Maintenance requested that we use HDMI 1.  The Guest cast remote for that TV was programed to use HDMI 1 for Guestcast.
column68: The IT company that manages the Network in this property is: Fortress Network Solutions, Inc.  The Tech that made all the Settings for us was: Bruce McKee  bmckee@coactivetech.net Fortress Network Solutions, Inc. 207-775-6030 ext 113 207-766-7546 (direct)  Collin McGuire, IT Director cmcguire@coactivetech.net 207-939-4903 (Mobile)  bill@nonantumresort.com – Head Engineer Jonathan.Lander@nonantumresort.com – Asst. Head Engineer  The hotel Network uses a ubiquity unified system; there are two core switches located on the 3rd floor.  USW #4 and #5, our guest cast equipment, are connected to Core SW 4.  The AP being used is AP Pro. They use a hallway deployment for the 2nd and 4th floors in the main building (Caridge House).  In Building 2 (Portside), the APs are in the 2nd-floor hallway to support floors 1-3.  The hotel is closed during the winter months, from December to April.  But the hotel is open from May to November.

column66: The property is made up of 12 buildings. During renovations over that last 2 years, conduit for network connection was installed under the parking lots to connect each of the buildings. A fiber "ring" was created going from the MDF to Bldg K (10s rooms), then to Bldg J (20s rooms), Bldg I (30s rooms), and finally to Bldg F (60s rooms). From each of these key locations, Cat6 links fan out to the remainder of the buildings.       The MDF has two ZDs. The original ZD1000 still controls two 2942s in Bldg L which was not part of the renovations. The new ZD1100 controls the remainder of the APs on the property.        The MDF has a Fusion and Core Switch. The Core Switch has GBIX fiber link to Bldg K. There are a total of 12 IDFs with HP 2530 8port PoE switches. Each guest building has 3 to 5 APs in the attic for coverage of the guest rooms.         Of note is that the Business Center AP goes through and existing Netgear 8 port switch back to the MDF Core switch. The VIP Rooms (700s rooms) IDF switch also goes through a non-manged D-Link switch back to the MDF Cores Switch.        There is a P2P link from bldg K to the SPA building where there is one AP. This consists of two Ubiq. NanoBeam P2Ps. The NanoBeam sender (Access pt.) in Bldg K is mounted outside under the roof overhang and cable goes into the attic to the Bldg K IDF Switch.         Recently four new T310s were added to cover the restaurant, its patio, and the GMs office. These four APs are running on Unleashed software as the ZD1100 wont support the T310s.         Lastly, AP-GM-Office T310 is powered from the IDF I Backbone switch. This switch in Bldg I that is specifically there to provide a connection for the AV Camera guys. The GM's new AP was added to this switch.    Recently, GuestCast was installed and has a GuestCast sever installed in the MDF.
column67: Of note is that the staff refer to the buildings by the room number range. This can be confusing so you will see in all of my documentation that I also give each building a "letter" designation where the Lobby Building is letter "A". If i refer to a building I also give the room number range as well.     The APs for the guest rooms are located in the attics of each of the 12 buildings. There are attic access hatches in the hallways or from a closet or electrical closet. The few APs that are not located in the attic are in the Lobby building. There is one 7055 mounted on a jack in the Aldelucia II ballroom, one R500 under the desk in the Business Center (Lobby), and one R700 in the MDF.          There is a NanoBeam P2P sender that connects the SPA building (Bldg "M") to the 10s (Bldg "K") Switch . Its located just out side of the Pool Building (Bldg "K") under the roof overhang. The receiver Station is in the out door pump/filtration room of the SPA Building itself.            The majority of the IDF switches are also located in the building attics. The few that are not are the Maint. Office IDF Switch which is in the water heater room back of the tool shed and the Bldg F (60s rooms) IDF Switch which is located in the basement water heater room of that building (mounted on the wall).            There are four key IDF switches that form the Fiber ring for the property in Bldgs K, J, I and F. The Fiber ring connects through conduit links under the parking lots (there are manhole covers where the conduit can be accessed in the parking lot).            Here are the room locations over which the APs are located in the attics or specifically in the Lobby locations mounted on walls or under desks (as in the BC): Rm 230  Rm 233  Rm 235 Rm 237 Rm 239 Rm 240  Rm 242 Rm 244 Rm 245 Rm 119 (IDF access panel) Pool Rm 116 Rm 226 Rm 224 Rm 222 Rm 271 Rm 275 Rm 278 Rm 253 Bldg G (50s rooms) bldg center attic Rm 250 Rm 260 Rm262 Rm264 Rm 521 Rm 523 Rm 525 Rm 527 Rm 285 Rm 283 Rm 281 Rm 295 Rm 292 Rm 292/295 attic center of Bldg Rm 293/294 attic center between rooms MDF Lobby Business Center  Rm 701 Rm 704 Rm 705 Andalucia II Meeting Rm (on wall) SPA bldg Staff Office attic (access in closet)      The MDF can be accessed from an outside door approximately at the back of the Adelucia I ballroom. Its part of the Lobby/Ballroom complex I called Bldg A.      There are three T310s covering the Restaurant and its patio. The patio AP is on the roof of the MDF. The other two T310s are on the restaurant roof. Lastly, there is a T310 mounted on the side of the 30's Bldg (I), that is mounted directly over the GMs office.
column68: Ping Watchdog is running on the P2Ps. Please refer to the document "P2P Ping Watchdog Notes Casa Munras" in the Network Diagram section of Docs.  Note that there are four new T310s installed. These four new APs are running on Unleashed software since the ZD1100 can not be upgraded to the proper level of firmare to run the T310s. The Master is currently 172.20.0.50.  ------------------------------------------------------------------------- IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 64.60.124.6 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 10.5.5.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: lib3rty 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN1 (18) and LAN2 (19) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. Enable the interface ETH2/LAN under the Interfaces menu under the Interface tab. 6. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "ETR3/MGMT" and change the IP address from 10.5.5.254/24 to 10.5.5.1/24 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Chromecast-VLAN500, Guest-WiFi-VALN200, GuestCast-MGMT-VLAN100, Menuvative-LAN300, Staff-WiFi-VLAN800   -------------------------------------------------------------- WAN DEVICES AND CONNECTIONS -------------------------------------------------------------- They have a 500meg fiber line coming in from Comcast. It goes to a fiber-to-eth modem in the MDF.  A single gray patch cable goes from the Comcast fiber modem to a white “TPX” box (Velocaloud). This TPX box converts a single Public IP from the Comcast Fiber Modem to another set of public addresses. The Fusion gets its WAN feed off of this white TPX box, which is why the Comcast public IP doesn’t match the Fusion for a WAN feed.  The hotel installed the white TPX box because the TPX has a backup failover 10mbps cellular feed (the smaller white box on top). However, that 10mps cell feed was designed only for voice, and having the guest Fusion connected means that if Comcast goes down, the Fusion itself will eat up all the bandwidth on that backup cell feed.  Velocloud IP info (belongs to the TPx team) Server IP: 107.0.92.122 Gateway: 107.0.92.121 Subnet Mask: 255.255.255.252 (/30)  If we have any issue with this device, we must contact the TPx support team at 877-487-8722

Do ssh into the CoreSW from Mikrotik 3. On the CoreSW disable the corresponding LAN port  for the Fusion where the traffic is (LAN3 1/4/2) 4. On Mikrotik enable Vlans... interfaces/vlan  5. Check arp on Mikrotik to see the traffic.  6. Finally on CoreSW disable LAN port where the MGMT is (LAN1 1/1/27)   + This property has 2 ISP, one primary and one secondary. The primary ISP is NaturalWireless: the Fusion WAN 3, IPMI, Mikrotik, and WattBox; the ISP feed is connected to the SWCore-MDF-B-1 port 1/1/13. column67: Alex Bermudez 2/27/19  We have Redundant Fusion Cluster in the MDF, we also have a redundant Smart Zone and a Brocade Core 7450 SW.  I have uploaded the Floor Diagrams for the Hotel to Google Docs.  There are 3 PDF files that are over 250MB in size.  I have uploaded the Equipment list and other documents to CRM.   Guest room AP deployment are located either in the closet or just above the Closet.  The AP's are powered and connected via Ethernet the Gpon Fiber system, all rooms have a fiber connection which are connected in the following IDF's  2,4,6,10,12,14,16. we do not have access to the Fiber Switches but from the Fusion you will be able to ping the AP. I have uploaded the latest equipment list, Config for Core SW.  APs in Landing Area---Hardwired---In front of the elevators---Fed from IDFs in every other floor. APs in Pool, Pool Bar, Food Court, Entrance---Hardwired---1st Floor---Fed from IDF in 1st Floor behind elevators tower. APs in Terrace-Dinning area---Hardwired---17th Floor---Fed from IDF 16th floor.
column68: --April 28, 2023-- New Fusion Backup 2 installation notes (Yoexy): - Connect WAN1 to Core-MDF1-01 (10.7.254.10) port 2/1/6  - Connect WAN1 to Core-MDF1-01 (10.7.254.10) port 1/1/8 - Connect iDRAC to AVHSW02-MDF (10.7.254.11) port 1/1/21 - Connect LAN1 to Core-MDF1-01 port 2/1/8 (just VLAN 7 is configured on 2/1/8 to be able to reach the SWs from the Fusion) - Connect LAN2 to Core-MDF1-01 port 1/1/9 (no VLANs are configured in this interface 1/1/9, VLANs are configured just in the Fusion)  ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- --January 19,2024--- As part of an IPTV demo project, new equipment and configurations were introduced to the network. The demo involves bypassing GPON technology and routing IPTV through the APs. The APs, equipped with a Ruckus fiber backpack (media converter), are connected via fiber to a switch located in the IDF. The following additions were made to the network:  - An ICX7550 switch (IP: 10.7.0.11) was installed on the 3rd floor IDF. This switch (port 1/1/23) is connected to the core switch (port 1/1/12). - Two existing APs, namely AP-Room 301 and AP-Room 303, are utilized in this demo. These APs were relocated from their original AP groups in the Default Zone to the Demo Zone on the controller. - Additionally, one new AP (AP-334) was incorporated into the network. This AP has been assigned to the Demo Zone on the controller.  _____________________________________________________________________________________ --Octuber, 2025--- After the network upgrade in Otuber, 2025, an H350 was installed in every room. The 2.4 is turned on only in the access points in every other three rooms.  _____________________________________________________________________________________ **where help is needed please email lho.pt@loewshotels.com which is our team email. This will ensure someone from the team can respond as quickly as possible. ***IN EVENT OF OUTAGE*** Best point of contact is LHO.PT@loewshotels.com for the email address and for the phone number you can call Rodell or Hector Rodell 321 303 8635 Hector 321 231 2478

column66: MDU Site 1000 User Fusion 10GB uplink and 10GB backbone on single-mode Fiber. Ruckus APs on vSZ-1.  Each apartment has an NIMs box in one of its closets, where there is an H550.  The XX16 units have an additional H550 fed off port 4 of the AP.  The PH suites also have one additional AP. All additional APs are named AP-Room-XXXXXX-2.  There are 23 Amenity area R350 APs on floors 1 to 6 and an R350 in the Penthouse.   ***************************************************************************************************************** *******************************RESIDENTS' WIFI EXPERIENCE******************************************* ***************************************************************************************************************** + There exists a single SSID named Bisby_Rooms broadcasted throughout the entire property. It is meant to provide private WiFi to each Tenant. +We are using DPSK on the vSZ-H in order to make each Tenant to use their own Password. The DPSK file is currently under Tab: Docs CRM (dpsk_Bisby_Rooms). +The VLANs associated with the DPSK are from 1000 to 1400. See Equipment list for details. +The clients using SSID: Bisby_Rooms won't face a Portal Page from the Fusion. +Front Desk has the List of Passwords (Codes), they are providing them to the Tenants. Note: The security level of the Codes is questionable. That's the way the client wanted. This may need to be changee once the Tenants start to realize how easy they are to guess. column68: ********************************************************************************************** ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 69.64.198.18 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.86.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN (port 1/2/7) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "MGMT172.16.87.254/23-VLAN-100" and change the IP address from 172.16.87.254/23 to 172.16.86.1/23 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresess List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 100, 200-203, 850, 1000-1400 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************  Site MDF is in the Main Telco closet on the Ground Floor near Elevator C's rear door. MDF has 3 UPS Units and 1 Watt Box that connects Fusion and Backup Gateway. Unit 2 has Core switch units 1 and 2, and Unit 3 has Core switch units 3 and 4. The main ISP feed has 10 GB uplinks to Fusion and Backup Gateway on both WAN and LAN. The Backup ISP feed has 1GB feeds to both Fusion and Backup Gateway.  There are 14 IDF, however, only 1 through 9 have UPS. All power should, however, be on a backup generator connection. This includes the MDF.  SNMP ports forward go through WAN2  69.64.198.20 --- See equipment list for details

column68: Contact Onsite:  Vanessa Manager Phone Number: 949-524-1682 -She know where we have all the equipment and the Maintenance guys. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- If for some reason we need to restart the ISP Provider, we can entry in the Wattbox and the ISP power connection are in Outlet-5  WattBox outlet Mapping: ----------------------------------- Outlet-1: Mikrotik Outlet-2: Fusion Outlet-3: Core-SW Outlet-4: NVR-1 Outlet-5: COX-ISP-Modem  If Fusion Fail: We have an Spare Gateway on-site (Mikrotik) fully configured, but is OFF due to it has the same WAN IP address the Fusion has. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Login into the WattBox and Turn ON the Mikrotik. 2. Login into the Mikrotik using WinBox Software. 3. Do ssh into the Core-SW through the MIkrotik and disable Fusion WAN port on CoreSW. 4. Make sure Interface ETH2/LAN on the Mikrotik is enable. 5. Make sure the SW port for ETH2/LAN has all the VLANs tag. 6. Verify the guest traffic is actually happening over the Mikrotik.

column68: You can call Miguel in engineering to check on the equipment for us at 909-435-6353. If he is unavailable you can call the FD and get transferred to engineering. - Brad 3/11/2019 The ISP Fiber feed comes into port 6 on the core switch, and feeds out to the Fusion igb1 port from the core switch port 8.  Our default gateway is the ISP managed Fortigate which is located on property.  If our WAN 1 gateway (66.215.13.97) is not responding to pings then it may just be a power outage at the property. The cable modem (WAN 2) connects directly to the Fusion with a red cable labeled "cable modem" and it also has a label that says WAN1, but its actually WAN2. -Updated by Walter 2/19/21  Ping Watchdog is enabled on the P2Ps.  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER TO EDGEROUTER: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Connect to the EdgeRouter using your web browser. 2. Open the EdgeRouter CLI by clicking on the CLI button found on the top right of the web user interface. 3. Ssh into the Core Switch(10.61.32.3) from the EdgeRouter terminal. 4. Disable port 23, which is connected to the Fusion LAN1 (This eliminates the LAN traffic to hit the Fusion) 5. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, enable all the VLANs using the "Actions" button to the right of each VLAN. 6. On the EdgeRouter dashboard, in the All tab, using the "Actions button, edit the MGMT-VLAN1 and change the EdgeRouter IP address from 10.61.32.13 to 10.61.32.1 7. Under the "Services" tab, enable the DHCP server named "MgmtVLAN100" using the "Actions" button. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the EdgeRouter: Guest-WiFi-VLAN200, Guest-WiFi-VLAN201, Guest-WiFi-VLAN202, Guest-WiFi-VLAN203.

column66: This is a campus system property which uses P2P bridges to distribute data between buildings. Ubiquity AirFiber devices are used to distribute data from Clubhouse Bldg to Bldgs 32, 5 & 11. Ubiquity M5 P2P are currently used to distribute data to other buildings. All buildings are wired together using outdoor cable that was run through underground conduit.  Fusion, ZD & Core switch are located in the Telco Rm on the basement level of the clubhouse building. From here a CAT5 uplink goes to a Ubiquiti tough switch located on a shelf in the closet on the 2nd floor. The AirFiber devices are plugged into this switch as well as the Bridge to Bldg14 & the Clubhouse Attic AP.   The AirFiber links are dedicated P2P bridges to Bldgs 32, 11 & 5.  (1) Fusion (77) R500 (1) ZoneDirector 3100 (6) Ubiquiti AirFiber  (16) M5, Ubiquiti NanoStation5 Outdoor 5GHz CPEs (1) Software Support for the ZoneDirectors (3)  24 Port switch HP Managed Switches (7) 8 Port switch HP Managed Switches  Note: The AirFiber bridges to buildings 5 and 11 were configured with 40 MHz channels and the AirFiber bridge to 32 was configured with 20 MHz channels based on the available frequencies. Link performance could be seen in the AirFiber dashboard. AirFiber devices were grounded and have in-line surge protection.
column67: MDF - Telco Rm, basement of Clubhouse The Modem, 8 Port Managed WAN Switch, Fusion Gateway, Core SW and ZD  AirFiber devices on the Clubhouse roof There are 3 Airfiber P2P devices on the clubhouse roof. Cabling from them goes to a closet on the 2nd floor of the clubhouse. On the shelf is an HP switch, a Ubiquity Tough Switch and the POE injectors for the AirFiber units. THESE ARE 50V injectors. NO OTHER INJECTOR WILL WORK ON THE AIRFIBER UNITS.  IDF For buildings that have switches they are located in the housekeeping closet on the 2nd or 3rd floor  Bldgs 10, 4 & 6 - Switches are on the 1st floor housekeeping room.  The Ubiquities are located on the roofs. All Ap's are ceiling mounted in the hallways. Fed via POE switch.  Rick is the maint. manager. Best contact for equipment.  APs and Ubiquiti POEs are in the Housekeeping closet in each bldg on the top floors. Access to attic is via hatch in these rooms.  NEW INFORMATION:  Each building now has 3 (R500) APs installed on the ceilings of the top floor. On the 3 story buildings, 3 APs were added on the 1st floor as well. Buildings now have wired connections between buildings going through underground conduit.   Buidings 4, 6 & 10 now have switches in them located on the 1st floor housekeeping closets.

column24: LG (xxLD340H, 60LV570H, 42LT670H, 55LV570H, 43LX570H) FMA supported.            LG (xxLY560H, xxLX560H) FMA not supported.
column30: This client doesn't have Beyond TV service. It's just Casting service. Chromecast: --HDMI 1 (rear side of the TV to make them safe). --Powered from USB port on one of the edges of the TVs.   Remotes: "Cast" and "TV" keys need to be programmed before give them to the client.  --Procedure for "Cast" key: See manual attached (Slate-Manual-Eng).. page 2 Programming a Macro. Keys to be programmed (5+8). --Procedure for "TV" key: See manual attached (Slate-Manual-Eng).. page 2 Learning Another Remote Key Function. Key to be learned (channel up).    Here the explanation why the remotes need to be reprogrammed: Vast majority of the TVs are xxLD340H, a few amount are 60LV570H, 42LT670H, 55LV570H, 43LX570H... all of them are supported by FMA LG-101 installed on the MDF. In a nutshell... it means the channel line up and all the configuration for the TVs come from FMA through the coax, They are MPI mode, impossible to change any configuration on them, impossible to flash them, also making the "Cast" Key and "TV" Key in the remote non-functional.  The good news is we got access to the FMA and some configuration were done on it, like adding channel 58 as a bridge to HDMI 1 where the Chromecast is plugged in.  All this results in a Macro Function for "Cast" key on the remote: 5+8.  What happen with different LG TV models? We found some other TVs: (xxLY560H, xxLX560H) FMA not supported.  For these TVs, TLX files were built in order to be Flashed.... (5 USB dongles were left with the TLX files on the Engineering Department, they were also trained). See attached these files: 39LY560H.tlx and 40LX560H.tlx Below the flashing procedure:  For Flashing a TV using USB Drive on LG TV (most recommended). --------------------------------------------------------------  >>Note: Those TVs not supported by LG FMA will need a Flashing. How to realize that a flashing is necessary? -No channel 00 The Row -No channel 58 (HDMI 1 Casting).  Step No1. ---------- >> Verify the model of the current TV getting into the Installer Menu. - Press "menu" repeatedly until nothing happen - Press 9876+ok - The model will be shown on the Left-Top corner, looks like (xxLY560H or xxLX560H). - Write it down or memorize it.   Step No2. ---------- -Unplug the Chromecast from the USB port on the side of the TV. -Insert the USB drive where the TLX files are. (Select: I will not use the USB). -Press "Menu" -Go to "Options" or "Lock" (just step on it, not get into it) -Press "7" 7 times... until another window appears.  -Pick up the correct option (teach to TV, import file TLX, Learn from USB) -Select the proper file, the one written on Step No1. -Press "Enter" -Once says completed, the TV will tune Channel 00 The Row. -Unplug USB and plug back the Chromecast.
column66: Updated 10-18-2019 JZ:  There are two Zones in the SZ: -	 One for the H500s that can’t be upgraded because the current firmware is the latest supported by these APs (3.6.2). -	The Default Zone with the remaining APs.  If the Default Zone needs to be upgraded remove VLAN 101 from the uplinks in the core switch and add it back one uplink at the time. Wait until all the APs in each IDF has downloaded the firmware and then move to the next uplink. This will avoid the SZ to crash when there are 500+ APs trying to download the firmware at the same time. (THIS ALSO APPLIED TO REBOOTING THE SMARTZONE) SW: 172.16.0.10 PORTS: 1/1/41, 1/2/2, 1/3/1 - 1/3/4, 1/4/1 - 1/4/4  Network Overview: -	PanicRow SSID only on 2.4 GHz -	btvcasting SSID only on 5 GHz (Wireless Client Isolation ON) -	2.4 GHz has been turned down 3dB(half power) property wide based on heat mapping results -	2.4 GHz frequency is only using channels 1, 6, & 11 (Panic System requirement) -	Guest Traffic VLAN 201 Node1 Only -	Chromecast Traffic VLAN 500 Node 2 Only -	New SW and Wi-Fi MGMT VLANs 100 & 101 Node 2 (Default Gateway) -	Old ZD and core SW are still accessible in case we need to go back and check some of the old network configuration.  Logistics: -	There are about 30 spare Chromecasts in the Simi Office that belong to The Row. If Chromecast devices need to be replaced we are supposed to get the rooms numbers from them pre-configured the units in the office and ship them. -	Some spare APs were left in the engineering department (2-H510s, 1-R510, & 1-R750) -	50+ preconfigured remotes were left in the engineering department ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Old Data: Our Backbone runs through the Admin's Switches which are all fed via Fiber and run back to the Admin's Fiber Core switch in the MDF. We are running 2 Vlans through their system. Our Management - Vlan 1000 and GuestWifi Vlan 3000. We then have our own switches which feed all of our AP's (Nnote that on floors 3,5,7,9,11,14,16,18,20,& 24 there is a 24port POE and an 8 Port POE switch feeding the APs). There is an IDF every 2 Floors starting on the 3rd Floor. here is how they Layout  Basement  MDF 3rd 5th 7th 9th 11th 14th 16th 18th 20th 22nd 24th 26th 28th   ALL APs ARE POE FED!!!   Chromecast Server Setup: To get the server online, please connect WAN VLAN (untagged) to IPMI and LAN2 To get the casting portion working, please connect: WAN1 - VLAN 500 Tagged WAN2 - VLAN 201 and 100 Tagged LAN1 - VLAN 100 Untagged (for the future)

column67: This network, with its own Fusion, is for Conference area wifi and wall jacks. The hotel has a separate Ruckus based Guest Wifi network but is separate from the conference equipment. The phone room on the 1st floor behind reception is the MDF. The Fusion and core switch (10.190.48.10) are located there. The 3rd floor has 2 stacked Cisco switche and one Cisco 48 port switch located in the storage room between the Monterey and Carmel Meeting rooms. The APs for the 2nd and 3rd floor meeting rooms are powered by PoE from this IDF. The Cisco Wireless Controller is also located in the 3rd floor IDF.         There is also an IDF in the 4th floor AV Office. This switch powers 2 of the Ballroom APs.          There is an IDF on the 25th floor and this IDF has two Cisco switches. There are 4 APs covering the 25th floor meeting rooms and they are powered from the swithces in this IDF.          The APs are located in the following meeting rooms or in the meeting room Foyers: AP1-Medoncino 3rd Fl. column68: Core Switch: 10.7.254.254  ********************************************************************************************* ******** IN CASE OF FUSION FAILURE MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK ******* ********************************************************************************************** 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 142.44.73.150 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, Open New Terminal CLI: "system ssh user=your-radius-user 10.7.254.254" ----- and the PW: your-radius-password 3. Once on the CoreSW (LPHL-MDF-SW1), disable the SW port when the Fusion-LAN2 (port 1/2/2) is to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select "SW-MGMT-VLAN-7" and change the IP address from 10.7.0.254/16 to 10.7.0.1/16 5. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 6. Select the submenu Addresses List on the IP menu and enable all the Addresses. 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers.  Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: 7, 8, 700, 800, 801, 816, 835, 1000, 1016  -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH13/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser. **************************************************************************************************.

column66: The Main Fiber Plugs into port 15 on the Core switch on vlan 900. WAN 2 back up cable modem pugs into the core switch on port 20 on VLAN2.     the MDF the Fusion feeds the Core switch and also connect to the PMS system via Cat5. Each IDF has 1 or 2 Cat5 runs to the MDF and this is how they are fed.   Currently the Lobby APs and Lounge AP are feed the Core switch.   The Ruckus APs in the guest hallway ceilings are fed via Cat5 from HP, Aruba, and Brocade witches in the IDFs on floors 5, 10, 17 and 19. See the WAP list for port mapping info.  H510 AP are installed in the Rooms, some rooms are Hard Capped so they are mounted outside the door.  R610 for Lounge is located right in the middle of the Lounge.  North Lobby AP is located in the Baggage holding room.  South Lobby AP is located in an access panel in the ceiling next to the Fire control station, which is located next to the Guest Elevators.    House keeping AP's are located in three locations: Trash room, Main Office, Laundry holding area near to the lower basement elevator.  Engineering AP's are located in the Engineering office, Paint Area and Water heater area.  Mechanical AP's are located in the Mechanical room on the 20th floor.  the AP's are installed on each side of the room.  HR/Accounting offices have 2 H510 AP's located in the Hallway in near the Director of HR office and in the Kitchen near the Accounting office.  Executive office has 2 AP (1 H510 and a R610) located in the conference room and in the office at the end of the hallway.
column67: The Fusion, SmartZone, ZD, and Core switch are located in the MDF. This is on the ground floor phone room in the service elevator hallway.   The 2nd floor IDf is where the ISP router is, we have a Cat5 cable that runs to the MDF from here to feed the Fusion. This IDF is also in the elevator lobby.   There are 4 IDF's that have Poe switches installed in them. The IDF is not a room but an area in the south end of the service elevator lobby mounted near the exit. the IDF floors are 5,10,17 and 19. Each IDF has either 3 Poe switches installed with a mix of directly terminated cables and patch panels. The housekeeping IDF is located in the Basement in Stacy's (Housekeeping Directors office).  The guest room APs are installed in the drop ceilings in the guest hallway, the Lobby APs are installed in the 2nd floor lobby ceiling in the south west corner and the north east corner. The Lounge/restaurant AP is installed in the ceiling near the second spot light bank near the 2nd closest spot light to the entrance.   See pictures for details.
column68: IF FUSION FAIL!!! ---------------------------------------------------- We have an Spare Gateway onsite: Mikrotik using different Public IP address --- 207.237.190.72 How to pass the traffic over the Mikrotik? 1. Login into the Mikrotik using WinBox Software. 2. Go over: Interfaces/Ethernet 3. Double Click on LAN/Eth2 and enable the Interface, then Apply. 4. At this moment you can have access to the core SW via SSH through the Mikrotik. 5. Do ssh on the CoreSW (172.17.0.10) through the Mikrotik. 6. Disable the port on CoreSW for Fusion LAN. 7. Verify you are getting ARP and check with someone onsite that the WiFi services is working.   IDF switches at this property are prone to overheating.  When they are overheating the PoE usually stops working.  This can be solved by cleaning the switches. Please contact Shawn at 646-393-7827, the cause is that the Laundry shoot is next to the IDF and the fans get clogged with Lint.  Recommend that a tech blow compressed air to clean out the vents of the SW.

column66: Consists of a VDSL2 system with Versa VDSL switch feeding modems in guest rooms connected to R510s. The 400reds building, where the meeting rooms are located, has to IDFs with ICX switches that are connected to the MDF via an Enable-IT VDSL bridge.
column67: Located in rack in GM's office.  The Modem is black  Fusion is on rack. The Versa VDSL switch, ZD1200 and HP Procurve core switch are also on the rack. There is a port on the Versa DSLAM that connects to a Versa VDSL bridge in the maintence room on grond level of Building A. This bridge feeds internet to the 5th floor meeting room.  Ruckus R510 APs are located in rooms listed on the WAP list. They are located either behind the curtain by the sliding glass door or behind the TV. There is a hotel owned Dell internet station located in the lobby. (MAC: 00-19-b93c-8c-a3)     The Baron and Stratton meeting rooms on the 5th floor of the 400 building have a R510 and a R510 respectively. These two APs are powered from an ICX IDF switch in the chair closet on the 5th floor. There is an R610 in the Matador meeting room on the 5th. There is also an un-managed switch in the Matador Meeting providing hardwire connection for guest attendees. The R610 in the Matador is powered from the ICX switch in the maintenance office on the first floor. The maintennce office IDF also provides the link to the MDF in the Lobby building via an EnableI-IT VDSL bridge.     There is an IDF consisting of an 8 port ICX switch in the Sales Office in the Gym building. This switch powers an R510 in the Sales Office and an R650 in the Gym itself. This switch is uplinked from the MDF via a Cat5e cable running from the MDF through the sir to the Gym building.
column68: Core Switch is the default gateway for the Fusions fiber uplink.  See WAN IP Info section for details.  ISP hand off comes into core switch on port 13, and Feeds the Fusion on port 14 The Aruba 2530-8G switch in the MDF (SW-MDF-1-02) is just there to drive the uplink cable to the Sales Office switch. The HP core switch (SW-MDF-101) wont drive the uplink cable directly, by actual testing.

column66: This System is a Fiber/Cat6 Infrastructure. From the MDF fiber goes to 4 IDF's on the 6th floor. Each of the 4 IDF's feeds IDF's on the 2nd, 4th, and 8th Floors. From there we have power being fed to in room AP's. These are 7055 AP's In wall with 4 LAN ports. They are Duel band AP's as well.  To see More detail, See network Diagram which is located in the Google Docs section under Properties, Northern California, Stanford Court Hotel
column67: MDF - Located on Lower Lobby Level. It is the Main Network Room on that Floor.  Fusion LG Series (RS) Zone Director 3250 Core Switch (ICX 7450 48P) IDF Switches - In each of the four closets at the corners of floors 2, 4, 6, and 8. Lobby Front Office Server Room IDF - There is an HP 2530 48p PoE switch in this server room that services AP195-8. The Rest of the Switches and AP's are located throughout the property. Please note that All Guest room AP's are in the Room and are powered via POE. To get a list and description of where all the equipment is located please see Equipment List in the Google Docs section under Properties, Northern California, Stanford Court Hotel
column68: 1.) Most of the IDF switches are HP 10/100 switches and when the demand on the 10/100 ports gets above 100megs the switch starts getting Tx drops. As a guest I experienced this and it manifests as random ping timeouts and slowed download/upload speeds. The guest bandwidth was originally set at 120mbps but I changed this to 40mbps to reduce the issue. I was seeing the issue occur when the total bandwidth demand got above 300megs. 2.) Sonifi StayCast casting server connects on the Lobby IDF switch. It's getting its ISP Feed from vlan2 on the Lobby switch. Realize that that vlan2 goes via 6th floor IDF switches to get to the Lobby IDF switch.  1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 12.161.61.164 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 10.60.30.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN3 is (1/3/3) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "bridge1" and change the IP address from 10.60.30.3/24 to 10.60.30.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Private Conv - VLAN 27, Guest-WiFi-192.168.48.1/22-VLAN100, Vendor-10.0.120.1/24-VLAN120, Guest Wired DHCP Pool, Vendor-192.168.65.1/24-VLAN250, Convention-192.168.70.1/23-VLAN300, Lobby-192.168.80.1/24-VLAN400, GalleryWiFi-192.168.90.1/24-VLAN500, Chromecast - VLAN 800 - Reserved, PoS Tablet - 192.168.211.1/24 - VLAN 801, WIFIMGMT - VLAN 802 192.168.4.1/24 -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.

column66: Main Gateway at the property is an Edge Router --- Our Fusion is behind it. ------------------------------------------------- Our Fusion manages the the Guest-Wi-Fi and Encore router the conference space.  All their equipment is Cisco (switches, WLCs, & APs. The APs will not be monitored for now. If you need to check AP status please login into each controller and check.  --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
column67: MDF (Fusion, Mikrotik, Core switch, Edge router and both wireless controllers) Located in the main building server room by the elevator.  --------------------------------------------------------------- Please find IDFs locations in the equipment list --------------------------------------------------------------- The Guestroom APs are in the hallway ceilings (Not visible) The common area APs are not visible either.
column68: Please contact the local IT if troubleshooting is needed: Scott Brock IT Manager 831-313-3686  The SNMP community name for all devices on this property is "Hotelw1f1" as our regular community wasn't supported on some devices.  ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Encore manages their conference space and they have their own router and switches. The wireless does come from the same Cisco APs that we manage; but when there is a meeting Encore comes to the property and make the hardwire connections to their switches and the local IT enables and renames the corresponding SSID. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- They currently have 2 wireless controllers. If a change is made please update both controllers: They went into renovation during COVID and some of the old APs were buried inside the ceiling and  they decided to add a new controller with additional APs to improve the signal. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ Additional notes:  They have in-room hardwired connections behind the desk. The in-room jacks are connected to unmanaged switches and tied back to VLAN 501.  IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 70.233.117.67 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 192.168.99.3 user=hisadmin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN1 (Gi1/0/9) and LAN2 (Gi1/0/10) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "VLAN-100-MGMT" and change the IP address from 192.168.100.254/24 to 192.168.100.4/24 6. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "VLAN-99-MGMT" and change the IP address from 192.168.99.253/24 to 192.168.99.254/24 7. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: VLAN-10-Guest_WiFi, VLAN 11 -10.71.0.1/20, VLAN 15 - 192.168.15.1/24, VLAN 20 - 192.168.20.1/24, VLAN 25 - 192.168.25.1/24, VLAN 30 - 192.168.30.1/24, VLAN-99-MGMT, VLAN-100-MGMT, VLAN 110 - 192.168.110.1/24, VLAN-200-Complimentary, VLAN-240-Thermostat, VLAN-300-MFA, VLAN 501-GuestHardwired 10.251.0.0/22, VLAN-504-Staycast-Device

column66: Allo is the current ISP, they are providing a 1Gig/1Gig Fiber feed to the hotel and is handing off the service via ethernet.   Ethernet cables in the Guest rooms have been run thru the right hand side of the hallway, where there is a chase.  The left hand side is were the Sprinkler system is located.  AP's located in the common areas are connect to ethernet connections in the ceiling. The Guest room hallways have Access panels in the middle of the hard cap and along the Chase on the right hand side.  We have left a pull string in the right hand chase just incase we need to run any new ethernet cable.  In all guest rooms the AP's are located above the Door, but for the 16th floor there is no room to mount the AP above the door so an access panel was installed in the closet where the AP is mounted face down.  BOH AP's are located in the Basement Breakroom, Housekeeping, and Engineering.  2nd Floor we have guest rooms but we also have the Fitness center, Pool, Terrace area that we use a T310 AP, one is located in the inside pool, the other is located in the terrace area to the left and right hand side to the pool.
column67: Fusion - is located in the MDF (basement)  Virtual Smartzone - Cloud  Mikrotic - MDF  WattBox - MDF  Switches: 172.16.34.10 - MDF Core SW 172.16.34.11 - 5th floor IDF 172.16.34.12 - 9th floor IDF 172.16.34.13 - 14th floor IDF  AP's are located in the common areas (basement, BOH,1st floor, Front desk, Restaurant, Fitness center, Pool, Terrace area) Guest rooms - Even floors odd rooms have AP's, Odd floors Even rooms have AP's.
column68: IF FUSION FAIL!!! ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- We have an Spare Gateway onsite: Mikrotik using different Public IP address --- 209.50.15.131 How to pass the traffic over the Mikrotik? 1. Login into the Mikrotik using WinBox Software. (Software required on your PC---> Download WinBox.exe from: https://mikrotik.com/download) 2. Go over: Interfaces/Ethernet 3. Double Click on LAN/Eth2 and enable the Interface, then Apply. 4. At this moment you can have access to the core SW via SSH through the Mikrotik. 5. Do ssh on the CoreSW (172.16.34.10) through the Mikrotik. 6. Disable the port on CoreSW for Fusion LAN. 7. Verify you are getting ARP and check with someone onsite that the WiFi services is working. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  Allo Fiber circuit is located is located in the MDF Top Right hand side of the wall, this ISP is using a ADTran and is providing service via ethernet handoff.  AP's located in the common areas are connect to ethernet connections in the ceiling,  the basement, and the 1st floor ethernet connections are labled for example A1-48, B1-48, C1-48.  The patch panel that these connections are connected to are right next to the Guest network half rack.  Please note you will need to tone out the connection and test the cable.   The following floors go to the following IDF's Floors 2-6 go to the 5th floor IDF Floors 7-11 go to the 9th floor IDF Floors 12-16 go to the 14th floor IDF  Ethernet cables in the Guest rooms have been run thru the right hand side of the hallway, where there is a chase.  The left hand side is were the Sprinkler system is located.  The Guest room hallways have Access panels in the middle of the hard cap and along the Chase on the right hand side.  We have left a pull string in the right hand chase just incase we need to run any new ethernet cable.  In all guest rooms the AP's are located above the Door, but for the 16th floor there is no room to mount the AP above the door so an access panel was installed in the closet where the AP is mounted face down.  2nd Floor we have guest rooms but we also have the Fitness center, Pool, Terrace area that we use a T310 AP, one is located in the inside pool, the other is located in the terrace area to the left and right hand side to the pool.  The AP's all run to the 5th floor IDF.  We ran 3 seperate 6stand fiber cables each cable is connected to the Core SW and to the 5th,9th and 14th floor IDFs, the color scheme for the fiber is blue/orange, green/brown, grey/white

column66: The Fusion is mounted and connected in the MDF which is connected with the IDFs via fiber and the access point are fed via a PoE switches. This building has 1 MDF located on the 1st floor next room 137.  IDF1 is in the Lobby/Office area where the GM sits.  IDF2 is located on the 2nd floor next to room 239.  The T300 AP's are located near the Cera Bodega Bar and the Serenity Pool.
column67: The Fusion is mounted and connected in the MDF which is connected with the IDFs via fiber and the access point are fed via a PoE switches. This building has 1 MDF located on the 1st floor next room 137.  IDF1 is in the Lobby/Office area where the GM sits.  IDF2 is located on the 2nd floor next to room 239.  The two T300 AP's are located in the Cera Bodega Bar and the Serenity Pool they are being feed by the HP Switch in IDF1 Lobby 10.20.28.11.  All Aruba AP's are located by the desk in the rooms, they are connected with a Cat 5e connection.  Please note that there is a server room for Highgate systems, and that is located on the 1st floor near the MDF.
column68: This is an in-room Aruba deployment with 103H access points. In the Pool area there are 2 Ruckus T-300s that are standalone IPs: 10.20.29.1 & 10.20.19.2  *** Please see the "Other" Section of the Docs for a guide on creating and editing networks in the Aruba Wireless Controller ***   ***************************************************************************************************** There is a hidden SSID named "aireus" on this network using VLAN 805. We are only providing Layer 2 for this SSID and passing it to the admin network via untagged VLAN 805 port 44 on the core switch (10.20.28.10) to their firewall.  In addition, there is no DHCP server on our Layer 2 segment, so any devices connecting to this network will need a static IP provided by Edge.  Van Owens is a good POC for this. vowens@edgecommunications.com  Note, aireus is a POS system replacing micros. Do not use this VLAN for anything else. There are also a few standalone Ruckus APs for the pool area. They are aware that roaming will not work the same in this area.  The standalone APs are attached to the 10.20.28.10 switch.    Below is the IP mapping for the aireus POS system. We do not control these IPs, this was provided by Van Owens at Edge. This is just for informational purposes.  At the time of this note the 2 mini iPADs are the only devices using the aireus SSID. The other devices are using hardwired ports on the same VLAN (805) -08/29/2022 reference FD # 32224  aireus server	 192.168.100.200  ipad 1	 192.168.100.114  ipad 2	 192.168.100.115  ipad 3	 192.168.100.116  ipad printer 1	 192.168.100.117  ipad printer 2	 192.168.100.118  ipad printer 3	 192.168.100.119  mini ipad 1	 10.255.4.10  mini ipad 2	 10.255.4.11  kitchen printer 1 192.168.100.120  -David.G 08/25/2022 *****************************************************************************************************

column68: IF FUSION FAILS, MOVE TRAFFIC OVER MIKROTIK: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1. Use Winbox software to log into the Mikrotik 76.81.137.61 (admin/GsquidPineapplejelly7&) 2. From the Mikrotik ssh into Core SW, run: "system ssh 172.16.0.10 user=admin" ----- and use the PW: SsquidPineapplejelly7& 3. Once on the CoreSW, disable the SW port when the Fusion LAN1 is (1/1/21) to ensure it won't be traffic over the Fusion. 4. Enable all the VLANs under the Interfaces menu under the VLAN tab. 5. On the IP menu, select the submenu Addresses, then select the interface "Mgmt-172.16.0.0/24-VLAN100" and change the IP address from 172.16.0.254/24 to 172.16.0.1/24 6. Select the submenu DHCP Server on the IP menu and enable all the DHCP servers. Notes: - These are the VLANs currently configured in the Mikrotik: Mgmt-172.16.0.0/24-VLAN100, Guest-192.168.10.0/23-VLAN200, Staff-WiFi-192.168.20.1/24-VLAN600. -In case a local connection is needed on the Mikrotik, please use ETH5/Local, make your PC static on 192.168.88.100/24, then type this IP 192.168.88.1 on the browser.

column66: This property does not have  monitoring or maintenance support. We installed a Fusion for them to replace their existing gateway.  However, here is some information regarding the networks that they currently have: The property has three parts as far as networks are concerned. There is the Lobby/administrative building, the Time Shares, and the Resort hotel.  The Lobby/Administrative building is at the entrance of the property. This building has its own MDF and ISP Feed and APS. Then there is the Time Share portion which has a separate owner and its own wifi. Lastly there is the hotel/resort portion which is now managed by Hersha (same as Larkspur) and has its own wifi and is the network that the Fusion is attached to. The Fusion is connected into a Netgear Core Switch which goes to a ZD1100 and Ruskus 7363s in each of the hotel beach house buildings. Some APs are MESHed from one building to another. The Guest LAN is on 172.20.1.1/22 (guest DHCP pool) and the Equipment (ZD and APs) are on 192.168.100.1/22. The Default IP of 192.168.5.1/24 still exists on Fusion LAN 2.
column67: This was a Fusion only install with no monitoring or maintenance support agreement. However, here is some information about their network. The guest wifi network consists of 3 Comcast ISP modems, a Fusion, a Netgear ProSafe GS728TP Core Switch, ZD1100, and Ruckus 7363 dualband APs.  The Fusion is configured with a static IP on one of the Comcast Modems. The Fusion is set for DHCP on the other two ISP  modems.          The Modems, Fusion, ZD1100, and Core Switch is located in the "Ice Machine" Building near the 717-617 Building. There is outdoor Cat5e/6 cable connecting to root 7363 APs in the surrounding buildings. These roots link via MESH to APs in nearby buildings. The APs are currently located in each buildings maintenance/storage closets on the 1st floor.

column66: This is a new type of system for us. This is a fully automated parking garage that uses the Root/Mesh APs to transfer data from the main computer to the small computers on each and every machines. These small computers are called PLC's (Programmable logic controllers)  We have a Fusion in place to hand out DHCP to the guests in the Waiting area. They wanted Wifi to be available for the guests in the waiting areas.   Here is the basic topology for the network.   Fusion to Core Switch. Core switch ties into their main server and North garage POE Switch. The Core Switch feeds POE to all the South garage Roots. The North garage POE Switch feeds POE to all North garage Roots.
column67: The main equipment is in the south garage control room. There is a POE switch in the North garage in a small network room that gets its feed from the south garage core switch. This north garage POE switch feeds all north garage Root AP's.  There are a bunch of mesh APs that are located on moving machines. These machines consist of LCM (Lower carrier machines) UCM (Upper carrier machines) and REM (Rack entry machine) VLC (Vertical lift carrier) PS (Pallet shuttle)

column66: There are 18 Ruckus APs installed on the property. 2 in Taper dorm 2 in Rochlin dorm 2 in Keefer dorm 2 in Lee dorm 6 in main administration bldg 2 in Student Union bldg The APs in the dorms are fed by 4-port PoE switches in each building's IDF. Internet feed comes from a SonicWall in the MDF of the Student Union Bldg. DHCP comes from a separate server The APs in the main bldg run through switches in the IDFs and MDF of that building, which is then linked via fiber to the SonicWall in the MDF of the Student Union Bldg. DHCP comes from a separate server. The APs in the Student Union Bldg are fed via a PoE switch in the MDF of the Student Union Bldg. Internet feed comes from a SonicWall in the MDF of the Student Union Bldg. DHCP comes from a separate server.
column67: Dorms: 2 APs are installed in the 2nd floor hallways of each dorm. APs are dome-down, visible on the ceiling. These are right above the front door and are there to cover the outdoor sitting areas.  Main Administration Building: There are 6 APs installed in the main building: - 3rd Fl Lobby, which is located in the drop ceiling directly above the old, disconnected Cisco AP that is mounted on the ceiling tile. - 3rd Fl Gindi Auditorium, which is located stage left on the wall. - 3rd Fl Cafeteria, which is located inside the ceiling tiles in the larger of the two rooms. - 1st Fl Temp Library, which is located inside the ceiling tiles in the study area, directly above the RJ45 port in the ceiling. - 1st Fl Synagogue, which is located inside the ceiling on the north side of the main Synagogue space. - 1st Fl Terrace, which is located inside the overhang to the south of the synagogue, about 3ft west of the access panel. column66: There are three satellite dishes on the roof, but four total LNBs (the device that takes the signal off the dish). One dish has an LNB that acts as two and has two cables coming from it instead on one as with the other two dish LNBs.        The satellite dishes are connected to a grounded connector and from there, four RG6 coax cables go down the outside of the building to the 2nd floor Housekeepers Lunch room next to the elevator. From the lunch room, these cables are connected to another set of four cables that go to the Office Room next to 216 on the 2nd floor. A fifth cable comes from the Housekeepers Lunch room from the input of the video amp, so there are actually 5 cables going from that room to the Office Room down the hall.         There is an equipment rack in that Office Room and the Smartbox is mounted in that rack. The four RG6 satellite cables are connected to a box called a 'DISH 4-Port High-Capacity Power Inserter'. That box provides power to the LNBs. From this box, four RG6 patch cables are connected to the connectors on the input side of the Smartbox.            The fifth cable coming into the room is connected to the blad in the output slot and is the feed to the video amp in the Housekeepers Lunch room. The output of the video amp provides the TV signal to the TVs on floors 1-8. Of note is that there is a large LCD TV in the conference room on the 8uth floor and that TV is also feed from this amp.         The Smartbox has four network jacks. Network port 1 on the Smartbox gives you acces to the Smartbox GUI. Port 1 on the Smartbox is connected via patch cable to the Comcast Modem directly above the Smartbox.
column67: The three satellite dishes are located on the roof above the 8th floor. There is a stairway up to the elevator room and then from there a door to the roof.     The Smartbox is located in the Office room next to room 216 on the 2nd floor. The video amp for the hotel is located in the Housekeepers Lunch room next to the elevators, also on the 2nd floor.

column66: APs that are installed on site are all connected to WAN ONT (fiber terminal) nodes. They all communicate back to the ZDs, that are installed in the CenturyLink data center, via Secured Tunnel. From there APs talk to our Cluster of Fusions, that are load balancing the traffic, and out to the internet. The system backbone essentially is CenturyLink Fiber.

column68: ***Kiosk Support*** If the client calls in for kiosk support we do need to help them.  Our job is to take down whatever information they give us, and relay this information to Neil Blidner neil@ttitel.com.  TTI will then work on the kiosk problem.  We relay the communication back and forth between TTI and the property. ***End Kiosk Support***  In the Fusion LAN1 is for the convention network and the core switch is the 2920 and LAN2 is for the guest network and the core switch is the 2530.  Do not change SSID setup if you do not fully understand it. It is there for a reason. 2920 switches cannot support more than 256 VLAN symotaniously, so we are tunneling per account dynamic VLANs to public spaces via 2920 core switch.  2530s on the other hand can support up to 512 VLANs. We are using VLANs 197-600 for the guest rooms where 2530s are present.   RAD-STAFF SSID is setup with RADIUS authentication for the admin network. It's fully controlled on the admin side, including DHCP and traffic handling. If this breaks, most likely something got changed on their side. The only config place we can change is under ZD -> Config -> WLAN -> RAD-STAFF SSID.  ********IMPORTANT*********** For any down AP that we are unable to bring back up remotely, please email 'rjames@ghgkz.com' 'jlanyon@ghgkz.com' and servicedesk@ghgkz.com   ************************************  I was told that this property's preferred contact for technical issues is by email. The email address that should be used is "technologyservices@ghgkz.com".    Charles 7/7/2017

column66: There is an HP ProCurve 2810-24G switch that is both the WAN and LAN core switch: http://209.249.118.4:60054 Ports 1-4, 10, 12 are on the WAN VLAN (1500). The ISP comes into port 1; the Guest Node, Convention Node and Cluster Controller are on ports 2-4; ports 10 & 12 are for hotel use.   Ports 5-7 are on VLAN 1501 and are for the cluster communication between the controller and nodes. All other ports are for either the convention LAN or guest LAN and are on their respective VLANs (see equipment list).  There are three Fusions at this location. One acts as a controller and houses all of the databases and configuration for its nodes. There are two nodes; one is for the guest network and one is for the convention network.  The guestroom switches (Ciscos) are located in IDFs on specific floors as outlined in the network documentation. The switches feed the wired room connections as well as all access points. The switches are not PoE; PoE injectors power all APs. The wireless network is Ruckus. The Guest WLAN is assigned VLAN 2. VLAN 2 is trunked back through the switches, not tunneled to the ZD.  Guest Towers Switches: The VLANs of all guest tower switches are configured with VTP. The Center Tower 10th floor switch (10.65.5.4) is the VTP server, all other switch are clients to this server. VTP Version 2; VTP Domain: westin-guest; VTP Password: 509hki.   STP is set to pvst (per-vlan spanning tree) and enabled on all VLANs. The Center Tower 10th Floor switch is set as the root bridge. All wired connection ports are have PortFast enabled. This allows laptops and other such user devices to have an immediate connection, but if a switch is plugged into one of these ports, the port will disable.  DHCP Snooping is also enabled on all VLANs on all switches. Only the ports interconnecting switches are trusted ports, meaning they allow DHCP packets. This blocks all rogue DHCP servers that may get plugged into wired room connections. Additionally, DHCP rate limiting is set on all untrusted ports so that someone can't do a DoS attack on our DHCP server.  Guest Tower WAPs H500s WAPs are installed inside rooms now. We use 2 data pairs that we take from the single cat5 coming into the room. The other 2 pairs are used for 2 lines of the analog telephone in the room.
column67: The Fusions, core switch and ZD are in a 4-post half rack in the MDF/telephone room located on the basement level near engineering office. Room switches are located in electrical rooms on specific floors noted in network diagram.  APs for the Executive Office Suite 508 and Suite 513 connect to a switch located in the 5th floor Electrical Room Suite 510. There is 1 linksys Switch, 2 trend-net switch and a fiber transceiver. All of the devices are labeled for the Guest Wifi.  Guest room APs are in the ceiling of the hallways. See equipment list for specifics.  See WAP list for location of convention switches.
column68: *******Please do not render any services, beyond those monthly contracted, to the hotel until a PO number has been provided to you by either Hilton Sher or Aaron Gonzalez.*******  if any of the Guest Ap's go down Find out what switch they are connected to and disable then enable the port. 95% of the time that will bring the ap's back up.  If WAPs go down and can't be recovered it is very possible that cable needs to be repaired. Some cabling was "repaired" using wirenuts for electrical cables.  If the hardwire connection not working for a guest - 90% chance it has to be fixed. Someone went through and spliced 3 ethernet cables inside the room together with electrical wirenuts. Especially this is a concirn for any suite and full floors 23-25.   Jaime Villanueva requested to remove Pool Switch and APs from management because they were replaced.

column66: MDF is located on the 2nd floor electrical closet. The MDF core SW feeds the 5th floor IDF via Fiber up-link. The IDF is located in the 5th floor electrical closet. The MDF's and the IDF's equipment are mounted into a tall vertical standing rack. In the MDF Comcast ISP feeds the Fusion trough the Core SW (HP 3500-24G-PoE+yl). The Core SW feeds the other switches, the ZD, the WPS, the Pool AP and 4 hardwired rooms (blue patch cables). The  the Lobby and the Conference AP are located on the 1st floor and connected to the 2nd SW (HP 2530-48G-PoE) in the MDF. The 1st, 2nd, 3rd floor APs (H500) were installed in the guestrooms behind the TV and those are connected to the 2nd SW (HP 2530-48G-PoE) in the MDF.  Every other room what doesn't have an AP are connected to the 2nd SW and the Core SW as hardwired. The 4th, 5th, and 6th floor APs (H500) are connected to the 1st SW (HP 2530-48G-PoE) on the 5th floor IDF and the hardwired rooms are connected to the 2nd SW (HP 2530-48G-PoE). The PMS device are connected to the Fusion, but not connected to their device because it wasn't present. Both electrical closet has a UPS also.

The IDF is located on the 5th floor electrical closet which has also a vertical standing rack and our 2 SW (HP 2530-48G-PoE) are mounted in it powered from a UPS.

column66: This system deployed H500 APs in guest rooms. From the basement MDF fiber connection goes to Bellman's IDF on lobby level. From here, CAT5 backbone home run goes to each IDF on the guest floors. Each guest floor IDF is located in the vending machine room.  White CAT5 cable was run from the IDF down the hallway, attached to a concrete wall, to specific guest rooms. Hotel plans to install hard cap ceiling which will cover up the cabling and asbestos ceiling as part of major renovation expected to begin in 2016.   The Bellman's IDF is located at the entrance to the hotel.  This system connects to the property PMS system. The link comes from the Bellman's IDF to a switch in the PBX room which then goes to the room where the PMS server is located.  The B-LEVEL IDF ls located in a storage room near the elevator. APs for the public spaces and meeting rooms are ceiling mounted. The Biz Center AP is located in a locked cabinet where the public computers are located.  Heat mapping was done for this project were clients request. Raw data files are posted to CRM.
