column32: Four Points by Sheraton San Diego
column66: This network uses R500, H510, R610 and T610 APs and are controlled by a Smart Zone 1200. They are connected to PoE Brocade switches.   Cat 6 cables were used to run from each IDF to the MDF and to the AP's. There is a spare cable run to each the guest room IDF's.    Meeting Rooms -  These are non-ruckus APs. They connect to a DLINK switch mounted in the service are between restaurant and meeting rooms. This area was not part of the initial installation/upgrade. No data on switch or AP configuration.
column67: MDF - Back office on first floor behind Front Desk. Fusion, ZD and Core Switch are mounted on a rack on the left hand side.  Guest Room APs  R500s and H510's are located on all 3 floors in the entry way past the bathrooms of guest rooms up next to the ceiling.  Room 3051 is the only exception to this. The H510 is located behind the main door into the guest room. (Old 7372 APs were mounted vertically in the hallways. These have been disconnected or removed as they are no longer being supported by the ZD's current firmware)  Public Area APs - Lobby - R610 Mounted horizontally on drop ceiling at main entrance. Atrium - R610 Mounted horizontally on drop ceiling on second floor between the meeting rooms. Pool - T610 Mounted vertically on the pool storage building next to the fitness room.  Restaurant - R500 Mounted horizontally on the drop ceiling in the middle of the restaurant.  Meeting Space APs Pavilion Room - There are 3 R610's laying inside of the drop ceiling. Each of these AP's are located next to a pillar. The 1st and last pillar on the left side of the room and the 3rd pillar on the right side of the room. You will need a scissor lift to reach these AP's. Palm Room - There are 2 R610's laying freely inside the drop ceiling. One is in the A room the other is in the D room. Both are in the center of the room next to where the room partitions move across.  Meeeting Space Hardline Connections Palm Meeting Rooms - All hardline connections for the Palm rooms A-D go back to the D-Link Switch. This is connected to the Palm Ruckus Switch on port 1/1/12. Pavilion Meeting Rooms - Hardline connections can either be from the Pavilion SW or from a Netgear unmanaged switch at the main entrance to the Pavilion rooms. The netgear switch is connected to the Pavilion switch on port 11.  IDF Locations A-Wing IDF - Is located in the A-Wing 2nd Floor electrical closet behind the vending and ice machines. B-Wong IDF - Is located in the B-Wing 2nd Floor electrical closet behind the vending and ice machines. Palm IDF - Is located high on the hallway wall between the Palm meeting rooms and restaurant kitchen. Pavilion IDF Switch is located in the back area

column68: This is a Stephen Durr property.   Do not deal directly with the property. Do not make any changes to his network without his authorization.  ***New Escalation Procedure for Stephen Durr Properties*** 1.	He is now being texted NOC alerts for GW’s, Wireless Controllers and switches for his properties. You don’t need to email him regarding those alerts, but you should email him for information about the devices as far as possible ETR, cause, if known,etc. so we can inform CAS. 2.	If the Call Center is receiving a lot of calls from a property and the equipment appears to be up, please call him and give him all the information. 3.	If a ticket is escalated and we cannot resolve the issue, we need to inform him of these with all pertinent information via email and a heads-up call. So, we need to pay close attention to the tickets and jump on any from his properties. If we call a guest and get vmail, close the ticket unresolved and email Stephen.  Stephen Durr 850-596-4378 stephen@net-worx.biz

column66: This property was upgraded from using 2942s located on only the 2nd floor to APs located on all floors powered via POE. 1st & 2nd floors ZF7372 are located in the drop ceilings. Existing data lines going to rooms were toned, cut and AP was put in. This method allowed wired room connection to be maintained. ZF7055 were put into rooms on the 3rd floor only. These are powered via POE. Some rooms had phones in the data jacks. Phone lines were put into the "passthrough" port of the WAP to maintain phone connectivity. All phones were checked after install and dial tone verified.   MDF - color coded cables were used. Yellow = POE device, Red = Uplink connection. Black=WAN connection. Blue=LAN connection. Devices were labeled and configured according to Marriott standards. Switches have VLANS configured on them.  Signal testing was performed using AirMagnet software. Heatmaps show that all rooms have a -65 dBM or better with the 5ghz band.
column67: Fusion, ZD, Core Switch, UPS, 2nd switch and cox modem are located in MDF on 1st floor of hotel building on the bottom of the rack closest to the door. Cables and switch are labeled. ZF7372 APs are located in drop ceilings on 1st & 2nd floors (location marked by red tape). ZF7055 are located in rooms on the 3rd floor. The are POE powered. A grey patch cable leads up to ubiquity sender located on the roof. A wireless bridge connects to receiver on the convention building. Sender is located in attic above storage room. A patch cable goes down to AP located in the storage room.

column68: Remotes for Quality Inn Southaven, MS This Inn has 2 brands of TV:  1.	Insignia which uses HDMI for the DIRECTV STB functions for the FTG STB are programmed into the slate remote. The “casting” and “TV” buttons are both programmed for the “input” scrolling menu for the TVs. HDMI is labeled “DIRECTV” and HDMI2 is Labeled “Chromecast” for the guestcast.  Scrolling to select the input is done by multiple presses of one button or the other. There is NO one press code for HDMI inputs on this consumer model TV 2.	Westinghouse: Which consists of 2 models: a.	One where the “source” button on the native remote only displays the input menu; then you need to navigate up or down and use the “OK” button” to select a new input. So these remotes required a macro for the two navigation buttons to function. See below for more detail on remote setup. b.	The other model the “Source” button brings up the input menus and scrolls in a downward fashion and loops through the input selections. The remotes for these TVs were programmed in front of the TV one at a time. See below for more details. Westinghouse remote programming- We had to use 4 of the blank [unlabeled] buttons on the remote to program “source” “Arrow up” “arrow down” and “OK” [select]. To build the Marcos on the remotes. The way the macros work if you use a key to build a macro you can’t change its assignment without effecting the macro. Also the EZ updater does not do a good job of duplicating the macros. So I have to correct Macros in front of every TV.  We have to have the arrow up and arrow down and OK buttons for FTG navigation. So I used the blank buttons on the remotes to copy the native remote as follows:  The button above the volume + [up} “Source” from the native remote The button below the volume – [down] “arrow up from the native remote The button below the Mute  “OK” button from the native remote The button below the CH – [channel down] button on the native remote With these buttons programmed – I was able to build macros for the Casting and TV buttons.   The remotes can be cloned with these buttons programmed for multiple remotes The 1, 2,3 to 9 and 0 [zero] must be programmed using the direct-TV remote [shipped on to Office with Masters] So the Westinghouse master has all of the buttons programmed for the TV Except the Casting and the TV which needs to be programmed using the 995 macro feature in front of the TV.

column68: This is a Stephen Durr property.  Do not deal directly with the property. Do not make any changes to his network without his authorization. The system at this property does not allow MAC exception to client isolation for wireless devices.   ***New Escalation Procedure for Stephen Durr Properties*** 1.	He is now being texted NOC alerts for GW’s, Wireless Controllers and switches for his properties. You don’t need to email him regarding those alerts, but you should email him for information about the devices as far as possible ETR, cause, if known,etc. so we can inform CAS. 2.	If the Call Center is receiving a lot of calls from a property and the equipment appears to be up, please call him and give him all the information. 3.	If a ticket is escalated and we cannot resolve the issue, we need to inform him of these with all pertinent information via email and a heads-up call. So, we need to pay close attention to the tickets and jump on any from his properties. If we call a guest and get vmail, close the ticket unresolved and email Stephen.  Stephen Durr 850-596-4378 stephen@net-worx.biz

column66: The AT&T line feeds the WAN of the ProCurve.  The T1 hooks directly up to a 5 port switch which feeds the hotel's PMS system and the hotel's Linksys router.  There is one cable in the ProCurve's LAN port and this cable is labeled as the hotel's guest network LAN.  This cable run goes upstairs into the 2nd floor breakfast room where it hooks into a small switch which is on a shelf above the door. This switch feeds an AP that is right next to it and sends another cable to two switches near the elevators, also on the 2nd floor.  The switches are in a locked white box near the vending machines. They are two large 24 port switches with almost every port having a cat 5 cable. These switches are for the wired room connections internet. Every room has a wired room connection.
column67: The ProCurve is located in the back office on the same cabinet as the hotels server / pms systsem.  There's also a Motorola Device connected to the ProCurve that may need to be reset. column66: This is a very simple network. There is only one network closet on the 3rd floor (MDF). Verizon router, ProCurve gateway, core switch, MDF switch 2, and Web Power Switch are all located here. Router, ProCurve (WAN and LAN ports), and WPS plug into MDF Switch 2, which is then connected to the Core Switch.  There are two PoE switches (Core Switch and MDF Switch 2) that feed all 28 access points. There are also 6 more switches for the guest room hard wires. All the APs are represented on a patch panel and then patch to the PoE switches. There were two types of APs installed 7055 in the rooms and 7352s in either first floor drop ceiling or 4th floor attic.
column67: The MDF is on the 3rd floor telephone room by the elevators. All the switches, ZD, ProCurve, and Web Power Switch are located in this room. The APs on the first floor(7352) are located on the drop ceiling. The APs on the 2nd and 3rd floor (7055's) are located inside the guest rooms; and the 4th floor APs are located in the attic.

column66: System was upgraded.  Ruckus install. From the 2nd floor MDF cables are run to the APs on the 3rd floor in the drop ceilings & 1st floor. APs are fed via POE. The fusion & HP POE core switch are rack mounted in the 2nd floor MDF. Each room also has a wired connection. There are 4 unmanaged D-link switches in the MDF.  Cables were run from MDF to location where biz center computer will eventually be placed on 2nd floor. A spare backup line for admin network was run from 2nd floor to 1st floor telco room.
column67: There are 4 7341 APs on 3rd floor located in the drop ceiling near the room listed on the WAP list. One AP (2942) is in the 2nd floor telco closet (MDF). Another is in the back office (1st floor) in drop ceiling near the door. The Fusion & HP POE core switch are in the MDF on the 2nd floor. Location was upgraded from 2 APs to 5. column66: HIS installed only the FUSIONs located at this property. All other equipment was preexisting.  The MDF is located in the basement, next to the IT director's office. The FUSIONs, ZD, and most of the switches are located here. The ISP feed comes into the core switch via a fiber uplink to the ISP's on-prem router. There are connections to both FUSIONs' WAN and LAN ports from the core switch. APs are patched to patch panels which are then connected to the switches. All switches in the MDF connect back to the Core Switch directly. There is an energy management system (Ving) in place which uses several of the switches, with each of the control units having its own wired connection.  Two switches are located in a separate closet on the 15th floor, just outside the service elevators. These also feed some of the APs and Ving controllers.  There are 126 APs that were previously installed, including ZoneFlex 7373, 7982, and 7055. APs are located in guest rooms on all guest floors (3-15), as well as the commons areas on the 1st floor and conference rooms on the 2nd floor.  The FUSIONS are set up for high availability, with daily backups being made of the primary FUSION configuration that is then sent to the backup FUSION. Failover is manual, however, and requires the most recent backup to be manually loaded from the backup FUSION's UI. Once this is done, the backup FUSION will immediately take over all functions of the primary. Do not activate a backup unless necessary as this will cause conflicts.

column66: This hotel owns the equipment. There are POE fed Ruckus AP on the 4th, 7th, 10th & 12th Floors. There are 10 aps per floor. Floors 4 & 7 are fed from a 24 port POE switch on the 5th Floor IDF and floors 10 & 12 are fed from a POE switch on the 12th floor IDF.   There is a Truffle that is aggregating the 2 internet feeds and a zone director to manage AP's. its accessible at 99.181.201.177  the truffle was removed Nick on February 02, 2011  There are 3 payment zones.   The lobby (HP procruve wireless type): paid via credit card only. Guestrooms: (Nomadix Gateway) Free to registered guests (PMS verification), paid via PMS & Credit card and Business Select which offers a static IP address. Convention Ballroom: (Colubris Gateway) - portal allows for username/password.  There are business center computer on property but are maintained by a different company.
column67: Guest room AP's are located in the drop ceilings on specific floors of the hotel. Gateways and core switch are located in MDF. IDF switches are located on specific floors noted in network document. (see below also).  *************************************************  ******************IPTV System Notes***************  Some rooms require room key to activate power in room. This is the Evolve system. The TV's and/or STB may end up in the outlet powered by this system. The always on outlet is the left one.  All the APs are inside drop seiling in the hallway. Most of the ceiling marked with black electrical tape for easier access to APs. All the APs are placed on the side of the elevators.   Each AP has its own cable run to it. They are placed in order in every switch starting from smaller room number. For instance AP_1202 is the in port 1 of the switch, AP 1207 is in the port 2 of the switch.

column66: Cox Uplink is connected to CoreSW port 20 on Vlan 900, Fusion Wan1 is connected to CoreSW port 21, IPMI is connected to CoreSW port 22 and WatTbox is connected to coresw on Port 23.  Uleashed AP's are connected to Ports 1-12 on CoreSW and the Unleashed AP Controller is connected to Port 1 with an IP of 172.16.0.50.  All the AP's are connected to the CoreSW via Ethernet cable.  The following guest Rooms have AP's installed, 101,103,105,201,203,205,207,301,303,305,307.  All the rooms except for room 103 and 105 are installed on top of the Main Door, the other rooms the AP is installed in the bedroom by the night stand.  Ethernet cable for Room 103 adn 105 are ran behind the Hotel by the Pool.  All other rooms have ethernet cables running down the hallway in outdoor white wire molding.  Ethernet for the guest rooms run from the MDF thru Engineering then thru housekeeping storage room.  From there it runs thru a hole that was created via core drilling, up to the second and 3rd floor and into the White external wire molding.  This process is done on both sides of the hotel.  The ethernet cable for Guest room 105 goes from the MDF to the Housekeeping office thru to the outside.  The cable runs along the bottom of the wall and zip tied to a PVC pipe.

column76: Fusion software support expired 6/21/12. They have made no effort to renew.   PMS Custom Field Mapping Info:  A0 - rate code  A1 - group code  A2 - block code  A3 - room type  A4 - membership type  A5 - membership number  A6 - source  A7 - membership level  A8 - special request  A9 - unused   We use data from two fields to provide free service to certain guests. A7 provides data on whether the guest is a Marriott Rewards Gold (X1), Platinum Elite (P6) or Platinum Premier (X4) member. A8 lets us know if the hotel has decided to give a guest free internet, which comes across as code I5. Fiber optic connection from MDF to each building. There are 3 switches in the MDF which have 2 gbics each. Each gbic goes to a specific building.  IDFs - Fiber connection recieved by HP POE switch which power WAPs. A 2nd non-poe switch is used for wired connections.
column67: ISP Circuit: MPOE for Fiber connection in the maintenance shop by the pool. There is only a fiber switch that was provided by Cox. A CAT5 cable runs through the underground conduit to the telephone room (MDF).  MDF - Telephone room. Lobby building. It is a door by the employee breakroom area. Has the Fusion, ZD, WPS, Core switch, additional HP switches with fiber gbic connection to building B-F. Equipment is in wall mounted rack.  IDFs - One in each building. Top floor. POE switch for WAPs & non POE switches for wired room connections. Equipment is in wall mounted wedge rack.  Main Building: WAP located in MDF. Another is located in the storage area facing the entrance to the fitness room. Business Center: A SMC switch is located for the room wall jacks is located in the drop ceiling above the printer on door side of room.  WAPs -   - Attic areas accessable via ventilation cover. -  IDFs - Rooms - located in kitchen area behind peg board. Access panel access to hollow space in wall.  All Guest room access points are behind peg board in access panel on Kitchen wall Attics are easily accessible from roof access in IDF in each building see Picture			 Main Building has Larger units on second floor.  These Units are serviced by the first floor common area AP's
column68: If the Fusion Gateway fails, login to the Mikrotik Gateway using Winbox and enable the LAN port. The Mikrotik can reach the core switch. The ISP is Cox.  They handoff their connection to Velocity (another vendor) into a device that Velocity refers to as a vband which is a switch.  The Fusion connects directly into the Velocity switch (vband) on port number 10 and the Fusion uses IP 70.166.222.213 on Fusion interface WAN1(em1) from this handoff. Juan is a good resource on location for troubleshooting.  For Guest LAN they are using Hyatt DNS 103.247.36.36 and 103.247.37.37 FD ticket 54138. CAROL RHYU did a whitelist to our public IP for these dns

column68: Everything is PoE fed, so the only time you would not be able to access something if the power went out.  The TVs are plugged into port 4 of the APs. APs are in every room. Ports 3 & 4 on the APs have VLAN ID of 850. Should a service call come in which describes a PROBLEM OF THE TV not having pictures when a channel is selected (black screen) but has power and cable guide menu, the solution is to REBOOT THE AP from the ZD. column68: This property is located on the beach front. If property reports loss of dial tone in bedroom IT IS NOT DUE TO THE DSLAM. It is most likely corrosion that has developed on either the phone cord or the jack in the wall. Steps: check wall phone for dial tone. Jiggle bedroom phone cable. Replace bedroom phone cord. Remove TW511 and replace phone face plate. CAUTION: POWER IS ON THE PHONE LINE. Make sure power is off before having tech work on phone jack.  2 Spare TW511, phone face plates, DSL filters for desk phone & wall phone were left with Carl.  We have a field nation tech that is good for maintenance at these properties.  His details are on the contacts page.  His name is Michael Dickerson

column66: Installed wireless system with 10 ruckus AP's. There is a fiber link between Bldg 1 (MDF) to Bldg 3 (idf) then from Bldg 3 to Bldg 4 (idf) & 2 (maintenence room). Trendnet media convertors were used. The blue & orange fiber cables were used. 2 APs were put in the attic space into bldgs 3 & 4 each by running CAT 5 from POE switch in IDF into attic space. Bldg 2 has an AP in the maintance room and a meshed AP in the laundry room. Bldg 1 has an AP mounted i the attic which covers lobby, MDF and convention space. There are up to 6 CAT 5 runs from this area to the patch panel in the MDF. There is a zone director, nomadix, 1 24 SMC managed switch and 2 24 port SMC unmanged switches in the MDF. 1 of the APs in bldg 1 is in the MDF. There are two 24 port unmanaged switches in IDF's 3 & 4 in which the room wired connections are plugged into. The timeout device will reboot the Nomadix, Ruckus & SMC managed switch but NOT the media convertor.      ALL the AP™s are located in the Attics except for the MDF AP and Building 2  AP mesh Laundry.

column66: Core equipment is located in the Basement, the Cat 5 cables run from there to the guest rooms for the phones.  This hotel do not have phones so we are using the cat 5 cables to provide service to our AP's.  These are H510 AP's so if the site decides to go with VOIP phones they can connect directly to the H510 POE port.  There are 2 buildings the first building has rooms from the first floor to the fourth floor.  The 1st floor only has room 101 and 102, the second floor has rooms from 201-204, the same for the 3rd floor and 4th floor.  The second building has rooms from the 1st floor to the 4th floor they are labeled x05 to x06. The Security cameras are getting an uplink from our core SW on Port 19 (192.168.20.1-254 vlan 300).  The NVR is located in the Office on the first floor in a Rack.  From there the NVR DHCP to all the Cameras.   Kasa SSID is for Admin and Staff use, this SSID is also being used by the door lock controllers which are located in various guest rooms.  The IP being used is Vlan 800 192.168.30.1/24  Kasa_Guest is the SSID for Guest staying in the Hotel, this SSID will be authenticated using the Portal Page  WiFiManagement is for HIS Admin.
column67: Basement is the MDF and all core equipment is located there.  All the AP's are located in the Guest rooms next to the bed.

column66: This property is still a work in progress. We were hired to install the Fusion and assist with the installation. Due to several factors we ended up installing a ZD3000 and a cluster of 2 SZ100. In the future the SZ100 cluster will stay and the ZD3000 will be removed. Right now they have 3 virtual separated management networks (VLAN 1 - Old HP Wireless, VLAN 20 - Ruckus Smart Zone Wireless, & VLAN 21 - Ruckus Zone Director Wireless). The ZD was installed to work with the convention APs for the Conference tool, so only convention APs were provisioned with the ZD, the rest of will be associated with the Smart Zone Cluster. The MDF is located in the Mezzanine level by the offices. In the MDF we have the Hotwire WAN switch that feeds the Fusion, the core SW, Smart Zones and ZD is also there. The property has two towers with IDFs in different floors. Generally one IDF feeds the floor above and the floor below. In the guest rooms they are installing H500s and these APs will be feeding a hardwired connection, a minibar and the TV in the future. For the common and convention areas they are using R710s and for the outdoor they are using T300s. All the IDF are connected via multi-mode fiber and the Legendary Tower IDFs uplink from the MDF and the Ocean Tower IDFs  uplink from the Swamp IDF.
column67: The MDF is in the mezzanine level and that is where the RS Fusions, Core switch 5406, Smart Zone 100 Cluster, and ZD are located. They have two towers and and the IDFs are as follow: Legendary Tower: - Swamp IDF in the Garage (5406 and 2510 switches) - SPA IDF (2915 - 8 port Switch) - Security Office IDF (5406 and 2610-48 switches) - 5th Floor IDF (5406 SW) - 8th Floor IDF (5406 SW) - 11th Floor IDF (5406 SW) - 14th Floor IDF (5406 SW) Ocean Tower - Parking Garage Valet IDF (2920-24 SW) - Ocean Tower Ballroom IDF (2920-48 SW) - 3rd Floor IDF (2920-48 SW) - 4th Floor IDF (5406 SW) - 7th Floor IDF (5406 SW) - 10th Floor IDF (5406 SW) - 14th Floor IDF (5406 SW) - 17th Floor IDF (5406 SW) - 20th Floor IDF (5406 SW) Cabanas IDF (2915-8 SW)
column68: At this point they have 3 different guest networks: Old HP solution WiFi (management VLAN 1), Ruckus WiFi for the guestrooms and common areas with the a redundant Smart Zone 100 cluster (management VLAN 20), and Ruckus WiFi for the convention rooms with the Zone Director 3000. The ZD was installed as a temporally solution for the conference tool that was sold.  The good point of contact for the property is Howard Chow IT personnel.

column66: Do not call the emergency number (603 254 8308) for any network issues or outages. Only call the main number (603-236-8301)  It starts with the modem and goes to the Colubris Gateway. From there it hits the ZD. From there a cat 5 goes up to a netgear 5 port switch in the managers apartment. Out of that it hits the Ubiquiti POE Injector. From there it goes to the first Sender Ubiquiti that is located on the side of the Clubhouse. From there it hits Building H. It then goes into a Netgear 5 Port switch that is located in the attic. From there it goes to the next sender and a root AP. The Ubiquiti Sender then has a shot From Building H to Building D. From there it goes into a 5 port netgear switch. Out of the Switch there is a Cat 5 that goes to the next Ubiquiti sender and a root AP. From there the Sender shoots From Building D to Building M. From there a Cat 5 cable gets run down the building through the basement and into RM 79's fist Floor Closet. In there is a 5 Port netgear Switch, 2 Ubiquiti POE Injectors and a Root AP. Coming out of the Netgear switch you have 4 cat 5 cables that go to the AP, both POE Injectors and the SPARE Ubiquiti Receiver that is mounted on the outside of RM 75.   AS A NOTE. THE CAT 5 CABLE THAT GOES FROM THE SPARE UBQUITI POE INJECTOR TO THE NETGEAR 5 PORT SWITCH IS UNPLUGED FROM THE SWITCH. IF YOU NEED THE SPARE UBIQUTI TO WORK ALL YOU NEED TO DO IS HAVE THE MAINTENANCE GUY GO TO RM 79 AND PLUG THE LAN CABLE THAT COMES OUT OF THE SPARE UBIQUITI POE INJECTOR INTO THE NETGEAR 5 PORT SWITCH. FYI THAT CABLE IS LABELED (ONLY PLUG INTO SWITCH IF NEEDED).

column66: Gates Hotel: This is a very simple network with the MDF on the 1st floor and uplinks to two 2nd-floor IDFs via multi-mode fiber. The building is divided in 3 sections A, B, and C. The single switch in IDF 1 feeds section A. There are two switches in IDF 2; switch one feeds section B and switch two feeds section C. All the in room access points are fed through the PoE switches. There are also two outdoor APs; one on the roof by room 236 and one in the pool bar.  24 North Hotel (Gates 2): Single-mode fiber connects IDF 2 at the Gates to 24 North (also called Gates 2 during construction). Multi-mode fiber connects the Gates 2 MDF and the 3rd and 5th floor IDFs. All fiber links are terminated with SC connectors.
column67: The MDF is located on the 1st floor behind the front desk, there you can find the Fusion, ZD, Core switch, and web power switch as well as the ISP router. The IDF 1 is located on the 2nd floor Boiler room and IDF 2 on the second floor Telecom room. The access points in guest rooms are installed below the TV and behind the furniture.  Access points in 24 North (Gates 2) are H500s mounted directly to the walls in-room, R700s in the public areas, and one T300 outside at the Pool Bar.  4 Outdoor AP (T300) installation on 07/07/2017. Engineering and Housekeeping had issues with their tablet system when they moved from one buildings to another on the front area between the buildings, by the dumpster area at the back of the Gates building, the front left parking lot area by the Gates building, and the parking area between the two buildings. We installed 4 extra T300 outdoor APs for the coverage for these areas. 3 APs on the Gates building. The APs are mounted on side of the building near to the roof. 1 installed on the Housekeeping building by the laundry, behind the 24 north's Pool, near the back-parking lot. The AP is on J-pipe facing the back-parking lot. There is an areal picture uploaded in the Docs for the APs locations and few more pictures from the installations.

column66: Internet feeds the Apps server, which distributes management data to all STBs via the property's switches. column30: To program a master remote for this property. Use any Samsung remote to duplicate buttons:  Power Sleep Volume Up Volume Down Mute   ************************************PROGRAM TV*************************************** To Program the SAMSUNG TVs you have to use a USB stick with flash files on it.  To create the flash file you can use any TV that has been programmed already: 1. Insert your flash drive in to the USB slot of the TV that is programmed 2. Power On the TV 3. Point remote to the IR of the TV and press 119 MUTE ENTER (between arrow buttons) 4. Go to Cloning -> Copy TV to USB  To program a TV with a flash drive: 1. Make sure you have a flash drive with TV settings on it (look above on how to create one) 2. Insert the USB drive into USB slot of the TV you wish to program 3. Power On the TV 4. Point remote to the IR of the TV and press 119 MUTE ENTER (between arrow buttons) 5. Go to Cloning -> Copy USB to TV
column66: ***************************************** 3/15/2018 The property hasn't paid their bill for Time Warner for the Internet for guest side internet. We are the only vendor that has WAN now. Out Casting SSID is providing free Wi-Fi access temporarily. There is a click-through page turned on. This means casting on the TVs is not working at the moment. Once they sort out this situation we can revert back to normal. *****************************************  ***************************************** Not all Chromecasts have a Wi-Fi connection at the moment. This is due to the fact that Wi-Fi system here is ancient and it still running 2942s. There is not enough coverage in every room. Property has a contract with Time Warner to upgrade the internet, but it is unknown when that is going to work. *****************************************  This is a Beyond TV install. We are not supplying the WiFi for this property. Backbone: We have a 100mbps x 100mbps pipe that comes into the Hotels Cisco Wan Switch.  From port 7 of the Hotels Core Switch I ran a cat 5 cable to the WAN1 port of our Fusion.  From the LAN of the Fusion we have a cat 5 to our HP core Switch.  From there Ports 21 and 22 Run Via Fiber to each IDF.  Once in the IDF we have 2 cisco switches in each one. Fiber comes into one switch and we have the first switch patched into the Second switch.  All the ports on the switch go into a patch panel which feeds each room's STB.  For more detail see the network diagram.  Opera PMS Version 5.0 Service pack 5.0.03.01/2 -- For opera tech support.  New HMS PMS service provider: IN4  Support: 877-772-4111 Property ID: 100068092

column68: Moving  forward  the GC_Corp   SSID   will not be used  for guests as a secondary  connection .  We want to use the guest wifi only. If guest have problems connecting take these simple steps to get them connected:   #1 forget the network   #2  clear the cache and browser history  #3  restart the device    #4   make device hasn’t been set for a static  IP address must be set on auto configuration .   ****THIS IS NO LONGER A NICK ROBBINS PROPERTY.****    “When guests call in you should get the building, and room number.  Buildings will either be a letter or a number. There is no portal page here.  Guests must enter the correct wpa2 key in order to be able to connect to the wifi.  The keys are as follows (all lowercase): Jan 2022 - snowflake22 Feb 2022 - freezing22 March 2022 -   shamrock22 April 2022 -   May -  June -  July -  August - September -  October - fallshere22 November -    The primary reason for guest calls here will be issues with the wpa2 key.  Since the wpa2 key changes each month they will need to forget their previous network before they can connect with the new wpa2 key.  The procedure for doing this is different on each operating system, and the agent that takes the call should help the guest with this process. Should you need to troubleshoot the wireless connection there are 2 Aruba access point controllers at this location.  To access these controllers, you need to form a Teamviewer connection to: Partner ID 877017360 Password 5091 If the guest is staying in a "letter" building (Building A room 204 for example) then the IP address for the controller is 10.100.8.10 If the guest is staying in a "number" building (Building 2 room 210 for example) then the IP address for the controller is 10.100.1.10 These IP addresses should be accessed using Google Chrome on the Teamviewer computer The credentials to access the controllers are: UN: admin PW: Tech8324$ If you need to reboot an access point this is found in in the Maintenance > Reboot menu.  You can then select the AP that you would like to reboot. The only change that agents are permitted to make in the controller is to reboot an access point.  No other changes should be made.

column76: PMS Custom Field Mapping Info:  A0 - rate code  A1 - group code  A2 - block code  A3 - room type  A4 - membership type  A5 - membership number  A6 - source  A7 - membership level  A8 - special request  A9 - unused   We use data from two fields to provide free service to certain guests. A7 provides data on whether the guest is a Marriott Rewards Gold (X1), Platinum Elite (P6) or Platinum Premier (X4) member. A8 lets us know if the hotel has decided to give a guest free internet, which comes across as code I5. column66: This is hybrid BeyondTV and WiFI property. We provide BeyondTV as well as Wi-Fi service in every guest room of the hotel.  The BeyondTV MDF is the central distribution location for the whole property. From there is has fiber runs to IDFs in the Hotel Tower (3East, 3West, 20North, 20East, and 40. Fiber connect to Cisco Switches that are isolated from each other via VLANs. From the switches it goes through MOCA systems that delivers data over existent COAXial cable to rooms. The MOCA systems consists of the 2 parts: Network Controllers (in closets) and modems (in rooms). Every controller supports 5-7 modems at the same time. MOCA system has tagged VLANs from WiFi to work. They are 100 & 102-105.
column67: All the modems, gateways, ZDs and switches are located in the Telephone room BTV Rack (adjacent to purchasing). All of which are specifically labeled.

column67: Devices are in the MDF located in the Engineering Dept Basement area.    MDF is located in the Engineering Dept in the Basement, There is 11 IDF's located on the 2nd -12th floor, Floor 2-3 have A Cisco 2960 SW, 4th floor to the 12th floor has a 10 Port 3560 POE SW.  Guest rooms have been setup with H510 Access points that are connected back to the IDF on the floor.  We are using a POE-A configuration, the 66 block is located in every idf from the 3rd to the 12th floor and we are using the B/BW and the G/GW pairs.  some rooms we are using the O/WO and B/WB pairs.  Please see Visio diagram and Pictures in crm.  In the Common areas we are using R510 access points, but they are not POE-A, we are using a start T568B configuration.  Please note that in the old internet configuration the AP's were in the hallways, now the only thing that was left was the Ethernet cable which can be accessed via access panels.  The Flint restaurant has 3 -R510 inside and 1 R510 outside above the Bar in the Patio in an Enclosure. On the 2nd Floor there is an AP in the Terrace Room, Sullivan Room, and the Wright Room.  We have a STB in the Wright Room behind the TV, we also have a STB in the GM office behind the TV.  We only have the STB not the Chromecast or MPI cable. In the MDF which is located in the Basement we have a R510 which is called Engineering.

column66: We are expanding a current setup here.  Modem goes to Fusion, Fusion Feeds a core switch. The core switch feeds the ZD, 3 Ap's ( the AP's were preexisting, they are set to DHCP ) the Ubiquiti sender POE injector, laundry room AP and 1 switch that is set to DHCP for in room hard connections. From there, they have a point to point to the Lobby Building ( NOTE: the Lobby building is separate from the Hotel building ( where all the guest rooms are ). from there the LAN side of the Ubiquiti receiver feeds a Ruckus AP to cover the Lobby Building.  They have a local portal page. They have 2 accounts. The Guests get the account that is bandwidth throttled. column66: This is a student housing residential in Mansfield. The staff there only work regular 9-5 hours during the week. There are no weekend staff of any kind.  Property is comprised of 2 buildings, A & B. Building B is where the leasing office is located. A ubiquity link bridges the 2 buildings. On the 1st floor of each building is a maintenance room. Inside the room is where the POE switches and hardware is located. 1 AP is located in 1 bedrooms of each apartment. Each apartment has between 1-4 bedrooms in them.  Bldg B has the AP's located in the Apartments please see equipment list, Bldg A has the AP's located in the Apartments please see equipment list  Modem 2 also feeds the front desk computer as well as the hotel's "key system." These machines are on static IPs and are connected directly to the modem.

column66: This is a campus environment. The ISP feed comes into the main bldg. Wifi equipment is located in a room behind the front desk. Several APs which service the main building connect here. There is a wifi bridge which connects the other buildings. This bridge connects through Bldg 2, Bldg 3 then to Bldgs 7 & 8.  Bldg 3 maids closet has a POE switch & a Zone Director. 12 APs are connected to it while the others are in stand alone mode. There are also some Value Point & Ubiquity APs on the property.  Cox communication brought in a line to the front office managers area. There are two modems. One is for office computers, the other (labeled "Guest Internet") is for guest internet system. AP's are plugged into an 8 port POE switch.  There is a firewall device connected behind the procure (10.1.2.40). It is managed by a 3rd party person named Danny Martinez (619-726-7441). He has the UN & PW for this device.

column66: This system is a mix of 2 technologies: VDSL 2+ and Hardwire PoE Ruckus system.  The main distribution comes from the MDF. All the VDSL equipment feeds from this rooms.   Ruckus AP's added to 3 rooms per floor from the 3rd floor to the 7th floor. Internet is fed from the Zebra Modems, but are powered with power adapters.
column67: MDF: Fusion, ZD, Core Switch, DSLAMs, additional 2910 switch, WPS MDF / Phone Room located in parking level B1 near HR. IDF: 3 Switches for WAPs and hardwire for convention space  WAPs in Rooms: In a single King Bed it is behind the bed In a 2 double bed rooms, it's under the desk In suites, it will be living room or master bedroom behind the bed.  WAPs in Hallways: Added AP's in B Building hallways from the 3rd floor to the 7th floor next to the service and guest elevators where the phones are, and in the 3rd floor hallway next to the guest elevator in the A building. These are configured on DSLAM 5.  Parking Garage: WAPs are strapped to ceilling  Public Spaces: Inside drop ceiling in accordance to the Visio  Pool WAP: Inside the Poll Bar, in an outdoor box.
column68: ***PHONES*** There are multiple phones in every rooms. There is always a phone in a bathroom, that is where feed for each room lands. We have installed filters behind each phone in the bathroom of each room with a modem. If phones start ringing in a room, there are 2 scenarios:  1. Phone was added to a phone plate that does not have a VDSL filter installed 2. Wiring has changed and needs to be troubleshot  In case that we are unable to fix an issue remotely, we can contact the IT onsite. Their number is listed on contacts:  310-899-8405  If for any reason there's no one available we should contact Tom.  **** Troubleshooting note for poor covered areas by ARA**** Most of APs are installed behind giant beds which are attenuating the signals .Even I had problem when  poor signal was in the room where was an  AP. so in this kind of cases move it to the wall plate next to the stone or by using cat3 move it behind bed to the open space .  Ruckus AP's have been added to 3 rooms per floor from the 3rd floor up to the 7th floor. These were added for the Alice ticketing system that the staff is using, but are broadcasting the Alice network and the guest network. These are connected to Zebra TW-522 Modems, but are powered with power adapters. The Ruckus AP's are mounted right next to the Zebra modems behind the beds, and the Zebra modems have their radios turned off. So that they don't conflict with one another. The LEDs on the Ruckus AP's have been turned off since the lights were disturbing the guests, and so guests were unplugging them. So you will need to check the link light on the port of the AP to see if it is connected or not.  *********emergency in case of Fusion Down******************(11-8-2021) IT is available from 8am to 5pm Monday though Friday. IT isn’t available (on-site) and there’s an emergency, please contact the IT Manager:  ·  Fabiano Russo at (310) 770-3327

column66: You have a TelPacific Router that Feeds into port 3 of the HP Core Switch. Ports 3-6 of the HP Core Switch are on VLAN 50 Untagged, and acts as virtual WAN switch.         The Fusion WAN1 Port is connected to port 4 on the HP Core switch. From the LAN2 Port on the Fusion it hits a HP 2520 8 port POE Core Switch (10.51.5.30). From there it goes into a Zone Director (10.51.5.12) and Zebra Ts-524 DSLAM switch (10.51.5.31). Hotel, other than the Lobby/Pool area, has TW-511 single band APs located in the rooms.    There are two Ruckus APs still attached to the ZD but only one, the Lobby AP, is powered from the Core Switch. The other, the outdoor AP outside 130 (2741) is connected to the Core Switch but not POE powered. That AP is a spare.  There is a physical cable that goes from Port 5 of the HP Core Switch to a Netgear 5 port Switch that is under the Front Desk that feeds the Kiosk and the other port goes into the Hotels Router which feeds their Office computers. There is a network diagram in CRM with a picture of the devices.

The network is setup in a mesh configuration, the Office AP is connected directly to Lan1 on the fusion.  The AP on the third floor is in mesh mode, due to the hotel being protected by the Historical society we are unable to run ethernet cable in the hotel.  I was doing some signal testing and found that in the terrace on the 1st floor the signal is not that good when the patio door is closed.  when the door is open i have no issues.  So i explained my findings to Dan and stated that we could put out another AP made for the outside to cover the terrace.  He stated that he would decide on a later date.  If we do send out another AP please configure the AP for Mesh so all the user needs to do is mount the AP.  We have installed Guest cast in all the rooms, the chromecast devices are connected to btvcasting SSID.

We have installed Guest cast in all the rooms, the chromecast devices are connected to btvcasting SSID.  Programming Guest cast remotes for the following TV. Toshiba Panasonic Samsung  First setup up Guest cast remote for the correct model: Press setup button on guest cast remote until it blinks twice, then hit the power button twice then type the following number Toshiba -9 Panasonic-3 Samsung- 5 Afterwards hold the setup button until the LED blinks twice.  Afterwards you will be able to turn on/off the TV, change the volume.    To program the other buttons you will need the original remote for each model TV.  The following buttons will need to be programed on the GuestCast remote. Toshiba- Casting, TV, mute Panasonic- Casting, TV, mute Samsung- Casting, TV, mute Comcast/Xfinity- Channel, Last, Info, channel numbers 0-9  Program buttons on guest cast remote: press the setup button till the led blinks twice, press the numbers 975.  this will put the remote in learn mode. Place original mfg remote in front of the the Guest cast remote. On the Guest cast remote press the desired button the led will blink fast, then press the same button on the original remote this will send the code to the Guest cast remote.  continue pressing the button you want to teach on the Guest cast remote with the original TV remote.  Buttons that will need to be programmed for the following TV. Toshiba: follow the above instructions to program GuestCast remote Casting- Press the Input/Source button to program Casting TV- Press the channel button 3 to program Live TV.  TV channel must be on 3 for the Guest to see TV Mute- Press the mute button on original remote to program mute on Guestcast remote.  Panasonic: follow the above instructions to program GuestCast remote Casting- Press the Input/Source button to program Casting. Guest will see a menu and they will need to select TV or HDMI for Chromecast. TV- Press the Input/Source button to program Live TV.  Guest will see a menu and they will need to select TV or HDMI for Chromecast. Mute- Press the mute button on original remote to program mute on Guestcast remote.  Samsung:follow the above instructions to program GuestCast remote Casting- Press the Input/Source button to program Casting. Guest will see a menu and they will need to select TV or HDMI for Chromecast. TV- Press the Input/Source button to program Live TV. Guest will see a menu and they will need to select TV or HDMI for Chromecast. Mute- Press the mute button on original remote to program mute on Guestcast remote.  Comcast/Xfinity: follow the above instructions to program GuestCast remote Channel up/down- Press the Channel up/dows on Comcast/Xfinity TV remote button to program channel selection on Guest Cast remote. Last button- Press the Last button on Comcast/Xfinity TV remote to program Last button on Guest Cast remote. Info button- Press the Info button on Comcast/Xfinity TV remote to program Info button on Guest Cast remote. Channel numbers- using the comcast/xfinity remote you will need to program all the number buttons on the Guest Cast remote  Type of TV in rooms- Toshiba - Room 7,8 One HDMI Port, Chromcast is connected to HDMI 1 Panasonic - Room 3,5 Chomecast is connected to HDMI 2 Samsung - Room 1,2,4,6 Chomecast is connected to HDMI 2  Comcast/Xfinity STB are connected to the Guest Room TV via Coax.

column66: The is a cable Internet feed.      This feeds the Fusion. The LAN of the Fusion connects to a Zyxel 24-port PoE switch. The Fusion is in the 1st floor and the switch is in the 2nd floor IDF. There are 2 Ethernet cables run between these rooms. The first cable connects the Fusion to the switch, the second cable runs out of the switch to the ZoneDirector, which is also located in the MDF.      Ten 2942 Ruckus APs compose the WiFi network at the property. Nine of these APs are PoE fed from the Zyxel switch. The 10th is a mesh AP in the restaurant kitchen.
column67: The modem, Fusion and ZoneDirector are located in the 1st floor phone room. The one mesh AP is located in the kitchen area of the restaurant.

column67: Fusion, ZD 1025 and SMC 24 Port VDSL Switch are located in the Main Telephone Room that is located on the 2nd Floor in the 2nd Building. ZD is plugged into this as well, which makes it easier to find, if necessary. From the Core Switch, pre-wired CAT-5 on the property feeds to modems within the rooms which then feed APs.  The HP ProCurve box, close to the rack is the Hotel Admin Network, not our equipment. We get our ISP feed via this router, into the FUSION'S WAN PORT.

column66: 21 rooms with the new Quam STB boxes.  We have Wifi and physical ethernet connections.  Unfortunately the ethernet jacks are not labled, to make those jacks live we will need to tone out the connections and mark them.   Ethernet locations are behind the bed near the phone, and behind the TV.  All the tv's onsite are Sony they range from 27" to 65, most on swivel mount others are on tilt only TV Brackets.  We have a fusion E100 and we have the BTV Streaming SSID broadcasting as well, the client wants to use the physical ethernet ports to connect Beyond TV.  I was able to tone out all the Data jacks for the TV in all the rooms.  I have labeled all the cables going back to the SW. Please see photos, you will see that all the connections are one for one.  Example Cable 1 is connected to Port 1 on the SW.

column66: This project was taken over from another vendor. No new equipment was installed other than a fusion. They were using a MSM 720 as BOTH a gateway and AP controller. The fusion was installed as the router and the MSM was kept to so that the HP model APs could be centrally managed. The MSM is NO LONGER being used as gateway.  The APs are a combination of older model HP APs and newer model HP dual band AP. They DO NOT have static IP addresses on them. They are dynamically assigned from the FUSION.  Switches are a combination of 3COM switches, Cisco switches and a unmanaged D-link switch located on the 9th floor. Switches are daisy-chained together using a cable which goes up the outside of the building.  Documentation was supplied to us by customer which is basically accurate.
column67: MDF: lobby level back office on shelf behind door. Fusion is below monitor. Core switch is 1 shelf above it. PMS Comtrol box: one shelf below Fusion. Connected to seperate Admin network  Switches: Switches are located in ceilings of each floor either above access panels or above drop ceiling tiles.  APs: These are located in ceilings either behind access panels or above drop ceiling tiles. There is one in each hallway and in the center hallway by elevator above fire alarm light.    IMPORTANT NOTE 07/31/2015: The APs at Herald Square have a bug right now that causes them to stop working completely (which requires reset to factory defaults to fix) if they lose their uplink to the controller for any reason.  This means if a switch gets rebooted, controller gets rebooted, power goes down, cable gets unplugged for a few seconds, etc that the APs will go down and will not come back up until reset to factory.  To Reset APs: Hold down the reset button until all of the following has happened:  1. All indicator lights go out  2. All indicator lights go solid  3. All indicator lights blink 3 times Then release the reset button immediately. After you have done this the AP will show up as a suspicious device in the controller.  You then need to approve it and the AP should come back up a few minutes after you do that.  The APs on the lobby level MUST be reset in the following order: AP in center of eating area, AP outside rooms 19/20, AP outside rooms 9/10. If not reset IN ORDER, they will not join the controller.

column68: Oddity note: When I first installed the equipment, I tried to config VLAN 1000 (Guest VLAN) on the AP Ethernet ports. I did it per the manual, configuring the ports as "ACCESS"  and setting the VLAN as 1000. However, the ports did not work on that VLAN until I switched the VLAN back to 1 and then back to 1000. Its was almost as though the new VLAN info did not get uploaded to the AP until I switched it back and forth from VLAN 1. Just an oddity.  They had trouble with their mgmt network cutting out daily for awhile. Had GM, Terry Arnold reboot the Startech Ethernet Bridge (can see it in MDF pic) which is plugged into port 11 of the core switch. Then had her reboot the bridge and the Netgear router in the office. column66: !!!WARNING!!! - Deviation from a standard We had to deviate from a standard procedures at this property. There are 2 things you need to know before you start working on the network: 1. Switches belong to the admin network (they did not want to buy new switches) 2. Management VLAN for Ruckus is TAGGED to the Ruckus WAPs (the admin network is running on VLAN 1 and they asked for wireless access to it. VLAN 1 does not touch the Fusion and we are not responsible for any portion of it, only for providing access to it from the switches)  Client wanted to save money, so that is a way we have to keep this network. We have went through switches that we are using and added vlan100 to them. That means that we DO have access to them. Please be careful about modifying the config on the switches as they are used for the admin purpose as well.    The system is a hybrid of Ruckus and VDSL2+ from Zebra. There are 3 buildings at this property: - 2400 Building - 2600 Building (Tower) - Pavilion  2400 and 2600 buildings are mainly Residential apartments. There we use VDSL2+ equipment.   Pavilion is all the Public and support infrastructure, like Restaurants, Offices and Kitchens.

column68: MGMT VLAN 100 is !!TAGGED!! to Ruckus WAPs.  If IT guy (Romeo Jano) calls with a request of installing a new WAP here is what you need to do: 1. Ask him what port and what switch it connects to 2. Configure the port as UNTAGGED (access vlan 100 or native vlan 100 for a trunk port)  3. Check the ZD make sure WAP come up, upgrades and goes down 4. Change the port to Trunk with Native VLAN 1 and Tagged allowed 1,100, 201 5. If none of this makes sense, talk to Walter or Trevor  *********************************************************************************************************************************** Please note: The Lifespace_Biz network should be tunneled and using VLAN 50. The admin DHCP server provides addresses with the 172.17.8.0/22 network and is untagged VLAN 50.  In addition, within the Access Point Policies menu in the Zone Director the Management VLAN should be set to VLAN 100 - David.G 09/01/2022 *********************************************************************************************************************************** Matt Ervin, the IT Project Manager for all Lifespace Communities asked that Gustavo.Moreno@LifeSpaceCommunities.com and Joseph.Ramagnano@lifespacecommunities.com be emailed on any down access points or equipment at the property.

column32: San Diego Family Housing, The Villages @ Serra Mesa
column66: The is a metro wifi project for a military housing neighborhood in Kerney Mesa, SD.  There are 351 buildings with 900 units. Belair equipment was used to create two layers of wifi access.   The upper layer is created using BA100 nodes mounted on roof tops. These have a 5ghz backhaul and 2.4ghz client radios in them. A 2nd lower layer is created using BA100 with only 2.4ghz radios. These are meshed into the system using the 2.4ghz radios.  Their APs are Bellair Nodes which are large barrel like devices that are in the attics of designated house; they communicate to each other wirelessly. Because of their strength they are usually able to get the signal down to the residents houses, but because of their locations the residents’ computers are unable to communicate back to them.   In order to bring satisfactory internet service into residences, Ruckus MetroFlex routers have been deployed into certain units. The installed network does not provide a connection for what seems to be most of the houses in this small community. It has been this way since I started here.   Our solution for the people who call has been to provide Metroflexes (repeaters) for the residents who are unable to connect to the WiFi network.   A survey and reinstallation would be good, but I don’t know (nor have I spoken with any technician who does) of how to deploy a WiFi network for a site like this. It is a small community of houses. There is no legitimate useable infrastructure as there would normally be inside of a building.  I’m not exaggerating when I say that most people in Serra Mesa Villages are unable to use this WiFi network.

Almost all APs are in the second floor inside rooms, mounted under desk next to the hard wire Ethernet jack . All these APs are connected to the switch in the second floor IDF.  The switches that feed the wired rooms  all in the IDF for that floor.  3rd floor AP installed in the 3rd Floor IDF on the ceiling (powered by PoE injector) , Lobby AP installed in the FD IDF on the ceiling , Admin AP installed in the basement next to the MDF on ceiling. All APs except 3rd floor IDF and Sunset Meeting room APs are connected to the appropriate PoE switches, These 2 APs get power trough PoE injector .

column66: ----------OLD DATA---------- Revenue Share Propterty.  RxG and 16 Teledex switches service 3 hotel towers and convention space.  ----------DATA as of 3-21-2014---------- This is hybrid BeyondTV and WiFI property. We provide BeyondTV as well as Wi-Fi service in every guest room of the hotel.  The BeyondTV MDF is the central distribution location for the whole property. From there is has fiber runs to IDFs in Casino, North and Sky Towers. Fiber connect to Cisco Switches that are isolated from each other via VLANs. From the switches it goes through MOCA systems that delivers data over existent COAXial cable to rooms. The MOCA systems consists of the 2 parts: Network Controllers (in closets) and modems (in rooms). Every controller supports 5-7 modems at the same time. MOCA system has tagged VLANs from WiFi to work. They are 100-104.

column68: 9 June, 2018.  The CMOS battery is dead.  Date/Time will need to be set before it will boot.  1.  There is a KVM switch installed here.  The Fusion is on Port 1.  Scroll-Lock, Scroll-Lock, 1, Enter should get you to the Fusion Display.  Try again if it's not on the Fusion, it does work.  2.  Press F1 to enter CMOS, no password required.  Enter the Date and time (press enter after each entry to proceed to the next field).  3.  Save and Reboot System.  4.  System should now load rXg.

column68: ***For Fusion Outages*** An outage occurred on 12/29/21 and the resolution was pressing f1 on a keyboard attached to the Fusion so that the Fusion would boot properly.  There is a setting in the BIOS that can be changed so that f1 does not need to be pressed to boot, but as of today (12/30/21) that setting has not yet been changed. With this in mind if the Fusion is down then someone on location should connect a keyboard to the Fusion and press f1 to get it to boot if this problem is suspected.  For down AP's: send an email to Dan Gaus: sales@teledata-solutions.com and also include itdept@esitg.com in the CC's. Include in the email a good description about where the down AP is, and what the point of failure is (Motorola modem, Ruckus AP, etc).  This is the generic support email for a company called ESI, which now does the IT support for the Pocono properties (these properties are no longer part of Highgate).  Updated 9/23/16 -Brad

column68: This is a Stephen Durr property.  Do not deal directly with the property. He is now being texted NOC alerts for GW’s, Wireless Controllers and switches for his properties. You don’t need to email him regarding those alerts, but you should email him for information about the devices as far as possible ETR, cause, if known,etc. so we can inform CAS. 2. If a ticket is escalated and we cannot resolve the issue, we need to inform him of these with all pertinent information via email and a heads-up call. column67: MDF is located behind the front desk in the lobby. It is considered the basement/lobby floor. Everything is located on the main Rack right by the entrance to the back area. everything has a label on it (even the modem). Modem is located on the rack under the Fusion gateway. Core Switch, Zone Director, Fusion Gateway all in MDF.  There are 3 IDFs at this property:  1st floor IDF (telephone room in the 1st floor parking garage) Switch is fed from the core switch. APs for the 1st floor are connected to this switch  3rd floor IDF (telephone room near room 313) Switch is fed from the core switch. APs for the 3rd floor are connected to this switch  4th floor IDF (meeting room on the 4th floor. it is located in the corner in a ceiling) It is unmanageable 16-port Netgear switch that feeds some of the hard lines in that meeting room. It is connected to the 3rd floor IDF switch.  5th floor IDF (telephone room by the room 505) Switch is frd from the 3rd floor switch. APs for the 5th floor are connected to this switch   All the APs are located in ceiling in from of rooms. All ceiling is drop-ceiling. All the APs are fed via POE.   There are 25 Dual-band APs that are managed by the ZD. Other 3 are regular 2.4Ghz APs. They are stand alone but possibly could be added to the ZD now that the Lic were upgraded to 50 APs. Please, refer to the documentation for the exact location.  Finally, there are two 7372 dual band APs in the staff area on the lobby level. These are the Maintenance Office and the Laundry across the garage from the lobby.

column68: The property upgraded the firmware on their devices and they are in the NEW Hibox already. Use this link below to troubleshoot. - Csaba 8/3/2019 https://184.105.79.68/hiboxadmin/Login                                     For Gateway outages send an email to Roberto Luna Osorio rluna@unicohotelrm.com; Israel Medrano Camelo imedrano@unicohotelrm.com;Irving Giovanny Uitzil Pech iuitzil@unicohotelrm.com>; Carlos Pech cpech@unicohotelrm.com  If new image is uploaded - This is of 07/04/2019 - they are still using old BTV system, IT uploaded an image to the Hibox and they hit publish (we don't have the access for it). But still the old image is being displayed.  1. Rebooted the box no go 2. new image that is uploaded has a different name and was uploaded to spanish and english. I asked them have it uploaded to all the languages they have. They did and rebooted the box but still no go. Waited for sometime and rebooted the box one more time still no go. 3. Restarted Squid by logging into caching server. The caching server can be accessed using ssh 60007. IP is same as fusion IP. command to restart caching server is "service squid restart" waited for 2 minutes and asked him to reboot the box.  This time new image is displayed on the TV. The issue is resolved.

column66: The property has one uplink that feeds the rXg. The property has both wired and wireless guest Internet. WiFi system is Ruckus.  Switches are Brocade 7250 and 7150 with 24-port Dell PowerConnects. 14 switches in the guest network; 2 switches on each end of all 7 floors. The Floor 1 West switch is the core switch in the MDF. 10.17.182.111  Guest WiFi in the rooms and the lobby employ dynamic VLANs on the Plaza-Guest-Wireless and Lobby-Free-Wireless WLANs. The rXg is the RADIUS server for this setup. For more information on how dynamic VLANs work with Ruckus, read the ZoneDirector User Guide section on "How Dynamic VLAN Works".  In the rooms, guests get assigned a VLAN within the range of 1000 - 1511 and tunneled back to the ZD. Each guest is in their own /30 subnet. Should more guests connect than there are VLANs available, guests are placed in VLAN 68, which is trunked back to the rXg through the switches.   In the lobby, guests get assigned a VLAN within the range of 2000 - 2063 and tunneled back to the ZD. Each guest is in their own /30 subnet. Should more guests connect than there are VLANs available, guests are placed in VLAN 11.

column68: ***If CAS escalates a ticket to NOC and we can't resolve the issue, Nick Robbins, the IT Administrator, needs to be emailed with the Subject Line of "Guest needs help getting on internet" at nick.robbins@tradingplaces.com ***  ****New intructions from Nick Robbins 7/30/19**** Moving  forward  the GC_Corp   SSID   will not be used  for guests as a secondary  connection .  We want to use the guest wifi only. If guest have problems connecting take these simple steps to get them connected:   #1 forget the network   #2  clear the cache and browser history  #3  restart the device    #4   make device hasn’t been set for a static  IP address must be set on auto configuration .   August's  guest password will be school08    “When guests call in you should get the building, and room number.  Buildings will either be a letter or a number. There is no portal page here.  Guests must enter the correct wpa2 key in order to be able to connect to the wifi.  The keys are as follows (all lowercase): January 2022 - snowflake22 February 2022 -  freezing22 March 2022 -   shamrock22 April 2022 -  springtime22 May 2022 - flowers22 June 2022 - travelers22 July 2022- patriot22 August - veryhot22 September -  October - fallshere22 Nov 2022 - turkey22 Dec   The primary reason for guest calls here will be issues with the wpa2 key.  Since the wpa2 key changes each month they will need to forget their previous network before they can connect with the new wpa2 key.  The procedure for doing this is different on each operating system, and the agent that takes the call should help the guest with this process. Should you need to troubleshoot the wireless connection there are 2 Aruba access point controllers at this location.  To access these controllers, you need to form a Teamviewer connection to: Partner ID 877017360 Password 5091 If the guest is staying in a "letter" building (Building A room 204 for example) then the IP address for the controller is 10.100.8.10 If the guest is staying in a "number" building (Building 2 room 210 for example) then the IP address for the controller is 10.100.1.10 These IP addresses should be accessed using Google Chrome on the Teamviewer computer The credentials to access the controllers are: UN: admin PW: Tech8324$ If you need to reboot an access point this is found in in the Maintenance > Reboot menu.  You can then select the AP that you would like to reboot. The only change that agents are permitted to make in the controller is to reboot an access point.  No other changes should be made.

column66: This property has 8 seperate buildings linked together using Ubiquity P2P wireless bridges. The backbone starts in Bldg 3 with 2 sender units creating the bridge in either direction. The bridges (sender & receiver) are located on the ends of each building with cabling that goes over the roof and through the attic to the IDF on the 2nd floors in the utility closet. An 8p POE switch is in the closet & the Ubiquity POEs. There are 2 APs on the 2nd floor in the hardcap ceiling at either end of the building behind the ceiling lights. column68: *** Hold off on creating CRM tickets or contacting the site for any offline devices. We are working on an updated process, no action until further notice. - Tanya January 2023  For offline equipment at this property a CRM ticket should be created and to be assign to Andrew Sette and copy Walter.  ZoneDirector Notes: The ZoneDirector is only accessible going through Node1 of the cluster. Use the following link: https://184.2.174.243:60002/  The main issue out there would be the MoCA equipment. There are 2 things;  1. NC Power Supplies randomly die and have to be replaced to get WAPs online 2. After they switched to HD video signal, some of the Modems stopped working due to loss of signal (something has changed on the COAX plant)  Possible solutions:  1. Buy Power Supplied from a different Vendor (5V, 3A) 2. a. Fix COAX plant     b. Install another DSLAM and more modems to fix the issue temporary  REFUND NOTE: If a guests requests a refund, find out if this is because they were charged for WiFi on their Resort Fee in addition to when logging into the Internet. Note this in the escalated ticket, along with Name, room number, charge date and amount. NOC Engineer will email Hotel Controller to handle refund.

column66: This place has 2 Kiosks. One biz Station and One Transnet Internet Station. They both have Brother 2140 Printers.      The Kiosks get their internet feed from the Hotels network. There is a jack behind the Transnet Internet Station that goes into a 5 port Switch that it located in the Cabinet that is under the Transnet Stand up Internet Station. The FD should have a key to open it up. If they dont have it the Gift Shop lady does. From that 5 port switch it Feeds the Transnet Internet Station and the Biz Station. If that Switch is unplugged then there will be no internet to either Station.         They have a T-1 router that hits a Netgear 5 port switch. From there it goes into the Hotels Linksys router that hits their 24 port switch that feeds thier office computers.      Out of the netgear 5 port switch it also hits our Colubris 3200 that goes into a Netgear 16 port Switch. From there it hits a Zone Director and many Fiber Bridges to different Buildings.       In each Building on the 2nd floor of each Corridor there is an IDF. Inside of the IDF there are a Fiber Receiver that converts fiber to Ethernet. I goes from the Ethernet Port into a Trendnet 5 Port Switch. out of the trendnet switch it goes into 1 root AP and 2 POE Injectors that have a Cat 5 Cable that Runs to the Upstairs AP or Downstairs AP.

column66: This property is comprised of 2 parts. The Main building and the bungalows. They are connected via a p2p connections. Outdoor APs on the main building are wired to the MDF.   Outdoor APs are located in the rooftops in specific areas around this campus. There are ubiquity receivers that create root APs. Other root APs are created via connecting secondary port of ubiquity to data in side of Ruckus POE injector. Also, LAN side or ubiquity POE into Ruckus POE.   MAIN BUILDING: These APs are mounted dome down in a North-South orientation on the building exerior over the porch of guest rooms. Since most of the APs on the roof of this part of the hotel exceed 330 feet, many of the APs are powered via the POE-OUT port of other APs that have a homerun to the MDF. Specific details on which APs are fed via the POE-OUT port can be found on the project network diagram.
column67: MDF - Telco room on garage level near maintenence shop. Fusion, ZD, core switch, patch panel are installed on rack. Wires to roof APs originate here.  Main Bldg:  Roof - Outdoor APs are mounted onto the both the east & west sides of the buildings. Ubiquity sender units are installed on the roof. This provides point to point connection to bungalows. Game Room: AP located in center of room above drop ceiling 2nd Fl Lounge: AP located behind TV  Bungalows:  Outdoor APs are located in the rooftops in specific areas around this campus. There are ubiquity receivers that create root APs. Other root APs are created via connecting secondary port of ubiquity to data in side of Ruckus POE injector. Also, LAN side or ubiquity POE into Ruckus POE.   Location of POE injectors are in service closets behind specific rooms. See Equipment list for locations.  MESH APs -  Mesh APs were added in the water heater closet next to specific bungalow rooms. They are on top of the vents.  In 212, the AP is under the nightstand in the bedroom. This is to cover the bedroom in 112. North Villas - installed in the access hatch outside room 362.

column68: This property is located on the beach front. If property reports loss of dial tone in bedroom IT IS NOT DUE TO THE DSLAM. It is most likely corrosion that has developed on either the phone cord or the jack in the wall. Steps: check wall phone for dial tone. Jiggle bedroom phone cable. Replace bedroom phone cord. Remove TW511 and replace phone face plate. CAUTION: POWER IS ON THE PHONE LINE. Make sure power is off before having tech work on phone jack.  2 Spare TW511, phone face plates, DSL filters for desk phone & wall phone were left with Carl.  We have a field nation tech that is good for maintenance at these properties. His details are on the contacts page. His name is Michael Dickerson

column66: This is a P2P outdoor deployment with WAPs (7363) inside of rooms and 7762 (outdoor) WAPs mounted on exterior of buildings. A primary link (link1) P2P connection is made from the ceiling of the lobby building to Bldg 7. From Bldg 7 P2P connections reach to Bldg411, 441. VDSL bridges are used to link MDF to Bldg 3 & Bldg 3 to Bldg 1. A root 7762 exists at each of these locations. See network drawing for specifics.  Bldg Summary:  Bldg 1 - VDSL bridge in 1st floor maid closet. Root connections. 7762 mounted outside on fairway side of structure. 7363 inside attic of Rm 202. Cable run from VDSL bridge location.  BLDG 2: 7363 inside attic of room 216  BLDG 3: Phone closet, south end. VDSL bridge slave from MDF & Master to Bldg 1. P2P sender connects to receiver on Bldg 4.  BLDG 4: P2P receiver connects to 7762 mounted mid building, fairway side.  BLDG 5: BLDG 6: 7762 mesh mounted on parking lot side of building. Meshed to Unit 441.  BLDG 7: Equipment in maids closet, 1st floor. P2P receiver from MDF. 8 port POE switch. PRIMARY LAN FEED. 7762 mounted on south corner of structure. P2P link to Bldg 411.  BELL TOWER: 7762 mesh unit. Covers wedding reception area.

column66: Once a year this client requests that we create new accounts for each unit at the property. The procedure to do this is as follows: A spreadsheet should be created called accounts.csv I am attaching a sample to this ticket of what was used this year. A separate spreadsheet should be made that will be sent to the client. In this case I am calling it GV Account Info 2021 (attached to the ticket). The Unit and Bed Letter Column should remain the same, but the username and password column can be anything. To generate the password I used an excel formula of =RANDBETWEEN(10000,999999) in each cell. The usernames and passwords that are created here should be copied to the accounts.csv sheet in columns A - C  SSH into the Fusion as the admin user Become the root user with: ********Begin Fusion CLI Commands ****** iui su password: [enter the first string of the IUI as the password] su - **********End Fusion CLI Commands ******* I'll attach an image to the ticket showing the procedure Next: Drag and drop the accounts.csv file into the home directly (/space/admins/admin) Change directory to /space/rxg/console/tools (command is cd /space/rxg/console/tools) cat /space/admins/admin/accounts.csv | ./import_accounts  For some reason the Standard account group doesn't associated properly with the accounts using the import script. Each account should be assigned to the "Standard" account group after create. The easiest way to do this is to go to Identities > Accounts > Zoom the Accounts menu to 5000 and then do a batch update to replace the account group with Standard.  After the import is successful test a username and password on the portal to make sure that it works. if it does then send the "GV account Info 2021" (or whatever you called it) spreadsheet to the client so they can distribute it at the property.  ** See the "Unknown" Section of the documents for the examples  --Reference from note by Walter - 11 Aug 2021
column68: See the "Unknown" section of the Docs for the list of per unit credentials.  File name ->  GV Account Info 2022-2023  Use the 2021-2022 copy to generate new credentials. I removed the formula from the updated copy.  David.G - 08/16/2022

column66: I will get a printed room layout and forward it to you, but I've  attached a photo (named Pelican Exterior in docs tab) that should give you a pretty good idea of how things layout. There are 10 floors with rooms starting at 01 at the east side and ending with 12 on the west. An example would be 101 being to the far east of the first floor and 112 to the far west or to your extreme right. East rooms would be 101-106 and west rooms are 107-112. An example would be on the 2nd floor we have AP's in 202, 204, 206, 209 and 211. That repeats as you go up.

column68: If CAS escalates a ticket to NOC and we can't resolve the issue, Nick Robbins, the IT Administrator, needs to be emailed with the Subject Line of "Guest needs help getting on internet" at nick.robbins@tradingplaces.com  ****New intructions from Nick Robbins 7/30/19**** Moving  forward  the GC_Corp   SSID   will not be used  for guests as a secondary  connection .  We want to use the guest wifi only. If guest have problems connecting take these simple steps to get them connected:   #1 forget the network   #2  clear the cache and browser history  #3  restart the device    #4   make device hasn’t been set for a static  IP address must be set on auto configuration .   August's  guest password will be school08    “When guests call in you should get the building, and room number.  Buildings will either be a letter or a number. There is no portal page here.  Guests must enter the correct wpa2 key in order to be able to connect to the wifi.  The keys are as follows (all lowercase): Jan 2022 - snowflake22 Feb 2022 - freezing22 March 2022 -  shamrock22 April 2022 - springtime22 May 2022 - flowers22 June 2022 - travelers22 July 2022- patriot22 August - veryhot22 September -  October - fallshere22 November - turkey22 Dec - snowman22  The primary reason for guest calls here will be issues with the wpa2 key.  Since the wpa2 key changes each month they will need to forget their previous network before they can connect with the new wpa2 key.  The procedure for doing this is different on each operating system, and the agent that takes the call should help the guest with this process. Should you need to troubleshoot the wireless connection there are 2 Aruba access point controllers at this location.  To access these controllers, you need to form a Teamviewer connection to: Partner ID 877017360 Password 5091 If the guest is staying in a "letter" building (Building A room 204 for example) then the IP address for the controller is 10.100.8.10 If the guest is staying in a "number" building (Building 2 room 210 for example) then the IP address for the controller is 10.100.1.10 These IP addresses should be accessed using Google Chrome on the Teamviewer computer The credentials to access the controllers are: UN: admin PW: Tech8324$ If you need to reboot an access point this is found in in the Maintenance > Reboot menu.  You can then select the AP that you would like to reboot. The only change that agents are permitted to make in the controller is to reboot an access point.  No other changes should be made.
