column66: This is a large and robust network utilizing enterprise-grade equipment in a high-availability network design.  The gateway is a Cisco ASA (security appliance). It can be accessed on its public IP via ASDM or SSH, or a VPN tunnel can be established to it using Cisco AnyConnect to allow direct connection to local devices.  There are also 2 FUSIONs that have public IP addresses; these currently serve only as DHCP servers for APs, wireless clients, and other devices. They can also be used to access internal network devices via SSH. Identical DHCP pools are set up on each Fusion except for the Fan Wireless (VLAN 101) which has a pool on each Fusion that does not overlap the other. In the event of a Fusion failure, there is redundancy for the Fan Wireless, however for other networks the DHCP Failover Procedure must be followed (listed above in Troubleshooting Notes).  The Core Switch is actually a pair of Cisco 6504E chassis switches that are linked in a Virtual Switching System (VSS) - the two physical chassis serve as one logical node. There is a redundant 10Gbps connection between the two chassis.  All other switches are Cisco 3560s, either 24-port or 8-port, each with 2 x 10Gbps fiber connections to the Core Switch. These links are logically bundled into LACP port-channels, allowing redundancy and higher bandwidth. Switches can only be accessed via SSH to their private management IP, from the Fusion or over a VPN.  There are two Ruckus SCG200 AP controllers in a redundant configuration, each with multiple connections to the core. These are used to configure and monitor the access points.  Access points are Ruckus 7982, 7782-S, 7782-N, or 7372.
column68: For assistance with down APs or other on-site troubleshooting, contact the following parties with Connectivity Wireless:  TO: Daniel Kurnath dkurnath@connectivitywireless.com (551-206-9857) CC: external_tickets@connectivitywireless.com FD 38966 -Tanya 3-24-2023  HIS, Marco is no longer with the company.  All issues and FD emails should be copied with below address:  external_tickets@connectivitywireless.com  Calixto Sanchez - csanchez@connectivitywireless.com Support - support@neutralconnect.com  **If during a game then also copy Neil Fariss with Angels IT** neil.fariss@angels.com  For login pages issues an email should be sent to Samer Fahmy with copy to Ron LaPierre.  samer@greenfieldlabs.ca ron@zenreach.com  The login page is managed by a company called Zenreach.  They may ask you for some information out of the SCG with regards to the authentication configuration.  Calls from this property will come to the NOC support team at all times during regular business hours, and will only be sent to Calltek during after-hours. Calltek has been advised to escalate all urgent calls from on-site staff immediately, following the standard after-hours escalation procedure. For non-urgent calls they will enter a ticket and escalate for Tier 2 resolution as soon as NOC team is next available.  If a new AP is added to the network, the following procedure must be followed:  1. Obtain the AP's MAC address from 5Bars, and find its IP address, using either the DHCP lease provided by the Fusion or the ARP table on the Core Switch. 2. Establish an SSH connection to the AP from the Fusion. Run the command "set director ip 10.200.10.5" (this is the control plane IP of the SCG - the management plane IP will not work). 3. Look in the SCG interface under Configuration > Access Points > Staging Zone for the new AP to appear. It can then be renamed and moved to the appropriate zone.   ############################################################################# NOC TEAM: YOU MUST CONTACT THE ENGINEERING SUPERVISOR OR  DIRECTOR OF NETWORK OPERATIONS IF THE PRIMARY FUSION (38.79.70.28) IS OFFLINE #############################################################################  To provide DHCP failover we will need to edit statements on the core switch, to modify the DHCP helper-address for all applicable VLANs to that of the backup Fusion.  DHCP Failover Procedure: 1. Establish either SSH session to Fusion or VPN tunnel to ASA 2. Establish SSH session to Core Switch at 10.200.9.1 3. Execute "show run | begin interface Vlan" and investigate the VLAN interface configuration.   Where configuration is as follows:    "ip helper-address 10.200.9.50" Modify the statement to read as follows:    "ip helper-address 10.200.9.54"  4. Write changes to startup-config  This will point DHCP requests to the backup Fusion. It is not necessary to change the configuration for interface Vlan101 as this subnet has two non-overlapping DHCP pools, one set up on each of the Fusions.  In addition to the above you will need to tag VLAN 63 on port Gi0/1 on the ISP Uplink switch (10.200.9.45) and remove VLAN 63 from port Gi0/4 on the same switch. This is needed to allow the OpenTable network to continue working as it uses the Fusion as its gateway.    ############################################################################# To create a new network with internet access see document on docs tab titled "How to create a new network with internet access Angels".

column68: *******ALL SUPPORT AGENTS - WHEN CALLING PROPERTY ONLY REFER TO YOURSELF AS BEING WITH ""*******Network Support"**************  ******************************************************************************************************************************************************************************* When working with the Aruba Cloud Controller. If you notice APs that are showing offline in the cloud controller but are pingable from the Fusion. Use the following commands   from the APs CLI to check if the AP is communicating / provisioned in the cloud.  1. Show about (Check if the AP has a Cloud Activation Key) 2. show ap debug cloud-server (Check the "cloud config received" option as well as the "IAP mgmt mode". The mgmt mode should be athena-mgmt not local-mgmt)  If this is confirmed as the error you will need to verify that this AP is communicating with the correct Virtual Controller (VC). The VC is an AP that is elected to the role. The VC address for the management zone is always the same. For example VC for mgmt2 is 10.102.0.2. For Mgmt3 it is 10.103.0.2. This address forwards traffic to the elected VC's actual IP address. The below command is one way to identify which VC the AP is actually communicating with.   Use the command -> show ap debug cloud-stats.   The output can be very verbose. Scroll to the very top and look for the line "MIB_MASTER_IP_ADDRESS(131)=IP Address" The IP address listed here should be the VC's IP address.  FD Ticket # 32267 can also be referenced for past history on this issue.  -09/08/2022 *******************************************************************************************************************************************************************************

column68: This property is located on the beach front. If property reports loss of dial tone in bedroom IT IS NOT DUE TO THE DSLAM. It is most likely corrosion that has developed on either the phone cord or the jack in the wall. Steps: check wall phone for dial tone. Jiggle bedroom phone cable. Replace bedroom phone cord. Remove TW511 and replace phone face plate. CAUTION: POWER IS ON THE PHONE LINE. Make sure power is off before having tech work on phone jack.  2 Spare TW511, phone face plates, DSL filters for desk phone & wall phone were left with Carl.  We have a field nation tech that is good for maintenance at these properties. His details are on the contacts page. His name is Michael Dickerson  Modem is located in the MDF and is next to the Fusion. Have the staff fallow the cable from the Fusion to the Modem to make sure they find the correct device.

column68: This is a Stephen Durr property. Contact Stephen Durr regarding any outage or support issues.  Do not deal directly with the property. Do not make any changes to his network without his authorization.  Note that all other APs listed in the Zone Director are not for this network, they are for a neighboring property and aren't supported. They can simply be ignored.  ***New Escalation Procedure for Stephen Durr Properties*** 1.	He is now being texted NOC alerts for GW’s, Wireless Controllers and switches for his properties. You don’t need to email him regarding those alerts, but you should email him for information about the devices as far as possible ETR, cause, if known,etc. so we can inform CAS. 2.	If the Call Center is receiving a lot of calls from a property and the equipment appears to be up, please call him and give him all the information. 3.	If a ticket is escalated and we cannot resolve the issue, we need to inform him of these with all pertinent information via email and a heads-up call. So, we need to pay close attention to the tickets and jump on any from his properties. If we call a guest and get vmail, close the ticket unresolved and email Stephen.  Stephen Durr 850-596-4378 stephen@net-worx.biz

column66: This location was upgraded from partial coverage to full coverage. Each building has an AP in the attic space. This is a big mesh network with 8 roots fed via Ubiquity wifi bridges. Many AP's are manually meshed to specific roots so not to overload any particular root with too many mesh AP's. General throughput measured is 4mb download.
column67: Procurve, Planet 8 port POE switch, Uquitity sender POEs and zone director are located on top shelf in maintence office. AP's and Ubiquity POE's are located in the attics of the buildings listed in the WAP list. Attic access is via specific units which Ed with maintenance knows. Comcast modem is located in office, under Berta's desk.  AP in Rec Center is located inside on ceiling.

column66: The MDF is in the basement and there is a ZD 1100, Fusion and Core switch. The Core switch is backboned to four other switches on floors 2, 4, 6 and 8 (located in the maids closets).      Each of the switches on the floors 2, 4, 6, 8 feed APs on two floors each. The APs in the basement level come off of the Core switch.       Their are three MESH APS. One is in a cabinet on the Mezz level above the Kevin Taylor restaurant. There is one behind the TV on the 9th floor and one behind the TV in the meeting room on the 8th floor.       Cabling to the APS goes through hard ceiling and in some cases is plastered into trenches in the walls. On the 9th floor only one cable exists due to 3 feet of insulation siting on the hard ceiling.       In level below the lobby, the basement level (called the concourse), the APS are in the cielings. In the L/R Stage they are above the ceiling tiles. In the Wine Cellar the AP is behind the access panel.
column67: The Fusion, ZD and Core switch are located in the MDF on the Concourse level (downstairs from the lobby).   On the Concourse level there are two APs. One is above the ceiling tiles in the Stage Right meeting room. The other AP is in an access panel on the left side of the Wine Cellar meeting room ceiling.     There are two APs on the Mezzanine level. One is in an access panel directly over the bar. This is the Lobby/Bar AP.  The other AP is a mesh and is in a cabinet on the mezz level over the Kevin Taylor restaurant.       From here up you will find the APs behind three 12'x12' white plastic access panels in the hallways of floors 2,4,6,8 outside rooms x03, x07, x09. On floors 3,5,7 there are two APs in the hallways outside rooms x03 and x09.       The 8th floor has an additional MESH AP in the Upstage meeting room center hallway . Its behind the TV in this room.       The 9th floor has an AP in the hallway outside 903. But the second AP on this floor is behind the TV in room 909.     The IDF Switches are in the maids closets on floors 2,4,6,8 across from 202, 402...etc.

column67: 2942s are located on the ceiling in the hallways in front of the elevators on every floor of every building. Phone cable is used as the backhaul with IDFs on the the 4th, and 2nd floors depending on the building. In the IDF is one SMC VDSL2 CPE which feeds a POE switch which then feeds the 2942.   Nstreams IRCs are mounted on the rear of the TV stand in the Living room of A units as well as on the back of TV stands in the bedroom of the B or lockout units.  VOD equipment in the MDF according to Bill Sims:  MODEM: In the MDF, a black motorola modem labeled 'VOD'.  the UPS there should be two units with dual power supplies the first one from the bottom is the RAID the next one up should be the video server with twin power supplies [two power outlets]. It also will have a blue VGA connector on the bake.  On the bottom of the rack, the box is called APC ("UPS 2200") resets the UPS for the rXg guest internet  More specifically: The video server should be the second 'box' from the bottom with two power plugs. It also should have a blue VGA connector for the monitor on the back. it also should be labled on the from "server" or video server"  The Web Power Switch is to the side of the main rack. it's off the rack for some reason at this time and just to the side about 2 feet with connections going to and from it. 12/12/12

column67: See Doc "PropertyDoc Master" on the docs tab for full details. MDF is located in the Worman House.  The following are in the MDF: PC running the Unifi controller software Ubiquiti Router (not in Unifi) provided by Protel.   Superclick's router Fiber switch that feeds other areas of the property.  For location of any other devices see the afore mentioned "PropertyDoc Master" word document on the Docs tab
column68: ***Lightning and power issues are the most common causes for outages at this location.  Each IDF/MDF has a UPS and they do not turn back on automatically after a power outage.***  ****NOT ACTIVE YET***To reboot/check any of our equipment during business hours M-F 8am-5pm Central Time, call 417-339-5223****   Our responsibility is to handle escalated guest tickets, monitor network hardware, and to work with hotel staff and Protel to resolve.  Protel is the company that is paying us, and we work together with them to keep the client happy. A different company (SuperClick) is receiving the first support calls from guests for this client. When a call comes in from this location it should be from a Superclick rep to our NOC phone number of 866 265 7575 ext 0 and by email to support@hotelwifi.com.  We have no ability to monitor the WAN at this property.  If both the Unifi controller, and Screenconnect PC cannot be accessed then the property should be called and asked to start the WiFi management computer in the Wormen House equipment room. Also note that the management computer and or UniFi controller being offline does NOT necessarily mean that there is an outage.  The network can work just fine without the controller.  Refer to the CRM docs tab for network documentation.  The property maps should be used in conjunction with "PropertyDoc Master.docx" to identify points of failure.  Most devices are in the Unifi controller, but not all of them.  The gateway for the network and several fiber switches are not in the controller. ****To troubleshoot LAN hosts, and to start the UniFi controller if it is not running use Screenconnect > HKI EXTERNAL group and connect to computer "BCL0ADMIN-PC".  The PC is generally already logged in, but incase it is not the Windows login is Protel / pr0t3l.  From here you can start the Unifi controller (an icon that says UniFi on the desktop) and run pings to any switch or AP.  You can also access the Protel managed Edgerouter at 172.16.0.1 protel / pr0t3l2929****  The NOC agent should attempt to resolve the issue remotely, if possible.  ***If issue is resolved remotely,  contact Guest asking them to check and make sure they are able to connect.  As well as follow up with email notification to:  BCL Front Desk – BCL.FD@big-cedar.com and BCL Engineering – BCL.ENG@big-cedar.com   ***If the issue cannot be resolved remotely, Hotel Internet Service will notify the following of current issues or concerns: BCL Front Desk – BCL.FD@big-cedar.com , BCL Engineering – BCL.ENG@big-cedar.com, as well as IT Support - IT.BCL@big-cedar.com  The Big Cedar Team at this point will handle things per procedure put in place by Big Cedar Lodge i.e., fix, troubleshoot issue, call for service ticket/truck roll.  call for service ticket/truck roll.

column66: The System Starts with the Comcast modem. This goes into the Colubris. Then the Zone Director plugs into the Colubris. From there it goes into a POE Injector that has a CAT 5 cable going into the only Root AP.      The Guests have Local Authentication that is set up in the Zone Director. Here is the basic information on this.      The guest will get a portal page that pops up as soon as they go to their browser. Once this is done. They will need to have a key. The Guests have a different key then the Owners do.       The Keys last for one year from April 28th 2008-2009   Here are the keys for the Guest and Owners      Owners- ETVJK-TQACO   Guests- ZEYHJ-KRUWS      PLEASE MAKE SURE TO ASK IF THEY ARE A GUEST OR OWNER FIRST. THE OWNERS DON'T WANT THEIR KEY GIVEN OUT TO GUESTS.      If you need more information please go to the PROPERTIES/FLORIDA/HARBOUR VILLA CLUB. In there is a Picture of the MDF, WAP list, Network Diagram and Zone Director back up file.
column67: The Modem, GW, Zone Director and POE Injector for the Root AP are located in the MDF. This is located on the second Floor as soon as you get out of the elevator. It is the first Door Right in Front of you.      The AP's are Mounted by the Exit Signs and get their Power form the Exit Sign. That is all the Mesh AP's at least. The Root AP gets it's power from the POE Injector that is located inside the MDF.

column66: This is a all wired network with WAPs located in the guestroom hallways, meeting room ceilings & public space areas that cover the coffeeshop, SPA and lobby area. Fiber optic cable connections are used as backbone to connect the 3 areas. Each WAP is wired back to an IDF via CAT6 plenum cable. Pull string was left in the ceiling of the hallways.  The fiber optic connections start in phone room on 2nd floor. This is where the modem is. Cables go to fiber junction box (phone room) which in turn connects to the Server room and home run up to the guestroom IDF switches.  The property has been upgraded with APs on every floor. The coverage is now excellent on 2.4 Ghz band and we have full 5G in every guest room as well.
column67: Phone room (2nd Fl, Admin area): Modem & fiber junction box.  Server Room (2nd Fl, Admin area): Fusion, ZD, Core switch, Wattbox, Fiber junction box, convention room switch.  IDF: located on 4th, 6th, 8th, 10th & 15th floors in maid storage closet.   Guest Rm WAPs: located in access hatch in each hallway (3 per)  Meeting Rm WAPs: located in ceiling hatches (or above vent cover) in Evergreen A, B & C, Aspen B, and Boardroom.  Public Space: Lobby, located in Elec closet opposite front desk. Montbleu Cafe (coffee shop): located in access hatch above high roller slot machines 15' from center of sitting area.  The SPA/pool area has a closet and there is an AP located there.   The Admin offices on the 2nd floor has an R510 above the exit sign just outside the Exec Office door. Also on the 2nd floor, the IT Office also has an IDF switch and an R510.   There are two R610s located along the catwalks in the ceiling above the "MB Zone", the sports betting area in the Casino. You have to go through the security control room and then out to the catwalks.

column66: The ISP feed comes from a Mikrotik RouterBoard port eth6. The Mikrotk gets its feed from an AT&T fiber modem. The Mikrotik port eth6 feeds to a virtual WAN Switch on ports 5-8, VLAN 50, of the SW-MDF-1-1 (Core) switch. The WAN feed to the Fusion gateway is from port 7. The Fusion LAN feed goes to the HP Core Switch. The DSLAM is connected to the Core Switch port 1 (Trunk Vlans 100 & 200). The Web Switch is connected to the "virtual WAN Switch" on port 5 of the Core Switch SW-MDF-1-1.  NOTE: THE Front desk CREDITCARD PC HAS A STATIC IP. THIS COMPUTER HAS TO HAVE THIS ADDRESS ON IT TO WORK AND RUN CREDIT CARDS!!!! (UPDATE: the internal network is now completely separate from us. they are set on their own connection from the same Tel Pacific router.) FD Gateway (Admin Router): IP: 192.168.0.101 SUB: 255.255.255.0 GW: 192.168.0.1 DNS: 192.168.0.1 The rest of the FD computers plug into the 5 port switch including the kiosk.  Zebra TW-511 APs are located in the following rooms: 114 117 120 123 126 138 150 162 174 186 233 245 257 267 279 291

column66: The new management vlan is 11 10.111.10.x/23.  Per Anton we will not have a patio AP at this time.  There is an IDF in the Kitchen area and behind the Front desk.  We do not have any Brocade SW in these locations but the following Cisco SW is providing service to the following AP's.  That would be the:  AP-Restaurant-Bar: Cisco 2960 x.x.x.43 Port 46  AP-Grill-Dining: Cisco 2960 x.x.x.45 Port 47  AP-ChampCarr: Cisco 2960 x.x.x.45 Port 34  Patch Panel A-D is located in MDF, Panel A-C are in front of the Rack where our equipment is located and in the back of the Rack on the Top you will see panel D.  Most of the 1st floor Ethernet connections are located in MDF.  The Restaurant, front desk data jacks are located in the IDF behind the Front Desk.  The Dining room, Wine Room and the Kitchen area are located in the Kitchen IDF. The Marina Switches are going to the Boat House on the second floor.  Each Marina Post has a 14*14 box that will hold the Brocade 7150-12 port switch and the T310 will be mounted below the box.  The T310 will be connected to port 1 on each Switch.  The Marina Switches are going to the Boat House on the second floor.  Each Marina Post has a 14*14 box that will hold the Brocade 7150-12 port switch and the T310 will be mounted below the box.  The T310 will be connected to port 1 on each Switch.  The cisco SW 2960 Ports 24-27 have been configured for Vlan 11.  Internet to the SWitches are being provided via mocha then converted to ethernet.  Each Marina Post has its on mocha to Ethernet converter, the Ethernet is connected to 1/2/1 or C1 on the sw.  Anton has asked to HIS to connect the Security cameras for the marina  to the Brocade switch on ports 2-5 on vlan 601. Classic Tower floors 4-6 we ran Ethernet to each room and placed the AP above the Door inside the room.  Only a few rooms on the 6th floor we could not place the AP in the rooms because the drop ceiling was placed under the Concrete Slab that are 8 inches thick and if we drilled thru we would be above the ceiling and would not be able to run the Ethernet cable.  so we mounted the AP against the wall facing into the room.  Floors 9-12 the AP's are mounted in the rooms near either the couch or by the desk.  One of the issues that i have encounted is that the keystone in some rooms where so fragile that they would break in my hands.  if the AP goes offline i recommend that the Keystone be replaced.  Floor 8 are the Meeting rooms and the AP's are located in Each Meeting rooms, the Drop ceiling grid is marked for the location of the AP.  The lobby AP's in floors 9-12 are located in the IDF where the Ice machine is located.  The AP's are mounted on a shelf in the IDF.

column66: Current Network is a converged network used for 2 purposes: Guest/Staff Wi-Fi Access, and IPTV  The network infrastructure includes copper (CAT5E, CAT6) runs along with CAT2 telephone wiring (VDSL portion). Some uplinks between IDFs and MDF use Multimode 62.5/125 Fiber Optics cabling. There is a detailed network diagram in CRM that reflects all parts of the infrastructure.   ***Details on Guest Wi-Fi Access***   ***Details on IPTV*** Channels are received on standard set-top boxes, which are connected via HDMI to IPTV encoders.
column67: Fusion, ZD, Procentric Server are located in the MDF room, Main Building. AP's are located in the rooms.
column68: For Down Access Points and switches email the following people Jose Antonio Vallejo Rainone' - javrainone@gmail.com luis.zapata@dauphintelecom.com support@belmond.com  A company called MVG Tech does maintenance for the property, especially with the TVs. Michael Van Grieken is the principal contact for MVG. They can also be contacted via - mvgtech.las@belmond.com   ***IPTV Troubleshooting***  For issues with specific TVs:  - Ensure that VLAN configuration is correct on all switches between TV and encoders. VLAN 6 is the IPTV VLAN. If TV connects to MDU and then to switch, or directly to the switch, the appropriate switch port should be untagged for VLAN 6. If TV connects to AP, relevant port on AP must be untagged for VLAN 6, and relevant port on switch must be tagged.   - Ensure that IGMP is configured correctly on switches. Ensure that IP address for VLAN 6 is correct (192.168.100.0/20) and that "ip igmp" is enabled. For any ports which are tagged for VLAN 6, ensure that the "ip igmp forward" command is also entered, as well as "no ip igmp querier" command. These commands will ensure that IGMP traffic is handled correctly.  If channels do not display properly or do not have sound:   - Find out if the problem is with certain TVs or property-wide.  - Have onsite tech test a TV connected directly to the Dish Network receivers to see if it is an issue with Dish's signal or with our equipment. If it works correctly when directly connected to the receivers, troubleshoot the encoders.  - Log in to the encoder to see if there are any input errors. If there are it may still be an issue with the receiver or with the connection between the receiver and the encoder.  - There is a mechanical system in place that acts as a keepalive for the receivers. They will time out if there is no use of the channel after a certain period. After installation a system was put in place that is essentially a mechanical arm that clicks a remote in the TV room every 4 hours to ensure that the receivers stay online. Have local tech check this to make sure it is working.  - Try replacing HDMI cables to encoders, and reboot the receivers and encoders.  - Adjust video/audio settings to various values and have tech test to see if issue is resolved.  ===

column66: The MDF is connected with the IDFs via fiber for the most part and the access point are fed via a PoE switches for the most part. There are also some mesh access point that have been added along the line to cover dead areas. We didn't install this network originally. We added, swapped, moved AP's and replaced all 3COM switches with HP switches. For network topology please refer to the network diagram.  Note: The new H500s were install in the jack by the desk. The old 7025s are still int the guestrooms behind the TV. All the switch ports to the behind TV jacks were turned off so those APs wont try to provision with the ZD.
column67: This is a very spread out site and there are 24 switches throughout the property. The MDF is behind the Simonton building which is also the IT manager office. The Fusion, ZD, and two switches are located in the MDF. The different IDF location are listed below: Building A Attic IDF is in the ocean side attic of the building (HP 24 port PoE SW). Building A Garage IDF is on the parking garage by HK(HP 8 port PoE SW). Building B IDF is in the ocean side attic of the building. (HP 24 port PoE SW) Building C IDF is on the second floor electrical closet in the side that faces building B. (Cisco 48 port PoE SW ) Building D Parking lot IDF is on the ground level electrical closet that could be access from the parking garage. (HP 24 port PoE SW) Buikding D Gym IDF is the door right in front of the Fitness Center Island Wing 1st floor IDF is the telephone room on the 1st floor in the toward the SMOB lobby. (HP 24 port PoE SW) Island Wing 2nd floor IDF is just above the 1st floor IDF (Old MDF) (2 HP 24 port PoE SW) La Mer IDF is a locked water proof box outside the building facing the Dewey House. (HP 24 port PoE SW) Dewey House IDF if in the kitchen area metal box above the door frame that takes to the patio. (HP 24 port PoE SW) Beach Cafe IDF is locate in the office inside the kitchen. (HP 8 port SW) Conference room IDF is a closet behind the building near the tranquility pool. (HP 8 port SW) Gingerbread House Keeping IDF is located in the 1st floor behind house keeping and next to the door that takes to the Pineapple pool. This is also a locked water proof box (2 HP 8 port SWs) Pineapple pool IDF looking at the bar is a closet in the right hand side of it. (HP 24 port PoE SW) Gingerbread phone room IDF is located next to the main entrance of the building just in front of the tranquility pool. (HP 8 port PoE SW) Avalon Alley IDF is behind the Gingerbread building. It is a the very end of the alley between the Avalon Building and the Gingerbread building. (HP 8 port PoE SW) Tower IDF is located in the side of the Tower building in the pathway coming from the Pineapple pool. (1 HP 24 port PoE SW & 1 HP  48 port PoE SW) Duval IDF is loacted in the alley behind the building. It is a locked water proof inside the storage. (HP 24 port PoE SW) SMH Lobby IDF is located behind the front desk of the Southernmost Hotel. (HP 8 port SW)

column66: Revenue Share Property.  Fusion is the gateway for both the convention spaces and the hotel. The Fusion has two LAN interfaces feeding the core switch. One interface for the convention and common areas; one for the hotel.  The hotel WiFi network is running through the VOD system. VOD network connects to the core switch on VLAN 2. ZD is also on VLAN 2.  The convention has a series of switches strung throughout various parts of the property (Mike has the info). Switches are trunked with VLANs 1000, 2008, 2009. Native is VLAN 1.  VLAN 1000 - Common spaces VLAN 2008 - Convention Wired VLAN 2009 - Convention Wireless

column67: Demarc: 2nd Floor Electrical Room: Location of ISP Modem (and admin network modem), and VDSL bridges (master). The VDSL bridge master is connected to ISP modem. The slave side is in the IDF.  MDF: Located in phone room of lobby building along the back side by the Nissan dealership. Fusion, Core Switch, DSLAM1 & WPS are located on a wedge rack.  The Slave VDLS Bridge is also located here. A CAT5 cable goes from here to the lobby which feeds the admin (Mirage) router locate in the GM's office.
column68: Demarc is located in Second Floor Electrical Room. There is a VDSL Bridge the feeds the WAN connection to the MDF.   If there is an ISP outage: 1st - Check the ISP modem. If there is no WAN connection then reboot the modem. If there is still no connection then call the ISP.  2nd - The Master VDSL Bridge is in the Demarc and the Slave is in the MDF. The uplink light on port one needs to be lite on the Master and Slave, if not the connection from the ISP modem is not up the ISP modem will need to be reboot to get this back up. If the connection still does not come up reboot the VDSL Bridge in the Demarc. If the light on port 1 comes back up and there is no internet connection then reboot the VDSL Bridge in the MDF. IF the connection has not come back up after rebooting then the modem may have stopped working. 3rd - Check the Fusion. There should be at least 3 lights on. If there is only one light on then the Fusion has power but is most likely not powered on.   For property outages contact:  Neige Bufano neige@good-nite.com    310-235-2745 /Ext. 417    424-298-7099 (cell) is the best contact to email if you suspect a power outage or have to escalate beyond a single property

column68: This is a Stephen Durr property.  Do not deal directly with the property. Do not make any changes to his network without his authorization.  ***New Escalation Procedure for Stephen Durr Properties*** 1.	He is now being texted NOC alerts for GW’s, Wireless Controllers and switches for his properties. You don’t need to email him regarding those alerts, but you should email him for information about the devices as far as possible ETR, cause, if known,etc. so we can inform CAS. 2.	If the Call Center is receiving a lot of calls from a property and the equipment appears to be up, please call him and give him all the information. 3.	If a ticket is escalated and we cannot resolve the issue, we need to inform him of these with all pertinent information via email and a heads-up call. So, we need to pay close attention to the tickets and jump on any from his properties. If we call a guest and get vmail, close the ticket unresolved and email Stephen.  Stephen Durr 850-596-4378 stephen@net-worx.biz

column66: The setup is 1 switch with Fusion and ZD + Management Server for BeyondTV demo. Everything is located in the MDF besides WAPs.  Tower A: WAPs are in the hallway on the 2nd floor. Each WAP covers about 4 rooms on each side of the hotel. There is full 2.4 and 5 GHz coverage on the 2nd floor. Floor 1 and 3 have full coverage on 2.4GHz and partial coverage on 5 GHz spec. Only about half of the rooms on the 1st and 3rd floor are covered within -65 dB on 5GHz. the rest are pretty weak. That is the reason there are separate SSIDs for each band. The owner did not ant to spend more money, so there you have it.  Tower B: The WAPs are feeding from the switch on the 1st floor, which feeds from the MDF via CAT5. That CAT5 runs from the MDF on top of the lobby (roof) and into Tower B. The cable was replaced with a new run on 13 Feb 2018. The switch for WAPs is installed at the end of the hallway in the Air Vent. The WAPs are PoE fed from that switch.  Meeting Room WAP is plugged into one of the old PoE switches because we have ran out of space on the 8-port HP.  Lobby WAP It is a Netgear Wireless Router that has been configured as an Access Point only. It is plugged in into one of the old PoE switches as well. The IP for it is static in the Fusion and we can get in to make changes if we have to.

column66: This is a large retirement community where the existing customer has requested HIS to run 2 x CAT6 cables to each room and run wire to a new wifi system. The building is shaped like a U. There are two data closets, North side & South side. A 12 strand MM fiber optic cable is to be used to connect the two sides. This was run through the parking garage. Cables run down each side to their corresponding data closets which are on the first floor.  WAPs are located in a staggered pattern in the drop ceilings of the hallways which are fed from Cisco POE switches located in the MDF & IDF.
column67: Fusion, Core Switch, ZD, & Web power switch are located in MDF which is in the south end first floor maintenance closet. All equipment is in a server rack.  All south side AP's connect here as well as room data connections. There is an additional 8p poe switch located on the 2nd floor maintenace room. This is where the admin network equipment is located. ISP modem is also in this room on the top of the rack - literally on the top of it.  APs are in the hallway located in the drop ceiling outside specific rooms.  There is one IDF located on the first floor north side in the maintenance closet. There is one 24p poe switch which is attached to a server rack. All north side AP's connect here including the lobby AP.  Fiber media converter is located in the MDF which connects to IDF.  All AP's are located in drop ceiling in hallways outside of respective rooms.  Left 2 spare APs in MDF rack. Timeout device present but not hooked up. WPS plugs into UPS as does client server.

column68: + This is a BeyondTV client only.  + The BeyondTV Fusion server is located in the MDF: - WAN 1 is connected to a dummy switch in port 6. -WAN 2: is connected to a HP switch(admin network) in port 3. - LANs ports are connected to a D-Link switch:     -Port 1/1/23: LAN 1     -Port 1/1/24: LAN 2  + The guest and admin network is managed by the company Tezla group, all our services are running by their equipment(See in google docs a small description of their network diagram).  + All televisions are wall-mounted, the Chromecasts are secured to the TV brackets.      - HDMI1: BeyondTV.     - HDM2: Chromecast and is powered up from USB port on the TV.     - Coax: Live TV.  + For the MPI to work properly, the TV needs to be setup in the hidden menu (mute + 119 + enter) in the vendor option like Samsung. In these TVs the vendor option comes by default as EBL.  +Tezla Group contact info:  - Phone: 410-546-4233  - Phone: 866-283-7378 --Rich(IT specialist):  - Phone: 410-430-4860  - email: rich@tezlagroup.com

column68: ISP wants to confirm with the property that there is no electricity outage at the property if the internet will down because this happens in case of a power outage in the hotel area the property is not making calls so we ask any staff Get direct contact numbers and contact them. If there is no electricity outage at the property, then contact the ISP.  To access the computer attached to com 3000 use RDP: 69.54.33.33:40099 UN: EliteBook PW: lib3rty   STB Hotel has LG TVs in every room.   •	Model: 55LV570H ONE per Room   •	Model: Also has ONE 65UV570H in Suite's Living Room  Remotes: RC-11.  TVs are hanged on the wall. Signal from DirectTV reach the rooms via Coax. Coax is connected direct to TV’s Coax input. STB are connected via Hardwire. STB manages TV via MPI cable. STB HDMI signal to HDMI-2 TV input. Chromecast signal to HDMI-3 TV input. Chromecast gets power from TV USB port. Note: In order to make MPI port on TV always ON, it’s necessary to run into TV’s Installer menu see installer menu in btv documents:   •	Using the original remote Press repeatedly “MENU SETTINGS” until the on-screen display of the Setup Menus.   •	Press "9876 + OK"   •	arrow down to Option 118---Power Savings (Putting in 001 to assure MPI port will be always ON, by default is 003).       There is one room STB that is configured differently from the other boxes and this should be consider for firmware updates: 728 - One TV has only 2 HDMIs so the STB switches between HDMI1 and 2 instead of 1 & 3. If a firmware update is performed we need to adb into this box and hard code the HDMI ports to 1 and 2. also 305 - (build.prop) should be changed to BTV > HDMI1 and Chromecast > HDMI3 311 - (build.prop) should be changed to BTV > HDMI1 and Chromecast > HDMI3 705 - (build.prop) should be changed to BTV > HDMI1 and Chromecast > HDMI3 204 - (build.prop) should be changed to BTV > HDMI1 and Chromecast > HDMI3     ****************************************************If the channels are coming through (due to power outage or storm). Do the next steps: ******************************************************************************* Re-seat blades in Com400. Unscrew a blade. Pull it out. Wait for 10 seconds. Plug it back in. Tighten the screws. 2. Check if the channels are back online (takes 2 minutes for it to start working) 3. If that does not help, reboot the TV Amplifiers in the 5th floor closet. Pull the power wait for 10 seconds and plug it back in. If that does not help, repeat step 1. Also, when they call try to get any information on any other issues they've been having as they are not real good at communicating issues to us. As an example, they had pixilating problems for over 6 months and didn't inform us about it.  ************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************  **** For New STBs **** This property is using STBs as a brain for the TVs. We are controlling the LG TVs via the MPI cables.  If you get an STB online that hasn't been properly provisioned, you need to do the following until we release a new firmware that has all the options built it: 1. Assign the STB a static lease      If you are swapping a STB in a room, make sure to replace that box 2. Ensure the box is running an Elliot Park firmware (use BTV Admin)     This is an automatic process and as long as the box is connected to the correct network, it will eventually upgrade. Usually 5-10 minute process. If it is not upgrading (you can use adb_logcal to see that), then reboot it. 3. from the Nagios server, "adb_connect xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx" to the box, where xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx the IP of the box 4. Run the following command "adb_mpi_install" ***************************

column66: 10Gbps backbone from edge to IDFs, 1Gbps to APs  59 IDFs (1 in MDF) - Extreme access switches (X440/X460)  1260 APs - Extreme (various models indoor and outdoor)  There is no portal page on the guest network.  A company called FSG installed the hardware at this property.  A company called SHI configured the firewall and DHCP server.  A company called Networking Matters configured the switches and APs.
column67: The MDF in Media Room, North side of stadium. MDF includes Firewall pair (Cisco 5585), core switch pair (Extreme S8), WLAN controllers (Extreme), access control appliances (Extreme), reporting servers (Extreme NetSight), and DHCP/DNS servers (Cisco UCS). All of this equipment has hardware redundancy.  APs are mounted underseat in fan seating sections, and in various other locations overhead (on posts or ceilings).  12 of the permanent IDFs are used for the wireless system, 6 on the ground level and 6 on the field level, in the corners and in the middle of the long sides of the stadium. The other IDFs are standalone boxes that are mounted in closets, on walls, or outside on supports. IDFs contain 1-2 switches (12 or 24 port), fiber patch panels, and a UPS. They are home-run back to the MDF via fiber.  There is a widespread cellular DAS (distributed antenna system) throughout the stadium. These are larger antennas and are generally marked by the carrier (Verizon, Sprint, etc).  The parking lots are currently covered only by DAS with units mounted on light poles. This may be replaced with APs in 2017.
column68: Log into the NetSight server to view AP status and configuration, wireless clients, switch status, and reports.  If any of the devices go down, email Joseph Kyle LaFleur (Kyle.LaFleur@5bars.com),  Bryan ( bryanc@5bars.com ), Tommy ( tommy.taylor@5bars.com ), and Alessandro Feitosa ( Alessandro.feitosa@5bars.com ) from 5Bars.  If unable to establish a VPN connection using AnyConnect, it is likely because other admins are currently connected (the ASA is only licensed for 2 concurrent connections). You can connect to the ASA using ASDM and view the active VPN sessions to see if this is the case.  Extreme Networks can be contacted for support on any of their equipment at 800 872 8440.  The service contract numbers for the stadium are 4-5970610071 and 4-6176862491.

column68: The Wi-Fi is challenging at this property (see "Supporting Document" in Docs). We have agreed to support the following rooms until their Wi-Fi network is augmented: 103, 104, 105, 106,108, 109, 203, 204, 205, 206, 207, 208, 209, 210, 211, 212, 214, 303, 307, 310, 311, 314.  IR Blasters - The IR Blasters seem to be more sensitive to wifi signal strength than the STB. The IR Blaster tends to stop communicating when Wifi signal is low and doesn't always reconnect by itself. The handling, if for example the IRB is not changing to the TV Channel from the Guide, is to manually unplug and re-plug the IRB (where the USB cord connects to the IRB) at the back of the TV, then test with the remote to see if the IRB is working. If that doesn't work, try restarting the STB IU or reboot the STB. I also noticed in a few rooms where the signal strength was good that the IRB would stop communicating despite the good signal strength. The same procedure should work to get the IRB back working.  Chrome Device - Sometimes the Chromecast device stops working due to low wifi signal strength. Unplugging and re-plugging the Chrome's USB connection from the TV will reboot the device and usually causes the Chrome device to reconnect.  Live TV and its connection - They have a coax cable that comes directly out of the wall to the TV set. It does not go into the STB, so any TV issue will be with the hotel TV provider. The only thing plugged to the STB is the HDMI cable, the IRB and the remote dongle.

column68: If DSLAM goes down email and Skype Brad McLeod brad@hotelwifi.com and let him know. For down DSLAM, don't call property as Brad says they won't do anything.  These AP's are in the rooms behind the night stands covering the phone jacks. They are powered by the DSLAM, and can be rebooted from there. If the AP doesn't come back up the AP may have been damaged or was removed.   MDF temperature is very high . They have AC but it is not working properly.  I installed fan toward to the rack . But temperature is again high during day times that equipment may become overheated . (Fan is connected to the Web Power Switch port 4, see equipm. list ) Manager promised to solve AC problem on Saturday 08/20/2016 .  ******* I was there 9/9/2016 they have  new AC for MDF. No overheating any more. I turned off the fan .
